headline: Senate Democrat Threatens to Block More of Military Aid to Egypt
abstract: The new chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee could force the Biden administration to reverse its decision to send Egypt $235 million in military assistance.
lead_paragraph: Senator Ben Cardin of Maryland, the new chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, pledged on Saturday to block the release of $235 million in military aid to Egypt, a move that could force the Biden administration to reverse its decision to prioritize national security interests over Congress’s concerns about the country’s human rights record.

headline: How Each Member Voted on the Senate Stopgap Spending Measure
abstract: The Senate overwhelmingly passed a bill to fund the federal government through mid-November. See how each senator voted.
lead_paragraph: The Senate overwhelmingly passed a bill to fund the federal government through mid-November. See how each senator voted.

headline: What Does a Russia-Leaning Party Win in an E.U. Nation Mean for Ukraine?
abstract: In much of Europe, the election in Slovakia was seen as a bellwether of mainstream support for Ukraine in its war with Russia. But voters seemed most concerned with pocketbook issues.
lead_paragraph: A Russia-friendly populist party finished first in a crowded field on Sunday in Slovakia’s parliamentary elections, a vote that many in Europe have seen as a bellwether of support for the war in Ukraine.

headline: Police Chief Who Ordered Raid on Kansas Newspaper Is Suspended
abstract: Gideon Cody, who orchestrated a widely criticized raid on The Marion County Record, was suspended indefinitely, a city official said on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: The police chief of Marion, Kansas, was suspended on Thursday, more than a month after he ordered raids on the office of a local newspaper and the home of its publisher in an act rarely seen in American journalism, one that was widely condemned by news organizations as a violation of the First Amendment.

headline: Chris Snow, Hockey Executive Who Publicly Faced A.L.S., Dies at 42
abstract: The assistant general manager of the Calgary Flames, he was given a year to live in 2019. He and his wife used the time to document life with the disease.
lead_paragraph: Chris Snow, the assistant general manager of the Calgary Flames of the National Hockey League, who, after being diagnosed in 2019 with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, became a prominent advocate for victims of the disease, died on Saturday in Calgary, Alberta. He was 42.

headline: Newsom Vetoes Bill Allowing Workers to Collect Unemployment Pay While Striking
abstract: The move marks a loss for the state labor federation and disappointed union leaders who had hoped to capitalize on a wave of high-profile strikes in the state.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Gavin Newsom of California vetoed legislation on Saturday that would have allowed workers to collect unemployment pay while on strike, disappointing union leaders who had hoped to capitalize on a wave of high-profile walkouts during the state’s “hot labor summer” this year.

headline: No Corrections: Oct. 1, 2023
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Sunday, Oct. 1, 2023.
lead_paragraph: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Through Triumph and Tragedy, Feinstein Helped Shape San Francisco
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, Oct. 1, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “She was part of that era when the focus was on legislating, policy and getting things done. I think maybe that has died with her.”

headline: Nikki Haley Won the Debate Stage. Now, She’s Trying to Win Over Iowa.
abstract: The former governor of South Carolina, who was ambassador to the United Nations under Donald Trump, now needs to appeal to early state voters.
lead_paragraph: About 15 minutes after Nikki Haley took the stage at a town hall in a Des Moines suburb on Saturday, the former governor of South Carolina and ambassador to the United Nations, was heckled — twice — by men demanding to know her views on Taylor Swift.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: A Cooking Editor Who Finds Inspiration Everywhere
abstract: For The Veggie, a New York Times newsletter, Tanya Sichynsky mines her personal life for recipe ideas.
lead_paragraph: If the DVD version of “The Dance,” a live album recorded by Fleetwood Mac in 1997, was playing in the living room of my childhood home, I knew I’d be in for one hell of a meal.

headline: ‘Before Leaving Town, We Stopped to Get Sandwiches to Eat in the Car’
abstract: Saving a spot in a long line, pulling weeds in Brooklyn and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: Maybe in Your Lifetime, People Will Live on the Moon and Then Mars
abstract: Through partnerships and 3-D printing, NASA is plotting how to build houses on the moon by 2040.
lead_paragraph: The moon is a magnet, and it is pulling us back.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Gilgo Beach Suspect May Have Hunted Them. Now They’re Key Witnesses.
abstract: Investigators are talking to women behind bars who worked as escorts and had encounters with the suspect, Rex Heuermann. They had been ignored for years.
lead_paragraph: Rex Heuermann has been under close and constant watch in a Long Island jail since he was charged in July with killing a succession of women and leaving them wrapped in burlap along an oceanfront road.

headline: The Hottest New Accessory in Niger? A Russian Flag.
abstract: Russia has quietly been distributing its own flags throughout West Africa, where they are now considered “so cool.”
lead_paragraph: Young people in West African capitals wave the flags at protests or as they race through cities on motorcycles. Tailors sew dozens of them a day in the narrow alleys of buzzing markets. Taxi drivers put them on their dashboards.

headline: Menendez Co-Defendant’s Curious Path From Bad Deals to a Meat Monopoly
abstract: After emigrating to New Jersey from Egypt, Wael Hana faced a string of business and legal problems. Then his friend started dating a powerful U.S. senator.
lead_paragraph: Just five years ago, Wael Hana was reeling from a string of bad business deals in New Jersey, having tried to launch a truck stop, an Italian restaurant, a limousine service and other companies without ever hitting it big.

headline: Close Enough to Call Back
abstract: One of the rarest editions of The New York Times, from election night in 2000, never made it further than the newsroom.
lead_paragraph: There is a lot of drama in a new history of The New York Times, “The Times: How the Newspaper of Record Survived Scandal, Scorn and the Transformation of Journalism,” by Adam Nagourney, a Times correspondent. Among the most anxious episodes was election night in 2000, which Mr. Nagourney called “a blur of changing headlines and stories rewritten in the space of minutes.”

headline: Four Seconds to Impact: On the Front Line With Ukraine’s Snipers
abstract: In a war built around artillery, tanks, drones and cruise missiles, the role of the sniper, unseen and lethal, occupies an often overlooked but essential part of the battlefield.
lead_paragraph: The Russian position was marked with the blue flag of Moscow’s elite airborne units but the fabric looked almost translucent through the Ukrainian sniper’s scope.

headline: Farewell to a Woman in Full
abstract: Sarah Burton says goodbye to Alexander McQueen with a triumphant collection; Gabriela Hearst departs Chloé.
lead_paragraph: At the end of the Alexander McQueen show, after Naomi Campbell had strutted by in a silver beaded dress with a heart-shape breastplate of a bodice and a skirt dripping in loops of fringe, and the audience had risen to its feet in a standing ovation, the designer, Sarah Burton, came out to take her bow. It would be, everyone knew, her last one for the brand.

headline: Wearables, Redefined
abstract: The love affair between fashion and technology gets revived at Coperni, Anrealage and Junya Watanabe. Will it be any more successful this time around?
lead_paragraph: In 2014 Jony Ive, then the chief design officer of Apple, came to Paris Fashion Week with his Big New Product, the Apple Watch, to convince the fashion crowd that wearables were the future of fashion. That turned out to be not exactly true (at least style-wise), but it hasn’t stopped two former Apple designers, Imran Chaudhri and Bethany Bongiorno, from returning nine years later to try again.

headline: A Novel of Survival and the Sublime in the Mojave Desert
abstract: Melissa Broder’s “Death Valley” follows a grieving narrator through her reconnection to the earth.
lead_paragraph: In Thomas Merton’s 1960 translation of the teachings of the fourth-century Christian monks known as the Desert Fathers, “Abbot Lot came to Abbot Joseph and said: Father, according as I am able, I keep my little rule, and my little fast, my prayer, meditation and contemplative silence … now what more should I do? The elder rose in reply and stretched out his hands to heaven, and his fingers became like 10 lamps of fire. He said: Why not be totally changed into fire?”

headline: Ferrante Before Ferrante
abstract: Elsa Morante’s propulsive 1940s saga of women’s lives, “Lies and Sorcery,” brings its penetrating insight to a new generation.
lead_paragraph: Elsa Morante published “Lies and Sorcery,” a nearly 800-page novel that combines mythic storytelling with Depression-era realism, in 1948, just when postwar literary Italy was embracing the modernist voices of writers like Natalia Ginzburg, Italo Calvino and Morante’s own husband, Alberto Moravia. Nonetheless, it received serious reviews and was a success across Europe. Although an abridged version appeared in America under the title “House of Liars,” the saga was never available in its entirety in English until now, courtesy of New York Review Books, in an inspired translation by Jenny McPhee.

headline: A Fitting — and Frightening — Homage to ‘The Haunting of Hill House’
abstract: Apparitions, black hares and time warps festoon the pages of Elizabeth Hand’s “A Haunting on the Hill,” set in the same moldering mansion as Shirley Jackson’s classic horror novel.
lead_paragraph: As Holly, the protagonist of Elizabeth Hand’s “A Haunting on the Hill,” approaches an imposing, deserted mansion tucked off a remote country road, she drives past a tree stump that’s “choked with poison ivy, a riot of scarlet leaves and white berries.” Though she doesn’t know it yet, the tree that once stood there claimed the life of Eleanor Vance, the tragic lead from the novel’s antecedent text, Shirley Jackson’s wildly influential “The Haunting of Hill House.” And so, a couple dozen pages into the book, Hand makes her first decisive mark on Jackson’s landscape, acknowledging her predecessor while making the house her own. When Jackson left Hill House, the tree was still standing. Hand is here to chop it down.

headline: Wall Street’s Most Hated Regulator Faces a Fundamental Threat
abstract: Rohit Chopra, who leads the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, says he is simply enforcing the law. Bankers call him reckless — a “regulator gone rogue.”
lead_paragraph: Rohit Chopra became one of the most powerful financial regulators by pairing bark with bite. As director of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, he has attacked — often with a hammer — the perpetrators of what he considers injustices against everyday Americans.

headline: The Deadly Red Tape of Israel’s Occupation in Palestine
abstract: In “A Day in the Life of Abed Salama,” Nathan Thrall untangles the political and personal story of a bus crash on the outskirts of Jerusalem.
lead_paragraph: On a rainy, windy morning in February 2012, on a highway outside of Jerusalem, an 18-wheeler collided with a school bus filled with kindergartners and their teachers. The bus rolled over and landed on its side, door-side down, and burst into flames. One teacher and six children died. Some of the survivors were so badly burned that a local man who broke a window and climbed into the bus to pull the children out couldn’t recognize them as human.

headline: Should Children Join the Killing in New Zealand’s War on Invasive Species?
abstract: A hunting contest has exposed tensions over which animals deserve protection, who gets to define humaneness and how children should be taught about conservation.
lead_paragraph: The pickup trucks rolled up one by one, ferrying a stream of animal carcasses into the show grounds. Pigs, deer, possums, even feral cats — all would be weighed and showcased, the bigger animals strung on racks, the smaller ones laid out in rows that became heaps as the day went on.

headline: Gen Z Wants Feminine Care Brands to Just Say Vagina
abstract: Brands selling feminine care products have dropped the euphemisms to sell to younger consumers. But are they still capitalizing on old stigmas?
lead_paragraph: On a recent July evening in Midtown Manhattan, a trio of teenage girls swooped into the feminine care aisle at Target. Skipping over the boxes of Always and Tampax tampons, they made a beeline to a shelf with sanitary pads from the Honey Pot Company. One asked her friend if she was going to pick out the pads with a “minty sensation.”

headline: Jonathan Lethem Returns to the Borough That Launched Him
abstract: In “Brooklyn Crime Novel,” the veteran author transports readers to a conflicted time in the old neighborhood.
lead_paragraph: Before “a writer living in Brooklyn” became a tiresome stereotype, there was Jonathan Lethem, who — like Bernard Malamud and Betty Smith before him — was actually born and raised in Brooklyn, giving his portrayals of the place, or a swath of it anyway, a dingy verisimilitude. He knows deep in his bones that a coffee shop is not a Starbucks but a diner, and what it means to take that coffee regular (milk and two sugars), like gas in a car.

headline: A Nobel Prize Might Lower a Scientist’s Impact
abstract: A team of researchers at Stanford find that older scientists are less productive after winning major awards like the Nobel and the MacArthur Fellowship.
lead_paragraph: Winning a Nobel Prize can be a life-changing event. The winners are thrust onto a world stage, and for many scientists the recognition represents the pinnacle of their careers.

headline: A Battered Supreme Court Returns to Confront a Challenging Docket
abstract: The justices will explore the scope of the Second Amendment, the fate of the administrative state and limits on free speech on the internet.
lead_paragraph: When the Supreme Court returns to the bench on Monday, it will face a docket filled with unfinished business. The justices will revisit issues like gun rights, government power, race and free speech even as they are shadowed by intense scrutiny of their conduct off the bench.

headline: He’s a Dab of Glue in a Broken City. Can He Hold It Together?
abstract: In America’s overwhelmed downtowns, private security guards like Michael Bock have become the solution of last resort.
lead_paragraph: Michael Bock was still on his way into work for his shift as a private security guard when he came upon his first emergency of the day. He drove into downtown Portland, Ore., a little after 6 a.m., and saw a man swinging a hatchet and chasing someone into the street. Bock, 46, pulled over and rolled down his window. “Security!” he yelled. “Can we please settle down?”

headline: Arnold Schwarzenegger Is Here to Pump You Up (Emotionally)
abstract: “The more powerful you are,” says the action icon, author of a new self-help book, “the more power you have in giving back.”
lead_paragraph: “The more powerful you are,” says the action icon, author of a new self-help book, “the more power you have in giving back.”

headline: When Taylor Swift and Travis Kelce Collided With Prime-Time TV
abstract: The Chiefs escaped with a win over the Jets on “Sunday Night Football,” but many viewers were watching for shots of a luxury suite.
lead_paragraph: The game on Sunday night between the Kansas City Chiefs and the New York Jets was not expected to be must-see TV, at least from a football perspective.

headline: Why Can’t We Stop Unauthorized Immigration? Because It Works.
abstract: Our broken immigration system is still the best option for many migrants — and U.S. employers.
lead_paragraph: ‘We’re getting no support on this national crisis,’ Mayor Eric Adams said in September at a town-hall-style gathering on Manhattan’s Upper West Side. He was talking about the influx of transnational migrants who have landed in the city’s shelter system: more than 118,000 since the spring of last year, with about 10,000 more arriving each month. There are now about 115,000 people in the city’s care, and more than half of them are migrants. In August, the city projected that it would spend $5 billion caring for migrants during this fiscal year.

headline: What Should You Do if Hotels Don’t Warn You About Strikes?
abstract: There is recourse for customers who arrive at a hotel and are surprised to find a boisterous picket line waiting to greet them.
lead_paragraph: There is no word that quite captures the opposite of hospitality, but I can describe what it feels like.

headline: To Many Americans, Government Dysfunction Is the New Normal
abstract: As the nation teetered on the brink of a shutdown, its citizens were largely focused on other things.
lead_paragraph: As the nation’s capital seemed to be barreling toward another debilitating federal government shutdown this weekend, America, well, did not exactly seem to be on the edge of its collective seat.

headline: Inside McCarthy’s Shutdown Turnabout That Left His Speakership at Risk
abstract: The Republican speaker opted to keep the government open the only way he could — by partnering with Democrats — in a surprise reversal that left him as politically vulnerable as ever.
lead_paragraph: Speaker Kevin McCarthy began the final day before a government shutdown pinned against the ropes, facing dim prospects of passing any stopgap funding measure to avert the crisis that was to go into effect when the clock struck 12:01 a.m. on Sunday.

headline: Trailblazer, Role Model, Mentor: Feinstein’s Impact on Women in Office
abstract: When Dianne Feinstein was elected in 1992, only two women were in the U.S. Senate. There were 25 on the day she died.
lead_paragraph: Dianne Feinstein had several lifetimes’ worth of accomplishments by the time she died on Thursday at 90. She was pivotal in crafting a decade-long bipartisan assault weapons ban. She helped lead the congressional response to the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks and questioned the Central Intelligence Agency for its use of torture. As mayor of San Francisco, she led her hometown through years of tumult.

headline: With Unrealistic Immigration Proposals, DeSantis and Trump Try to Outdo Each Other
abstract: In dueling speeches in California, the two Republican candidates pushed for mass deportations, a position that is as extreme as it may be unfeasible.
lead_paragraph: As a presidential candidate, Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida has said he would authorize the use of deadly force against people crossing the border, seek to end the practice of birthright citizenship and send the military to strike against drug cartels inside Mexico, a key ally of the United States, even without the permission of its government.

headline: Trailing in Polls, Conservatives Look to Unleash the ‘Real Rishi’ Sunak
abstract: The British prime minister is trying to redefine himself as a conviction politician, leaning into the newly potent issue of meeting climate goals without raising costs for hard-pressed Britons.
lead_paragraph: When Rishi Sunak arrived at the Conservative Party’s annual conference on Sunday, it was his first as Britain’s prime minister. The question looming for many attendees in the cavernous venue in Manchester is whether it could also be his last.

headline: Ukraine Downplays Uncertainty Over U.S. Support After Funding Bill Passes With No Aid
abstract: Kyiv expressed confidence that Washington would continue to support its war against Russia, even after Congress passed a stopgap funding bill that did not include money for Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Ukraine’s government said on Sunday it was confident that the United States would continue to support it in its war with Russia, even after the House passed a stopgap spending bill to avert a government shutdown that did not include any additional money for Kyiv.

headline: An Ancient City, Now in Ruins, Struggles to Keep Its Soul
abstract: Seven months after powerful earthquakes battered the historic city of Antakya in southern Turkey, life feels temporary as residents await reconstruction.
lead_paragraph: The businessman fondly recalled his bakery and cafe in the ancient Turkish city of Antakya, where his staff made bread, cakes and cookies and locals gathered for breakfast, coffee and ice cream.

headline: Turkey Strikes Kurdish Rebels After Suicide Attack in Ankara
abstract: “Many terrorists were neutralized,” Turkey said of the airstrikes, which it ordered after the P.K.K. took responsibility for a bomb attack.
lead_paragraph: Turkish warplanes on Sunday struck targets affiliated with a Kurdish rebel organization in northern Iraq, the Turkish Ministry of Defense said in a statement, hours after the separatist group took responsibility for a suicide bombing that wounded two police officers in Ankara, the Turkish capital.

headline: ‘Dumb Money’ Exposes the Baffling Allure of Bad Investment Advice
abstract: Pegged to the movie “Dumb Money,” a discussion of the growing stupidity in the stock market.
lead_paragraph: The new movie “Dumb Money” dramatizes the true story of an unlikely messiah named Roaring Kitty who decides to sink his life savings into shares of the video-game seller GameStop and then praise the stock to his fans. So many people buy GameStop shares that the company’s valuation soars, crushing the positions of professional hedge funds that had bet against it. Thus, a band of lovable misfits triumphs over the Wall Street fat cats.

headline: Spider Boots, Boxers, Hoverboards: When Ukrainian Troops Ask, We Deliver
abstract: An army of individuals transport needed nonlethal supplies to Ukrainian military personnel in the field.
lead_paragraph: This past summer, Britain’s defense minister at the time, Ben Wallace, chided Ukraine for not showing enough gratitude for the West’s weapons supplies. “We’re not Amazon,” he said.

headline: The Enemies of Literature Are Winning
abstract: This is why I hate Banned Books Week.
lead_paragraph: Walk past any bookstore or library in America this week, and you are likely to find a sign exhorting you to “Read a banned book.”

headline: The Climate Fight Will Be Won in the Appliance Aisle
abstract: Why I’m worried about the next phase of the Inflation Reduction Act’s rollout.
lead_paragraph: More than a year after its passage, much about President Biden’s climate law, the Inflation Reduction Act, is working.

headline: One Reason the Trump Fever Won’t Break
abstract: Christian nationalism may not be serious, but it’s very dangerous.
lead_paragraph: The more I consider the challenge posed by Christian nationalism, the more I think most observers and critics are paying too much attention to the wrong group of Christian nationalists. We mainly think of Christian nationalism as a theology or at least as a philosophy. In reality, the Christian nationalist movement that actually matters is rooted in emotion and ostensibly divine revelation, and it’s that emotional and spiritual movement that so stubbornly clings to Donald Trump.

headline: The Sunday Read: ‘The Art of Telling Forbidden Stories in China’
abstract: Many Chinese writers are looking for ways to capture the everyday realities that the government keeps hidden — sometimes at their own peril.
lead_paragraph: As China strove for a larger role on the international stage at the turn of the century, the arrival of the internet and a relatively relaxed political environment spurred a boom in self-expression. Many writers tested the boundaries of Chinese literary culture, experimenting with subjects that were quotidian but taboo on the page: corruption, sexual desire and evolving gender roles.

headline: At Least 13 Killed in Nightclub Fire in Spain
abstract: Spanish authorities are investigating the origins of the blaze, in the southeastern city of Murcia, which also left at least four people wounded from smoke inhalation.
lead_paragraph: At least 13 people were killed on Sunday after a fire broke out in a nightclub complex in southeastern Spain, the authorities said, adding that the number of victims could rise as emergency workers continued to search through the damaged structure.

headline: Shutdown Avoided
abstract: A compromise in Congress averted a government shutdown, but battles over federal spending remain ahead.
lead_paragraph: A government shutdown seemed all but certain. Millions of federal workers and members of the military braced for late paychecks. National parks planned to close.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Oct. 2, 2023
abstract: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
lead_paragraph: 1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:

headline: McCarthy Faces Test as Gaetz Moves to Oust Him for Working With Democrats
abstract: A day after the Republican speaker turned to Democrats for help passing a stopgap spending bill to avert a shutdown, the far-right congressman promised to try to remove him from his post.
lead_paragraph: Speaker Kevin McCarthy’s leadership position is in peril after his most outspoken Republican critic, Representative Matt Gaetz of Florida, said on Sunday he would follow through on threats to try to remove Mr. McCarthy from the job.

headline: A Blind Spot for Two-Parent Privilege?
abstract: Readers respond to a column by Nicholas Kristof. Also: Donald Trump’s appeal; diversity statements; artificial intelligence.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Pretty Perfect Pollo Asado
abstract: Marinated all afternoon, placed on the grill an hour before sunset and served with warm tortillas, rice and beans, hot sauce and lime wedges.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. September played out strangely where I hang out: unreasonably Augustlike at first, and then hard into autumnal damp and gloom. I know we’re nowhere near last licks on grilling season, but there’s something a little valedictory about lighting the fires these days. I feel as if I’m cooking on borrowed time.

headline: Serbia’s President Rejects Claims of Troop Buildup Near Kosovo
abstract: Aleksandar Vucic called Washington’s assertions of a “destabilizing” military presence along the border a “campaign of lies” after an attack in Kosovo renewed attention to a territorial conflict.
lead_paragraph: President Aleksandar Vucic of Serbia on Sunday rejected White House assertions that he was engaged in a “destabilizing” buildup of forces along the Kosovo border, which has raised fears that the decades-old conflict between Serbia and its former territory was about to flare.

headline: They Ran for a Better Life, Straight Into a Wildfire
abstract: Greek authorities assumed the victims were asylum seekers because no one was looking for missing people locally. And for more than a month, their identities, and the circumstances of their deaths, remained a mystery.
lead_paragraph: As they traversed the harsh, wooded terrain in northeastern Greece, the 18 asylum seekers were presented with an agonizing dilemma: Take the safer route through villages and over highways, but into the arms of the Greek authorities, or travel through the forests and fields being ravaged by Europe’s largest recorded wildfire.

headline: How ‘No One Will Save You’ Terrifies Us With Hardly a Word
abstract: For the Hulu hit, the director relied on visual and sound cues to create both the scares and the plot. Stephen King and Guillermo del Toro are fans.
lead_paragraph: The nail-biter “No One Will Save You” quietly materialized on Hulu Sept. 22 and became a streaming darling overnight, an apt entrance for a largely dialogue-free chiller about an alien invasion.

headline: Nightclub Fire Kills More Than a Dozen People in Spain
abstract: A blaze broke out at a nightclub complex in Murcia, Spain, causing a section of the building to cave in.
lead_paragraph: A blaze broke out at a nightclub complex in Murcia, Spain, causing a section of the building to cave in.

headline: ‘Celebrate Jaap!’ the Philharmonic Says as a Maestro Departs
abstract: The final season of Jaap van Zweden’s brief tenure as music director in New York began with a new suite for the star violinist Joshua Bell.
lead_paragraph: The elements came out for “The Elements.”

headline: At Fall for Dance, Meeting Enthusiasm With Mediocrity
abstract: The festival, with its variety of styles and cheap tickets, plays to excited audiences. Why can’t it give them better programs?
lead_paragraph: Part of the promise of New York City Center’s Fall for Dance festival, now in its 20th season, has been to lure new audiences to dance. In that spirit, Michael Rosenberg, the theater’s new president and chief executive, has been making curtain speeches before this year’s performances, asking first timers in the house to make some noise, then celebrating the big, raucous response as the sound of the future of live performance.

headline: Longtime Union Leader Steps Fully Into Hollywood’s Spotlight
abstract: Duncan Crabtree-Ireland, the lead negotiator for SAG-AFTRA, will be a key player as the guild begins talks with the studios again on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Duncan Crabtree-Ireland, the executive director and chief negotiator for the actors’ union, has spent the past two decades toiling behind the scenes during contract talks. The spotlight, he knows, is for the SAG-AFTRA president, usually a well-known performer like the current office holder, Fran Drescher.

headline: Baton Rouge Officers Accused of Covering Up Use of Excessive Force
abstract: The Baton Rouge Police Department charged three of its officers and a deputy chief with trying to hide their use of stun guns during a strip search.
lead_paragraph: Three officers and a deputy chief of the police department in Baton Rouge, La., were charged with attempting to cover up their use of stun guns during a strip search inside a department restroom, the police chief said on Friday.

headline: Huge Antigovernment Crowds March in Poland Ahead of Critical Election
abstract: The fate of democracy and aid for Ukraine undergird the October vote, which will decide whether the governing Law and Justice party secures an unprecedented third term in a row.
lead_paragraph: Huge crowds marched through Poland’s capital, Warsaw, on Sunday, converging around a giant flag commemorating a 1944 uprising against Nazi Germany, as opponents of the governing party sought to rally voters for a critical general election that they see as the last chance to save the country’s hard-won democratic freedoms.

headline: Against the Wall, McCarthy Does the Right Thing
abstract: At the last possible moment, Kevin McCarthy earned some credit for keeping the government open. But not a lot of credit.
lead_paragraph: Only an extremely shallow man would repeatedly wait until the last possible moment to do the right thing, no matter how obvious that thing might be. But in today’s Washington, the Republican Party usually doesn’t do the right thing at all, so the House speaker, Kevin McCarthy, deserves some credit for putting his job on the line on Saturday to end the threat of a government shutdown.

headline: Monday Briefing: U.S. Aid to Ukraine Is Uncertain
abstract: Plus NASA’s plan to build houses on the moon.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. Congress narrowly avoided a government shutdown on Saturday by passing a stopgap spending bill to temporarily keep the government open; however, the bill did not include any additional aid for Ukraine. The White House and leaders of both parties in the Senate pushed for more Ukraine funding to be included, and the failure to do so highlighted the decreasing willingness of some Republicans to fund Kyiv’s war effort.

headline: Unease in the West as Slovakia Appears Set to Join the Putin Sympathizers
abstract: The front-runner in the parliamentary vote has pledged “not to send a single cartridge” to neighboring Ukraine, a sign of the flagging European support for a victim of Russian aggression.
lead_paragraph: The victory of Robert Fico, a former prime minister who took a pro-Russian campaign stance, in Slovakia’s parliamentary elections is a further sign of eroding support for Ukraine in the West as the war drags on and the front line remains largely static.

headline: Chipotle Manager Pulled Off Worker’s Hijab, U.S. Says in Lawsuit
abstract: An official with the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission, which filed the lawsuit, said the nature of the allegations was “quite egregious.”
lead_paragraph: An assistant manager at a Chipotle restaurant in Kansas pulled off an employee’s hijab, according to a federal lawsuit that contains allegations of religious harassment that a federal official described as “quite egregious.”

headline: Scissors Sound
abstract: Alexandria Mason’s New York Times debut has us spellbound.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Tim Wakefield, Pitcher Who Helped Boston Break the Curse, Dies at 57
abstract: After surrendering a homer that ended the Red Sox run in 2003, he played a critical role in the team’s World Series victory a year later.
lead_paragraph: Tim Wakefield, a right-handed knuckleball pitcher for the Boston Red Sox who in 2004 played a critical late-innings relief role in the team’s winning its first World Series championship in 86 years, died on Sunday. He was 57.

headline: Two People Killed by Grizzly Bear at Banff National Park in Canada
abstract: Park officials found the victims early Saturday morning, after receiving an alert from a satellite device hours earlier. A grizzly near the site displayed “aggressive behavior,” they said.
lead_paragraph: A grizzly bear is believed to have attacked and killed two people at a national park in southwest Canada, park officials said on Sunday.

headline: Dozens Search for Girl Who Disappeared Camping With Family Upstate
abstract: Police say Charlotte Sena, 9, may have been abducted in Moreau Lake State Park.
lead_paragraph: Authorities in New York were engaged in a frantic search for a missing 9-year-old girl on Sunday after she disappeared during an early evening bike ride in a state park north of Albany on Saturday.

headline: As His Fraud Trial Begins, Trump Looks to Capitalize on It
abstract: The former president is making the case to his supporters that he is being wrongfully targeted. And it might bring him more support.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump detoured from the campaign trail on Monday to attend the opening of the civil trial in the New York attorney general’s fraud case against him, as his political team seeks to turn the spectacle into a rallying cry for supporters.

headline: On a Warm Day in Iowa, Trump Heats Up His Push for Caucus Support
abstract: A Trump campaign event on Sunday was part of an effort by the former president to increase his presence in Iowa and to shut out his rivals in January’s caucuses.
lead_paragraph: By the time the doors opened Sunday morning, the line to enter former President Donald J. Trump’s caucus organizing event in Ottumwa, Iowa, snaked down the sidewalk and around the parking lot.

headline: What Role Should Young People Play in the Fight Against Climate Change?
abstract: Young people around the world are worried about the planet. What can they do about it?
lead_paragraph: In June, a group of young people in Montana won a landmark lawsuit related to climate change when, for the first time in the United States, a judge ruled that the state’s failure to consider climate change when approving fossil fuel projects was unconstitutional. Youth-led climate litigation is moving forward in other states too — and elsewhere around the world. With these lawsuits, along with social media activism and protests, Gen Z is making its voice heard.

headline: Newsom Names Emily’s List President as Feinstein Successor
abstract: Laphonza Butler will fill the Senate vacancy left by the death of Dianne Feinstein, the governor announced Sunday.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Gavin Newsom of California announced on Sunday night that he has chosen Laphonza Butler, the president of Emily’s List and a former labor leader, to fill the vacancy left in the Senate by the death of Dianne Feinstein.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Outside the Beltway, Dysfunction Induces a Big Public Yawn
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, Oct. 2, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “Our expectations have plummeted, and we have become dangerously numb to the failures of our government.”

headline: No Corrections: Oct. 2, 2023
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Oct. 2, 2023.
lead_paragraph: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

headline: Why the ‘Mother of the Atomic Bomb’ Never Won a Nobel Prize
abstract: Lise Meitner developed the theory of nuclear fission, the process that enabled the atomic bomb. But her identity — Jewish and a woman — barred her from sharing credit for the discovery, newly translated letters show.
lead_paragraph: There is a memorable scene in “Oppenheimer,” the blockbuster film about the building of the atomic bomb, in which Luis Alvarez, a physicist at the University of California, Berkeley, is reading a newspaper while getting a haircut. Suddenly, Alvarez leaps from his seat and sprints down the road to find his colleague, the theoretical physicist J. Robert Oppenheimer.

headline: Pick Pumpkins, Pick Apples and Get Out of Town
abstract: Ideas to interact with nature this month.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Monday. I am filling in for my colleague James Barron. Today we have an autumn cornucopia of seasonal outings.

headline: Monday Briefing
abstract: An averted government shutdown.
lead_paragraph: Congress narrowly averted a federal shutdown as the House, in a stunning turnabout, approved a stopgap plan to keep the U.S. government open until mid-November. The bill, which will keep money flowing to government agencies, does not include money for Ukraine despite a push for it by the White House and members of both parties in the Senate.

headline: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Catfish’ and ‘Sullivan’s Crossing’
abstract: The MTV show is back for a ninth season. The CW premieres a new show based on a novel of the same name.
lead_paragraph: With network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Oct. 2-8. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: Word of the Day: a cappella
abstract: This term has appeared in 56 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The term a cappella has appeared in 56 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on March 30 in “The Indie-Rock Trio boygenius Returns, Confident and Connected” by Jon Pareles:

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Trump’s Trial Starts Monday. It Will Spotlight What He’s Really Worth.
abstract: The judge in the civil case has already decided Donald J. Trump inflated his financial statements. Now, he will make rulings that will affect Mr. Trump’s future as a businessman.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live coverage of Trump’s civil fraud trial.

headline: New York Schools Came Back From the Brink. Now a New Crisis Looms.
abstract: The city faces billions in financial pressures in the coming years that threaten to worsen inequality across the nation’s largest school system.
lead_paragraph: Just a year ago, the outlook for New York City was bleak: The nation’s largest school system had lost 120,000 children in five years, and Mayor Eric Adams warned gravely, “We’re in a very dangerous place.”

headline: E.U. Foreign Ministers Hold Surprise Summit in Wartime Kyiv
abstract: Nearly all of the European Union’s top diplomats met in the Ukrainian capital, convening to reassert the bloc’s commitment against Russia’s invasion.
lead_paragraph: Nearly all of the European Union’s highest diplomats met in Ukraine’s battered wartime capital on Monday, convening a surprise summit to reassert the bloc’s commitment to Ukraine against Russia’s invasion and to rebut concerns that some countries’ support might be waning.

headline: E.U. Foreign Ministers Gather in Kyiv for Surprise Summit
abstract: The gathering in Kyiv, Ukraine, was described as the first time foreign ministers of the 27 E.U. nations met outside its borders.
lead_paragraph: The gathering in Kyiv, Ukraine, was described as the first time foreign ministers of the 27 E.U. nations met outside its borders.

headline: Typhoon Koinu Nears Southern China After Killing 1 in Taiwan
abstract: The storm is expected to graze China’s southern coast this weekend. It has drenched Taiwan and the Philippines.
lead_paragraph: Southern China was bracing for torrential rains and winds as Typhoon Koinu edged closer to the coast on Friday. The storm left one person dead in Taiwan, adding to what has already been an active typhoon season.

headline: Shoes on the Table! And Other Challenges to the Fashion Status Quo
abstract: It’s time we expect more from our clothes. Assessing the options at Balenciaga, Loewe, Hermès and Comme des Garçons.
lead_paragraph: Backstage after his autobiographical and quasi-retrospective Balenciaga show, Demna, the mononymic bearded creative director of the brand, was standing in a long hooded black coat like some sort of rebel wizard and holding up his iPhone to show off a photo.

headline: The Secret Memo From the General Who Foresaw Black Hawk Down
abstract: A warning sent to the Army chief of staff predicted the battle for Mogadishu.
lead_paragraph: The battle of Mogadishu in early October 1993 shocked most Americans. U.S. forces had been deployed to Somalia to support a U.N. humanitarian mission and had helped end a famine, saving hundreds of thousands of lives. Ten months later, there was pitched street fighting in Mogadishu, 18 dead American soldiers, more than a thousand Somali casualties and the horror, replayed over and over on TV, of American bodies being dragged through the streets by angry mobs.

headline: The Most Important Eight Hours of Your Day? They Weren’t Always.
abstract: Kenneth Miller’s “Mapping the Darkness” takes on the turbulent study of sleeping, its heroes and villains and its ongoing fight for respect.
lead_paragraph: In 1979, the surgeon general, Julius Richmond, launched Project Sleep, a research and educational initiative to increase the understanding of insomnia and other sleep disorders, and to further their treatment. Tremendous excitement ensued within a sleep science community that had been working largely unrecognized and underfunded for decades. Project Sleep could, at last, turn decades of arcane study into policy. Actual change. Praise be!

headline: Can a New At-Home Test Tell You if You’re in Menopause?
abstract: The maker says the test can clear the confusion. Doctors aren’t so sure.
lead_paragraph: An at-home menopause test kit from Clearblue, the maker of pregnancy tests, is now on store shelves across the United States. The company says the test, which became available in August, helps women determine which stage they’re in during the lead-up to menopause. Last week at a meeting of the nonprofit Menopause Society, the company presented data from a study it funded, suggesting that the test can pick up on hormone levels and other indicators associated with the life phase.

headline: Daniel Clowes Dreams of the Apocalypse
abstract: His new graphic novel, “Monica,” is a mother-daughter tale steeped in counterculture and cataclysm.
lead_paragraph: In 1989, Daniel Clowes kicked off his comic series “Eightball” with an issue subtitled “An Orgy of Spite, Vengeance, Hopelessness, Despair and Sexual Perversion,” and dude was only half kidding. “Eightball” was like no other comic on the stands, a demented cornucopia that brought into sharp relief Clowes’s remarkable sweep of gifts: his spare, uncanny compositions; his parodic brilliance; his pitch-perfect captures of his alienated characters’ inner lives; his surrealistic flights and pulpish progressions; his inability to remain in any generic lane whatsoever; and his true superpower, a scabrously radiant honesty that had no equal in comics or “literature.”

headline: Climate Change Is Forcing Families Into a New Kind of Indefinite Hell
abstract: We need to fund measures that both prevent disappearances through emergency preparedness and resolve them.
lead_paragraph: The August wildfire that roared through the town of Lahaina in Hawaii burned so hot that some of the dead were effectively cremated, their bones combusting to unidentifiable ash. Other bodies may have been lost in the Pacific Ocean, into which many of those fleeing the inferno were forced to plunge. As of Sept. 22, 97 people have been confirmed dead, and the Maui Police Department still lists 22 people as missing.

headline: The Great American Teacher Crisis
abstract: College students don’t want to become educators. Here’s how to change that.
lead_paragraph: Job satisfaction for teachers is at a 50-year low. They are leaving the profession while fewer and fewer college students are interested in joining the field. The Opinion writer Jessica Grose argues that Americans have to change the way they pay, train and appreciate teachers — or millions of children will suffer the consequences.

headline: How a Pricing Change Led to a Revolt by Unity’s Video Game Developers
abstract: In an industry where customers are slow to trust and quick to criticize, a new fee from Unity infuriated studios that use its platform.
lead_paragraph: John Riccitiello probably should have seen the outrage coming.

headline: ‘You Couldn’t Plan It All if You Tried’: Cruising the Rhone River in High Style
abstract: On a first-time luxury river cruise in France, our reporter learns why this all-inclusive trip, despite its expense, was worth it.
lead_paragraph: Marble floors, an emerald-green Murano chandelier, a life-size glass horse set against the backdrop of a cascading waterfall: Boarding the S.S. Catherine was like stepping into a meticulously curated room featured on the cover of Architectural Digest.

headline: Prozac Nation, Meet Lexapro Sweatshirts
abstract: Last year, when Eileen Kelly began a line of antidepressant-themed sweatshirts, they sold out fast. Now other brands are lining up to release anxiety-themed T-shirts and other mental health merch.
lead_paragraph: When Eileen Kelly began a blog, “Killer and a Sweet Thing,” in 2016 that focused on mental and sexual health, it was rare to see sites entirely devoted to such topics — let alone ones filled with levity. “Society’s attitude toward mental health has evolved significantly,” Ms. Kelly said, pointing to the memeification of mental health on the internet.

headline: They Accidentally Bought the Wrong House. So They Made It the Right House.
abstract: After becoming the inadvertent owners of a crumbling building in rural Scotland, a couple spent five years reviving it. With a little help.
lead_paragraph: One morning this past June, Claire Segeren and Cal Hunter received legal permission to live in their own home. It had only taken five years.

headline: He Announces Baseball Games in Spanish. It Is Not His First Language.
abstract: Bill Kulik, a Spanish-language radio broadcaster for the Philadelphia Phillies, mixes in English and Spanglish to the delight of some listeners, but the irritation of others.
lead_paragraph: Bill Kulik is a longtime Spanish language radio broadcaster for the Philadelphia Phillies. But listeners tuning in wouldn’t always know that.

headline: Power of Older Women? Extinct G.O.P. Moderates? It’s Time for the Mailbag.
abstract: We’re answering reader questions on polling and elections, including the underexplored area of longevity.
lead_paragraph: You may be partly joking, Mary, but this is probably a minor reason Democrats do a bit better among older voters than people might guess!

headline: Crypto Goes on Trial, as Sam Bankman-Fried Faces His Reckoning
abstract: The FTX founder’s uphill court battle starts Tuesday, after he has come to symbolize everything that went wrong with the cryptocurrency industry.
lead_paragraph: Follow live updates on the Sam Bankman-Fried fraud trial.

headline: $900,000 Homes in California
abstract: A loft-style condominium in Los Angeles, a three-bedroom retreat in Palm Springs and a bungalow in Oakland.
lead_paragraph: This loft is near the intersection of Hollywood and Vine, in the heart of Hollywood. The building, which was once a department store and later held office space, is a contributing structure to the National Register-listed Hollywood Boulevard Commercial and Entertainment District. It was redesigned in the late 2000s by Kelly Wearstler, an interior designer.

headline: Chris Sununu Saw Small Signs of Trump’s Defeat at the Debate
abstract: Gov. Chris Sununu thinks fewer Republican candidates equals Donald Trump losing the nomination. Jane Coaston interviews him about how to make that happen.
lead_paragraph: We saw a crowded Republican debate stage of seven candidates last Wednesday night — the kind of big field that worries New Hampshire’s governor, Chris Sununu, who has argued that candidates need to drop out if one or two strong rivals emerge to stop former President Donald Trump from winning the G.O.P. nomination.

headline: ‘Two Trains Charging at Each Other’: A Texas Bishop Takes On the Pope
abstract: Bishop Joseph Strickland, a hero to the emboldened traditionalist wing of American Catholicism, is in open warfare with the Vatican as it hosts a landmark gathering.
lead_paragraph: This year alone, Bishop Joseph Strickland of Tyler, Texas, has accused the pope of undermining the Catholic faith, has suggested that other Vatican officials have veered so far from church teaching that they are no longer Catholic, and has warned that a landmark global gathering that opens this week at the Vatican could threaten “basic truths” of Catholic doctrine.

headline: Who’s Rooting Hardest for a Sam Bankman-Fried Conviction? The Crypto Industry.
abstract: Crypto insiders, who have been trying to distance themselves from the FTX founder, are united in their zeal to see Mr. Bankman-Fried held to account.
lead_paragraph: Follow live updates on the Sam Bankman-Fried fraud trial.

headline: My Fellow Republicans: It’s Time to Grow Up
abstract: A former member of Congress has advice for his fellow Republicans who are considering ousting Speaker McCarthy.
lead_paragraph: Extremists in my party have threatened to try to remove Speaker Kevin McCarthy for relying on the votes of Democrats to keep the government open. Some of them appear to be authoritarian separatists who reject pluralism — a founding American principle that expects disparate groups to come together to keep the government functioning. Some of them just know that a crowd can be whomped up by overwrought pronouncements of existential threats from the “demons” on the other side.

headline: Now Republicans Are Trying to Redefine Abortion Itself
abstract: With post-Roe outrage showing no sign of waning, strategists on the right are pushing a new lexicon on abortion.
lead_paragraph: In the year since Roe v. Wade was overturned, the Republican Party has tested out constantly changing talking points and messages on abortion in an attempt to make its anti-abortion policies sound less extreme. Conservatives are even considering moving away from the term “pro-life,” fearing that voters have newly negative associations with the label.

headline: What Is a Synod in the Catholic Church? And Why Does This One Matter?
abstract: A seemingly obscure meeting could be the culmination of Francis’ papacy and lay the groundwork for lasting change on issues like married priests and the blessing of gay unions.
lead_paragraph: Even for a Roman Catholic Church rife with esoteric terminology that often defies comprehension by the uninitiated, this month’s Synod on Synodality at the Vatican — essentially a major workshop for church leaders and lay people on how to work together for the good of the church — has proved mystifyingly meta for many of the rank-and-file faithful.

headline: Vatican Assembly Puts the Church’s Most Sensitive Issues on the Table
abstract: Pope Francis’ calls for open-minded discussion will be tested this week as bishops meet with lay people, including women, to debate topics such as married priests and the blessing of gay couples.
lead_paragraph: Throughout his decade as leader of the Roman Catholic Church, Pope Francis has allowed debates on previously taboo topics and set in motion subtle shifts toward liberalizing changes that have enraged conservatives for going too far and frustrated progressives for not going far enough.

headline: Great Books Will Always Be Their Own Best Defense
abstract: I read banned books. So does almost everybody else.
lead_paragraph: During my grade school years in the early 1970s, I read everything. Books, of course — books about dogs and teen detectives and gruesomely martyred saints — but also the morning newspaper and the evening newspaper, a long-dead relative’s ancient encyclopedias, my father’s Reader’s Digest, my mother’s Southern Living. In the time-honored tradition of nerds everywhere, I read the backs of cereal boxes with the same rapt attention that I devoted to “Old Yeller” and Nancy Drew. If there were words before me, I read them.

headline: Russia May Be Planning to Test a Nuclear-Powered Missile
abstract: Visual evidence from a remote base in the Arctic shows launch preparations mirroring those that preceded earlier tests.
lead_paragraph: Satellite imagery and aviation data suggest that Russia may be preparing to test an experimental nuclear-powered cruise missile  — or may have recently tested one — with a theoretical range of thousands of miles.

headline: Why Do Runway Models Always Look So Grumpy?
abstract: A reader wonders why we rarely see smiles on the catwalk — and if that’s always been the case in fashion.
lead_paragraph: I get this question all the time from people who catch sight of runway photos during fashion month. In fact, designers do sometimes ask their models to smile. Giorgio Armani did it this season for his Emporio Armani show. Sonia Rykiel used to do it all the time. She even had her models skip down the catwalk to add extra zest. And it was almost always … terrifying.

headline: Gaetz Moves to Oust McCarthy, Threatening His Grip on the Speakership
abstract: The move forces a vote within days on whether to keep the speaker in his post, a challenge that only two other House speakers have faced in the history of the chamber.
lead_paragraph: Representative Matt Gaetz of Florida moved on Monday to oust Speaker Kevin McCarthy from his post in an act of vengeance that posed the clearest threat yet to Mr. McCarthy’s tenure and could plunge the House into chaos.

headline: Investigators of Iraqi Wedding Hall Blaze Call for Officials to Be Fired
abstract: The fire that killed almost 120 people had been accidental, a report said, but occurred after a series of decisions that proved deadly.
lead_paragraph: Investigators looking into the cause of a deadly fire at a wedding hall in northern Iraq called on Sunday for the firing of a half-dozen provincial and local officials for their failure to enforce compliance with even minimal safety standards in the hall’s construction and operation.

headline: Kevin McCarthy Surprised Us All
abstract: Does this mean there’s a sanity caucus out there for the taking?
lead_paragraph: Gail Collins: I didn’t think I’d be saying this, Bret, but we’ve dodged a shutdown. It’s a stupendous moment for Kevin McCarthy. Now if he gets tossed out as House speaker by the right wing, he’ll go down in history as the guy who sacrificed his career for the common good. As opposed to the best possible previous scenario: the boring career pol who was too scared to keep the government running.

headline: Redfin, the Online Real Estate Broker, Leaves a Powerful Realtor Group
abstract: The brokerage said it would require many of its brokers and real estate agents to cancel their memberships with the National Association of Realtors, prompted by allegations of sexual harassment within the group.
lead_paragraph: Redfin is cutting ties with the National Association of Realtors, one month after The New York Times published an article detailing a yearslong pattern of allegations of sexual harassment, discrimination and retribution that the organization did not address.

headline: Today’s Top News: Trump’s Fraud Trial Begins, and More
abstract: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — it’s available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

headline: Nobel Prize Awarded to Covid Vaccine Pioneers
abstract: The physiology or medicine prize for Katalin Karikó and Drew Weissman recognized work that led to the development of vaccines that were administered to billions around the world.
lead_paragraph: Katalin Karikó and Drew Weissman, who together identified a chemical tweak to messenger RNA, were awarded the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine on Monday. Their work enabled potent Covid vaccines to be made in less than a year, averting tens of millions of deaths and helping the world recover from the worst pandemic in a century.

headline: The Orion Nebula Is Full of Impossible Enigmas That Come in Pairs
abstract: In new, high-resolution imagery of the star-forming region, scientists spotted worlds that defied explanation, naming them Jupiter Mass Binary Objects.
lead_paragraph: We have discovered a lot in this universe. Planets that orbit stars at right angles. Forbidden worlds that have cheated death. Space explosions that defy explanation.

headline: Amazon’s Most Beloved Features May Turn Out to Be Illegal
abstract: A long-awaited lawsuit accuses the internet giant of protecting an online retail monopoly.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. government has filed a landmark antitrust lawsuit against Amazon, pointing to a set of familiar features that have made, the internet retail giant so beloved by consumers.

headline: A Public Health Setback
abstract: Abortion politics are threatening a successful global AIDS program.
lead_paragraph: For decades, the U.S. has bankrolled global efforts to fight the spread of AIDS, saving tens of millions of lives. Congress has extended the program on a bipartisan basis since President George W. Bush created it in 2003.

headline: Wildfires in Canada Bringing Hazy Skies Over New York, Other Regions
abstract: The impact on air quality was expected to be mild, officials said. Other cities also registered moderate air quality readings.
lead_paragraph: Smoke from wildfires in Canada was drifting over New York and other states on Monday, officials have warned, adding that they were anticipating slight impacts on air quality in some places.

headline: Extreme Eye Contact and Other Ways of Dating
abstract: Forget dinner and a movie: Let’s see if we can gaze into each other’s eyes for three minutes instead.
lead_paragraph: What happens when you skip the small talk during a date and go straight to hand-holding?

headline: Crypto’s Trial of the Century Is Set to Begin
abstract: Sam Bankman-Fried, the founder of the failed crypto exchange FTX, gets his day in court on Tuesday. The trial will shine a harsh glare on the wider sector.
lead_paragraph: The corporate world will cast its eyes on courts in New York and Washington this week, as a series of high-profile business cases are set to kick off.

headline: Russian and Ukrainian Officials Both Predict U.S. Support for Kyiv Won’t Change
abstract: Officials in Moscow and Kyiv played down the significance of a U.S. government spending bill that lacked new funding for Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Russian and Ukrainian officials voiced a rare note of agreement on Monday, with both sides playing down the significance of a U.S. government spending bill that lacked new aid for Kyiv.

headline: South Asians Are Divided Over a Pending Ban on Caste Discrimination
abstract: Some say a bill awaiting Gov. Gavin Newsom’s signature that would forbid caste-based bias is badly needed, while others say it unfairly singles out Hindus for legal exposure.
lead_paragraph: It’s Monday. Not everyone thinks a bill awaiting Governor Newsom’s signature that would ban caste-based discrimination is a helpful step. Plus, Laphonza Butler is the governor’s choice for the state’s vacant U.S. Senate seat.

headline: Trump’s Fraud Trial Starts With Attacks on Attorney General and Judge
abstract: Donald J. Trump appeared in court as lawyers for New York’s attorney general, Letitia James, painted him as a fraudster. His lawyers said she was out to get the former president.
lead_paragraph: The trials of Donald J. Trump began Monday in a New York courtroom, where the former president arrived to fight the first of several government actions — a civil fraud case that imperils his company and threatens his image as a master of the business world.

headline: Tesla’s Sales Slip as It Readies Factories for New Models
abstract: Analysts expected a decline in sales for the quarter. Still, the dip may raise concerns about flagging demand.
lead_paragraph: Sales of Tesla electric cars slipped from July through September after the company paused production at some factories to upgrade assembly lines.

headline: China Evergrande’s Founder: From Rags to Riches to Under Investigation
abstract: Hui Ka Yan, who grew up poor in the countryside, was a symbol of China’s economic rise. With Evergrande teetering, his future is uncertain, too.
lead_paragraph: Hui Ka Yan founded the real estate behemoth China Evergrande. His promise to transform rural villages to metropolises with middle-class comforts made him one of China’s wealthiest people. He rubbed shoulders with officials in the highest levels of government, celebrating the Communist Party’s 100th anniversary in 2021 at Tiananmen Square.

headline: Beyoncé’s ‘Renaissance’ Film Coming to Movie Theaters
abstract: The singer’s blockbuster tour ended over the weekend without the release of a visual component. But a “Renaissance” film will be released in December, she announced on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Beyoncé’s 56-show Renaissance World Tour ended over the weekend without the release of any much-anticipated visual component tied to the singer’s shimmering 2022 dance album. Beyoncé, however, may have had a plan all along: “Renaissance: A Film by Beyoncé” will be released in movie theaters on Dec. 1, the singer announced on Monday, immediately following the tour’s final show in Kansas City, Mo.

headline: A Lightning Rod Defends His Legacy (and Has a Few Regrets)
abstract: In his memoir “The Controversialist,” Martin Peretz reflects on his long tenure as publisher and editor of The New Republic.
lead_paragraph: “When you talk about politics,” the critic Irving Howe said, “you should stand.” Martin Peretz quotes this line early in “The Controversialist,” his new memoir, as a style of moralizing he was never crazy about. But the observation suits him. Peretz writes as if he were pacing around a dining-room table, ego and self-loathing fighting it out in his head.

headline: Supreme Court Turns Away Challenge to New York’s Rent Regulations
abstract: Landlords had argued that a rent-stabilization law that covers about a million units is an unconstitutional government taking of private property.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court announced on Monday that it would not hear a challenge to New York’s rent-stabilization regulations, under which the government sets maximum permissible rent increases and generally allows tenants to renew their leases indefinitely.

headline: Can You Find The 13 Adventure Travel Books Hidden in This Text?
abstract: Jump into book discovery with this Title Search puzzle that hides the names of more than a dozen books about road trips and exploring new places.
lead_paragraph: Jump into book discovery with this Title Search puzzle that hides the names of more than a dozen books about road trips and exploring new places.

headline: Jurist presiding at Trump’s civil trial will serve as judge and jury.
abstract: Justice Arthur F. Engoron, a fan of puns and pop culture, will decide the fate of the former president’s family business at his civil fraud trial.
lead_paragraph: Arthur F. Engoron, who is presiding over Donald J. Trump’s civil fraud trial, is an independent and thoughtful — if somewhat quirky — jurist who has served for 20 years in New York City Civil and State Supreme Court.

headline: ‘We Taylor-gated’: Taylor Swift Fans Descend on a Jets Game
abstract: Football fans mingled with Swifties, on public transit, in the parking lot and at the game. Everyone was dressed for the occasion.
lead_paragraph: It was a standing-room-only crowd gathered in the aisles of a New Jersey Transit train from New York’s Penn Station to New Jersey at 5 p.m. on Sunday evening.

headline: How PETA Infiltrated Major Fashion Shows This Season
abstract: An inside look at how and why the animal rights activists returned to disrupting the runways.
lead_paragraph: A young woman crouched in the tall grass, waiting for her moment to strike.

headline: India’s Early Electronic Music From the ’70s Is Finally Being Released
abstract: A trove of tapes discovered in a cupboard at the country’s National Institute of Design showcases artists composing early synth recordings on their own terms.
lead_paragraph: When the musician and artist Paul Purgas was invited in 2017 by the National Institute of Design in Ahmedabad, India, to play some of the music he’d found in its archives that year, he was initially very keen. These were tapes that had been hidden from the public for decades; they proved the existence of a fertile avenue for electronic music in 1960s and ’70s India, and he was determined for people to hear them. But as he went to use the institute’s aging reel-to-reel machine, he got a nasty surprise: an electric shock.

headline: Kenyan-Led Security Mission in Haiti: What to Know
abstract: With hundreds killed, abducted and injured in a worsening cycle of gang violence in Haiti, a Kenyan plan to lead a mission to help stabilize the country won U.N. approval on Monday.
lead_paragraph: In one attack, gang members opened fire on people called to a protest by a church leader. In another, they set seven people on fire. And after months of escalating violence in Haiti, hundreds if not thousands have been killed — spurring a desperate vigilante movement against the gangs and a mass flight from Haiti’s cities.

headline: Bears Are Having a Moment
abstract: If you’ve fallen into the rabbit hole of bear videos on TikTok, you’re not alone. But are there more bears or just more viral clips?
lead_paragraph: In August, a black bear bit a man who was camping in Colorado, officials released a statement about “bear activity” in Tennessee after one tried to find food in a car, and a grizzly attacked a man in Wyoming.

headline: Five Easy Recipes With Smart Shortcuts
abstract: There’s no blender required for mattar paneer, a reader favorite, and a clever crumb cake works with whatever fruit you have on hand — fresh, frozen or dried.
lead_paragraph: I love mattar paneer (the traditional Indian dish of peas and paneer in spiced, creamy tomato gravy), but I don’t love the break-out-the-blender hassle of puréeing the sautéed onions, tomatoes and cashews that you’ll find in most recipes. Sadly, that one step has usually been enough to knock the dish out of my low-effort weeknight dinner rotation.

headline: Met Museum’s Great Hall Store to Become Gallery
abstract: A renovation will create more exhibition space for the popular Costume Institute show as well as a new store and restaurant at the plaza level.
lead_paragraph: In an attempt to modernize how visitors experience its 19th-century building, the Metropolitan Museum of Art is planning to turn the large store off its Great Hall into an 11,500-square-foot gallery for its blockbuster Costume Institute exhibitions and to transform an entrance underneath the main staircase into a retail space and restaurant that will be open to the public even when the museum is closed.

headline: Bizarre Cancer Has Been Spreading Among Shellfish for Centuries, Studies Find
abstract: The cancer likely started off as an immune cell that mutated, multiplied and adapted to survive in the water.
lead_paragraph: In the 1970s, soft-shell clams started mysteriously dying off in Maine and the Chesapeake Bay. Years later, scientists identified the culprit: a bizarre form of cancer that spread like an epidemic.

headline: A New Satellite Outshines Some of the Brightest Stars in the Sky
abstract: Astronomers warn that BlueWalker 3, a test spacecraft with a large array of antennas, could be the first of many larger satellites in low-Earth orbit that interfere with astronomical observations.
lead_paragraph: Last November, a satellite in low-Earth orbit unfurled into an expansive array that extends across nearly 700 square feet, about the size of a studio apartment.

headline: Notebook and Pen in Hand, a Swiftie Watches the N.F.L. and Learns
abstract: As two of America’s biggest fandoms collide, the pop star’s biggest fans are studying up and cheering along.
lead_paragraph: During one of the cutaway shots of the 12-time Grammy winner Taylor Swift at Sunday night’s football game between the Kansas City Chiefs and the New York Jets, Zainub Amir, one of the singer’s ardent fans, grinned.

headline: Church Collapse in Mexico Kills 11 During Collective Baptism
abstract: A church roof fell in a city on Mexico’s Gulf Coast as dozens of parishioners were at Sunday Mass. Rescuers said at least three children were among the dead.
lead_paragraph: Rescuers in northern Mexico recovered the bodies of 10 people who died after the roof of a Roman Catholic church collapsed during Sunday Mass in Ciudad Madero, an oil-refining city on the Gulf of Mexico. Among the youngest victims were three children, including a 1-and-a-half-year-old boy.

headline: Philadelphia Journalist Is Killed in His Home
abstract: Josh Kruger, 39, was shot seven times. The police said that no arrests had been made.
lead_paragraph: A freelance journalist was shot and killed at his home in South Philadelphia early Monday morning, the police said.

headline: Putin’s Next Target: U.S. Support for Ukraine, Officials Say
abstract: Russian spy agencies and new technologies could be used to push conspiracy theories, U.S. officials say.
lead_paragraph: Russia’s strategy to win the war in Ukraine is to outlast the West.

headline: Justice Thomas Recuses as Supreme Court Turns Down Appeal From Eastman
abstract: John Eastman, a conservative lawyer who had advised President Donald J. Trump, had sought to wipe out a decision that he said had harmed his reputation and that of his client.
lead_paragraph: Justice Clarence Thomas, in a break from his practices in earlier cases involving the 2020 election, recused himself on Monday when the Supreme Court turned down an appeal from an architect of a plan to subvert the 2020 election.

headline: A Shutdown Averted, at Least for Now
abstract: Readers criticize congressional chaos and discuss Speaker Kevin McCarthy’s role. Also: James Dolan, in Las Vegas and New York.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Multiple People Killed After Church Roof Collapses in Mexico
abstract: Surveillance footage shows the moment the roof of a church in Ciudad Madero, Mexico, collapsed during Sunday Mass.
lead_paragraph: Surveillance footage shows the moment the roof of a church in Ciudad Madero, Mexico, collapsed during Sunday Mass.

headline: Wildfires: Stay Safe in a Warming World
abstract: Climate change has made wildfires a year-round threat to travelers. Here’s how to minimize your risk, and what to do if you’re in the path of a fire.
lead_paragraph: Climate change is warming up the spring, lengthening the summer, and drying out soil and vegetation, leading to more frequent, destructive wildfires. This year alone, wildfires have left at least 98 dead on Maui, forced mass evacuations from several Greek islands, and raged across Canada, forcing an entire city to evacuate and fouling the air across North America. If you’re traveling in this environment — especially if you’re planning a trip to the outdoors — how can you stay safe? Here’s how to prepare yourself, and what to do in case of an emergency.

headline: A Brooklyn Artist Interrogates N.Y.P.D. Surveillance Films
abstract: Kameron Neal, an artist in residence with New York City’s Department of Records, was struck by the power dynamics between the watchers and the watched.
lead_paragraph: For two decades, plainclothes intelligence officers from the New York Police Department used hand-held 16-millimeter cameras to film people without their consent, producing footage of Vietnam War protesters and Black Panther activists, of Martin Luther King Jr. and John F. Kennedy.

headline: Alice Shalvi, Hailed as a Mother of Feminism in Israel, Dies at 96
abstract: She was an often defiant, galvanizing force in pressing for equal treatment for women in marriage, employment, education and more.
lead_paragraph: Alice Shalvi, an innovative educator and social activist revered by many as a founding mother of modern Jewish feminism in Israel, died on Monday at her home in Jerusalem. She was 96.

headline: Microsoft C.E.O. Testifies That Google’s Power in Search Is Ubiquitous
abstract: Satya Nadella, the chief executive of Microsoft, is the government’s biggest-name witness in its landmark antitrust case against Google.
lead_paragraph: Satya Nadella, Microsoft’s chief executive, testified on Monday that Google’s power in online search was so ubiquitous that even his company found it difficult to compete on the internet, becoming the government’s highest-profile witness in its landmark antitrust trial against the search giant.

headline: When Mr. Secretary Loves to Rock
abstract: A viral video of Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken introduced Americans to the guitar geek hidden within.
lead_paragraph: It’s usually not a good sign when video of a senior government official singing goes viral on social media, where the crowds are as tough as they come.

headline: Horace Ové, Pioneering Black Filmmaker in Britain, Dies at 86
abstract: His feature-length film, “Pressure,” mapped the struggles of Black Britons in an era of unyielding racism. He was knighted in 2022.
lead_paragraph: Horace Ové, a prolific and groundbreaking Trinidad-born filmmaker and photographer whose 1975 film, “Pressure,” explored the fraught experience of Black Britons and is considered the first feature film by a Black British director, died on Sept. 16 in London. He was 86.

headline: What to Know About Laphonza Butler, Newsom’s Appointee to the Senate
abstract: Ms. Butler, 44, was chosen on Sunday to fill the vacancy created by the death of Senator Dianne Feinstein.
lead_paragraph: Laphonza Butler, president of Emily’s List and a former labor leader, is Gov. Gavin Newsom of California’s choice to fill the Senate seat of Dianne Feinstein, who died at 90 on Thursday in Washington, D.C. The selection was announced on Sunday.

headline: A Chance to Sample a Famous Reuben
abstract: Zingerman’s bring its sandwich to New York City for a one-day-only engagement, a new oasis for caviar opens in Queens and more food news.
lead_paragraph: Yes, you can get a Reuben in lots of New York delicatessens and sandwich shops. Zingerman’s Deli, the long-established Jewish food emporium in Ann Arbor, Mich., is renowned for its version and will be bringing them to New York to the Olly Olly Market in Chelsea on Saturday. The classic Reuben and a pickle, along with “Binny’s Brooklyn Reuben” made on grilled pumpernickel, and other combinations including corned beef and pastrami sandwiches, all $25 each, will be freshly made and sold from noon to 8 p.m. or as long as supplies last.

headline: Frans Hals and the Art of Laughter
abstract: His grinning subjects can be hard to take seriously. But a major exhibition argues that Frans Hals is an old master on par with Rembrandt and Vermeer.
lead_paragraph: What made people in the Dutch Golden Age laugh? The person who knew best was the painter Frans Hals.

headline: Giving Workers a Raise Is Not Going to Make Inflation Worse
abstract: Financial analysts dread the specter of a wage-price spiral, but in reality the phenomenon is rare.
lead_paragraph: As the United Auto Workers strike against General Motors, Ford Motor and Stellantis expands and the union continues to hold out for big wage increases, some analysts are worrying that higher pay will be inflationary. The nightmare scenario is that wages drive up prices, which cause workers to demand even more money, and so on, in a ruinous upward spiral. Geoff Yu, a senior market strategist at BNY Mellon, said on Bloomberg Television last month that the unions are “making the gamble or the determination” to ask for more money in a way that could trigger a wage-price spiral.

headline: The Americans Most Threatened by Eviction: Young Children
abstract: About a quarter of Black babies and toddlers in rental households face the threat of eviction in a typical year, a new study says, and all children are disproportionately at risk.
