There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: Workers Exposed to Extreme Heat Have Few Protections
abstract: Tens of millions of Americans are struggling to cope with soaring temperatures. OSHA is developing new workplace safety standards, but they are not yet complete.
lead_paragraph: Anthony Soto, a 22-year-old baggage claim employee at the Dallas Fort Worth International Airport, crumpled to the floor near gate C15 after a seizure last October that he attributed to hot indoor conditions and strenuous lifting. In record-setting heat in Texas this past summer, Mr. Soto, who has epilepsy, had four more seizures that left him speechless, his body unresponsive, he said.

headline: Need News Fast? Try Listening to Your Headlines.
abstract: “The Headlines,” a show by The New York Times, promises to bring listeners the most noteworthy news of the day in about 10 minutes.
lead_paragraph: What do a Republican presidential debate, Meta’s foray into artificial intelligence and a new musical by the composer Stephen Sondheim, who died in 2021, all have in common?

headline: Subway Gunman Gets 10 Life Sentences, One for Each Person He Shot
abstract: Prosecutors had asked a judge to give Frank James 10 life sentences, one for each victim wounded in the April 2022 shooting aboard an N train in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Frank James, who opened fire in a morning-rush subway car in Brooklyn in April 2022, wounding 10 people but miraculously killing none before making his escape by blending into the fleeing crowd, was given 10 life sentences — one for each person he shot — in federal court on Thursday.

headline: Football and Bag of Money
abstract: What do you think this image is communicating?
lead_paragraph: What do you think this image is saying? How does it relate to or comment on society? Can you relate to it personally? What is your opinion of its message?

headline: New U.A.W. Chief Has a Nonnegotiable Demand: Eat the Rich
abstract: Shawn Fain’s disdain for the “billionaire class” informs his showdown with Detroit’s automakers. Now he must prove that his hard-core tactics pay off.
lead_paragraph: For as long as anyone can remember, the Indiana city of Kokomo has been a conservative stronghold. Ronald Reagan crushed Walter Mondale in Kokomo. Bill Clinton lost twice. So did Barack Obama. The current mayor, a Republican, is running unopposed for re-election. It’s a town known for something it would prefer to forget: a Ku Klux Klan rally in 1923 that was the largest ever.

headline: Was New York City Unprepared to Handle Last Week’s Extreme Rainfall?
abstract: The city comptroller and the City Council will open separate inquiries into the city’s preparation for the storm.
lead_paragraph: Six days after the remnants of Tropical Storm Ophelia paralyzed New York City, trapping children in flooded schools and halting swaths of subway and railroad service, the city’s preparation for the storm and its response are facing scrutiny.

headline: Half of New York City Children Passed Math and Reading Tests
abstract: The proficiency rates are up, but the state’s annual exams were overhauled, so the results can’t really be compared with those from last year.
lead_paragraph: About half of New York City students showed proficiency on math and reading exams this year, according to data released on Wednesday — scores that, on paper, represented a rise over last year.

headline: Shades of Gray, and Then Some
abstract: During Paris Fashion Week, almost every color could be spotted on the streets and the runways.
lead_paragraph: A particular color can often dominate both the runways and the crowds at any fashion week. But this season, instead of coalescing around a certain shade, designers and attendees seemed to embrace many of them.

headline: The Wegovy Shortage Drags On, Leaving Patients in Limbo
abstract: The situation has left many patients frustrated and unable to start taking the weight loss drug.
lead_paragraph: When Mark Basa needed his next dose of Wegovy, he worked his way down a list of 10 CVS stores within a 25-mile radius of his Peekskill, N.Y., home — and struck out at every one. In the 10 weeks he couldn’t find the drug, he regained the eight pounds he had lost on the medication, and his blood sugar rose. He felt himself get out of breath more often. His shirts fit tighter.

headline: Move Over, Machu Picchu: There’s More to See in Peru
abstract: In recent years, Peru has engaged in a grass-roots effort to elevate Huchuy Qosqo, Waqrapukara and other archaeological sites that are just as well preserved or culturally significant as Machu Picchu itself.
lead_paragraph: Elvis Lexin La Torre Uñaccori knows quite well that a wonder of the world often creates a less-wondrous world of waste — he is the mayor of Machu Picchu Pueblo, the gateway village to the bucket-list destination in Peru that draws millions of visitors (and their trash) each year.

headline: 36 Hours in Florence, Italy
abstract: Nighttime strolls, lesser-known museums and tiny trattorias reveal a more intimate side of this popular Italian destination.
lead_paragraph: Nighttime strolls, lesser-known museums and tiny trattorias reveal a more intimate side of this popular Italian destination.

headline: A Start-Up’s Alternative to Uber: Employing Its Own Drivers
abstract: Alto is trying to fill a more expensive niche, especially as politicians and labor groups argue that the contractor model exploits drivers.
lead_paragraph: The white S.U.V. pulled away from the curb at Dallas Fort Worth International Airport, bound for downtown Dallas. There was an issue.

headline: Banana Yoshimoto Wants Books to Give Her Insomnia
abstract: “I love it when I don’t have any plans the next day and end up reading until daybreak because I can’t sleep,” says the author, whose new novel is “The Premonition.” “It’s the best feeling.”
lead_paragraph: What books are on your night stand?

headline: Something ‘Old World,’ Something New
abstract: Michael Mendieta, a comedy writer, and Whitaker Irvin Jr., an energy executive, blended their different backgrounds into a happy life together.
lead_paragraph: On the surface, Michael John Mendieta and Whitaker Ben Irvin Jr. couldn’t be more different.

headline: A ‘School Dance for Adults’ Embraces the Aughts
abstract: From Disney Channel bops to Nickelodeon theme songs, tween pop from the 2000s is proving to be an unironic draw at parties across the country.
lead_paragraph: It’s a Friday night in 2006: The Bagel Bites are defrosting in the oven and a case of Capri Suns is chilling in the refrigerator. You turn on the TV in the living room, click your way to the Disney Channel, and prepare to sing both the Troy and Gabriella parts in “Breaking Free” from “High School Musical.”

headline: Down With Efficiency! (When We Get Around to It.)
abstract: The relentless pursuit of an optimized life robs people of whimsy and joy.
lead_paragraph: We are no longer achieving an acceptable level of whimsy. In even the smallest corners of daily life, we are asked to abandon delicious inefficiencies — the archaic flights of fancy, the capricious nonsense — in favor of a totalizing commitment to the false idols of logic, regularity and efficacy.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on the Texts His Wife Doesn’t Appreciate
abstract: When a reminder about picking up a package is about more than a simple chore.
lead_paragraph: Daniel writes: When I walk the dog, I leave the house via the garage. Sometimes I see there’s a package at our front door that we haven’t noticed. I text my wife to notify her, so that she can get it because I may forget by the time I’m back. She does not appreciate this, particularly when I do it even though I know she’s not at home.

headline: Why Summers May Never Be the Same
abstract: The globe’s warmest months on record redefined summer for many Americans.
lead_paragraph: It felt like the opening minutes of a disaster movie.

headline: Diesel Prices Could Keep Inflation High
abstract: The cost of the fuel has been rising in recent weeks and could spike this winter because of supply problems, analysts warn.
lead_paragraph: Inflation has been easing around the world. But what happens next could depend partly on the cost of diesel, a wild card that few analysts have been able to predict well.

headline: Kate Soper Returns to Opera With a Story Medieval and Modern
abstract: “The Hunt,” set to premiere this month in New York, mines ancient lore about unicorns, but asks questions of today. Who has power, and who has rights?
lead_paragraph: On a recent summer morning in New York, three sopranos, a director and a small crew gathered for a rehearsal of “The Hunt,” a new opera by Kate Soper.

headline: Revering the Earth, Colombian Artist Delcy Morelos Brings It to Chelsea
abstract: To make sense of her country’s history of violence, the artist evokes beauty in the land. At Dia, you can smell, enter and touch.
lead_paragraph: When the Colombian artist Delcy Morelos created a giant maze of earth at the Venice Biennale in 2022, she watched some visitors respond to the structure in a way that troubled her.

headline: Now Is the Time to Pay Attention to Trump’s Violent Language
abstract: Alex Kingsbury thinks there could be dire consequences if we continue to ignore the former president.
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump has never been shy with his language, but recently, the Times editor Alex Kingsbury argues, his violent speech has escalated. In the past few weeks alone, Trump suggested that his own former general was treasonous, said that shoplifters should be shot and exhorted his followers to “go after” New York’s attorney general. Alex says he understands why voters tune Trump out but stresses the need to pay attention and take action for the sake of American democracy.

headline: Baseball Has Lost Its Poetry
abstract: A languorous 19th-century invention is being forced to fit a 21st-century pace of life.
lead_paragraph: The playoffs are upon us, and this year Major League Baseball likes to think of itself as having a lot to cheer about. Regular-season attendance for games and viewership on TV are the highest they’ve been in years, a result, many people say, of bold changes to the game’s rules: bigger bases to encourage more stealing (read: action), the intentional walk rule (which eliminates the staging of four outside lobs from pitcher to catcher) and the prohibition on pitchers’ throwing to first base as often when a runner’s on.

headline: What Can Writers Learn From Turtles?
abstract: While doing rescue work with snappers and tortoises, Sy Montgomery made a few observations that could come in handy in the literary world.
lead_paragraph: Sy Montgomery is the author of so many books, a list of titles sprawls over two pages at the front of her new best seller, “Of Time and Turtles.” She’s written for readers of all ages about dozens of animals — tigers and tree kangaroos, kakapos and cockatoos, just to name a few — so this naturalist is well qualified to make a connection between her latest subjects and her own career.

headline: Poem: Jobs for the Weekend
abstract: This is not some placid, ideal garden, but a real one — edgy, animate and bustling.
lead_paragraph: The work of the garden is never merely human work. The animals, insects and plants join in labor with the gardener, sometimes in harmony with human plans, but just as often thwarting or diverting them. This is one way a garden becomes a paradox: Its purported peace is the total effect of the garden’s frenetic, multispecies, conflict-rich choreography. Oki Sogumi’s “Jobs for the Weekend” captures not some placid, ideal garden, but a real one — edgy, animate and bustling. Selected by Anne Boyer

headline: Would You Ever Want to Live on the Moon or Mars?
abstract: Have you ever dreamed of visiting another celestial body or planet?
lead_paragraph: Can you envision yourself living on the moon or somewhere else beyond Earth? If so, why? What is compelling about traveling to other worlds in space?

headline: The Genius Behind Hollywood’s Most Indelible Sets
abstract: How Jack Fisk, the master production designer behind ‘Killers of the Flower Moon’ and many other films, brings the past to life.
lead_paragraph: Kihekah Avenue cuts through the town of Pawhuska, Okla., roughly north to south, forming the only corridor you might call a “business district” in the town of 2,900. Standing in the middle is a small TV-and-appliance store called Hometown, which occupies a two-story brick building and hasn’t changed much in decades. Boards cover its second-story windows, and part of the sign above its awning is broken, leaving half the lettering intact, spelling “Home.” The space inside, in the language of the plains, is “humble”: Its ceilings are low, its walls wood-paneled, its floors carpeted in tight-woven grids. If it weren’t for the giant inflatable University of Oklahoma Sooners mascot in its front-window display, the store would be easy to miss completely.

headline: ‘Antiracism’ Was Never the Right Answer
abstract: Ibram X. Kendi became a national arbiter on race, even though his reductionist approach was at odds with principles of free inquiry and expression.
lead_paragraph: The recent turmoil at Ibram X. Kendi’s Center for Antiracist Research at Boston University, with more than half its staff laid off and half its budget cut amid questions of what it did with the nearly $55 million it raised, led to whoops of schadenfreude from Kendi’s critics and hand-wringing from his loyal fans.

headline: The Kaiser Strike Isn’t Your Typical Labor Action
abstract: Health care policymakers and industry leaders must reckon with the difficulties facing workers if we want to avert strikes.
lead_paragraph: In April 2020, when I would walk home after a long day treating patients in a New York City emergency room, an orchestra of pots and pans would erupt from seemingly every window to honor frontline workers. Nothing could make those early pandemic days easier for me and my colleagues, but those haphazard symphonies of appreciation helped keep us going. At that time, health care workers had every reason to hope that once the Covid-19 pandemic waned, long-overdue and much needed changes to our health care system would finally materialize.

headline: 10 Zinfandels and Blends to Drink Right Now
abstract: They have veered wildly in style and critical esteem. Now consumers can select from a wide diversity of wines.
lead_paragraph: Few grapes have traveled so jagged an up-and-down journey as zinfandel. It has oscillated wildly in both style and popularity.

headline: Some Key Facts About Fentanyl
abstract: It’s lowering American life expectancy and influencing the nation’s politics.
lead_paragraph: Fentanyl has become a leading cause of death in the United States, an issue on the presidential campaign trail and the subject of major diplomatic efforts by the Biden administration.

headline: How a Chain-Snatching and a Vegas Beatdown Led to Tupac’s Murder
abstract: Grand jury witness testimony describes how hyperlocal clashes between warring gang factions spilled into a fatal dispute that would alter the course of hip-hop history.
lead_paragraph: In the adrenalized aftermath of a Mike Tyson prizefight in 1996, a black BMW carrying the rapper Tupac Shakur pulled up to a red light just off the Las Vegas Strip, thrilling the women in the car next to him.

headline: Remembering Senator Dianne Feinstein: ‘She Showed the Way’
abstract: Women dominated the stage at a memorial on Thursday for Ms. Feinstein, who broke barriers, over and over.
lead_paragraph: Almost everyone on the stage outside San Francisco’s City Hall on Thursday afternoon was a woman: the vice president, the former speaker of the House, the city’s mayor and more.

headline: From a Floating Home in Portland to a Hilly Perch in Los Angeles. Which House Was Right?
abstract: After 20 years on the Columbia River in Oregon, a retired couple tested the dryer environs of Southern California to be closer to their children. Here’s what they found.
lead_paragraph: After 20 years on the Columbia River in Oregon, a retired couple tested the dryer environs of Southern California to be closer to their children. Here’s what they found.

headline: Migration and Fentanyl Take Center Stage as U.S. and Mexican Officials Meet
abstract: The secretary of state and other top Biden administration officials met with Mexico’s president and other officials to discuss issues that have divided the two countries.
lead_paragraph: President Biden’s top cabinet officials and their Mexican counterparts presented a united front after talks on Thursday to combat drug and gun trafficking, and placed a new emphasis on managing record levels of migration.

headline: To the World, McCarthy’s Exit Is Just Another Example of U.S. Disarray
abstract: Amid upheaval on Capitol Hill and the undermining of democratic norms, the country’s institutions are under profound stress.
lead_paragraph: There was a time, not that long ago, when the United States presumed to teach the world how it was done. When it held itself up as a model of a stable, predictable democracy. When it sent idealistic young avatars to distant parts of the globe to impart the American way.

headline: How to Fix Wordy Writing
abstract: A writer and teacher shares a lesson for helping students understand the importance of clear, concise writing, and spotting needless words.
lead_paragraph: This idea was submitted by Chelsey Philpot, who teaches nonfiction writing at Boston University. She is the author of two young adult novels (“Be Good Be Real Be Crazy” and “Even in Paradise”) and her work has been published in The New York Times, The Boston Globe, Slate and BuzzFeed.

headline: Today’s Top News: Secretary Blinken Travels to Mexico, and More
abstract: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

headline: The Mosquitoes Are Winning
abstract: The rapid evolution of the insect has helped drive up Malaria deaths in Africa, fueling a growing public health threat.
lead_paragraph: For decades, the world seemed to be winning the war against mosquitoes and tamping down the deadly diseases they carried. But in the past few years, progress has not only stalled, it has reversed.

headline: Do You Know the History of the Nobel Prize in Literature?
abstract: Take this short trivia quiz to see how much you remember about the esteemed award and its past recipients.
lead_paragraph: Take this short trivia quiz to see how much you remember about the esteemed award and its past recipients.

headline: TikTok Forced to Close Shopping Feature in Its Second-Largest Market
abstract: TikTok’s retail ambitions have confronted an obstacle in Indonesia, which views the app as a threat to local businesses.
lead_paragraph: Indonesia was one of the first countries where TikTok launched TikTok Shop, betting on the app’s potential to become a successful retail platform for the company’s second-largest user base.

headline: America’s Political Turmoil
abstract: A survey of the chaos across the U.S. political system.
lead_paragraph: Imagine if you were a foreign leader surveying the political chaos in the United States:

headline: ‘Fair Play’ Review: Risky Bonds
abstract: One couple can’t achieve work-life balance is in this impeccable debut feature from Chloe Domont.
lead_paragraph: “Fair Play” is a superbly malevolent erotic thriller about two ambitious financial analysts who drink too much, sleep too little and cannot afford to bring their feelings to work. The trouble is that Emily (Phoebe Dynevor) and Luke (Alden Ehrenreich) are secretly engaged — a tension aggravated when their boss, Campbell (an intimidating Eddie Marsan), promotes her over him. “I’m so happy for you,” Luke manages to croak. Emily believes him (briefly) but Chloe Domont, the writer and director of this impeccable debut feature, suspects this couple might not survive her cutting observations on money, gender and power. Domont doesn’t destroy their bliss with a sledgehammer; she uses a shiv. The agony that follows is a star-making performance for Dynevor and a star-correcting one for Ehrenreich who, in playing a nepotism hire confounded by his first brush with failure, reminds audiences why we’ve been rooting for the actor to succeed.

headline: ‘The Caine Mutiny Court-Martial’ Review: Righting the Ship
abstract: William Friedkin’s final film, an adaptation of the Herman Wouk play, offers a bracing demonstration of the director’s sensibility and craft.
lead_paragraph: For his final feature, William Friedkin, who died in August, has made a movie without a second of wasted time, down to his signature preference for an abrupt parting cut. The film, scripted by Friedkin himself, is the latest adaptation of a stage warhorse: Herman Wouk’s play “The Caine Mutiny Court-Martial,” the author’s dramatization of the trial portion of his Pulitzer Prize-winning novel, “The Caine Mutiny.” (The 1954 film version, featuring an unmatchable Humphrey Bogart as the unstable Lt. Cmdr. Queeg, used the whole book.)

headline: ‘Cat Person’ Review: A Viral Short Story Padded for the Big Screen
abstract: This screen adaptation trades the insidious discomfort of Kristen Roupenian’s story for heavy-handed metaphors and on-the-nose thrills.
lead_paragraph: Kristen Roupenian’s viral short story “Cat Person,” published in The New Yorker during the height of #MeToo, struck such a cultural nerve that some readers mistakenly referred to it as a nonfiction “article.”

headline: ‘Mister Organ’ Review: Antiques Sideshow
abstract: A documentarian’s investigation into peculiar events outside a New Zealand antiques shop turns into a horror story.
lead_paragraph: When the New Zealand journalist David Farrier began investigating a peculiar series of events happening in a car park outside an antiques store in a town he likens to the antipodean equivalent of Beverly Hills, he most likely had no idea he’d wind up being haunted for life. Farrier directed and co-stars in an account of those events that can rightly be called a documentary horror film. If its title, “Mister Organ,” initially strikes you as humorous, you won’t be laughing long.

headline: ‘Joan Baez I Am a Noise’ Review: Fountain of Nostalgia
abstract: A new documentary about the folk singer and activist Joan Baez contains a gold mine of archival materials.
lead_paragraph: In a letter to her parents, the singer Joan Baez describes the work of recalling repressed memories of being abused by her father as “the bone-shattering task of remembering.”

headline: ‘Foe’ Review: The Space Between
abstract: Saoirse Ronan and Paul Mescal play a farm couple with a less-than-idyllic marriage in the Midwest of the future.
lead_paragraph: Set in a future when devastation of the environment has humanity turning to outer space as a homestead, “Foe” presents a spectacle of futility. Not the climate change disaster itself, which is tangential to the plot, but the sight of great actors throwing themselves into this material, as if they were slogging through a Tennessee Williams marathon instead of the equivalent of a distended “Twilight Zone” episode with an aesthetic that might be described as “Dorothea Lange filter.”

headline: ‘My Love Affair With Marriage’ Review: A Tale of Love and Loss
abstract: This animated musical about a young woman’s sexual and romantic awakening uses a gloriously tactile aesthetic.
lead_paragraph: “You’re not a complete person without your soul mate,” croon three mythical birdlike women early in the coming-of-age musical “My Love Affair With Marriage.” The vocal trio — who fall somewhere between a Greek chorus and the “Macbeth” weird sisters — are among countless whimsical devices that elevate this beguiling animated feature, which traces the sexual and romantic awakening of a young woman in the Soviet Union.

headline: ‘More Than Ever’ Review: A Shared Melancholy
abstract: This middlebrow weepie about a woman dying from a rare lung disease stars Vicky Krieps and Gaspard Ulliel in his final role before his death in 2022.
lead_paragraph: Since her star-making turn in “Phantom Thread,” the Luxembourgish actress Vicky Krieps has found fertile work, particularly in European productions, playing women responding to tragedy, sometimes with recklessness or self-harm.

headline: ‘The Royal Hotel’ Review: Pulling Pints and Watching Their Backs
abstract: Two young women struggle to handle the obstreperous patrons of a remote Australian pub in this coolly calibrated thriller.
lead_paragraph: We are barely 12 minutes into Kitty Green’s “The Royal Hotel” before the first C-word is dropped, but it isn’t gratuitous. The film’s language, dominated by the braying of obnoxious, bellies-to-the-bar boozehounds, is both spice and thickening agent in its pervasive mood of clammy menace. Our reward for enduring this relentless churn of apprehension is not the one we anticipate.

headline: ‘Totally Killer’ Review: More Like Marty McDie
abstract: This teen slasher comedy with a time-traveling twist can’t muster up enough charisma to make its mash-up concept sing.
lead_paragraph: “Totally Killer,” a time-travel teen slasher comedy, is quick to acknowledge itself as a mash-up of two 20th-century cultural touchstones. “Have you seen the movie ‘Back to the Future?’” Jamie (Kiernan Shipka), the movie’s teenage protagonist, asks a pair of cops, before later making an allusion to “Scream,” Wes Craven’s spooky-season classic. The somewhat gimmicky genre combination may have had the potential to be a winning combo, but “Totally Killer,” directed by Nahnatchka Khan, struggles to muster up enough charisma to stick the landing.

headline: ‘She Came to Me’ Review: A Sea of Troubles (the Romantic Kind)
abstract: A love-triangle comedy from Rebecca Miller, starring Peter Dinklage, Marisa Tomei and Anne Hathaway, gets an emotional boost from an unexpected source.
lead_paragraph: There’s a scene in “She Came to Me,” the writer-director Rebecca Miller’s juggling act of a romantic comedy, that sounds like the setup of a joke: An opera composer and a tugboat skipper walk into a Brooklyn dive bar. The composer’s wife, a psychiatrist, is back at their brownstone. But for the blocked composer, Steven (Peter Dinklage), his wife, Patricia (Anne Hathaway), and his seafaring muse, Katrina (Marisa Tomei), what happens next is hardly a laughing matter.

headline: ‘When Evil Lurks’ Review: These Demons Are Fast and Furious
abstract: Humans become bloodthirsty demons in a shockingly grisly new contagion horror film from Argentina.
lead_paragraph: Evil strikes fast and mean in Demián Rugna’s punch-to-the-face new film.

headline: Two Cult Classics Restored and Brimming With Chaotic Life
abstract: Timothy Carey’s erratically brilliant “The World’s Greatest Sinner” and Emilio Fernández’s redemption melodrama “Victims of Sin” finally come to big screens.
lead_paragraph: “Why can’t I be a god?” wonders Clarence Hilliard, the insurance salesman turned aspiring dictator in “The World’s Greatest Sinner.” Like a grenade slowly rolling around a room, Timothy Carey’s erratically brilliant, thoroughly independent 1962 film tracks Clarence’s rise from family man to rock’n’roller to megalomaniac politician. Along with Emilio Fernández’s “Victims of Sin,” from 1951, it’s one of two outstanding, larger-than-life restorations that are receiving theatrical premieres this week.

headline: ‘Shadows in the City’ Review: A Sleazy Slice of 1980s No Wave
abstract: The director Ari M. Roussimoff’s black-and-white homage to the downtown crowd gets a raw screening at the Museum of Modern Art before its restoration.
lead_paragraph: The visual artist and performer Ari M. Roussimoff and his camera crew — including the cinematographer and director Ellen Kuras — crept about the lower depths of 1980s Manhattan, Brooklyn and Queens shooting an underground horror movie in 16-millimeter black-and-white film. The thing he assembled, “Shadows in the City” (1991), is an astonishing and often queasiness-inducing curio of No Wave cinema.

headline: Otobong Nkanga Wins the Nasher Prize for Sculpture
abstract: Her expansive sculptures that tackle the plundering of minerals and resources have earned her the $100,000 cash prize — one of the art world’s top honors.
lead_paragraph: The Nigerian-Belgian artist Otobong Nkanga makes unorthodox work addressing the global extraction of natural resources. She has sung to copper mines in Namibia and balanced potted plants on people’s heads in Switzerland. But now, her expansive view of sculpture is being recognized by one of the art world’s top honors: the Nasher Prize.

headline: ‘Dicks: The Musical’ Review: Hitting High Notes, Going Lowbrow
abstract: Larry Charles’s musical comedy is so hellbent on being outrageous that it just ends up being tiresome.
lead_paragraph: The funniest part of “Dicks: The Musical” sneaks in at the very end, when outtakes are interspersed with the credits. Nathan Lane, in particular, comes across as a living illustration of the words “game” and “trooper.” He and his co-star Megan Mullally, pros that they are, elegantly suggest hints of disbelief at just how they ended up in a movie in which his character spits pre-chewed cold cuts into the gaping maws of hideous puppet monsters and hers complains that her vagina has flown away (at one point it attaches itself to someone like the facehugger in “Alien”).

headline: More Rentals Are on the Market. Why Are They So Hard to Find?
abstract: This year’s peak rental season was tight in most U.S. regions, but overall, better than last year’s.
lead_paragraph: Last week in this space, we reported on the spate of new rental apartments that have landed on the U.S. market recently — more than 1.2 million over the past three years, mostly on the high end. But what has this meant for renters competing to find their next home? According to a new study by RentCafe, this year’s peak rental season (April through June) was in fact less competitive than last year’s, thanks in part to that increased inventory and to fewer prospective renters vying for each unit.

headline: New Details About FTX Emerge as Bankman-Fried’s Trial Begins
abstract: A report about when employees discovered a secret link between the crypto exchange and a sister trading firm raises questions as witnesses started testifying.
lead_paragraph: The first witnesses for the fraud trial of Sam Bankman-Fried, the founder of the fallen crypto exchange FTX,  began to testify on Wednesday, as prosecutors and defense lawyers squared off on whether the company failed because of fraud.

headline: A Giacometti for a Cezanne: Jeffrey Epstein’s Role in a Pricey Art Deal
abstract: Mr. Epstein helped the billionaire Leon Black defer capital gains taxes from the swap. A Senate committee is scrutinizing some of Mr. Black’s art deals as it looks into tax avoidance schemes.
lead_paragraph: In late 2016, when the private equity mogul Leon Black was trying to sell one expensive piece of art to buy another without incurring a hefty tax bill, he turned to the one man he knew who could help pull it off: his friend Jeffrey Epstein.

headline: What to Know About the Kaiser Permanente Strike
abstract: Roughly half of Californians with private insurance receive medical care through the Kaiser Permanente health care system.
lead_paragraph: Kaiser Permanente has an enormous footprint in California.

headline: Homes for Sale in New York and New Jersey
abstract: This week’s properties are a six-bedroom homes in Woodmere, N.Y., Tenafly, N.J.
lead_paragraph: A six-bedroom, three-and-a-half bath, 3,729-square-foot house built in 1926, with an entry foyer, a gas fireplace in the living room, an office, a family room, formal dining room and eat-in kitchen, a finished basement with laundry and storage, and a detached two-car garage, on 0.26 acres. Joey Frankel, Douglas Elliman Realty, 561-901-9232; elliman.com

headline: Homes for Sale in Manhattan and the Bronx
abstract: This week’s properties are in Morningside Heights, the Upper East Side and on the Grand Concourse.
lead_paragraph: A two-bedroom, two-bath, roughly 1,500-square-foot apartment with a windowed kitchen, a living room with built-in bookshelves, a bedroom with mahogany pocket doors and built-in bar cabinet, a smaller room that could be used as a third bedroom, windowed bathrooms, window-unit air-conditioning and ample closets, on the top floor of a six-story 1906 doorman building with a live-in super, storage units, a bike room and shared laundry. Jeffrey Stockwell, Ben Haymes and Dominique Ramirez, Brown Harris Stevens, 917-449-3433; bhsusa.com

headline: A Mordant Glimpse at the Austrian Aristocracy
abstract: Plus: bracelets with spell-casting instructions, a Caribbean resort — and more recommendations from T Magazine.
lead_paragraph: The name Hemlock Neversink might conjure a wooded fairyland, and that idea isn’t too far from the truth. The 34-room all-inclusive hotel, opening Oct. 13, is set on 230 tree-filled acres in New York’s Catskills region. Activities include guided bird-watching and pine-needle weaving, but the core purpose of the property is to serve as a wellness retreat. Guests will be offered a survey with questions such as “How structured do you like your days?” and “Would you like to move or rest?” The answers are meant to inform a daily itinerary created by the Hemlock team, which might include animal therapy with an on-site herd of goats or a morning cardio dance class. At the spa, nature-inspired treatments such as the Neversink Ice and Stone Ritual, which involves an herb-infused cold water bath, a hot steam shower and a hot river-stone massage, are available for an added charge. The property’s design draws from the region’s Quaker heritage, with a neutral color palette, ash and walnut furniture and quilt-inspired custom wool rugs by Manhattan’s Crosby Street Studios. The husband-and-wife owners, Sims and Kirsten Foster, who were recently nominated for a James Beard Award for Outstanding Restaurateur for their other Catskills hotels (including the DeBruce and Kenoza Hall), conceived of another inviting dining space for Hemlock Neversink: Bittersweet, which has two fireplaces, will focus on seasonal and locally sourced dishes. From $399 a night, hemlockneversink.com.

headline: Turnover of Election Officials in Swing States Adds Strain for 2024, Report Says
abstract: The Voting Rights Lab said a wave of departures in Arizona, Pennsylvania and other battleground states could create uncertainty in the presidential election.
lead_paragraph: A tide of resignations and retirements by election officials in battleground states, who have increasingly faced threats, harassment and interference, could further strain the election system in 2024, a national voting rights group warned in a report released on Thursday.

headline: Where to start? A guide to Fosse’s work.
abstract: His writing is spare and existential, often focusing on the interior lives of rather solitary characters.
lead_paragraph: Throughout a decades-long career, the playwright and author Jon Fosse has inspired comparisons to Henrik Ibsen, Samuel Beckett and even George Harrison from the Beatles.

headline: Major China Art Auction Fails to Draw Big Bids
abstract: A portrait by Amedeo Modigliani sold for less than expected and several artworks went unsold as China’s best-known art investor liquidated part of his collection.
lead_paragraph: The largest auction ever held by Sotheby’s in Asia of a single owner’s art collection raised less money than expected on Thursday, a sign that rising global interest rates may be starting to weigh on the market for fine art.

headline: George Santos’s Treasurer Pleads Guilty in Federal Inquiry
abstract: Nancy Marks, one of the embattled congressman’s closest associates, oversaw the campaign finances that have faced widespread scrutiny.
lead_paragraph: The treasurer who oversaw the finances of Representative George Santos’s political campaigns surrendered to federal prosecutors on Thursday afternoon and admitted to her role in fraudulently reporting a fictional $500,000 loan that Mr. Santos claimed to have made to his campaign.

headline: Women Could Fill Truck Driver Jobs. Companies Won’t Let Them.
abstract: Three women filed a discrimination complaint against a trucking company over its same-sex training policy, which they say prevented them from being hired.
lead_paragraph: The trucking industry has complained for years that there is a dire shortage of workers willing to drive big rigs. But some women say many trucking companies have made it effectively impossible for them to get those jobs.

headline: What Does It Really Mean to Dissociate?
abstract: People are turning to social media to define dissociative disorders, but those portrayals aren’t always accurate. Here is a primer.
lead_paragraph: Have you ever zoned out?

headline: Quick Noodle Soup for a Long Day
abstract: And green shakshuka with avocado and lime, chickpeas escabeche and actually flavorful baked chicken breasts.
lead_paragraph: Noodles are fun and soup is soothing, which makes this somen noodle soup with bok choy and mushrooms from Sue Li delightful and comforting. Sue creates a gently seasoned broth out of soy sauce, dehydrated shiitakes and sesame oil, but feel free to gussy it up however you like. In the recipe notes, readers share that they’ve used vegetable and chicken broth, have added a couple of teaspoons of miso and have swirled in chile crisp. And if you don’t have somen noodles on hand, any thin wheat or rice noodle will do. So to amend a previous statement: This dinner is delightful and comforting — and versatile.

headline: What’s Going On in This Graph? | ‘Spelling Bee’
abstract: Could you have found the easiest words in the New York Times puzzle “Spelling Bee”? How about the hardest words?
lead_paragraph: Note: Comments are open for student responses. A live moderated discussion of this graph will take place on Oct. 18.

headline: Wildlife Find Human Voices Scarier Than Lion Roars, Researchers Say
abstract: A new study observed the reactions of various wild animals in response to human voices, lion snarls and other noises in South Africa’s Kruger National Park.
lead_paragraph: A new study observed the reactions of various wild animals in response to human voices, lion snarls and other noises in South Africa’s Kruger National Park.

headline: Watch How Animals React to the Scariest Sound on the Savanna
abstract: When confronted with recordings of human voices, 19 species fled instantly, while they were less frightened by lion sounds and other potentially threatening recordings.
lead_paragraph: Panting after chasing the impala now in its jaws, a leopard drags its prey to a shady spot beside a water hole. Before it can sit down to feast, a voice, seemingly out of nowhere, begins speaking calmly. “It is very difficult to talk in Afrikaans …,” begins the bodiless voice. The leopard pauses, glances toward the source of the sound and then drops its hard-earned quarry and runs.

headline: Trump Asks Again to Delay Documents Trial Until After Election
abstract: The former president’s lawyers said his trial on charges of mishandling classified information should be delayed from its planned start in May because of problems gaining access to all the evidence.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for former President Donald J. Trump have again asked a federal judge to postpone until after the 2024 election his trial on charges of mishandling classified documents.

headline: Rescuers Search Through Rubble Following Deadly Russian Strike
abstract: Video released by the Ukrainian government and verified by The New York Times shows the aftermath of a deadly attack on a store in Hroza, Ukraine, that killed more than 50 people.
lead_paragraph: Video released by the Ukrainian government and verified by The New York Times shows the aftermath of a deadly attack on a store in Hroza, Ukraine, that killed more than 50 people.

headline: The Upside of a Population Decline
abstract: Readers disagree with an essay expressing concern about a decline after a peak. Also: Rudy Giuliani’s drinking; book bans; masks in hospitals; wedding magic.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Uganda’s Top Opposition Leader Says He Is Under House Arrest
abstract: The police denied that they had arrested Bobi Wine, a challenger to Uganda’s autocratic president, saying they “escorted” him from an airport to his home.
lead_paragraph: Uganda’s top opposition leader said on Thursday that he was seized at the airport and put under house arrest following his return from abroad, a claim the authorities denied despite a history of crackdowns by the East African nation’s autocratic leader against his top challenger.

headline: Once a Ticket to Travel and to Socialize, Paper Covid-19 Cards Are Going Away
abstract: The C.D.C. has stopped distributing the 3-by-4-inch cards, a mainstay of American wallets in the earlier days of the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: The paper Covid vaccination cards were, for a time, a mainstay of American wallets — pulled out before bouncers, inspected at airport desks and shared with pride on social media accounts.

headline: Remnants of Philippe Expected to Bring Strong Winds and Heavy Rains to Maine
abstract: A flood watch was in effect on Saturday for parts of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, just a week after New York City experienced heavy flooding.
lead_paragraph: After drenching Bermuda, parts of the Virgin Islands and Puerto Rico this week, the remnants of former tropical storm Philippe are expected to bring heavy rain and gusty winds to parts of New England, particularly Maine, into early Sunday morning, forecasters said.

headline: Cornel West, Dropping Green Party, Will Run as an Independent
abstract: The left-wing scholar and writer has sought and then abandoned two third-party nominations since announcing his presidential campaign in June.
lead_paragraph: Cornel West, the left-wing academic and third-party presidential candidate, said on Thursday that he would not seek the Green Party’s nomination for president, running instead as an independent.

headline: U.S. Will Build Stretch of Border Wall and Begin Deportations to Venezuela
abstract: The decisions underscore the challenges facing the Biden administration as humanitarian crises around the world drive more migrants to the U.S. border.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration on Thursday said it would expand former President Donald Trump’s wall on the Mexican border and begin deporting thousands of Venezuelans in an effort to cut down on the migrant surge that shows no signs of abating.

headline: The Remaking of The Wall Street Journal
abstract: Emma Tucker, the top editor, is moving away from some of the organization’s traditions.
lead_paragraph: Last month, Emma Tucker, the new editor in chief of The Wall Street Journal, gathered the newsroom to share a blunt message: The media industry had morphed “beyond recognition” and The Journal needed to adapt, or be left behind.

headline: Film Club: ‘Oasis’
abstract: How does coming-of-age test the bonds between twin brothers?
lead_paragraph: Note: Our next Film Club will publish on Thursday, Oct. 19.

headline: An Experimental Label’s Music Is Now Streaming. Here’s Where to Start.
abstract: Listen to 15 streaming highlights from the vast catalog of Tzadik, the imprint founded by John Zorn.
lead_paragraph: John Zorn started the Tzadik label with Kazunori Sugiyama in 1995. Since then, this imprint has amassed a vast catalog of experimental music from the worlds of classical, jazz, rock and beyond.

headline: Visa Applicants’ Social Media Data Doesn’t Help Screen for Terrorism, Documents Show
abstract: A Trump-era practice of vetting the social media profiles of visitors has provided scant value, intelligence officials concluded. But the Biden administration has kept the policy in place.
lead_paragraph: A disputed rule that forces millions of applicants for a visa to enter the United States to disclose their social media profiles to the government has done little to help screen for possible terrorists, newly disclosed documents show.

headline: How the Big Chip Makers Are Pushing Back on Biden’s China Agenda
abstract: Nvidia, Intel and Qualcomm are campaigning to protect their businesses before further crackdowns on the sale of semiconductor technology to Beijing.
lead_paragraph: A year after the Biden administration took its first major step toward restricting the sale of semiconductors to China, it has begun drafting additional limits aimed at denying Beijing the technology critical to modern-day weapons.

headline: Suspect Charged in Fatal Stabbing of Advocate in Brooklyn
abstract: The early morning killing this week of Ryan Carson, a public policy activist, appeared to be a random attack that led to an outpouring of grief.
lead_paragraph: A man was arrested and charged with murder on Thursday in connection with the fatal stabbing earlier this week of an activist in Brooklyn, the New York City Police Department said.

headline: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to HBO, Hulu, Apple TV+ and More in October
abstract: Here’s the best of what’s coming to Amazon, Max, Apple TV+ and others.
lead_paragraph: Every month, streaming services add movies and TV shows to its library. Here are our picks for some of October’s most promising new titles. (Note: Streaming services occasionally change schedules without giving notice. For more recommendations on what to stream, sign up for our Watching newsletter here.)

headline: Alabama Is Ordered to Use Map With Two Districts That Empower Black Voters
abstract: The new district map is a remedy to Alabama’s illegal dilution of Black voting power, and may lead to the election of two Black representatives for the first time in the state’s history.
lead_paragraph: A federal court ordered Alabama on Thursday to use a new congressional map that could lead the state to elect two Black representatives for the first time in its history, by creating a second district with close to a majority of Black voters.

headline: Three Sauces to Make With Tahini
abstract: They’re made to slather on sweet potatoes, coat chewy noodles and dress all number of salads.
lead_paragraph: One of the many things I adore about my friends is that we will text each other, apropos of nothing and with zero pleasantries, about what we’re eating at any moment.

headline: Why Trump and the Rest of the G.O.P. Won’t Stop Bashing Electric Vehicles
abstract: The industry’s transition to battery power is already underway. Republican presidential candidates are pushing to reverse course.
lead_paragraph: Fresh off a walking tour of blighted Flint, Mich., on Wednesday, Vivek Ramaswamy spoke excitedly about a comeback for the “forgotten America” that he has made a part of his long-shot bid for the presidency.

headline: Robert Glasper Leans Into the Drama
abstract: Mounting his fifth annual residency at the Blue Note (after a viral beef at the Grammys), the pianist, producer and composer is hungry for a challenge.
lead_paragraph: In February, on the night of this year’s Grammy Awards, the pianist, producer and composer Robert Glasper was enjoying himself in the audience at the Microsoft Theater when he realized he didn’t have his phone. He had given it to his assistant earlier in the evening, before taking the stage to accept the award for best R&B album — his second win in that category and fifth career Grammy.

headline: Man Who Plotted to Kill Queen Elizabeth With Crossbow Gets 9 Years
abstract: Jaswant Singh Chail, 21, was convicted of treason. His intrusion on the grounds of Windsor Castle on Christmas morning 2021 was foiled by the police.
lead_paragraph: When two police officers confronted Jaswant Singh Chail on the grounds of Windsor Castle on Christmas morning in 2021, he was clad in black, wearing a metal face-mask and wielding a crossbow. “I am here to kill the queen,” he told them.

headline: Armed Man Seeking Wisconsin Governor Posts Bail and Returns With Rifle
abstract: The man was taken into custody inside the State Capitol on Wednesday after asking to see Gov. Tony Evers, the authorities said. He posted bail and returned hours later with a rifle.
lead_paragraph: A man who was looking for Gov. Tony Evers of Wisconsin was arrested with a handgun inside the State Capitol in Madison on Wednesday, posted bail and then returned with an “AK-47-style” rifle and was arrested again, a state spokeswoman said.

headline: Putin Claims Russia Successfully Tested a Nuclear-Powered Missile.
abstract: “No one in their sound mind will use a nuclear weapon against Russia,” the Russian president said. The test could not be independently verified.
lead_paragraph: President Vladimir V. Putin claimed on Thursday that Russia had successfully tested the Burevestnik, an experimental nuclear-powered cruise missile, and had almost completed work on a new type of nuclear-capable ballistic missile.

headline: Solo Plays This Fall: Patrick Page, Isabelle Adjani and More
abstract: For theatergoers who love uncrowded stages, the coming months bring a range of works, from musical comedies to Shakespearean dramas.
lead_paragraph: Solo shows have been around as long as there has been theater — longer, actually, if we count storytelling by a campfire. There is an elemental intimacy about the format and, let’s face it, an economic appeal at a time of belt-tightening.

headline: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: I know, I know, today is Nobel Day in the literary world, so I won’t be the one to tear you away from Jon Fosse’s haunting Scandinavian struggles with art and mortality. But once you’ve finished the final volumes of his “Septology” (published last year in the United States, and a finalist for the 2022 National Book Award in translation), why not kick back and cleanse your mental palate with a book about the ultimate unknowability of the nature of reality?

headline: We Should Have Known So Much About Covid From the Start
abstract: The immunologist Michael Mina says even its worst aspects should have been expected from a new pathogen for which there was no immunity.
lead_paragraph: America has begun to treat Covid-19 like just any other disease — boosters are now arriving on an annual fall cycle, on the flu model, with large portions of the country not bothering with them, also on the flu model.

headline: New Evidence That Ancient Footprints Push Back Human Arrival in North America
abstract: Following up a on study in 2021 of tracks found in New Mexico, researchers used more methods to bolster the claim that the tracks are up to 23,000 years old.
lead_paragraph: Hidden within the seemingly barren expanse of White Sands National Park in New Mexico are human footprints. But these impressions are much more than random tracks: They are ancient vignettes cast in gypsum-rich sand. The footprints tell stories of hunters stalking a giant sloth; a traveler slipping in mud with a child on one hip; children jumping in puddles, splashing in play; and more.

headline: As Egypt’s Presidential Vote Nears, Dissent Flickers Around el-Sisi
abstract: Voters will choose a leader in December. It will probably be President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, though with the economy in dire straits, protests are gaining momentum.
lead_paragraph: Songs in praise of Egypt’s military were blaring and banners emblazoned with President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi’s face were waving when a poet took the stage at a government-sponsored rally this week in Marsa Matrouh, a city on Egypt’s Mediterranean coast.

headline: A Concert, an Ancient Arrow and a Mysterious Library: Creative Writing By Teens
abstract: Some favorite student responses to four recent Picture Prompts.
lead_paragraph: Every week as a part of our writing prompts, we publish four short, accessible, image-driven Picture Prompts that invite students to do a variety of kinds of writing. Each week, at least one of those prompts asks students to use their imaginations to write the opening of a short story or poem inspired by an image — or, to tell us about a memory from their own lives that it makes them think of.

headline: Elon Musk Says SpaceX Could Land on Mars in 3 to 4 Years
abstract: The prediction is the latest in a series of ambitious timelines for reaching the red planet that the entrepreneur has previously failed to meet.
lead_paragraph: Elon Musk, the founder of SpaceX, said the company could land a spacecraft on Mars three to four years from now.

headline: Jon Fosse, Norwegian Author, Receives the Nobel Prize in Literature
abstract: Long a favorite to receive the award, Fosse has found acclaim for work that explores mortality and religion, and radiates serenity.
lead_paragraph: The Norwegian novelist, poet and playwright Jon Fosse — who has found a growing audience in the English-speaking world for novels that grapple with themes of aging, mortality, love and art — was awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature on Thursday, “for his innovative plays and prose which give voice to the unsayable.”

headline: Higher Rates Stoke a Growing Chorus of Deficit Concerns
abstract: A long period of higher interest rates would make the government’s large debt pile costly, a possibility that is fueling a conversation about debt sustainability.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. government’s persistent budget deficit and growing debts were low on Wall Street’s list of worries when interest rates were at rock bottom for years. But borrowing costs have risen so sharply that it is causing many investors and economists to fret that the United States’ big debt pile could prove less sustainable.

headline: ‘Too Young for Me!’: A Senior Center Watches ‘The Golden Bachelor’
abstract: The commentary was sharp and the drinks were virgin at a watch party for the new dating show featuring singles between 60 and 75.
lead_paragraph: After Zumba class wrapped up at the Oakland Senior Center on Friday, regulars gathered around a projector screen with mocktails and plates piled with cheese and crackers to watch the premiere of “The Golden Bachelor,” the reality franchise’s latest spin on its dating show formula.

headline: A Grown-Up Slumber Party at an English Country Hotel
abstract: To mark the opening of her latest hospitality project, Estelle Manor, Eiesha Bharti Pasricha hosted a celebration of female friendship and ingenuity.
lead_paragraph: For Eiesha Bharti Pasricha, the artistic director of the London members’ club Maison Estelle, entertaining is sacrosanct. Growing up in an Indian family in New Delhi — her father is the businessman Sunil Bharti Mittal — she understood early on that hospitality was not just a nicety but a cultural value to be upheld. “Hosting is the way we express our care,” says Bharti Pasricha, 39, who is known among her friends for organizing frequent dinners at her home in London’s Notting Hill neighborhood. “My grandmother always used to say, ‘Your guest is God.’”

headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
abstract: Our TV critic recommends an international smorgasbord, with great shows from Sweden, Austria and France.
lead_paragraph: ‘Love & Anarchy’When to watch: Now, on Netflix.

headline: ‘Colette and Justin’ Review: The Colonized Speak Up
abstract: In a new documentary, a filmmaker turns his lens on his grandparents during a pivotal moment in the history of the Democratic Republic of Congo.
lead_paragraph: In “Colette and Justin,” directed by Alain Kassanda, the French-Congolese filmmaker uncovers a tangled and pivotal era in Congolese history and the central role his grandfather had in the country’s path toward independence in 1960.

headline: How Do You Fight Bird Flu in France? Vaccinate 64 Million Ducks.
abstract: The inoculations are aimed at curbing the spread of a lethal strain of bird flu, and to support foie gras, a cherished delicacy.
lead_paragraph: To protect its flocks and its foie gras from the ravages of bird flu, France has begun a mass vaccination of 64 million ducks.

headline: How Will ‘Loki’ Handle the Multiverse? Its Writer Talks Season 2.
abstract: Eric Martin discusses the second installment of the Disney+ series starring Tom Hiddleston as the God of Mischief.
lead_paragraph: Loki has worn many hats since his initial appearance in the Marvel Cinematic Universe in 2011.

headline: Floorboards (Possibly) Trodden by Shakespeare Are Found in England
abstract: Boards dating to the 15th century were found during renovations at St. George’s Guildhall. However, some Shakespeare experts are not certain the playwright touched them.
lead_paragraph: How important is the wooden stage on which William Shakespeare might have played?

headline: The Pope’s Warning to a Warming World
abstract: Naming and shaming the countries and industries he sees as bad actors.
lead_paragraph: In 2015, Pope Francis offered a sprawling meditation on man’s place on Earth and the spiritual implications of human-caused global warming. Eight years later, he appears to have little patience for such ruminations.

headline: Joe Christopher, an Original Met Who Was Amazin’ in ’64, Dies at 88
abstract: He hit .300 in the expansion franchise’s third season, a rarity for a team better known for finishing in last place than for great on-field achievements.
lead_paragraph: Joe Christopher, an original New York Met who achieved an unusual feat of competence in that often-bumbling, last-place franchise’s third season when he batted .300 in 1964, died on Tuesday in Edgewood, Md. He was 88.

headline: In Kevin McCarthy’s Hometown, Reflections on His Sudden Fall
abstract: Bakersfield, Calif., became more diverse and culturally expansive while the former House speaker was increasingly caught up in Washington’s barbed politics.
lead_paragraph: Outside Dagny’s Coffee Company, a downtown cafe that serves as a kind of crossroads for a broad swath of Bakersfield, Katherine Haas, 38, was trying to make sense of Kevin McCarthy’s stunning ouster as House speaker this week.

headline: Trump Seeks Dismissal of Federal Election Case, Claiming Immunity
abstract: Donald Trump’s lawyers asked a judge to throw out charges that he conspired to overturn the 2020 election, arguing that a president could not be criminally prosecuted for official acts.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for former President Donald J. Trump asked a judge on Thursday to throw out a federal indictment accusing him of conspiring to overturn the 2020 election and claimed that because the charges relate to actions he took as president, he should be “absolutely immune from prosecution.”

headline: Mexico-U.S. Ties: What to Know About Migration, Fentanyl and Guns
abstract: Tensions over soaring migration, overdose deaths and the role of U.S. guns in cartel violence have strained relations.
lead_paragraph: Relations between the United States and Mexico are at a critical juncture, as top Biden administration officials press Mexico’s government to do more to blunt soaring migration and to confront drug cartels producing fentanyl, a synthetic opioid that has unleashed a staggering overdose crisis.

headline: Putin Suggests New Narrative for Prigozhin Plane Crash: Cocaine and Grenades
abstract: The Russian president said grenade fragments were found in the bodies recovered from the crash site after the Wagner mercenary leader’s plane went down in August.
lead_paragraph: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia claimed on Thursday that the warlord Yevgeny V. Prigozhin and his associates may have brought down their private jet with hand grenades while possibly under the influence of cocaine — a new narrative from the Kremlin about the August plane crash widely seen as an assassination carried out by the Russian government.

headline: How MAGA Corrupts the Culture of the White Working Class
abstract: Republican elites are delivering the worst kind of red meat to their working-class base.
lead_paragraph: I’m not exactly optimistic about human nature. Yes, I certainly believe that human beings are capable of great good, but consider me in agreement with the Christian apologist G.K. Chesterton, who wrote that the doctrine of original sin was “the only part of Christian theology which can really be proved.” Or, to quote a more modern pair of thinkers, the Indigo Girls, “Darkness has a hunger that’s insatiable. And lightness has a call that’s hard to hear.”

headline: Five Japanese Cocktail Bars With Fantastic Food
abstract: Come for the whiskey highball, stay for the fried freshwater crabs and delightful oden.
lead_paragraph: Some of my favorite Japanese restaurants are bars. Of course, there are the izakayas scattered around the city, where eating and drinking are as inseparable as sushi and rice. But there are also bars that happen to have excellent food even though they are best known for their beverages (cocktails and highballs, most often, but also whiskey, shochu and sake). Fortunately, they seem to be proliferating. These are a few of my favorites.

headline: George Tyndall, U.S.C. Gynecologist Accused of Sex Abuse, Found Dead
abstract: He had been accused by hundreds of patients and was expected to face a criminal trial next year.
lead_paragraph: George Tyndall, the former University of Southern California gynecologist accused of sexually abusing hundreds of patients dating as far back as the 1990s, was found dead at his home in Los Angeles on Wednesday, his lawyer said.

headline: Opposition to Ukraine Aid Becomes a Litmus Test for the Right
abstract: The drama that has played out among House Republicans over the past week has highlighted a sharp decline in the party’s willingness to back continued aid for Kyiv’s fight against Russia.
lead_paragraph: The Republican meltdown on Capitol Hill that toppled the speaker this week and left the House in chaos has also highlighted a sharp decline in G.O.P. support for continuing to send aid to Ukraine, and how opposition to helping Kyiv has become a litmus test for the right.

headline: Drone Attack at Military Graduation in Syria Kills at Least 80, Government Says
abstract: Retaliatory shelling by Syrian government forces against towns in the northwest killed at least eight people, according to a rights group.
lead_paragraph: At least 80 people were killed in central Syria on Thursday by drones carrying explosive ammunition targeting the graduation ceremony for cadets of a military academy, according to Syrian state media.

headline: Jon Fosse’s Books Seek and Find the Divine
abstract: The Nobel Prize winner writes about characters trying to transcend their worldly lives.
lead_paragraph: At a dinner party this winter in Toronto, when a table-wide silence descended, I tried to fill it by asking what everyone was reading. A colleague snorted and pointed out that any time people ask that question, what they’re really doing is waiting to announce what they are reading. I was offended because she was right.

headline: House Democrat Asks if Mar-a-Lago Can Be Taxed at Value Trump Gave It
abstract: The former president’s valuation of his residence and private club is part of New York’s civil fraud case against him.
lead_paragraph: Attempting to call former President Donald J. Trump’s bluff, a congressman from Florida on Thursday asked Palm Beach County to tax Mar-a-Lago, Mr. Trump’s seaside residence and private club, at the value he claimed it was worth, more than $1 billion.

headline: Monitor Condemns Rikers Violence as 9th Person Dies in Custody This Year
abstract: A scathing report about the troubled Rikers Island jail complex and another death there come as New York City faces the prospect of losing power over its jails.
lead_paragraph: A detainee died early Thursday at the Rikers Island jail complex, hours before the federal official appointed to monitor Rikers issued his latest scathing report about the dangerous dysfunction that persists there. The death, of a 27-year-old man awaiting trial on robbery charges, was the ninth in New York City custody this year.

headline: Biden Watches Republican Dysfunction From a Distance
abstract: President Biden has chosen not to weigh in forcefully on the Republican meltdown in the House, instead trying to contrast his own achievements with the chaos of his rivals.
lead_paragraph: Just a week ago, President Biden vowed never to “hide from history” as he tries to defend American democracy, arguing in a major address that the best way to challenge extremist elements in the Republican Party is to “make clear where we stand.”

headline: Listen: Dating After 60, San Francisco Is OK, Mother’s Cartel Hunt, ‘Modern Love’
abstract: Each week, we share the best of new audio journalism and storytelling.
lead_paragraph: Audiophiles,

headline: U.S. to Begin Deporting Venezuelans in Effort to Cut Down Border Numbers
abstract: The measure is the latest attempt by the Biden administration to try to reduce unlawful crossings at the southern border.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration will start deporting Venezuelans who crossed into the country illegally, officials said Thursday, in its latest attempt to stem the pace of migrants fleeing the humanitarian crisis in that country.

headline: S.E.C. Sues Elon Musk to Compel Him to Testify on Twitter Purchase
abstract: The agency said Mr. Musk was subpoenaed to testify last month about his purchases of Twitter’s stock last year, but he failed to appear.
lead_paragraph: The Securities and Exchange Commission sued Elon Musk on Thursday to force him to testify about his accumulation of shares in Twitter, which the tech billionaire bought last year and has since renamed X.

headline: Gathering to Mourn the Dead, and Dying Themselves in an Explosion in Ukraine
abstract: Ukrainian officials said a Russian strike had killed at least 51 people in a tiny village with no obvious military or industrial targets nearby.
lead_paragraph: They came to mourn the dead, but in a split second of thunder and flying debris, more than 50 people who had gathered for a wake were themselves killed on Thursday when a giant explosion tore through a shop in a tiny Ukrainian village.

headline: Friday Briefing: Strike Kills 51 in Ukrainian Village
abstract: Plus the Nobel in literature.
lead_paragraph: At least 51 people were killed yesterday when a rocket hit a group of people gathered for a wake in the village of Hroza in northeastern Ukraine, Ukrainian officials said.

headline: Russell Sherman, Poetic Interpreter at the Piano, Is Dead at 93
abstract: He was a passionate, idiosyncratic performer of the classical canon in concerts and on recordings and admired as an educator.
lead_paragraph: Russell Sherman, a pianist admired for his poetic and idiosyncratic interpretations of Schoenberg, Beethoven, Debussy, Liszt and others, died on Sept. 30 at his home in Lexington, Mass. A longtime music educator as well, he was 93.

headline: North Carolina Radio Station Won’t Ban Met Opera Broadcasts After All
abstract: The station, which had called the Met’s newer operas unsuitable because of their “difficult music” and “adult themes and harsh language,” reversed course.
lead_paragraph: The music director of a nonprofit North Carolina classical radio station said on Thursday that the station would reverse course and air several contemporary operas being performed by the Metropolitan Opera this season that the station had originally said were unsuitable for broadcast, citing their “adult themes and harsh language.”

headline: A Glass of Wine and a Binder of Bills: How Feinstein Paved the Way for Women
abstract: As they remembered Dianne Feinstein, Vice President Kamala Harris and Senator Chuck Schumer hailed her efforts to support other women in power.
lead_paragraph: After Kamala Harris was sworn in as the junior senator from California in 2017, Senator Dianne Feinstein pulled her into a private hideaway off the Senate floor.

headline: Trump Endorses Jim Jordan in Race for House Speaker
abstract: Representatives Jim Jordan and Steve Scalise sought support from members of the fractured Republican Party, and then former President Donald J. Trump weighed in.
lead_paragraph: The two leading candidates to become the next Republican speaker of the House worked the phones and the halls of the Capitol on Thursday, vying for support from within their party’s fractured ranks as the chamber remained in a state of paralysis after the ouster of Representative Kevin McCarthy of California.

headline: Biden Is Expanding the Border Wall
abstract: Also, the Nobel Prize in Literature. Here’s the latest at the end of Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Confronted with a surge of migrants, the Biden administration has decided to waive more than 20 federal laws and regulations, including environmental ones, to build barriers along the U.S.-Mexico border. The move is a remarkable reversal for a president who campaigned vociferously against a wall and halted its construction on his first day in office.

headline: American Jet Shoots Down Turkish Drone in Syria
abstract: The Pentagon said the drone had been observed carrying out airstrikes shortly before flying within about 550 yards of U.S. forces.
lead_paragraph: An American F-16 fighter jet shot down a Turkish military drone on Thursday that entered a restricted zone in northeastern Syria and came within about 550 yards of U.S. ground forces, according to Pentagon officials.

headline: Did Feinstein’s Decision to Serve Until the End Damage Her Legacy?
abstract: The senator faced calls to step down as her health declined, amid concerns about the effectiveness of an aging Senate.
lead_paragraph: Over more than a half-century of public life, Senator Dianne Feinstein’s accomplishments rivaled those of anyone in the national arena: The 1994 assault weapons ban. The Senate Intelligence Committee’s report on the use of torture. Her trailblazing example as a woman in an overwhelmingly male-dominated political landscape.

headline: If Moderate Republicans Were Brave, They Could Save the House
abstract: By cooperating with Democrats, they could elect one of their own as speaker.
lead_paragraph: This article has been updated to reflect news developments.

headline: Trump Said to Have Revealed Nuclear Submarine Secrets to Australian Businessman
abstract: Soon after leaving office, the former president shared sensitive information about American submarines with a billionaire member of Mar-a-Lago, according to people familiar with the matter.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after he left office, former President Donald J. Trump shared apparently classified information about American nuclear submarines with an Australian businessman during an evening of conversation at Mar-a-Lago, his private club and residence in Florida, according to two people familiar with the matter.

headline: Will Voters Send In the Clowns?
abstract: Why would they think that a party that can’t manage itself can manage the economy?
lead_paragraph: I’m not a historian, but as far as I know, America has never seen anything like the current political craziness. There have been bitter disputes within Congress — in 1856, Charles Sumner, an abolitionist senator, was attacked and severely injured by a pro-slavery representative. But these were conflicts between parties, and slavery was nothing if not a substantive issue.

headline: Dick Butkus, Fearsome Hall of Fame Linebacker, Is Dead at 80
abstract: He was both hard hitting against the run and fleet-footed in foiling pass plays in his eight seasons with the Chicago Bears. He later took up acting.
lead_paragraph: Dick Butkus, the Chicago Bears’ famously hard-hitting Hall of Fame middle linebacker of the 1960s and ’70s and a selection for the N.F.L.’s 100th anniversary all-time team, died on Thursday at his home in Malibu, Calif. He was 80.

headline: Flying on the Same Plane, Lake and Gallego Clash Over Border Politics
abstract: The confrontation happened just days after Kari Lake filed to run for the seat, which is now held by Kyrsten Sinema.
lead_paragraph: Arizona’s high-profile Senate race has not yet begun in earnest, but on Thursday, the Republican Kari Lake and Representative Ruben Gallego, a Democrat, were already trading barbs — in midair.

headline: Granddaughter Recalls Dianne Feinstein’s ‘Unwavering Support’
abstract: The pioneering senator supported many women who followed in her footsteps, including her granddaughter, who now works for the city that Ms. Feinstein once led.
lead_paragraph: The president and vice president of the United States. Democratic leaders of the House and the Senate. Her boss, the mayor of San Francisco.

headline: Britain’s Labour Scores Decisive Victory in Parliamentary Election in Scotland
abstract: The opposition party took back a parliamentary seat in a win that observers said showed a path to power in next year’s general election.
lead_paragraph: Britain’s opposition Labour Party won back a parliamentary seat in Scotland on Friday by a thumping margin, after a closely watched race that had been viewed as a barometer of the party’s national appeal before a general election next year.

headline: Cut Out
abstract: Zhouqin Burnikel and Tom Pepper open our solving weekend.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues

headline: Variety: Acrostic
abstract: David Balton and Jane Stewart’s puzzle takes us on a challenging ramble.
lead_paragraph: ACROSTIC — Today’s passage concerns a  feel-good topic, I hope! It comes from a 2021 book called “From Rails to Trails,” by Peter Harnik, who co-founded the Rails-to-Trails Conservancy in the 1980s and has been a critical force in converting at least 20,000 miles of unused railroad tracks into recreation paths nationwide. You can now get from New York City to Canada on a bicycle, and even on foot (or, if that’s overwhelming, you can amble from the Whitney Museum of American Art to Hudson Yards on the High Line). This major revitalization effort has many benefits for people who use the paths for exercise, but rail trails also boost local economies and create passageways for wildlife.

headline: Trump Drops Lawsuit Against Michael Cohen, His Former Fixer
abstract: The suit had been seen as an effort to silence Mr. Cohen, who is scheduled to testify against Mr. Trump in the civil fraud case brought by New York’s attorney general.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump on Thursday dropped a lawsuit he had filed against his former fixer, Michael D. Cohen, abandoning what has been seen as an effort to silence Mr. Cohen, who has become one of the former president’s loudest critics.

headline: Trump Escalates Anti-Immigrant Rhetoric With ‘Poisoning the Blood’ Comment
abstract: When asked about immigration in a recent interview, the former president used language with echoes of white supremacy and Hitler.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump said undocumented immigrants were “poisoning the blood of our country” in a recent interview, language with echoes of white supremacy and the racial hatreds of Adolf Hitler.

headline: I.R.S. Puts Lien on Giuliani’s Palm Beach Condo for $550,000 Tax Debt
abstract: The action by federal tax officials is the latest sign of Rudolph W. Giuliani’s growing financial troubles.
lead_paragraph: The I.R.S. has placed a lien on a Florida property owned by Rudolph W. Giuliani, the former New York City mayor and lawyer for Donald J. Trump, because he owes roughly $550,000 in income taxes, according to a court filing.

headline: Millions of Candies Are Recalled After Child Chokes to Death
abstract: More than 70 million rolling candies made by two separate manufacturers pose a choking hazard to children, the U.S. Consumer Product Safety Commission said.
lead_paragraph: More than 70 million rolling candies made by two companies were recalled on Thursday, six months after a 7-year-old girl in New York choked to death.

headline: My (Liberating) Secret Shame
abstract: I may be unable to have children, and I am relieved.
lead_paragraph: When I was 16, my mother told me that I would never be happier. Entering womanhood, leaving home, joining the work force, having children — these phases, according to her, would all be marked by suffering and disappointment.

headline: Corrections: Oct. 6, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, Oct. 6, 2023.
lead_paragraph: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about a group of Indigenous women in Greenland who say Danish doctors inserted intrauterine devices without their consent misidentified the source of a 1972 study of the IUD program. It was a health officer in southern Greenland, not the Population Council, which published it.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Soaring Temperatures Are Taking a Toll on Workers
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, October 6, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “I start looking at my hands and I think, How am I already sweating? I haven’t done anything.”

headline: They Saw Each Other at a Jazz Club and Never Looked Away
abstract: Robyn Green was drawn to Jeb Roberts during his guitar solo of a favorite song. The moment Mr. Roberts introduced himself, he knew he liked Ms. Green.
lead_paragraph: On an October evening in 2018, Robyn Marie Green accompanied some of her co-workers to watch Olivia K & the Parkers, a jazz group from Brooklyn, perform at Groove, a jazz bar in the West Village in Manhattan. The band covered “What You Don’t Do” by Lianne La Havas, who is one of Ms. Green’s favorite artists. During the song’s guitar solo, Ms. Green found herself drawn to the guitarist — John Edward Bradly Roberts.

headline: A Co-Sign From Grandma Sealed the Deal
abstract: When Felix Allen III returned to his hometown, Waco, Texas, he was hoping to soon move again to a big city for his career. But after meeting Brandon Marshall, he decided to stay.
lead_paragraph: Before Felix Rameshad Allen III had even heard of Brandon Aaron Marshall, Mr. Allen’s grandmother, Bertha Mae Allen, was already a fan of Mr. Marshall. She had watched him on KWTX-TV News 10, an affiliate of CBS in Waco, Texas, where he was a reporter.

headline: He’d Never Date a Lawyer. Or So He Said.
abstract: When Rakim Brooks met Ray Biggs six years ago, Mr. Brooks was in his pajamas. The two spent the night dancing in a nightclub.
lead_paragraph: Ray Anthony Biggs II and Rakim Hassan Daquan Brooks both describe themselves as “genteel” — leave it to a nightclub to loosen them up.

headline: They Met the Old-Fashioned Way: Playing Glow-in-the-Dark Dodgeball
abstract: Yan Fu and Leslie Hamilton, the marathon sea swimmer, were on opposing New York City teams. But after late-night hot dogs and a swipe of Chapstick, they joined forces forever.
lead_paragraph: Yan Fu deserves some of the credit for the marathon sea swimmer Leslie Abigail Hamilton’s groundbreaking lap around Staten Island this summer.

headline: After the Rain Comes the Reckoning for the Mayor
abstract: Two investigations will consider how the city prepared for and responded to last week’s torrential storm.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Friday. Today we’ll look back at last Friday, the day record-breaking rains inundated New York City, and discuss the city’s preparedness — or its lack of it.
