headline: Venezuela Seeks Arrest of Juan Guaidó, Former Opposition Leader
abstract: The attorney general accused Mr. Guaidó, who now lives in the United States, of misusing state funds for his own benefit, which he denied.
lead_paragraph: The Venezuelan authorities said on Thursday that they were seeking the arrest of Juan Guaidó, the former opposition leader who is in exile in the United States.

headline: Friday Briefing
abstract: A devastating strike on Ukrainian civilians.
lead_paragraph: At least 51 people were killed yesterday when a rocket hit a group of people gathered for a wake in the village of Hroza in northeastern Ukraine, local officials said. The strike was one of the deadliest wartime attacks on civilians since Russia’s full-scale invasion began more than 19 months ago.

headline: Word of the Day: estimable
abstract: This word has appeared in 16 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word estimable has appeared in 16 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on April 6 in “‘Paint’ Review: Watch It Dry” by Jeannette Catsoulis:

headline: Jimmy Kimmel Calls Gaetz ‘the Least Popular Guy in Congress Right Now’
abstract: “Ted Cruz must be glowing,” Kimmel said on Thursday about the scorn piling onto Representative Matt Gaetz.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Recent fighting in the House has highlighted a drop in Republican support for aid to Kyiv.
abstract: The Republican meltdown on Capitol Hill that toppled the speaker this week and left the House in chaos has also highlighted a sharp decline in G.O.P. support for continuing to send aid to Ukraine, and how opposition to helping Kyiv has become a litmus test for the right.
lead_paragraph: The Republican meltdown on Capitol Hill that toppled the speaker this week and left the House in chaos has also highlighted a sharp decline in G.O.P. support for continuing to send aid to Ukraine, and how opposition to helping Kyiv has become a litmus test for the right.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: New York’s Right to Shelter Is Under Attack. Again.
abstract: The mayor is going to court over the city’s unique decree guaranteeing a room to all New Yorkers. It is not the city’s first time, with dozens of similar challenges over the past decades.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday night, the City of New York filed court documents asking to get out of an obligation it has maintained, if not happily or even willingly, for more than 40 years. The matter at hand was the 1981 consent decree that has come to be known as right to shelter, the result of a lawsuit that successfully sought to require the city to provide a bed to any homeless man who asked for one.

headline: A Wave Goodbye
abstract: Tell us a story, real or made up, that is inspired by this image.
lead_paragraph: Use your imagination to write the opening of a short story or poem inspired by this illustration or, describe a memory from your own life that this image makes you think of.

headline: Crossing Swamps and Sieving Sewage: A Year of Reporting on Mosquitoes
abstract: For a series on the health threats posed by mosquitoes, a Times reporter followed the insects into drainage pipes, bedrooms and the rainforest.
lead_paragraph: In one corner of the low-roofed shed, a cluster of mosquitoes, most likely carrying malaria, rested on a wall. In the opposite corner, a herd of goats — who seemed displeased to see me — huddled together. I crouched on the dirt between the two parties, trying to offend neither, taking notes.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”

headline: There’s a New Beach in Manhattan. Just Don’t Try to Swim There.
abstract: You can find sand, sun and Adirondack chairs along the Hudson River. New Yorkers in bathing suits are taking advantage of the still warm weather.
lead_paragraph: Swimming is not allowed at Manhattan’s newest beach.

headline: In Britain, a New ‘Big Brother’ Aims for Old TV Magic
abstract: The reality show dominated U.K. pop culture in the early 2000s. The producers of an upcoming revival hope the original format will break through in a changed TV landscape.
lead_paragraph: In 2000, when the reality TV show “Big Brother” premiered in Britain and the United States, both versions had the same format: A group of contestants were filmed around the clock doing menial tasks and making endless small talk, and were evicted via weekly audience votes until a winner took home a cash prize.

headline: Strong U.S. Job Growth Shows Economy Is Defying Challenges
abstract: Employers added 336,000 jobs in September, almost double what experts had forecast and the biggest gain since January. Markets welcomed the report.
lead_paragraph: In a sign of continued economic stamina, American payrolls grew by 336,000 in September on a seasonally adjusted basis, the Labor Department said on Friday.

headline: Despite the economy’s resilience, the outlook is hard to gauge.
abstract: With chaos lurking in Washington, interest rates surging and student loan payments resuming, the recovery faces new challenges.
lead_paragraph: The jobs report for September arrives at a moment of eager anticipation among economists and investors, all seeking clarity in a perplexing moment.

headline: How strikes are (and aren’t) reflected in the jobs report.
abstract: Three of the country’s major automakers are facing an expanding strike that started on Sept. 15. Hollywood producers and screenwriters reached a contract agreement late last month to end a 148-day walkout, but striking actors are still locked in negotiations.
lead_paragraph: Three of the country’s major automakers are facing an expanding strike that started on Sept. 15. Hollywood producers and screenwriters reached a contract agreement late last month to end a 148-day walkout, but striking actors are still locked in negotiations.

headline: Jhumpa Lahiri Translates the Varieties of Strangeness
abstract: In “Roman Stories,” written in Italian, nine protagonists have little in common except their foreignness.
lead_paragraph: When Jhumpa Lahiri released her first story collection, “Interpreter of Maladies,” in 1999, it earned her near-immediate status as one of the English language’s most exciting working authors.

headline: Where to Find a Horse, a Hemp Farm and a War
abstract: New books by Finn Murphy, Will Grant and Peter Stark explore the past and present of the American West.
lead_paragraph: How original can a story about an East Coast rich man trying to get richer in the West still be in 2023? The answer, to save you and perhaps future writers a bit of time, is not very! But, if you can trudge through Finn Murphy’s ROCKY MOUNTAIN HIGH: A Tale of Boom and Bust in the New Wild West (Norton, 220 pp., $27.95), with its obligatory self-aware colonizer-capitalist bit (“I’m not sure if I’m the canary in the coal mine or part of the problem,” he says of the way he always seems to end up settling in gentrifying towns. “Probably the latter”), you will find something interesting hidden here.

headline: He Warned Turkey About Earthquakes. Now He Fears for Istanbul.
abstract: Naci Gorur, a geologist, has become a household name in Turkey for imploring the country to prepare for quakes he has predicted. He has been disappointed by the response and is deeply worried about Istanbul.
lead_paragraph: The news that a powerful earthquake had struck southern Turkey first reached the eminent geologist in a pre-dawn video call from a phone number he did not recognize.

headline: Audiobook of the Week: What’s Really in a Hot Dog?
abstract: “Raw Dog,” by the comedian Jamie Loftus, is an investigative memoir that’s part gonzo travelogue and part takedown of the factory farming system.
lead_paragraph: Most of us don’t want to think too much about our hot dogs: what’s in them, how they were made, what “nitrates” really do. In her new audiobook, “Raw Dog,” the comedian Jamie Loftus bravely rips off the Band-Aid of her own hot dog ignorance. The audiobook is many things: part gonzo travelogue in which Loftus and a boyfriend spend the summer of 2021 traversing the country to sample its dogs; part cultural analysis of the tube meat as American icon; part takedown of the factory farming system; part memoir about a crumbling relationship straining under the weight of cheap motel rooms and indigestion.

headline: Ghosts Come in Many Forms in Bryan Washington’s New Novel
abstract: In “Family Meal,” the author follows the jagged reunion of two former best friends, each grappling with grief and complicated relationships.
lead_paragraph: The act of leaving has been central in the work of the phenomenally precocious Bryan Washington — the leaving of stagnant relationships and rainy-day lovers; the leaving of families and communities that restrain and too often reject; the leaving of old selves; and in some cases, the tragic leaving of this world. But Washington’s fiction is much less concerned with the heartache and devastation commonly caused by such departures and much more obsessed with how absence and exodus create a smithy in which new selves can be forged.

headline: My Hair Was Always a Source of Tension Between My Mother and Me. Then We Met Charlotte.
abstract: The quest to find a stylist for my natural hair spanned continents and changed my life.
lead_paragraph: As a child of mixed-race heritage, I often found that my hair was a source of tension between my mother and me. My father hails from Eritrea in East Africa, and my mother is from Sweden, so she and I have vastly different hair textures. When I was a girl — until about the age of 10 — my thick and curly hair was a nightmare for her to manage.

headline: It Takes a Lifetime to Survive Childhood Cancer
abstract: Years after they overcame a diagnosis, patients are still living with their treatment’s toll.
lead_paragraph: One night in 1981, in the middle of bath time, Marty Gonzalez noticed a strange glow that seemed to emanate from inside one of the eyes of her 9-month-old daughter, Marissa.

headline: Going to the Chapel (at Home)
abstract: From stoops and staircases to backyards and balconies, couples are choosing the comforts of home and the emotional bonds they have with their spaces as wedding locations.
lead_paragraph: The bride walked down a 10-foot runner. Oscar, a 7-year-old French bulldog dressed in a bow tie, was the best man and tagged alongside the groom. Twenty guests cheered the couple as they took their vows in the picturesque venue in Fort Greene, Brooklyn.

headline: Newly Published, from Graphic Novels to a Covid-Era Literary Obsession
abstract: A selection of recently published books.
lead_paragraph: ROAMING, by Jillian Tamaki and Mariko Tamaki. (Drawn & Quarterly, $34.95.) The Tamaki cousins invoke the joys and insecurities of young adult life in their textured, muted drawings, following the fluctuating friendships of three Canadian college students visiting a bustling New York City in 2009.

headline: It’s a Woman’s World. We’re All Just Living in It.
abstract: Cat Bohannon’s “Eve” is an opinionated clapback against centuries of male-centric evolutionary history.
lead_paragraph: In the opening scene of “2001: A Space Odyssey,” a pack of male hominids gather, screech and chase one another around Stanley Kubrick’s set. Then one picks up an animal bone and starts dominating. Humanity has dawned. Ta-da!

headline: Kate DiCamillo Is Not Afraid of the Dark
abstract: As a new novella and a new edition of “The Tale of Despereaux” remind us, her stories demand a lot from young readers, but the rewards can be magical.
lead_paragraph: Kate DiCamillo learned the craft of storytelling by sitting on old ladies’ porches on her dead-end street in Central Florida. Her mother had moved her there to escape an abusive father and a climate that was the suspected culprit in her relentless illness.

headline: How to Protect Your Retirement From Nagging Inflation
abstract: Social Security’s cost of living adjustment, coming next week, helps retirees keep up with their bills, but there are other strategies for coping.
lead_paragraph: The Social Security cost of living adjustment for 2024, expected to be announced Thursday, is forecast to be 3.2 percent, far below the 8.7 percent increase older Americans received this year. The smaller increase would reflect the cooling of consumer prices, but inflation is an ever-present risk that should be a consideration in your retirement plan.

headline: Dancers and Video Game Characters Merge in the Uncanny Valley
abstract: Some dancers have found a niche on TikTok and other platforms imitating video game characters — moving like a machine’s idea of a human.
lead_paragraph: Watch a TikTok video by @dem_bruddaz, and you might feel a queasy mixture of recognition and disorientation.

headline: An N.B.A. Power Broker, Growing Up and Finding Peace
abstract: In a new memoir, Rich Paul, known to many for his long association with LeBron James, details his difficult upbringing and the valuable lessons it taught him.
lead_paragraph: When Rich Paul considers his life now, he sometimes thinks how far it seems from his childhood, growing up Black in a particularly dangerous part of Cleveland.

headline: They’ve Been Stateless for 10 Years. Now Many Are Facing Deportation.
abstract: Ten years after a court order ruled that children of Haitian migrants in the Dominican Republic were not entitled to citizenship, many live in fear of arrest or expulsion.
lead_paragraph: Before leaving his house each day, Castillo Javier Police always made sure he carried the essentials. Hat. Wallet. Birth certificate. But the last item still did not stop him from being detained — and then deported.

headline: Why I Keep Watching In-Flight Meltdowns
abstract: How the airplane became a viral sensation, the star of videos about questionable behavior — and the new backdrop for social disillusionment.
lead_paragraph: In September, a 10-second TikTok kicked off weeks of debate. A wobbly camera stared down the center aisle of an airplane. A short story appeared, overlaid in white text: “I was seated next to a mom who had a baby in her lap and a toddler beside her. It was a lot. I offered to switch seats with the dad, who was a few rows up, so he could be with his family. He says ‘Great, thanks’ AND SENDS OVER ANOTHER SMALL KID TO SIT WITH THE MOM. He enjoyed a kid-free flight.”

headline: A Tiny Australian Home That Feels a Lot Bigger
abstract: How do you make a 375-square-foot apartment feel luxurious? It’s all in the planning.
lead_paragraph: How do you make a 375-square-foot apartment feel luxurious? It’s all in the planning.

headline: How Do You Make a 375-Square-Foot Home Feel Luxurious?
abstract: It’s all in the planning, as one couple in Brisbane, Australia, discovered.
lead_paragraph: In the early days of the pandemic, Andy and Luana Longworth hatched a plan with 18 of their closest friends: Faced with the prospect of social isolation, they would all move in together and live as one big, happy pod.

headline: How the Humble Paperback Helped Win World War II
abstract: A new exhibition tells the story of the Armed Services Editions, pocket-size paperback weapons in the fight for democracy.
lead_paragraph: When American soldiers fought on the battlefields of World War II, they were carrying more than weapons. They also carried ideas — quite literally.

headline: Is Chaos the Only Thing Republicans Can Trust?
abstract: ​​Kevin McCarthy’s ousting is just a symptom of the G.O.P.’s deeper problems.
lead_paragraph: Now that Kevin McCarthy is no longer speaker, who’s in charge of the Republicans, and is this overthrow what voters actually want?

headline: What to Know About the ‘Morning-After’ Pill for S.T.I.s
abstract: Doxycycline can help prevent sexually transmitted infections. Here’s how to use it.
lead_paragraph: As sexually transmitted infections continue to climb in the United States, a promising tool to combat them is drawing more attention. This week, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention released a draft proposal to recommend the antibiotic doxycycline as a “morning-after” pill to help prevent chlamydia, syphilis and gonorrhea infections among people at especially high risk.

headline: The Mystery of What Happened to a 9/11 Suspect’s Sons
abstract: A psychologist working for the C.I.A. had threatened while interrogating Khalid Shaikh Mohammed to kill one of his preteen sons. But they were never in U.S. custody.
lead_paragraph: The fate of the sons of Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, the man accused of being the mastermind of the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks, has long been a source of mystery and controversy.

headline: For Republicans in the Trump Era, Chaos Often Seems to Be the Point
abstract: A revolt in Congress. Insurgent candidacies in swing states. A likely nominee on trial. This week showed how the party has turned more insular, antagonistic and repellent to general-election voters.
lead_paragraph: Turbulence has trailed the Republican Party ever since Donald J. Trump’s rise. This week, that chaos looked like an organizing principle.

headline: How Much Faith Do You Have in the U.S. Political System?
abstract: Do you worry that political divisions are too deep, the government is too dysfunctional or civic norms are too challenged? Or are you confident that American democracy is still strong?
lead_paragraph: That’s how David Leonhardt begins Thursday’s The Morning newsletter.

headline: Hiring Is Rising Along With Rates. Are They on a Collision Course?
abstract: A run-up in longer-term interest rates could help the Federal Reserve get the economic cool-down it wants — but it also risks a bumpy landing.
lead_paragraph: Heather Mahmood-Corley, a real estate agent, was seeing decent demand for houses in the Phoenix area just a few weeks ago. But as mortgage rates pick up again, she is already watching would-be home buyers retrench.

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, Oct. 6, 2023
abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
abstract: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including the debut of Season 2 of “Loki” on Disney+.
lead_paragraph: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including the debut of Season 2 of “Loki” on Disney+.

headline: Between a Rock and a ‘Hard’ Insurance Market
abstract: Factors including catastrophes linked to climate change are prompting insurers to raise premiums — a “hardening” market.
lead_paragraph: Factors including catastrophes linked to climate change are prompting insurers to raise premiums — a “hardening” market.

headline: Can We Talk About Joe Biden?
abstract: As worried as many of us are about the president’s chances, he is our best shot at beating Trump.
lead_paragraph: Nearly two decades ago, I tried to write a group biography about the senators whose offices happened to be on the second floor of the Russell Office Building on Capitol Hill. The group included John McCain, Joe Biden, Lindsey Graham and Chuck Hagel. I got to know and study each of those senators during that long-ago-abandoned project.

headline: Google’s Trial Heats Up + How to Wear A.I. + It’s Our Birthday!
abstract: How long can Google hold on to its jackpot of business models?
lead_paragraph: The antitrust trial against Google has led to some of tech’s biggest players testifying in court, and things have gotten spicy. The New York Times reporter Cecilia Kang tells us the wildest moments in the trial so far.

headline: How to Break Through When Your Teen Tunes You Out
abstract: Meaningful conversations are possible, but you might have to change your approach, experts say.
lead_paragraph: I picked up my teenage daughter from marching band practice last week. She got in the car and immediately started texting.

headline: In Times of Danger, There’s Strength in Numbers
abstract: An illustrated ode to Richard Adams’s novel “Watership Down.”

headline: 6 New Paperbacks to Read This Week
abstract: Selected paperbacks from the Book Review, including titles by Charlayne Hunter-Gault, Hua Hsu, Kate Manning and more.
lead_paragraph: Selected paperbacks from the Book Review, including titles by Charlayne Hunter-Gault, Hua Hsu, Kate Manning and more.

headline: Peso Pluma, Mexico’s Breakout Music Star, Finds New Spotlights
abstract: The reigning king of corridos tumbados is bringing an updated version of traditional music to international collaborators and audiences.
lead_paragraph: Backstage at the MTV Video Music Awards last month, at the Prudential Center in Newark, the out-of-nowhere Mexican superstar Peso Pluma gathered his band for an inspirational talk. That night, he was to become the first Mexican artist to ever perform on the show, but before the dress rehearsal of his song “Lady Gaga,” he set aside around 10 minutes to reminisce with the musicians who have been with him for years, telling them how none of his success would have been possible without them. At the end, almost the whole band walked out of the room in tears.

headline: Confessions of a Pop-Tarts Taste Tester
abstract: When my family was enlisted nearly 60 years ago, little did we suspect that the pastry would become a pop-culture phenomenon and inspire a Seinfeld movie.
lead_paragraph: Almost every family has a secret they never discuss. Ours is this: We were taste testers for Pop-Tarts.

headline: As Winter Looms, Venezuelan Migrant Surge Overwhelms Chicago
abstract: Police stations have become tent encampments. More than 800 migrants are sleeping at Chicago O’Hare International Airport. City officials are scrambling.
lead_paragraph: The buses packed with Venezuelan migrants are now arriving in downtown Chicago day and night, doubling in number in recent weeks. City officials are struggling to open more shelters, while more than 2,300 migrants are sleeping at police stations, in lobbies and just outside in makeshift camps.

headline: Scream Along With Pussy Riot
abstract: In the first major museum retrospective devoted to the Russian art provocateurs, they pump their fists and cause a fuss. They want you to do the same.
lead_paragraph: Downstairs at the Louisiana Museum of Modern Art, about 20 miles north of Copenhagen, a woman is urinating on President Vladimir V. Putin. Balanced on a table above a black-and-white portrait of the Russian leader, her blonde hair and face shrouded in a bright-red balaclava, she hitches up her loose dress and answers nature’s call, drenching the photograph before kicking it to the ground.

headline: Who is Narges Mohammadi?
abstract: Iran’s most prominent human rights campaigner, Ms. Mohammadi is at least the fourth Nobel laureate to win the prize while imprisoned.
lead_paragraph: Narges Mohammadi, the most prominent human rights activist in Iran, has dedicated her career to fighting government repression with a focus on women’s rights. She is currently serving a 10-year jail sentence in Tehran’s Evin Prison for “spreading anti-state propaganda.”

headline: Strike Killed 1 in 6 of Ukraine Village’s Residents, Officials Say
abstract: The population of Hroza, near Kharkiv, had dwindled to 300 before Thursday’s strike, which hit people gathered for a memorial service.
lead_paragraph: Grieving families awaited news of loved ones into the night. A mobile phone somewhere among the charred personal belongings rang and rang, with no one to answer. The bodies — more than 50 in all — were sheathed in white bags and carted away near a slide and a swing set in a children’s playground.

headline: Biden Will Continue Border Wall, and More
abstract: Plus, a Republican split on Ukraine aid and a lawsuit by female truck drivers.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

headline: Chaos or Conscience? A Republican Explains His Vote to Oust McCarthy.
abstract: Representative Tim Burchett of Tennessee talks about why he felt so betrayed.
lead_paragraph: The ouster of House Speaker Kevin McCarthy a few days ago demonstrated how powerful a small group of hard-right House Republicans have become and how deep their grievances run.

headline: Abe Lincoln and Kevin McCarthy
abstract: Refusing to listen to the other side of a debate doesn’t have a very good record of success.
lead_paragraph: In our polarized society, the simple act of listening to people with whom you disagree — let alone working with them — can be grounds for rebuke.

headline: How Aligning With China Changed Life in the Solomon Islands
abstract: The author of a new book on the diplomatic switch says that ending recognition of Taiwan affected life in unexpected ways across the island nation.
lead_paragraph: In 2019, the Solomon Islands ended its decades-long alliance with Taiwan and instead diplomatically recognized China, a much-publicized decision that prompted fears of Beijing’s growing influence in the region and divided residents within the island nation of 700,000.

headline: ‘The Exorcist: Believer’ | Anatomy of a Scene
abstract: David Gordon Green narrates a sequence from his film, featuring Leslie Odom Jr. and Lidya Jewett.
lead_paragraph: David Gordon Green narrates a sequence from his film, featuring Leslie Odom Jr. and Lidya Jewett.

headline: How Light Creates Suspense in ‘The Exorcist: Believer’
abstract: The film’s director and co-writer, David Gordon Green, narrates a sequence featuring Leslie Odom Jr. and Lidya Jewett.
lead_paragraph: In “Anatomy of a Scene,” we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series on Fridays. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.

headline: Five Children’s Movies to Stream Now
abstract: This month’s picks include a splashy Pixar creation, an Adam Sandler comedy and the newest installment in the “Spy Kids” franchise.
lead_paragraph: Watch it on Disney+.

headline: Russian Nobel Recipient and Other Laureates Ask for $100 Million in Aid
abstract: Dmitri A. Muratov, who shared the prize in 2021, has used the honor to raise funds for people affected by the war in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: The Russian Nobel Peace Prize winner Dmitri A. Muratov said on Thursday that 47 other Nobel laureates have signed a letter urging the world’s billionaires to donate $100 million to help children displaced by the war in Ukraine and other conflicts.

headline: Drake Releases ‘For All the Dogs’ Album, With Assists From Bad Bunny and Kevin Durant
abstract: The album features appearances by SZA, 21 Savage and J. Cole, plus a surprise role for an NBA star. After its release, the rapper said he would consider a temporary break from music.
lead_paragraph: After a summer of teasing, various delays, dozens of arena concerts and eventually another No. 1 single, the rapper Drake released his fourth album in barely two years on Friday morning, ahead of a tour-ending, two-night run of shows in his hometown, Toronto.

headline: A Mega-Deal May Await in the Oil Patch
abstract: Exxon Mobil is reportedly in talks to buy Pioneer Natural Resources, a major shale driller, in what would be the biggest takeover of the year.
lead_paragraph: Reports that Exxon Mobil is near a $60 billion takeover of the shale oil producer Pioneer Natural Resources — in what would be the biggest deal of the year — are the latest sign that cash-flush corporate titans are once again willing to buy growth. (The reports caution that talks between Exxon and Pioneer are continuing and may not lead to a transaction.)

headline: My No-Recipe Recipe for Flawless Salmon
abstract: Three ingredients, fifteen minutes, perfect fish.
lead_paragraph: I flew out to Omaha last weekend. There was plenty to do.

headline: ‘A Slap in the Face of Voters’: What R.N.C. Members Say About Trump’s Calls to Cancel Debates
abstract: Many members of the Republican National Committee say they are giving little weight to the Trump campaign’s appeal.
lead_paragraph: After refusing to participate in the first two Republican debates, former President Donald J. Trump and aides to his campaign have spent the past week arguing that there should be no more. The Republican National Committee, they say, should treat the race for the party’s nomination as over, given Mr. Trump’s large lead in the polls.

headline: Jobs Gains Heat Up Even as the Federal Reserve Looks for Cooling
abstract: Fed officials are happy when the labor market looks strong, but they are trying to cool the economy down to fully wrangle inflation.
lead_paragraph: Federal Reserve officials are likely to keep a close eye on the job market’s strength in light of September jobs data, which showed that employers hired at an unexpectedly rapid clip.

headline: Easy Mode: Clues for Oct. 6
abstract: Get some help on the Friday crossword puzzle.
lead_paragraph: Friday crosswords are among the hardest of the week. They are themeless, which means you can’t rely on that extra level of context to solve the puzzle, and the clues are written with a higher level of wit and wordplay. We know this can be daunting for newer solvers. If you need a little hint to unlock the puzzle, we’ve provided easy clues you can use. We recommend ctrl + f the number of the clue you’re looking for. You can also play a digital version of this puzzle with easy clues by signing up for our Easy Mode newsletter.

headline: A New Effort to Make College Aid Offers Easy to Understand
abstract: After years of criticism about financial aid letters that are confusing and sometimes misleading, about 400 schools have agreed to bring “clarity” to their communication.
lead_paragraph: Colleges and universities have been criticized for years for sending out financial aid offers to students that are confusing, opaque and sometimes misleading.

headline: In Berkeley, Indigenous Peoples’ Day Is a Decades-Old Tradition
abstract: Berkeley was an early adopter of the holiday, in protest of the annual celebration of Columbus’s arrival in the Americas.
lead_paragraph: A dozen states and more than a hundred cities will celebrate Indigenous Peoples’ Day on Monday, a holiday intended both to honor Native cultures and to offer something of a rebuke to Columbus Day. In 2021, President Biden became the first U.S. president to formally recognize the holiday, a signal of its growing acceptance.

headline: Investing Has Been Ugly. Stick With It Anyway.
abstract: Most people have lost money in the markets over the last several months, but people who have held on have prospered, our columnist says.
lead_paragraph: This is one of those stretches when you may want to avoid looking at your investments.

headline: Music Too Fast for Feet
abstract: Since Europe’s clubs reopened after pandemic lockdowns, young partygoers have been drawn to a hard, driving style of techno. It’s changing the way people dance.
lead_paragraph: It was Friday night, and the clubgoers at the Sputnikhalle nightclub in Münster, Germany, were primed to go hard. Decked out in black clothes and sunglasses, despite the dim light, the young crowd chanted the name of Héctor Oaks, a Spanish D.J., as he began playing his signature muscular, fast techno. Standing on top of the club’s risers, the crowd barely tried to keep up with the beat. Instead of moving their legs, many just oscillated their hips.

headline: A Calamitous Flood Shows the Dangers Lurking in Melting Glaciers
abstract: A glacial lake’s overflow swept away more than 100 people in the Himalayan state of Sikkim in India. Climate change is aggravating the threat of such phenomena.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after midnight on Tuesday, 17,000 feet up in the Himalayas just south of India’s border with China, some slight shift started an avalanche. Snow, ice and boulders slid into a giant glacial lake a mile below, causing it to burst its banks. From there, catastrophes multiplied as the water cascaded down mountain valleys below.

headline: ‘My Heart Stopped’: Iranian Activist’s Family Exults From Afar, but Remains Fearful for Her
abstract: The family of Narges Mohammadi, who is serving a 10-year jail sentence in Tehran, had not yet spoken with her about the Nobel Peace Prize, because they cannot call the prison where she is held.
lead_paragraph: Narges Mohammadi’s 16-year-old son, Ali, who lives in Paris, was in school when the Nobel Peace Prize was announced on Friday. He kept refreshing his phone under the table until 11 a.m. struck — and his mother’s name flashed across the screen.

headline: Yields Jump and Stocks Swing After Strong Jobs Report
abstract: Employment data for September showed surprising strength in the economy, but that resiliency has become a cause for concern among investors.
lead_paragraph: Markets fluctuated sharply on Friday after a fresh report on hiring pointed to a much stronger labor market than economists had expected, intensifying concerns among investors that the Federal Reserve would need to clamp down on the economy more forcefully to bring inflation under control, but also offering some comfort that any additional pressure would be set against a resilient backdrop.

headline: It’s the Flavor That Slays in This Killer Pasta
abstract: A regional favorite in Bari, Italy, has found new American fans, thanks in part to Stanley Tucci’s “Searching for Italy.”
lead_paragraph: When it comes to cooking pasta, Celso Laforgia breaks every rule in the book. His spaghetti isn’t ivory-colored and tender. It’s dark as polished ebony and it crunches like grissini. He doesn’t cook it in boiling water. He chars the raw noodles in a skillet. He seasons it not with the usual fresh garlic, but with powdered, and if that’s not iconoclastic enough here in southern Italy, his restaurant, Urban L’Assassineria Urbana in the pulsing city of Bari in Apulia, serves such decidedly un-Italian dishes as tacos and bao.

headline: Adams to Migrants in Mexico: We Love You. Now Stop Coming to New York.
abstract: Mayor Eric Adams went to Latin America with two missions: to promote New York City and praise earlier immigrants, and to tell new immigrants about the misery that awaits them if they come.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Eric Adams of New York City touched down in Mexico this week on an urgent four-day mission: to witness firsthand the forces that have brought more than 120,000 migrants to New York, and to warn migrants in transit of the misery that awaits them once they arrive.

headline: Chloe Domont on Her Dangerous Date Movie, ‘Fair Play’
abstract: The writer-director discusses her Netflix film about power dynamics within relationships, and how it might end up facilitating breakups.
lead_paragraph: All is indubitably not fair in love, war, or “Fair Play,” the crackling feature debut from the writer-director Chloe Domont that became a sensation at this year’s Sundance Film Festival. (It sold there to Netflix for $20 million, and is now streaming on the platform).

headline: Hidden Art: A Rhapsody for the Soul, in 10 City Corners
abstract: A Baedeker for adventurers yearning for the unknown, the unnoticed and the unexpected on a walk around New York City.
lead_paragraph: When I emerge from an art gallery or a museum, the world around me looks different. Leaving the Metropolitan Museum of Art late one afternoon, the color of the sunlight is amplified by my memory of the luminous gold in a peacock’s tail rendered in a Japanese painting. Tire scuff marks on a curb near the Museum of Modern Art seem to recall the numinous power of Mark Rothko’s untitled black on gray painting.

headline: Former Americans Who Gave Up Their Citizenship Want Their Money Back
abstract: Former U.S. citizens who live abroad have filed a class-action lawsuit saying the $2,350 fee to relinquish their nationality was exorbitant.
lead_paragraph: Last fall, Nina Nelson went to the U.S. Embassy in Paris and renounced her citizenship to the United States of America.

headline: The Best of Late Night This Week
abstract: After a five-month writers’ strike ended last week, the late night shows returned on Monday. In their monologues, the hosts expressed gratitude to be working again and caught up on news old and new. Here's what they had to say.
lead_paragraph: After a five-month writers’ strike ended last week, the late night shows returned on Monday. In their monologues, the hosts expressed gratitude to be working again and caught up on news old and new. Here's what they had to say.

headline: For Gaetz, Washington Drama Could Fuel Florida Ambitions
abstract: As rumors swirl about a 2026 bid for governor of Florida, Matt Gaetz said his only political goal was “electing President Trump again.”
lead_paragraph: Representative Matt Gaetz’s successful push to oust Speaker Kevin McCarthy has ratcheted up speculation that the fourth-term Republican congressman already has his eye on his next target, still three years away: the Florida governor’s mansion.

headline: The Joys of Walking, Together and Solo
abstract: Responses to a column by Lydia Polgreen. Also: A healthier life; using cruise ships to house homeless people; toxic military bases; song of the crickets.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Five Action Movies to Stream Now
abstract: This month’s picks include vengeful spouses, plenty of brawling and a little bit of cheese.
lead_paragraph: Crime and corruption are rampant in the fictional Japanese metropolis of Kaiko City: The underworld kingpin Gojo (Lily Franky) is running for mayor to redevelop an impoverished neighborhood into a high-stakes nightlife denizen of gambling. The only person who can stop him is the disgraced former cop Torada (Hitoshi Ozawa). Released early from prison by desperate prosecutors to be captain of Special Investigation Division Zero, he is willing to work outside the law to get the job done.

headline: Russia Bids to Rejoin U.N. Human Rights Council
abstract: The vote scheduled for Tuesday in the U.N. General Assembly could be close, in part because of Russia’s support among some countries of the global south.
lead_paragraph: Russia is seeking election to the United Nations’ top human rights body in a vote next week that will offer the latest test of international support for the Western-led diplomatic isolation imposed on Moscow for its invasion of Ukraine.

headline: Amazon Launches First Project Kuiper Satellites to Orbit
abstract: The two prototype spacecraft will test systems to be used in a planned megaconstellation to provide internet service from orbit that will eventually compete with SpaceX’s Starlink service.
lead_paragraph: In a space race between two businesses started by Jeff Bezos, his e-commerce company, Amazon, beat his rocket company, Blue Origin, to orbit.

headline: The Real Problem With V.A.R.
abstract: If process and hubris trump getting calls right, the system has broken down.
lead_paragraph: There are very few coherent sentences in what will, in time, doubtless come to be known as the Luis Díaz Tape, a sort of Premier League equivalent to the Zapruder film. The various protagonists communicate in clipped and meaningless phrases, any clarity sacrificed on the altar of self-important brevity.

headline: Michael Lewis Doesn’t Do Villains
abstract: With his new book about the crypto mogul Sam Bankman-Fried — and new questions about his old work — the famously charmed writer finds himself under a microscope.
lead_paragraph: A hike is Michael Lewis’s interview format of choice. When he first met the FTX founder Sam Bankman-Fried in late 2021, he took the cargo-shorted chief executive on a walk through the eucalyptus trees near his Berkeley, Calif., home.

headline: The Weekender
abstract: The story behind Tupac’s murder. Also: The colors of Paris Fashion Week and the evolution of same-sex relations in mammals.

headline: Review: After Hovering, Steve Reich Brings Back the Pulse
abstract: In “Jacob’s Ladder,” which premiered at the New York Philharmonic on Thursday, Reich’s signature chugging rhythms returned.
lead_paragraph: Thursday evening was a major moment for musical Minimalism.

headline: Eddie Martinez Defers to the Desires of His Paints
abstract: At his studio in Queens, the artist’s routine includes turkey meatballs, cut-up Crocs and the patience to let his materials set his pace.
lead_paragraph: In the artist Eddie Martinez’s dense, polychrome paintings, each mark is haunted by the gesture that made it and each color seems to demand its own verb: The thick gray drips; a bright red streak declares; a daub of blue hesitates. Even white pigment, which has frequently appeared in Martinez’s pieces since his 2018 “White Out” series, has a charged presence, boldly countering a base painting or washed thinly across the canvas so that the ghost of an underlying color peeks through. His teeming works seem, on the one hand, to be urgently composed, but the carefully accrued coats of paint — sprayed, silk-screened or directly applied from pigment sticks — also point to an artist who knows how to surrender to the pace set by his materials. “I need the paint to dry to produce the layers,” Martinez tells me one overcast afternoon in his studio in Ridgewood, Queens, ahead of his solo show at London’s Timothy Taylor gallery, opening October 12. The walls are hung with pieces in varying stages of completion. He pauses in front of one and leaves a single, deliberate stroke of brown. “I have to override my impatience for the sake of letting it become the painting it needs to become,” he says.

headline: Henri Dauman, Photographer of Postwar Celebrity Life, Is Dead at 90
abstract: He fled Nazi persecution in Paris, learned his craft as a teenage orphan and became known for his shots of Marilyn Monroe, Elvis Presley, Jacqueline Kennedy and many others.
lead_paragraph: Henri Dauman, a Holocaust survivor and French émigré who as a magazine photographer depicted the ascent of postwar political and celebrity culture with his pictures of President John F. Kennedy’s funeral, Elvis Presley entering and leaving the U.S. Army and Elizabeth Taylor reacting viscerally to a heavyweight title match, died on Sept. 13 at his home in Hampton Bays, N.Y. He was 90.

headline: Fatal Crash Involving Nadine Menendez Is Under New Investigation
abstract: The scrutiny could create fresh legal and political peril for Senator Robert Menendez, a Democrat, who has been charged with accepting bribes.
lead_paragraph: The New Jersey attorney general’s office seized records on Thursday from Bergen County law enforcement agencies to review whether the investigation of a fatal 2018 car crash involving the soon-to-be wife of Senator Robert Menendez was handled properly, two officials said.

headline: At City Ballet, Barbie Basics at the Gala, and a Glittering Revival
abstract: New York City Ballet hosted a gala with unfortunate new costumes for Balanchine’s “Who Cares?” But the repertory is what matters, and it’s been dazzling.
lead_paragraph: This year’s New York City Ballet fall gala was an outlier. In recent years, fashion has taken center stage, with designers and choreographers collaborating to make new work. But on Thursday, this annual event at Lincoln Center took a different path. As the actress Sarah Jessica Parker, a vice chair of the company’s board of directors, put it in remarks before the show: “Tonight, we’re going vintage.”

headline: A Tree Was Felled. No One Heard It. How Do You Find Out Who Did It?
abstract: A week after someone cut down the iconic tree at Sycamore Gap, the police and local residents appear no closer to answering the most persistent question: Why?
lead_paragraph: Tony Gates was one of the first to hear the bad news. The chief executive of Northumberland National Park, a 400-square-mile swatch of rolling hills and wild moorland on England’s northern edge, he received a phone call early last Thursday informing him that one of the area’s most celebrated landmarks, the tree at Sycamore Gap, was no more.

headline: Who Is Madonna, Anyway?
abstract: A conversation with the biographer Mary Gabriel, whose substantial new book offers a comprehensive and surprising look at the pop star’s life and career.
lead_paragraph: Madonna released her first single in 1982, and in one guise or another she has been with us ever since — ubiquitous but also astonishing, when you consider the usual fleeting arc of pop stardom. How has she done it, and how have her various personae shaped or reflected the culture she inhabits? These are among the questions the renowned biographer Mary Gabriel takes up in her latest book, “Madonna: A Rebel Life,” which casts new light on its subject’s life and career.

headline: U.S. Aid to Ukraine, and When It Might Run Out, Explained
abstract: President Biden has said the United States will assist Ukraine’s fight against Russia “for as long as it takes.” But Republican support for continuing aid has declined.
lead_paragraph: Billions of dollars in U.S. military and economic aid have enabled Ukraine to fend off Russia’s invasion, but the future of that support is now in serious doubt.

headline: The Big Number: 1,300
abstract: The disgraced founder of the failed cryptocurrency exchange FTX faces a mountain of evidence against him.
lead_paragraph: The disgraced founder of the failed cryptocurrency exchange FTX faces a mountain of evidence against him.

headline: ‘Billions’ Season 7, Episode 9 Recap: The Walls Close in
abstract: Chuck joins the mutineers in a spectacular way as Mike sets traps for Wendy and the rest.
lead_paragraph: Think of this week’s episode of “Billions” as the Death Star trash compactor. In this memorable scene from “Star Wars,” our heroes, Luke, Leia, Han and Chewie, are stuck waist-deep in refuse as the walls of the compactor slowly close in on them. Shooting at those walls, climbing them, bracing them with metal beams — nothing works. It is simply a race against time: Either their robotic friends C-3PO and R2-D2 figure out how to shut down the space station’s trash compactor, or — well, as Han Solo puts it, “We’re all going to be a lot thinner.”

headline: Murray Stenson, Unassuming Leader of a Cocktail Renaissance, Dies at 74
abstract: A staple of the Seattle bar scene, he was both a throwback to an earlier era and an inspiration for a new generation of bartenders.
lead_paragraph: Murray Stenson didn’t look like a revolutionary. Balding and slightly stooped, the son of a small-town grade-school principal, he spent decades quietly making cocktails at bars around Seattle, honing his classic, unfussy style. He favored regulars over celebrities, steady work over flair, handwritten notes over email.

headline: U.S. Resumes Food Aid for Refugees in Ethiopia
abstract: But food supplies will remain suspended for tens of millions of Ethiopians until the government takes steps to root out corruption.
lead_paragraph: The United States will resume food aid to refugees in Ethiopia, more than four months after suspending it because of large-scale diversions and theft of rations meant to feed millions of hungry people.

headline: ‘Winning Time’ and the Joys of Unnecessary Shows
abstract: Goodbye to the small screen’s silver age.
lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago, a little bit before the Hollywood writers’ strike finally resolved itself, HBO announced that it would be canceling “Winning Time,” the show about the 1980s Lakers just then wrapping up its second season. You don’t want to make too much of any one cancellation, but since I was a fan of the show, I’ll take the risk and say that its truncation was a bellwether for the transformation of television that everyone sees happening — the end of the streaming smorgasbord, the end of peak TV.

headline: No Charges for Troopers Who Killed ‘Cop City’ Protester Near Atlanta
abstract: Prosecutors said that the protester, Manuel Esteban Paez Terán, posed an “immediate threat” to state troopers who were trying to clear activists from a forest where a police training center was being built.
lead_paragraph: The state troopers who shot and killed a protester in January in a forest near Atlanta will not be criminally charged, a Georgia prosecutor said on Friday.

headline: Riccardo Muti Takes a Victory Lap With the Chicago Symphony
abstract: The orchestra’s former conductor — now its music director emeritus for life — opened Carnegie Hall’s season with a two-night engagement.
lead_paragraph: When Riccardo Muti stepped down from the Chicago Symphony Orchestra last season, after 13 years as its conductor, the ensemble promptly turned around and named him music director emeritus for life.

headline: Stockholm Offers Fighter Jets for Ukraine if Sweden is Allowed to Join NATO
abstract: The offer appeared to be the latest move in an ongoing diplomatic effort to persuade Turkey to drop its objection to Sweden joining the military alliance.
lead_paragraph: The Swedish defense ministry said on Friday it could contribute its Gripen warplanes to a Western coalition that is trying to speed fighter jets to Ukraine — but only after Sweden is allowed into NATO.

headline: House Speaker, Ukraine War, Border Wall: Trump’s Influence Reaches a Post-Presidency Peak
abstract: A Republican leadership vacuum has allowed the former president to exert power over his party — and in the country — in a way that lacks much historical precedent.
lead_paragraph: From a House leadership contest to the southwestern border and a foreign war, Donald J. Trump’s influence this week seemed to pervade the nation’s politics more than it has since the first weeks after his exit from the White House.

headline: The N.Y.C. Subway Is No Longer Broke. Can It Buy Rider Happiness?
abstract: For as long as many New Yorkers can remember, the M.T.A. has needed more money. Now its budget is finally whole, and the pressure for good service is on.
lead_paragraph: It was one of New York City’s most enduring crises: For decades, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority had warned that it was teetering on the brink of financial ruin.

headline: The Narrative of Sam Bankman-Fried and More: The Week in Reporter Reads
abstract: Articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
lead_paragraph: This weekend, listen to a collection of articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.

headline: Narges Mohammadi, Iranian Rights Activist, Receives Nobel Peace Prize
abstract: Ms. Mohammadi, currently held in Tehran’s notorious Evin Prison, has pushed for peaceful change in Iran for 30 years, with a focus on women’s equality.
lead_paragraph: Narges Mohammadi, Iran’s most prominent human rights activist and an inmate in the country’s notorious Evin Prison, was awarded the 2023 Nobel Peace Prize on Friday, in an effort by the Norwegian Nobel Committee to support women’s rights in Iran.

headline: 18 Migrants Killed in Bus Crash in Mexico
abstract: State officials in Mexico said that the bus was transporting 55 people, many of them believed to be from Venezuela.
lead_paragraph: A bus carrying dozens of mostly Venezuelan migrants crashed in southern Mexico on Friday, killing 18 people and injuring  29 others, officials said.

headline: Gary Wang, an FTX Founder, Says Sam Bankman-Fried Steered Misuse of Funds
abstract: Mr. Wang is one of three key witnesses who pleaded guilty and agreed to cooperate against Mr. Bankman-Fried, the onetime crypto mogul on trial for fraud.
lead_paragraph: Gary Wang, a former top executive of the failed FTX cryptocurrency exchange, testified that Sam Bankman-Fried, the company’s founder, was the final decision maker at the firm and directed a closely related hedge fund to misuse as it pleased billions of dollars in money from FTX customers.

headline: How Do Americans Feel About Politics? ‘Disgust Isn’t a Strong Enough Word’
abstract: Voters’ broad discontent with disarray in Washington transcends political parties, race, age and geography.
lead_paragraph: Whitney Smith’s phone buzzed with a text from her mother, alerting her to the latest can-you-believe-it mess in Washington: “Far right ousted the House speaker. Total chaos now.”

headline: Schumer Leads Bipartisan Trip to China Amid Tensions
abstract: Among the issues the Senate majority leader said he hoped to address with top Chinese officials were economic reciprocity and fentanyl.
lead_paragraph: Senator Chuck Schumer, Democrat of New York and the majority leader, is leading a bipartisan congressional delegation on Friday to China, where the group plans to meet with top government and business leaders at a time of rising tensions between the United States and Beijing.

headline: U.A.W. Cites Progress in Talks and Holds Off Expanding Strikes
abstract: The United Automobile Workers reported improved wage offers from the automakers and a concession from General Motors on workers at battery factories.
lead_paragraph: The United Automobile Workers union said on Friday that it had made progress in its negotiations with Ford Motor, General Motors and Stellantis, the parent of Chrysler, and would not expand the strikes against the companies that began three weeks ago.

headline: My Husband Is Facing Dementia. Can I Help Him End His Life?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on how to assist a spouse in the midst of a life-or-death dilemma.
lead_paragraph: I’m in my early 70s, and I’m married to a man in his 60s. My husband’s father struggled with Alzheimer’s for almost a dozen years before he died. It was incredibly hard on everyone involved. And now my husband is in the midst of his own health crisis. He has had some significant cognitive decline in the past two years, which affects his ability to function to his satisfaction. He is constantly looking for his phone or iPad. He gets lost while driving. He sometimes asks me to help him send a text or email because he can’t remember how to do it. This causes him so much shame. He says he no longer belongs in this world. His dysfunction reminds him of his father’s decline, and he doesn’t want to put himself or others through that pain.

headline: In Argentina, the U.S. Dollar Could Soon Become King
abstract: The leader in the country’s presidential race wants to ditch the peso, but dollarization has big risks.
lead_paragraph: Americans complain that inflation has eroded the value of their money, but the U.S. dollar looks lovely to the people of Argentina, where consumer prices rose 124 percent in August from a year earlier. The threat of hyperinflation has become a central issue in the presidential election on Oct. 22, which The Times has described as “a new test of the strength of the far right around the world.” The leading candidate in the race, which could go to a November runoff, is a radical libertarian who promises to bring rising prices under control by getting rid of the peso and fully dollarizing the Argentine economy.

headline: Am I Still Contagious?
abstract: We’re entering the germiest time of year. Here’s how to navigate eight of the most insidious and infectious illnesses.
lead_paragraph: We’re entering the germiest time of year. Here’s how to navigate eight of the most insidious and infectious illnesses.

headline: The Blast That Wiped Out a Family and Left Rows of Empty Homes
abstract: A missile strike on the Ukrainian village of Hroza killed at least 52 people, including every known member of one immediate family. As much as a third of the population was killed in the strike. “Everybody died,” one resident said.
lead_paragraph: Wreaths and a yellow-and-blue Ukrainian flag still festooned the freshly cut grave in a village cemetery.

headline: Ellsworth Johnson, Last Survivor of a Secret Army Unit, Dies at 100
abstract: During World War II, he parachuted into France and China as part of a special operations group on missions for the Office of Strategic Services, precursor of the C.I.A.
lead_paragraph: Ellsworth Johnson, an American medic who parachuted into enemy-occupied France and China during World War II and was believed to be the last surviving member of an Operations Group that spawned today’s Green Berets, died on Sept. 30 in Zeeland, Mich. He was 100.

headline: The Many Lives of Tomato Pie
abstract: It may look a little different across cities in the Northeast, but this Italian American staple is always an exercise in restraint.
lead_paragraph: On the website for Frank Pepe Pizzeria Napoletana in New Haven, Conn., ordering the “Original Tomato Pie” is accompanied by a warning: “By selecting this, you are acknowledging that this pie has no Mozzarella on it.”

headline: How Do I Pay for College?
abstract: Answers to your questions about one of the biggest challenges facing students.
lead_paragraph: Answers to your questions about one of the biggest challenges facing students.

headline: How Biden’s Promises to Reverse Trump’s Immigration Policies Crumbled
abstract: President Biden has tried to contain a surge of migration by embracing, or at least tolerating, some of his predecessor’s approaches.
lead_paragraph: Immigration was dead simple when Joseph R. Biden Jr. was campaigning for president: It was an easy way to attack Donald J. Trump as a racist, and it helped to rally Democrats with the promise of a more humane border policy.

headline: Baseball’s Mets Investigation Will Seek to Answer What Steve Cohen Knew
abstract: The league is looking into whether the team, which Mr. Cohen bought three years ago and has spent lavishly on, violated rules regarding its injury list.
lead_paragraph: Major League Baseball, which is investigating whether the Mets’ front office cheated by putting healthy players on the injured list, will examine whether the team’s owner, Steven A. Cohen, knew or should have known if his team was breaking the rules, according to two people familiar with the matter.

headline: Kaiser Permanente Workers Near End of Strike Without a Deal
abstract: Friday was the third day of a walkout for thousands of health care employees. No new contract talks were scheduled until next week.
lead_paragraph: Kaiser Permanente health care workers were finishing a three-day strike on Friday, and were expected to return to work early Saturday morning without a new contract.

headline: More Brokerages Leave Powerful Realtor Group
abstract: Re/Max and Anywhere Real Estate, a brokerage franchiser, will no longer require agents to belong to the National Association of Realtors, as part of agreements to settle two class-action lawsuits.
lead_paragraph: Several of the country’s largest real estate brokerages, including Coldwell Banker, Century 21 Real Estate, Sotheby’s International Realty and Re/Max, are severing their allegiance to the National Association of Realtors, a powerful trade organization whose grip on the real estate industry appears to be loosening.

headline: Former U.S. Soldier Is Accused of Trying to Give Classified Secrets to China
abstract: Joseph D. Schmidt, who served in a military intelligence battalion, was arrested this week in San Francisco after relocating to Hong Kong since 2020.
lead_paragraph: A former U.S. Army soldier who fled to Hong Kong has been charged with trying to deliver classified secrets to the Chinese government, according to federal court documents unsealed on Friday.

headline: Flashback: Your Weekly History Quiz, October 8, 2023
abstract: Can you sort 8 historical events? The development of dating, mRNA and The Supremes.
lead_paragraph: Can you sort 8 historical events? The development of dating, mRNA and The Supremes.

headline: Russell Batiste Jr., the Drumming Heartbeat of New Orleans, Dies at 57
abstract: A pyrotechnic funk and R&B mainstay, he was a vital figure in his home city as a member of one of its celebrated musical dynasties.
lead_paragraph: Russell Batiste Jr., a pyrotechnic drummer and scion of one of New Orleans’s most celebrated musical dynasties, whose furious style and genre-busting approach provided the rhythmic pulse for bands like the Meters and Vida Blue and musical artists like Harry Connick Jr., died on Sept. 30 at his home in LaPlace, La., outside New Orleans. He was 57.

headline: Presley Highlights Medicaid in Campaign to Unseat Mississippi’s G.O.P. Governor
abstract: Brandon Presley is using Medicaid expansion as a wedge issue in his challenge to Gov. Tate Reeves of Mississippi.
lead_paragraph: The Mississippi governor’s race is surprisingly close, given how deeply red the state is. A key reason, at least according to the Democratic challenger Brandon Presley, is Medicaid.

headline: Crocs Cowboy Boots? ‘Don’t Overthink It.’
abstract: The company sure didn’t when it was developing its mutant cowboy boots, the brand’s latest attempt to create a wearable meme.
lead_paragraph: John Wayne never dreamed of this kind of ventilation.

headline: Judge Allows Oklahoma Ban on Transition Care for Minors to Take Effect
abstract: A federal judge in Oklahoma denied a request to temporarily block the state’s law banning transition care for transgender minors.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge in Oklahoma denied a request on Thursday to temporarily block a state law banning gender transition care for those under 18. The law, which also makes it a felony crime for a medical professional to provide the care, goes into effect immediately.

headline: U.S. Job Growth Surges Past Expectations
abstract: Also, Narges Mohammadi wins the Nobel Peace Prize. Here’s the latest at the end of Friday.
lead_paragraph: American employers added 336,000 jobs last month, according to government data released today. The increase was almost double what economists projected, signaling once again that the labor market, and the broader U.S. economy, is surprisingly resilient.

headline: A Jack-o’-lantern by Any Other Name, Lewis Is Defining Halloween
abstract: The towering decoration from Target, which has become a must-have among Halloween fans, will sass you.
lead_paragraph: He stands eight feet tall and is shrouded in a black, gauzy robe, with his monstrous, orange hands open in a welcoming gesture. His toothy grin, cloaked under a hood, is indiscernible.

headline: As Venezuelans Face Deportation, Many Still Seek to Enter the U.S.
abstract: The attempt to reduce unlawful crossings at the southern border will not deter Venezuelan migrants from traveling north, advocates say.
lead_paragraph: Carolina Urribarrí’s mother was distressed when she called her daughter on Friday morning. “You can’t leave! They’re going to send you back!” she yelled. She had seen a video on TikTok — the United States was going to start deporting Venezuelans who entered the country illegally.

headline: Why Does the Nobel Committee Overlook Saudi Women Activists?
abstract: Political calculations should not keep others from joining Narges Mohammadi of Iran.
lead_paragraph: This column has been updated.

headline: Biden, the Border, and Why a New Wall Is Going Up
abstract: The Biden administration’s decision to add to the border wall is a confusing one. And the president has insisted that he does not think the new wall will be effective.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration said on Thursday that it would build up to 20 miles of border barriers authorized during the Trump administration in Texas’ Rio Grande Valley.

headline: For Biden’s Dog, a Belated Exile: ‘How Many Bites Does It Take?’
abstract: The end of a pet’s troubled term in the White House hints at the complicated dynamics inside one of the world’s most exclusive mansions.
lead_paragraph: If you want a friend in Washington, get a dog, Harry S. Truman supposedly once said. But what if the dog is not all that friendly?

headline: Review: In ‘Bite Me,’ Taking Aim at Familiar Teenage Tropes
abstract: Eliana Pipes’s new play is too pat to convincingly explore the societal imbalances resulting from race, class and gender.
lead_paragraph: Good girls falling for bad boys is a cornerstone of high school dramas. Usually the story goes something like this: She sticks to the rules while he breaks them, and their meeting inspires a mutual coming-of-age.

headline: 115 Decaying Bodies Found in ‘Horrific’ Scene at Funeral Home, Officials Say
abstract: A smell coming from a rural Colorado facility that had promised “green” burials led to the “very disturbing” discovery, a sheriff said.
lead_paragraph: A foul smell led investigators to find at least 115 decaying bodies at a funeral home in rural Colorado that had promised “green” burials, officials said on Friday, describing the scene as “horrific.”

headline: Mike Lindell’s Lawyers Say He Owes ‘Millions’ in Fees
abstract: The disclosure, made in a court filing this week, is a sign that the pillow magnate and leading supporter of the election denial movement is facing financial stress.
lead_paragraph: For nearly three years, the pillow entrepreneur Mike Lindell has been one of the leading financial supporters of the election denial movement, a tireless promoter of false claims that Donald J. Trump won the 2020 election and of efforts to change how Americans vote.

headline: Days Before a Vote, Republicans Feud Over How to Choose a New Speaker
abstract: A quiet fight over the rules highlights the depth of G.O.P. divisions. It could set the stage for a bruising election to choose a successor to the party’s ousted speaker.
lead_paragraph: House Republicans, divided and demoralized after the ouster of their speaker this week, are now quietly feuding over how to elect a successor.

headline: 13-Year-Old Boy Stabbed to Death on City Bus on Staten Island
abstract: The police said the teenager was killed during an argument on the bus that may have been gang-related.
lead_paragraph: A 13-year-old boy died after he was stabbed Friday afternoon on a city bus on Staten Island, and another teenager is suspected of killing him, the police said.

headline: Family Sentenced for Selling Bleach as ‘Miracle’ Covid-19 Cure
abstract: Mark Grenon, 66, and three sons sold $1 million of an industrial bleach solution that they claimed to be a cure-all, prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: A Florida man and three sons who used a business masquerading as a church to sell more than $1 million of a deadly bleach solution that they claimed was a “miracle” cure for Covid-19 and other diseases were each sentenced on Friday to several years in prison, federal prosecutors in Miami said.

headline: As Wisconsin Supreme Court Takes Up Maps Case, Impeachment Threat Looms
abstract: Justice Janet Protasiewicz’s decision to participate in a case challenging state legislative district maps could spur Republicans to impeach her.
lead_paragraph: The liberal majority on the Wisconsin Supreme Court on Friday agreed to hear a case challenging the state’s Republican-drawn legislative districts, a decision that could spur impeachment proceedings against a newly elected justice, Janet Protasiewicz, who refused to recuse herself from the case.

headline: Get Wildly Enthusiastic
abstract: You’ll need a can-do spirit to navigate this themeless from Alex Vratsanos.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — There is a lot going on in this crossword, the first themeless puzzle from Alex Vratsanos for The New York Times since 2018. That grid from five years ago was memorable for its interesting geometry; the thrill today comes more from the clues and the entries. There’s great trivia — much of it ingeniously concealed — and a neat bit of letter play involving the last three letters of the alphabet.

headline: From the Fringe to the Center of the G.O.P., Jordan Remains a Hard-Liner
abstract: Once a tormentor of the Republican Party’s speakers, the Ohio congressman and unapologetic right-wing pugilist has become a potential speaker himself.
lead_paragraph: As a co-founder of the conservative House Freedom Caucus, Representative Jim Jordan, Republican of Ohio, once antagonized his party’s leadership so mercilessly that former Speaker John A. Boehner, whom he helped chase from his position, branded him a “legislative terrorist.”

headline: Suspect in Killings at Colorado Supermarket Is Mentally Competent, Judge Says
abstract: The man is accused of murdering 10 people in Boulder, Colo., in 2021.
lead_paragraph: A judge ruled on Friday that the man charged with fatally shooting 10 people at a supermarket in Boulder, Colo., in 2021 is mentally competent to stand trial, court records show, a reversal of a prior ruling.

headline: Quotation of the Day: This Bachelor Has Seniors Hooked
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, October 7, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “Love is blind, but marriage is an eye-opener.”

headline: Corrections: Oct. 7, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Oct. 7, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Page 6 this weekend about a new musical inspired by the singer Alicia Keys’s life misspells the name of her skin care line. It is Keys Soulcare, not Key SoulCare.

headline: Here is what to know about the surprise attack on Israel.
abstract: Sirens sounded across southern and central Israel early Saturday as salvos of rockets hit Israeli cities and gunmen crossed the border from Gaza.
lead_paragraph: Fighting continued into the evening on Saturday in one of the broadest invasions of Israeli territory in 50 years, as Palestinian militants from Gaza fired another round of rockets at Israel’s central heartland, including Tel Aviv, and Israel worked to clear militants from Israeli towns and retaliated with huge strikes on Gazan cities.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: How S. Epatha Merkerson, Actor, Spends Her Sundays
abstract: Known for “Law & Order” and now starring in “Chicago Med,” the actor can be found most Sundays at home in her favorite place: a bedroom she converted into a quilting studio.
lead_paragraph: The actor S. Epatha Merkerson is perhaps best known for her 17 consecutive seasons as Lt. Anita van Buren on the “Law & Order” franchise. But she has held many stage, film and TV roles over her nearly 50-year career, ranging from “Pee-wee’s Playhouse” to “Lincoln” and “The Piano Lesson,” and has won an Emmy, a Golden Globe and several NAACP Image Awards.

headline: Migrant Crisis Tests New Yorkers Who Thought They Supported Immigration
abstract: As the city’s resources strain under the influx of thousands of migrants, New Yorkers are still resolutely in favor of welcoming newcomers. But for how long?
lead_paragraph: Carin Bail said she was walking with a friend in Queens this spring when they stopped to talk with a woman who was holding a baby and crying. The woman had just arrived at a nearby migrant shelter, she explained in Spanish, and her baby would not eat the food there.

headline: Nicole Scherzinger as Norma Desmond? Yes, There’s a Connection.
abstract: It’s been cathartic to “create art from places of torment,” the singer-actor said ahead of the opening of “Sunset Boulevard” in London.
lead_paragraph: Nicole Scherzinger was exhausted. It was a week since Jamie Lloyd’s new production of Andrew Lloyd Webber’s “Sunset Boulevard” had begun performances, and Scherzinger was playing the lead role of Norma Desmond — the forgotten star of the silent screen whose attempt at a comeback doesn’t end well.

headline: It’s Not Your Imagination. Summers Are Getting Hotter.
abstract: As the planet has warmed, summer temperatures have shifted toward more extreme heat.
lead_paragraph: As the planet has warmed, summer temperatures have shifted toward more extreme heat.

headline: Ann Patchett Isn’t Parting With WordPerfect
abstract: The best-selling novelist refuses to yield when it comes to writing software, but she’s had a bit of a change of heart on Barnes & Noble.
lead_paragraph: Ann Patchett’s new book is called “Tom Lake” for some of the same reasons her previous novel was called “The Dutch House”: She thought it was clear, memorable and would sell well in bookstores like the one she owns in Nashville. It’s the kind of calculation that may have helped both books become best-sellers but that Patchett once considered a concession.

headline: When Did Cashing Savings Bonds Become So Impossible?
abstract: Citing potential fraud, banks are making it increasingly difficult to pay out savings bonds. An unlikely beneficiary is the federal government.
lead_paragraph: Hoping to cash in a paper savings bond that’s been lying around for a few decades? Set aside a lot of time for disappointment.

headline: A New Mother Finds Solace From the Patriarchy — in Sex Work
abstract: The heroine of Ainslie Hogarth’s “Normal Women” is so desperate to escape the confines of conventional, upper-middle-class womanhood that she turns to a yoga studio that looks a lot like a cult.
lead_paragraph: Can you return to the person you once were? Can any of us ever truly go home again? The “Motherthing” author Ainslie Hogarth’s second novel, “Normal Women,” roots around this trope of going back — to your old town and your old self — and how geography, psychology and maternity can alter your very identity.

headline: Giving a Voice to the London Readers Don’t Often Hear
abstract: While working on a new novel, “Mister, Mister,” the author Guy Gunaratne examined Britain’s political legacy, and underwent a deeply personal transformation.
lead_paragraph: Yahya Bas, the hero of Guy Gunaratne’s new novel, “Mister, Mister,” is a tricky character to pin down. Is he an idiot, poet, jihadist or all of these at once?

headline: An Officer Is Charged With Murder. Colleagues Briefly Drop Their Guns.
abstract: In Britain, where guns are rare, armed police officers have set off a debate about the extraordinary power they hold, and the extraordinary risks they face.
lead_paragraph: When England’s prosecution service announced last month that a police officer would be charged with murder after fatally shooting an unarmed Black man in London, the news was met with relief by the dead man’s family.

headline: On This Nature Preserve, Farmers Are Welcome, if They Follow the Rules
abstract: Can Europe fight the effects of extreme weather while producing enough affordable food? A model combining conservation with agriculture may offer a solution.
lead_paragraph: With cows grazing in a vast meadow surrounded by wire fencing, and with farmers checking to see how their livestock were faring under a scorching sun, it looked like a classic pastoral scene set on what was surely land dedicated to agriculture.

headline: With These Several Rings, I Thee Wed
abstract: Traveling? Completing manual labor? Mindful of safety? There are alternative rings for that.
lead_paragraph: Married people don’t always wear wedding bands or engagement rings — at least not their original ones.

headline: Human Resources, for Plants
abstract: A cadre of creative types now cares for the hundreds of thousands of corporate plants in New York City, one leaf at a time.
lead_paragraph: Felipe Gallegos used to work in fashion, designing store displays for Abercrombie & Fitch and Uniqlo. Now he spends his days with plants, helping them thrive in office buildings across New York City.

headline: A Polarized Australia Confronts ‘Trump Style Misinformation’
abstract: The reverberations from election conspiracy theories, until recently the domain of political fringes, could be acute, as witnessed by the United States and Brazil.
lead_paragraph: The ballots should, according to the official instructions, be marked with a “yes” or a “no.” A clear and legible “y” or “n” is also likely to be counted. So is a checkmark, for affirmative, but an “X” is considered too ambiguous by the authorities and does not count as a “no” vote.

headline: There’s a Dangerous Dog in My Building. What Can I Do About It?
abstract: Laws about dangerous dogs are designed to protect you, but before you involve the authorities, your condo has a duty to protect its unit owners.
lead_paragraph: Q: There is a vicious dog in my Philadelphia condo building. The dog has attacked at least two building employees, leaving bite marks and drawing blood. It also lunged at a resident who was able to jump out of the way. Each time, the dog was leashed. The owners have been asked by the condo board to muzzle the dog, but it doesn’t wear one, and the condo board hasn’t imposed fines. I reported the situation to the police, to no avail. I’m concerned that someone may be mauled by this dog before long. What do you recommend?

headline: Interested in an Electric Vehicle? Consider Buying Used.
abstract: The prices of used battery-powered models have fallen sharply, as the supply of cars and trucks has improved.
lead_paragraph: If you’re in the market for an electric vehicle, the time might be right to consider a used one.

headline: The Hidden Places Where You Find Your People
abstract: An artist reflects on the pockets of community New Yorkers carve out in a city of millions.

headline: How the Costs of Car Ownership Add Up
abstract: Pandemic disruptions drove the expenses associated with owning a car through the roof, creating a financial burden that many drivers didn’t bargain for.
lead_paragraph: Pandemic disruptions drove the expenses associated with owning a car through the roof, creating a financial burden that many drivers didn’t bargain for.

headline: In Provence, Winemakers Confront Climate Change
abstract: Centuries-old varieties are being altered by weather patterns, threatening the economics of businesses in one of the world’s most important regions.
lead_paragraph: “You can taste the climate change.”

headline: Harry Smith Was a Culture-Altering Shaman. Can the Whitney Contain Him?
abstract: A solo show takes on the legacy of the painter, folk musicologist, filmmaker, obsessive collector and underground legend. It also hints at what has been lost.
lead_paragraph: “Far-out” is an accurate, but inadequate, descriptor for the high-flying (and often plain high) cultural magus named Harry Smith (1923-91). And the label “polymath,” too, while true, falls short for this innovative painter-filmmaker-collagist-musicologist-designer-scholar-curator-collector/hoarder, whose very first and very strange (it could not be otherwise) institutional solo is at the Whitney Museum of American Art.
