abstract: Zachary David Levy’s puzzle could be the next big thing.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Tropical Storm Lidia Moves Inland in Mexico, Killing 1
abstract: The “extremely dangerous” storm made landfall on the country’s west-central coast Tuesday evening.
lead_paragraph: Lidia remained dangerous even as it transitioned to a tropical storm late Tuesday, killing at least one person as it moved further inland from the west coast of Mexico and spreading life-threatening winds and heavy rains that unleashed some flooding, forecasters and officials said.

headline: Israel and Hamas Battle Around Gaza as Netanyahu Warns of ‘Long and Difficult War’
abstract: A senior Israeli defense official said that an early estimate showed about 700 Israelis were believed to be dead, and Gaza officials said more than 400 Palestinians have been killed.
lead_paragraph: Israeli troops fought to expel Palestinian militants from Israeli territory for a second day on Sunday, battling in firefights between homes, ducking under rocket fire and striking Gazan cities from the sky in retaliation for the militants’ assault, which officials described as the worst attack on Israel in decades.

headline: Hamas Attack Raises Questions Over an Israeli Intelligence Failure
abstract: American and Israeli officials said none of Israel’s intelligence services had specific warning that Hamas was preparing a sophisticated assault.
lead_paragraph: The devastating surprise attack by Hamas on Saturday represented an equally stunning intelligence failure by Israel that involved undetected warnings, overwhelmed missile defenses and a slow response by apparently unprepared military forces, former and current U.S. officials said.

headline: U.S. Continues Push for Saudi-Israel Ties Even as War With Hamas Begins
abstract: As Israel prepares an offensive in Gaza, President Biden and his aides are gauging whether Saudi officials remain interested in opening up diplomatic relations.
lead_paragraph: President Biden’s top aides scrambled on Sunday to reaffirm their commitment to the idea of potential normalization of diplomatic ties between Saudi Arabia and Israel, even as Israel prepares for the start of a full-scale war against Palestinian militants.

headline: ‘Everyone Was Surprised’: Palestinians in Gaza React to Conflict
abstract: While recovering from Israel’s retaliatory airstrikes, Gaza residents expressed surprise and shock at the brazen attack by Hamas on Israeli soil.
lead_paragraph: While recovering from Israel’s retaliatory airstrikes, Gaza residents expressed surprise and shock at the brazen attack by Hamas on Israeli soil.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Steve Young, Girls’ Flag Football, and Finding the Next Calling
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, October 9, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “We talk about inclusion a lot now. This is what it feels like and looks like. And it feels like we should have been doing this for 30 years.”

headline: No Corrections: Oct. 9, 2023
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Oct. 9, 2023.
lead_paragraph: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

headline: Green Energy Casts a Shadow Over a Cherished English Landscape
abstract: Residents of East Anglia fear that planned power lines for offshore wind projects will blight their rural idyll.
lead_paragraph: Charlotte Banks lives in a house that just about anyone would envy. Hempnalls Hall, a pink structure dating to the 16th century, rises above an even older moat, dug to keep marauders away in ancient times.

headline: Monday Briefing
abstract: The Hamas-Israel war has entered a new phase.
lead_paragraph: For two days, Israeli troops have fought to expel Palestinian militants from Israeli territory, battling in firefights between homes, ducking under rocket fire and striking Gazan cities from the sky. In what officials described as the worst attack on Israel in decades, militants on Saturday infiltrated more than 20 Israeli towns and army bases. Read our timeline.

headline: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Saturday Night Live’ and ‘Shining Vale’
abstract: The NBC skit show starts its 49th season, and the Starz show returns.
lead_paragraph: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Oct. 9-15. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: We Just Saw What the World Is About to Become
abstract: The conflict over Nagorno-Karabakh is a harbinger of global disorder.
lead_paragraph: The history of Armenians in Nagorno-Karabakh was ended in the old manner of conflict resolution: siege, conquest, expulsion. After a 10-month blockade, Azerbaijan launched an attack on Sept. 19, claiming the enclave in a day and causing nearly the entire ethnic Armenian population to flee. Give war a chance, as the saying goes.

headline: Chemena Kamali Appointed Creative Director of Chloé
abstract: The decision by the French fashion house is the latest in a string of hirings and firings at the top of the luxury industry.
lead_paragraph: Ten days after the designer Gabriela Hearst presented her last show for Chloé at Paris Fashion Week, the French fashion house confirmed the appointment of her successor, Chemena Kamali.

headline: A former Israeli military spokesman paints a grim picture of the fighting ahead.
abstract: Lt. Col. Jonathan Conricus called the situation “dire” on Sunday and said that the military had sent at least 100,000 reservists to southern Israel near the border with Gaza.
lead_paragraph: A former spokesman for Israel’s military gave a blunt assessment of the situation in Israel on Sunday, warning that it would take hours or longer to reclaim all the towns in southern Israel where the military was still battling Hamas militants.

headline: Oil Prices Were Going Down Again. Then War Started in the Middle East.
abstract: After flirting with $100 a barrel this summer, crude prices had fallen significantly in the past week on the expectation that demand was waning.
lead_paragraph: After a surge this summer when oil prices approached $100 a barrel, the cost of crude was tumbling again. Now a Middle East war has sent it right back up.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Hype Candidate vs. Reality
abstract: Some candidates sound promising on paper but fall short when put to the test.
lead_paragraph: Some candidates sound promising on paper but fall short when put to the test.

headline: A Fake Loan Could Mean Real Trouble for George Santos
abstract: Representative George Santos was seemingly implicated in a fraudulent loan scheme that his treasurer admitted in her guilty plea.
lead_paragraph: Of all of the revelations to emerge from the federal prosecution of Representative George Santos’s treasurer, the most outrageous is the existence of a $500,000 loan that did not in fact exist.

headline: Parking in New York City Really Is Worse Than Ever
abstract: There are more cars but fewer available spots on the street. There are fewer garages — and exorbitant prices. For city drivers, it’s a growing headache.
lead_paragraph: After his shift at his limo company ended one night this year, Arben Elezi called his wife to tell her he would be home as soon as he found a parking spot. Hours later, she called him, frantic — he was still not back. He told her to look out the window of their Upper West Side apartment.

headline: What to Know as the U.K. Appeals a Ruling on Its Rwanda Asylum Policy
abstract: Britain’s Supreme Court will determine whether the Conservative government’s plan to deport asylum seekers to Rwanda is lawful.
lead_paragraph: The British government began its appeal on Monday of an earlier court decision that determined a policy to deport asylum seekers to Rwanda was unlawful, opening the latest chapter in a legal saga that has played out since the highly contentious plan was announced in 2022.

headline: El Anatsui Builds Monumental Art From Daily Life
abstract: As his newest sculptures fill Tate Modern’s Turbine Hall, the Ghanaian artist is returning to his roots and thinking about his legacy.
lead_paragraph: It’s one of the great origin stories in contemporary art, a flash of instinct that would revolutionize a field. In 1998, El Anatsui was walking around Nsukka, Nigeria, and noticed a bag of aluminum bottle caps by the roadside.

headline: Single Winning Ticket Sold for $1.76 Billion Powerball Jackpot
abstract: The winning ticket was sold in California, where another $1 billion-plus jackpot was won this summer.
lead_paragraph: One of the largest Powerball jackpots ever has been won, the lottery group said Wednesday night. At $1.765 billion, it was the second-largest jackpot ever in the United States.

headline: Israeli Father Tells of Moment His Wife and Children Became Hostages
abstract: Yoni Asher says his wife and two daughters, ages 5 and 3, were kidnapped from an Israeli border town by gunmen on Saturday and taken to Gaza.
lead_paragraph: Yoni Asher’s nightmare began early on Saturday morning during a phone call with his wife, Doron Asher Katz.

headline: Taking a Stand on Native American Rights
abstract: New works of nonfiction and fiction transcend stereotypes, and connect a wealth of ideas and facts for young readers.
lead_paragraph: Over the last 25 years, children’s books by Native American authors and illustrators have presented a vibrant and expansive view of American Indians and America. Joseph Bruchac has been telling Native American stories since the 1970s, helping to fill the void he noticed as a child eager to read about his Abenaki heritage. With often inspired results, he has brought careful research to folk tales, biographies and novels.

headline: A Radical Queer Novel Challenges the Idea of History Itself
abstract: Justin Torres’s genre-defying new book, “Blackouts,” explores what it means to be erased and how to persist after being wiped away.
lead_paragraph: In erasure poetry, an original text is blacked out to create, or reveal, a different story embedded inside it. Whether the initial author intended this second message is irrelevant; the fact that some later poet could erase it into being is all the authority these writers need to argue that the uncovered piece was there all along. In this way, erasure poetry is much like queer history, a discipline that revolves around reading against the archive — mining biased sources for neutral facts, reading meaning into what isn’t said as much as what is, and flensing useful details off a rotten mass of lies.

headline: This Above All: My Undying Obsession With ‘Hamlet’
abstract: For one critic, every encounter with this Shakespeare play deepens her understanding of its insights into grief, family and gender.
lead_paragraph: A few weeks ago two friends and I were talking about our obsessions. One had been sleepless all week, playing the new Zelda video game with few breaks. The other revealed that she was deep into Taylor Swift. I said I had so many fandoms that I didn’t know if I could name a favorite.

headline: How Your Diet Affects Your Skin
abstract: Fruits, vegetables, dairy, soda — here’s what the evidence suggests about foods and skin health.
lead_paragraph: If you’ve ever looked in the mirror and noticed a new pimple or sallow skin, it’s natural to wonder if the food you eat is somehow responsible.

headline: Vaults, Ducts, Kitchens: Everything Must Go When a Company Moves Out
abstract: As companies reduce their office footprint to accommodate remote work, they are turning to decommissioning teams to clear out furniture, fixtures and equipment.
lead_paragraph: Wayne Horne’s job comes with many challenges. This time, the problem was a generator that was too large to fit through its existing vent.

headline: Country Roads, Coastal Views and Autumn’s Bounty in Rhode Island
abstract: The farm stands, art galleries and land-conservation efforts in the East Bay region show why fall is the golden season in the Ocean State.
lead_paragraph: “We’re growing a small business and learning as we go,” said Claire Bowen as she arranged bushels of sweet and charmingly imperfect organic apples on a late-September afternoon. “We hope to cultivate connections between local farms and local tables.”

headline: Ozempic Can’t Fix What Our Culture Has Broken
abstract: When women say that it is better to be sick and thin than healthy and fat, they are perfectly rational.
lead_paragraph: We have become fluent in the new language of pharmacology, diabetes, and weight loss. Ozempic, Wegovy and Mounjaro are part of our public lexicon. Glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) receptor agonists are lifesaving drugs, created to help the hundreds of millions of people with Type 2 diabetes and clinical obesity. They promise to rid the United States of obesity, if our country can figure out how to make the pricey fix affordable.

headline: The A.D.H.D. Drug Shortage Is Causing Real Pain
abstract: The United States cannot continue torturing people who rely on controlled substances to function.
lead_paragraph: Edward Krumpotich, a drug policy consultant based in Minnesota, was diagnosed with severe attention deficit hyperactivity disorder at age 15 — but he didn’t get help for it until he was 37. In the interim years he suffered from methamphetamine addiction, which he later realized was driven by attempts to self-medicate his untreated A.D.H.D. He attended more than 30 rehabs before one finally prescribed stimulant medication for him.

headline: Heat, High Water, Hurricanes: Schools Are Not Ready for Climate Change
abstract: A storm can last a day. But the disruption to learning can last years. As natural disasters become more common, school districts are grappling with how to adapt.
lead_paragraph: When Hurricane Michael hit the Florida Panhandle in 2018, Calhoun County schools were ravaged. Winds of 160 miles per hour destroyed an elementary school and ripped high-school bleachers from the ground.

headline: Is the Literary Hat the New Tote Bag?
abstract: For $27 (not including tax and shipping), you can own a baseball cap embroidered with the name of your favorite literary darling, too.
lead_paragraph: Zadie Smith. Elif Batuman. Joyce Carol Oates. Dionne Brand. Alice Munro. Patricia Lockwood. Olga Tokarczuk. Lydia Davis. Rachel Kushner. Deborah Levy. Rachel Cusk. Yoko Tawada. Chris Kraus. Mary Gaitskill. Sheila Heti. Fleur Jaeggy.

headline: Australia Must Finally Listen to Its Indigenous People
abstract: A referendum would give a voice to a group ignored by the Constitution.
lead_paragraph: If you found yourself in the ocher-colored sands of an Australian desert, listening to the creation stories of Indigenous elders, you would discover that these tales are as marvelous and powerful — in their telling, humanity and spirit — as the greatest dramas by Euripides and Shakespeare.

headline: Two Irish Guys in New York: Fast Friends Make Fortunate Roommates
abstract: They were relieved to find a new two-bedroom in Brooklyn, and surprised by the hearty welcome they got as the first residents in their building.
lead_paragraph: From the time Niall Dennehy arrived in New York, he was booked every night. It was because of Dublin, his hometown.

headline: Where This Summer Was Relentlessly Hot
abstract: See where temperatures around the globe in 2023 were abnormally high during the warmest summer on record.
lead_paragraph: See where temperatures around the globe in 2023 were abnormally high during the warmest summer on record.

headline: Grizzlies Are Coming to Town. Can the West Live With Them?
abstract: Montana and its neighbors are adopting new strategies to deal with the increasing number of bears and attacks on humans.
lead_paragraph: Aries, an Anatolian shepherd, warily watches a stranger approach a pen where he and other members of his family — including eight fuzzy, 2-month-old puppies — roam alongside a grunting pig and several bleating goats.

headline: Is It Still Worth Going to the Movies?
abstract: After 23 years of film criticism, I was back in front of the screen as a civilian. I had no idea what I would find.
lead_paragraph: Until this summer I hadn’t been to the movies in more than 23 years.

headline: $5 Million Homes in California
abstract: A four-bedroom cottage in Carmel, a Spanish Colonial Revival estate in Los Angeles and a two-bedroom retreat with a guesthouse in Calistoga.
lead_paragraph: This house is a few blocks from Carmel Beach and within walking distance of the Carmel Beach Walk, a hiking trail with sweeping ocean views. It is close to the Clinton Walker House, a Frank Lloyd Wright home added to the National Register of Historic Places in 1977.

headline: What Climate Change Does to My October Garden
abstract: By the time the butterflies finally arrived here, the fall wildflowers were mostly gone.
lead_paragraph: In Middle Tennessee, October is supposed to mean golden light and falling leaves and clear nights cool enough to make you spread a blanket across the foot of the bed in case the chill turns to genuine cold. October doesn’t normally bring an explosion of butterflies. The time for butterflies is September, with its mild warmth and blooming roadside flowers — snakeroot, asters, ironweed and the splendid goldenrod — all in their fullest glory.

headline: Can I Be a Feminist and Still Love Fashion?
abstract: A reader wonders whether her clothing choices help uphold rigid beauty standards for women.
lead_paragraph: This is a complicated question, but for me feminism is largely about choice: the power for women to make their own choices over their lives, bodies and future. And to decide who they want to be and how they want to look to communicate that identity to the world.

headline: What We Can Do to Make American Politics Less Dysfunctional
abstract: We need to rethink party primaries, which give our politicians all the wrong incentives.
lead_paragraph: The disarray engulfing the House of Representatives has been unprecedented, yet somehow it has also felt inevitable. No sitting speaker has ever been removed before, but the process that brought about Kevin McCarthy’s overthrow was the culmination of several related trends that have amounted to a repudiation of coalition building in American politics.

headline: The Cosmic, Outrageous, Ecstatic Truths of Werner Herzog
abstract: The filmmaker’s new memoir, “Every Man for Himself and God Against All,” prompts a critic’s incredulity.
lead_paragraph: I don’t believe a word of the filmmaker Werner Herzog’s new memoir, which bears the self-deprecating title “Every Man for Himself and God Against All.” (What is this, a Metallica album?) But then, I’m not sure we’re supposed to take much of it at face value.

headline: Russia’s Economy Is Increasingly Structured Around Its War in Ukraine
abstract: The nation’s finances have proven resilient, despite punishing sanctions, giving it leeway to pump money into its military machine.
lead_paragraph: “Everything needed for the front,” Russia’s finance minister declared, echoing a Soviet slogan from World War II as he talked about the government’s latest spending plans.

headline: Scalise, a McCarthy Rival, Seeks to Unite Republicans in Taking His Place
abstract: The second-ranking Republican, who was cut out of major decisions by the previous speaker, is pitching himself as uniquely positioned to unify the deeply divided House G.O.P.
lead_paragraph: When Harriet M. Hageman announced her 2022 primary challenge against Representative Liz Cheney of Wyoming, House Republican leaders quickly endorsed her bid to oust a colleague whose condemnations of former President Donald J. Trump had made her a pariah in her own party.

headline: Does the Supreme Court’s Cherry-Picking Inject Politics Into Judging?
abstract: By choosing among and sometimes writing the questions the court agrees to answer, recent studies say, the justices have distorted the judicial process.
lead_paragraph: We say that the Supreme Court decides cases, but that is not correct. It picks isolated questions to answer, often choosing among ones proposed by the parties or writing ones of its own.

headline: The Republican Meltdown Shows No Sign of Cooling Off
abstract: A basic rule of Trumpism is that he always gets worse. And the world isn’t getting any better, either.
lead_paragraph: Gail Collins: Bret, when we started our conversations, you generously agreed to stick to domestic issues. I’ve always steered away from commenting on foreign affairs because I have so very many colleagues who know so very much more about them than I do.

headline: Across the Mideast, a Surge of Support for Palestinians as War Erupts in Gaza
abstract: The escalation laid bare the limitations of diplomatic deals between Israel and Arab governments as long as the underlying conflict continues. “We told you so,” a Saudi scholar said.
lead_paragraph: When the United Arab Emirates, Bahrain and Morocco announced that they were establishing relations with Israel in 2020, Emirati officials said the deals were symbols of peace and tolerance, while then President Donald J. Trump declared “the dawn of a new Middle East.”

headline: Metro Bank, a Troubled U.K. Lender, Raises Money to Shore Up Finances
abstract: After days of talks the bank said it had raised extra money from shareholders and bondholders and would refinance a big chunk of debt.
lead_paragraph: Metro Bank, an upstart British lender, said on Sunday that it has raised 325 million pounds, or $395 million, in new capital to help ease regulators’ worries about its financial health.

headline: War in Israel
abstract: Palestinian militants launched the biggest attack against Israel in 50 years, prompting intense retaliation.
lead_paragraph: Warning: this episode contains descriptions of violence.

headline: Claudia Goldin Wins Nobel in Economics for Studying Women in the Work Force
abstract: Her research uncovered the reasons for gender gaps in labor force participation and earnings. She is the third woman to win the prize.
lead_paragraph: The Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences was awarded on Monday to Claudia Goldin, a Harvard professor, for advancing the world’s understanding of women’s progress in the work force.

headline: The Global Context of the Hamas-Israel War
abstract: The Hamas attack is a sign of a new world order.
lead_paragraph: Russia has started the largest war in Europe since World War II.

headline: ‘The Mill’ Review: A Cog in the Machine
abstract: This spare dystopian thriller offers a serviceable but mostly unimaginative satire of a capitalist nightmare.
lead_paragraph: If we as a nation are reaching an increasingly critical juncture over the fate of labor, “The Mill” is a film that appears startlingly well-suited for the moment. The dystopian thriller, directed by Sean King O’Grady, almost literally translates the idea of cog in a machine, following Joe (Lil Rel Howery), a middle manager within a major corporation called Mallard, as he mysteriously wakes up in an open-air prison and is forced to push a grist mill hundreds of times, 18 hours a day. He doesn’t know how he got there, only that, as a neighboring prisoner who talks to him through a vent explains, you better keep working or get “terminated.”

headline: U.S. Dysfunction Clouds Economic Diplomacy Efforts
abstract: Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen calls on Congress to authorize more economic support for Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: As Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen arrives in Morocco this week to meet with her international counterparts, she will be representing a nation that has led the world’s post-pandemic economic recovery but is now struggling with potentially destabilizing political dysfunction.

headline: Tallying the Costs of the Israel-Gaza War
abstract: The price of crude oil has risen and global markets are under pressure as the death toll exceeds 1,100 and Israel begins a “complete siege” of the Gaza Strip.
lead_paragraph: More than 1,100 are dead as Israel fights to drive out Palestinian militants from towns near the Gaza Strip, two days after hundreds of Israelis were killed or captured in surprise attacks. Israel just ordered a “complete siege” of Gaza, as rockets continue to land on both sides of the border and Israeli forces prepare for a potential ground invasion.

headline: Chevron Shuts Down Natural Gas Platform Near Gaza Strip
abstract: The U.S. energy company temporarily closed operations at its Tamar natural gas field, which is about 12 miles from the Gaza Strip, at Israel’s request.
lead_paragraph: Chevron, which has substantial natural gas investments in the eastern Mediterranean, said on Monday that it had temporarily shut down operations at one of its major natural gas platforms off Israel’s coast.

headline: Nikki Haley Raises $11 Million, Battling With DeSantis to Take On Trump
abstract: The former South Carolina governor has made gains in recent months — in fund-raising and polling — that have helped her compete for the No. 2 spot in the primary field.
lead_paragraph: Nikki Haley, the former governor of South Carolina, has ramped up her fund-raising in recent months, a sign that her performance in the early presidential debates may have invigorated her 2024 candidacy.

headline: Zelensky Compares Assault by Hamas on Israel to Moscow’s Invasion of Ukraine
abstract: Volodymyr Zelensky, the Ukraine president, told a NATO meeting that “terror will have no allies” if the world unites against acts of aggression.
lead_paragraph: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine on Monday condemned Hamas for its surprise assault on Israel and likened the attack to Russia’s invasion of his own country. In a speech to NATO, he also criticized Iran for its support of Hamas and Moscow.

headline: The First Magazine for Black Children Is Revisited, Its Message Still Resonant
abstract: An anthology that combines new work with selections from The Brownies’ Book, a children’s magazine launched by W.E.B. Du Bois, is bringing its mission to bear in a new national context.
lead_paragraph: The first magazine created especially for Black children, The Brownies’ Book, debuted in January 1920, its pages filled with the voices of children and their parents, of poets and college coeds, biographers and advice columnists, schoolgirls and scholars, spinners of fables and gatherers of folk tales, and a panoply of Black figures staking a claim in the history of a country that would rather not acknowledge them. It brimmed with playful illustrations, photographs, and travelers’ sketches. On the cover was a portrait of an adolescent ballet dancer, pearls at her neck, a crown on her head, arms aloft; a picture of self-confidence and elation.

headline: Xi-Schumer Meeting Raises Hopes of Smoother U.S.-China Relations
abstract: Mr. Xi said there were “1,000 reasons” to make the relationship work. Earlier, the Senate majority leader had criticized Beijing for its response to the attack by Hamas in Israel.
lead_paragraph: China’s top leader, Xi Jinping, met with Senator Chuck Schumer, the majority leader, in Beijing on Monday and expressed hopes of “peaceful coexistence” between China and the United States, even as escalating violence in the Middle East threatens to deepen a wedge between the two powers.

headline: Do You Know These Science Fiction Novels That Became TV Shows?
abstract: Try this short quiz to test your knowledge of books that found a new life on television.
lead_paragraph: Try this short quiz to test your knowledge of books that found a new life on television.

headline: Hamburg Airport Suspends Flights Over Threat to Iranian Plane
abstract: All flights were suspended for more than an hour, but after what security officials said was a vigorous search, the airport reopened.
lead_paragraph: The authorities at the Hamburg Airport in Germany suspended all flights for roughly 90 minutes on Monday after receiving what they called “a credible threat” that mentioned a specific flight coming from Tehran.

headline: Israeli Airstrikes Hit Marketplace and Mosques in Gaza, Killing Dozens
abstract: The strikes also hit two hospitals, schools and infrastructure, the U.N. said.
lead_paragraph: Israeli airstrikes pounded Gaza on Monday, flattening mosques over the heads of worshipers, wiping away a busy marketplace full of shoppers and killing entire families, witnesses and authorities in Gaza said.

headline: Turmoil Engulfs Canadian Art Museums Seeking to Shed Colonial Past
abstract: As Canada reckons with its colonial history, a push to “decolonize” museums has rocked its National Gallery and other museums.
lead_paragraph: One of the fiercest fights in the past year in Canada has taken place not in a hockey rink, but inside the stately facades of its national art museum.

headline: Yewande Komolafe’s Five-Star Sheet-Pan Gochujang Chicken
abstract: “Trying not to hyperbolize, but this may be the single most delicious recipe from this site I’ve ever cooked.”
lead_paragraph: I’m not one for PSLs or decorative gourds, but I did go completely nuts last weekend at my local farmers’ market with the first autumn squashes. A copious haul of shapely butternuts and striped delicatas — that’s my seasonal home décor.

headline: Teen Depression Rose Sharply During the Pandemic, but Treatment Didn’t Follow
abstract: Approximately 20 percent of teenagers had major depressive disorder in 2021, but less than half who needed treatment received it, a new study found.
lead_paragraph: Approximately 20 percent of adolescents had symptoms of major depressive disorder in 2021 — the first full calendar year of the pandemic — but less than half who needed treatment received it, according to a new study.

headline: U.A.W. Workers at Mack Truck Go on Strike
abstract: The strike at the truck manufacturer by 4,000 members of the United Automobile Workers comes in the middle of the union’s strikes at three large U.S. car companies.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 4,000 members of the United Automobile Workers union went on strike against Mack Trucks on Monday after rejecting a tentative contract that union’s leaders had worked out with the company.

headline: Vermont Utility Plans to End Outages by Giving Customers Batteries
abstract: Green Mountain Power is asking state regulators to let it buy batteries it will install at customers’ homes, saying doing so will be cheaper than putting up more power lines.
lead_paragraph: Many electric utilities are putting up lots of new power lines as they rely more on renewable energy and try to make grids more resilient in bad weather. But a Vermont utility is proposing a very different approach: It wants to install batteries at most homes to make sure its customers never go without electricity.

headline: For Israelis, Scale of Tragedy Starts to Set In
abstract: The feeling of shock among Israelis over the attack by Hamas and the obvious intelligence failure that allowed it to happen is compounding the fear of what might yet be to come.
lead_paragraph: Israel’s news sites are compiling their own lists of the dead and the missing. Funerals are taking place all around the country. After a weekend of attacks, confusion and chaos, the scale of the tragedy that has befallen Israel was coming into sharper focus on Monday.

headline: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. to Run for President as Independent, Leaving Democratic Primary
abstract: The political scion told supporters he would end his campaign as a Democratic candidate and run as an independent, potentially upsetting the dynamics of the 2024 election.
lead_paragraph: In a move that could alter the dynamics of the 2024 election, Robert F. Kennedy Jr. said on Monday that he would continue his presidential run as an independent candidate, ending his long-shot pursuit of the Democratic nomination against an incumbent president.

headline: In Paris, a Madonna Musical Pays Tribute (in Pink)
abstract: “Holidays,” the first musical to include the pop icon’s songs, arrives just days before her “Celebration” tour starts. But matching the star’s talents is a challenge.
lead_paragraph: Two lovers belting “Open Your Heart.” A misunderstood woman exhorting a roaring audience to “Express Yourself.” A gay wedding extravaganza set to “Like A Prayer.”

headline: A Clash of Views Over the Israel-Hamas War
abstract: Sampling the responses as the conflict rages on. Also: A Covid Catch-22; treating drug addiction; private security guards in a distressed downtown.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Lost in Tibetan Avalanches, 2 American Women Close to a Record
abstract: The mountaineers, who hoped to become the first American women to scale the world’s 14 tallest peaks, were among climbers struck by avalanches on Mount Shishapangma. One was 80 meters short of her goal, her mother said.
lead_paragraph: Two climbers who were hoping to become the first American women to scale the world’s 14 tallest peaks were among a group of mountaineers struck by avalanches in Tibet on Saturday.

headline: Attack Ends Israel’s Hope That Hamas Might Come to Embrace Stability
abstract: Israel had considered Hamas a terrorist organization but one that could play a useful role for Israel in the Gaza Strip, which the group controls. Now, senior Israeli officials say, Hamas must be crushed.
lead_paragraph: Since its founding, Hamas has declared that Israel has no right to exist, that there are no Israeli civilians and that every Israeli citizen is a soldier of the state, and thus a legitimate target.

headline: Charles Feeney, Who Made a Fortune and Then Gave It Away, Dies at 92
abstract: After piling up billions in business, he pledged to donate almost all of his money to causes before he died. He succeeded, and then lived a more modest life.
lead_paragraph: Charles F. Feeney, a pioneer of duty-free shops and a shrewd investor in technology start-ups who gave away nearly all of his $8 billion fortune to charity, much of it as quietly as he had made it, died on Monday in San Francisco. He was 92.

headline: Israel Orders ‘Complete Siege’ of Gaza and Hamas Threatens to Kill Hostages
abstract: Israel mobilized 300,000 reservists amid signs that it could be preparing for a major ground invasion of Gaza, and it bombed hundreds of sites, including mosques and a marketplace.
lead_paragraph: Israel ordered a “complete siege” of the Gaza Strip on Monday as it retaliated for the largest and deadliest incursion into its territory in decades, while Hamas threatened to respond to the Israeli bombing campaign by executing civilians its fighters took hostage in Israel.

headline: It’s Drake’s Season of Discontent, Again
abstract: The rapper’s new album, “For All the Dogs,” comes after a summer of live-show triumph and extra-musical boredom.
lead_paragraph: The dominant preoccupation of the hip-hop internet in recent days has been the matter of what Drake — who remains, at 36, the most popular English-speaking rapper on the planet — should rap about.

headline: Israel’s Attackers Took Over 200 Hostages. Here’s What to Know About Them.
abstract: The Israeli military said 240 people had been taken hostage during the Hamas attack. Just four have been released; one has been rescued.
lead_paragraph: Hamas, the group that controls the Gaza Strip and staged the surprise attack on Israel on Oct. 7, and other Palestinian groups are believed to be holding more than 200 hostages — people taken after Hamas stormed across the border in a brazen assault that killed at least 1,400 people.

headline: We Need to Know When to Opt Out of Optimizing
abstract: The relentless pursuit of efficiency in all domains of life is harming us, two books argue.
lead_paragraph: We love to optimize our home lives, to tweak our processes at work, to attain peak efficiency in all things and to squeeze all the juice from all of our lemons. I personally admit to choosing T-shirts “first in first out” — that is, pulling them from the bottom of the stacks in the dresser drawer instead of the top so each is worn with precisely the same frequency.

headline: Skeletons of 1918 Flu Victims Reveal Clues About Who Was Likely to Die
abstract: While a narrative emerged that the pandemic indiscriminately struck the young and healthy, new evidence suggests that frail young adults were most vulnerable.
lead_paragraph: The flu typically kills the very young, the old and the sick. That made the virus in 1918 unusual, or so the story goes: It killed healthy young people as readily as those who were frail or had chronic conditions.

headline: Terence Davies, 77, Dies; Filmmaker Mined Literature and His Own Life
abstract: With a poetic sensibility, “Distant Voices, Still Lives” echoed his Liverpool upbringing, and “The House of Mirth” put Edith Wharton’s novel on the screen.
lead_paragraph: Terence Davies, a British screenwriter and director known for his poetic, intensely personal films like “Distant Voices, Still Lives” and literary adaptations like “The House of Mirth,” died on Saturday at his home in the village of Mistley, Essex, on the southeast coast of England. He was 77.

headline: ‘I Just Hope That They Are Alive’: How Hamas Abducted 150 Israelis
abstract: Palestinian militants kidnapped scores of Israelis in an unprecedented attack that took the Israeli-Palestinian conflict into unknown territory. Their relatives recount how they were captured.
lead_paragraph: Gaya Kalderon last heard from half her family at 8:26 a.m. on Saturday morning.

headline: For 26 Hours, One Family Took Shelter as Hamas Attackers Overran Their Kibbutz
abstract: In their home’s safe room, Sarit Kurtzman, her husband and their 14-month-old daughter waited out the attack.
lead_paragraph: When Sarit Kurtzman heard rocket sirens early Saturday morning, she grabbed her 14-month-old daughter, Zohar, and quickly made her way with her husband, Yonatan, to the safe room in their home in the kibbutz Alumim in southern Israel.

headline: The Attack on Israel Demands Unity and Resolve
abstract: America and other allies have a crucial role to play in supporting Israel at this painful moment.
lead_paragraph: The brutal terrorist attack on Israel by Hamas is a tragedy, one that may change the course of the nation and the entire region.

headline: Tuesday Briefing: Israel Orders a ‘Siege’ of Gaza
abstract: Plus can betting save the world?
lead_paragraph: Israel’s defense minister ordered a “complete siege” of the long-blockaded Gaza Strip yesterday, as Israeli forces battled Palestinian assailants in border towns for a third day and launched retaliatory strikes that hit hundreds of sites in Gaza, including mosques and a marketplace.

headline: Trump Uses Support for Israel to Revive Travel Ban Talk
abstract: His remarks echoed the type of anti-Muslim rhetoric that he successfully tapped into during his 2016 presidential run.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump, while addressing the fighting in Israel on Monday, attempted to stoke fear of attacks taking place on U.S. soil and suggested that a travel ban like the one he implemented as president could stop such violence.

headline: Hollywood Writers Ratify New Contract With Studios
abstract: The vote, which followed the end of the strike on Sept. 27, officially brought to a close a bitter, five-month labor dispute. The actors remain on strike.
lead_paragraph: Hollywood film and TV writers voted overwhelmingly to approve a new three-year contract with the major entertainment studios, the Writers Guild of America said on Monday, formally bringing to a close a bitter five-month labor dispute.

headline: N.Y. Officials Visiting Israel Find Themselves Confronted With War
abstract: Representative Daniel Goldman and Senator Cory Booker had unexpected experiences of the attack, as did police officials visiting from the New York area.
lead_paragraph: The air raid sirens began screaming at 6:30 a.m. Saturday, rousing Representative Daniel Goldman and his family from sleep inside their Tel Aviv hotel room. Then came a voice over the intercom, commanding them in English and Hebrew to immediately seek shelter.

headline: Washington Rallies Behind Israel, but a Lasting Consensus May Prove Elusive
abstract: Democrats and Republicans put aside an increasingly partisan divide over Israel to condemn the Hamas attack. But that support may be harder to maintain as Israel retaliates.
lead_paragraph: The staggering Hamas surprise attack on Israel has done what Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu never could — united America’s fractious politicians behind his nation again. Sort of. Mostly. For now.

headline: Unity Chief Resigns After Pricing Backlash
abstract: John Riccitiello angered video game developers who use Unity’s software when he announced a new fee structure that could have significantly increased their costs.
lead_paragraph: John Riccitiello, the chief executive of Unity Technologies, abruptly stepped down on Monday, less than a month after a change to the company’s pricing structure infuriated thousands of software developers who rely on the video game company’s tools.

headline: McCarthy Floats Return as Divided G.O.P. Prepares to Choose a Speaker
abstract: Less than a week after his ouster, the former speaker indicated he would be open to reinstatement as Republicans prepared to discuss whom to nominate to succeed him.
lead_paragraph: Former Speaker Kevin McCarthy floated the possibility on Monday that he might be open to reclaiming the post from which he was ousted less than a week ago, even as two other Republicans vied to replace him in a contest that has highlighted the party’s deep divisions.

headline: At least 11 U.S. citizens were killed in Israel, Biden says, and others may be captives of Hamas.
abstract: “I have directed my team to work with their Israeli counterparts on every aspect of the hostage crisis, including sharing intelligence,” the president said in a statement on Monday evening.
lead_paragraph: At least 11 U.S. citizens have been killed in Israel and an unknown number are still unaccounted for, President Biden said in a statement on Monday evening, saying that “we believe it is likely that American citizens may be among those being held by Hamas.”

headline: Will Hurd Drops Out of G.O.P. Presidential Race and Endorses Haley
abstract: The former congressman, who had staked out an anti-Trump position, failed to gain traction in a crowded field.
lead_paragraph: Will Hurd, a Republican former congressman from Texas who was once seen as a rising star in the G.O.P., announced on Monday that he would suspend his campaign for president. He endorsed Nikki Haley, the former U.N. ambassador and governor of South Carolina.

headline: Special Counsel Interviewed Biden About Classified Documents
abstract: Robert Hur, the special counsel appointed to investigate how sensitive material ended up at the home and office of President Biden, met with the president over the past two days.
lead_paragraph: President Biden met over the past two days with Robert K. Hur, the special counsel investigating how classified documents improperly ended up at Mr. Biden’s home and an office he used after leaving the vice presidency, the White House disclosed on Monday.

headline: Videos Show How Attack on Music Festival Began
abstract: Social media videos and closed-circuit TV footage verified by The New York Times reveal how armed men stormed a music festival in southern Israel, killing an estimated 260 people.
lead_paragraph: Social media videos and closed-circuit TV footage verified by The New York Times reveal how armed men stormed a music festival in southern Israel, killing an estimated 260 people.

headline: Among American Jews, ‘You See a Lot of Broken Spirits’ After Attacks
abstract: A community with diverse views and opinions on Israel appeared to be largely united in shock and anger at the violence by Hamas.
lead_paragraph: The deadly attacks and kidnappings in Israel this weekend shocked Jews across the United States, leading to tightened security at American synagogues, the cancellation of some holiday celebrations and a sense of horror and helplessness amid concern for relatives and fears of more violence to come.

headline: South Korean Chip Makers Get U.S. Waivers From China Export Rules
abstract: A government official in Seoul said the decision settled a trade issue that had threatened to impede the China operations of Samsung and SK Hynix.
lead_paragraph: The South Korean government said on Monday that the country’s semiconductor manufacturers had secured waivers from U.S. government rules that threatened to limit their businesses in China.

headline: Police Fatally Shoot Driver Who Crashed Into Chinese Consulate in San Francisco
abstract: The investigation into the episode is continuing, and the authorities have not released the name of the suspect.
lead_paragraph: The police fatally shot a driver who crashed into the visa office at the Chinese consulate in San Francisco on Monday afternoon, the San Francisco Police Department said.

headline: Our Own Language
abstract: What made-up words, abbreviations or nicknames do you use with your friends and family?
lead_paragraph: A recent article from the Style section reports:

headline: Do You Share Music Tastes With Your Parents?
abstract: Nu metal, a genre popular around the turn of the millennium, is making a comeback with Gen Z. Do you ever listen to songs or artists from earlier eras?
lead_paragraph: What kind of music do your parents like? Do you enjoy listening to it with them, whether in the car or at home, or do you wish they would put on something else?

headline: The Mystery Company With One Foot in the Premier League
abstract: 777 Partners had been scooping up big-name soccer teams for two years when it bid for Everton. Doubts about its finances could kill the deal.
lead_paragraph: The acquisitions came so quickly that it was hard to keep up. An agreement to buy the oldest soccer team in Italy. An investment in one of the most popular teams in Brazil. Stakes in well-known clubs in Belgium and France, Germany and Australia.

headline: A Solar Eclipse Shines Light on Traditions That Still Matter Today
abstract: Among Indigenous peoples of the Americas, from Navajo Nation down to the rainforests of Brazil, events like the annular eclipse on Saturday have important and distinctive cultural meanings.
lead_paragraph: Follow live updates on the 2023 ring of fire solar eclipse.

headline: Country Garden Caves to Debts as China’s Real Estate Crisis Worsens
abstract: The property giant was unable to repay a loan and signaled it would default on its debt, becoming one of the biggest casualties of China’s deepening property crisis.
lead_paragraph: The embattled property developer Country Garden said on Tuesday that it was unable to repay a loan and expected to miss upcoming overseas debt payments as a result of plunging sales from China’s spiraling property crisis.

headline: Tuesday Briefing
abstract: A “complete siege” of Gaza.
lead_paragraph: Israel’s defense minister ordered a “complete siege” of the Gaza Strip as Hamas, the militant group controlling the territory, threatened to execute a civilian hostage every time an airstrike hit Gazans “in their homes without warning.”

headline: Quotation of the Day: ‘They Took Him’: Israeli Families Left in Dread
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, October 10, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “I am looking on Instagram and I see a video. And it’s my brother.”

headline: Myanmar Military Bombs Refugee Camp, Killing 29, Rebels Say
abstract: Eleven of the dead were under 16, and 56 people were wounded, said the Kachin Independence Army, which controls the area.
lead_paragraph: Myanmar’s military bombed a camp for displaced people in the northern part of the country, killing 29 people and wounding 56 others, a spokesman for an ethnic rebel group that controls the area said on Tuesday.

headline: How a Radio Station Is Empowering Women in a Rural Heartland
abstract: With shows that encourage listener participation, a community radio station in the Indian state of Haryana is helping women overcome deeply patriarchal attitudes.
lead_paragraph: The women gather in a whitewashed room with a view of yellow mustard fields. They adjust their hijabs as they take seats on a dhurrie with a gaping hole. In their midst is the day’s star: an oval speaker.

headline: Word of the Day: zoonotic
abstract: This word has appeared in 18 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word zoonotic has appeared in 18 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Aug. 22 in “‘Don’t Kiss or Snuggle Your Turtle,’ C.D.C. Warns Amid Salmonella Outbreak” by Eduardo Medina:

headline: Late Night Hosts Address the Hamas Attacks on Israel
abstract: Seth Meyers kept things serious, while Stephen Colbert and Jimmy Kimmel tried a touch of levity around a tough subject.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Why Tugboats Are Key to the $19 Billion Overhaul of Kennedy Airport
abstract: Renovating one of the world’s busiest airports is replete with engineering challenges, such as how to circumvent the area’s overburdened roadways.
lead_paragraph: To turn New York City’s outmoded Kennedy Airport into a collection of gleaming, modern terminals connected by smooth, untangled roadways, you must start with one of nature’s most basic building blocks: tons and tons of rocks.

headline: Sparks Fly When the N.F.L. and Pop Collide. So Does Coverage.
abstract: When two worlds — one dominated by the N.F.L. and the other by Taylor Swift — collided, so did culture and sports coverage at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Matt Stevens, a Culture reporter for The New York Times, is unabashedly a “Swiftie.” For years, a portrait of her hung in his home. In 2012, when he worked for The Los Angeles Times, Stevens was even selected as a finalist in a nationwide “biggest fan” contest that drew thousands of applications.

headline: Scream Queen? More Like Stream Queen.
abstract: “Ehrengard: The Art of Seduction,” a new fantasy dramedy on Netflix, had Queen Margrethe II of Denmark as its costume and production designer.
lead_paragraph: Once upon a time, there was a princess in Denmark who aspired to become an artist.

headline: No Corrections: Oct. 10, 2023
abstract: No corrections appeared in print on Tuesday, Oct. 10, 2023.
lead_paragraph: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

headline: Fragile Global Economy Faces New Crisis in Israel-Gaza War
abstract: A war in the Middle East could complicate efforts to contain inflation at a time when world output is “limping along.”
lead_paragraph: The International Monetary Fund said on Tuesday that the pace of the global economic recovery is slowing, a warning that came as a new war in the Middle East threatened to upend a world economy already reeling from several years of overlapping crises.

headline: A Son’s Conversation With His Mother as Gunmen Attacked Her Kibbutz
abstract: Yonatan Ziegen said he last heard from his mother on Saturday when they were texting during an assault on Be’eri, an Israeli kibbutz. She messaged him to say that assailants were in the house before going silent.
lead_paragraph: Yonatan Ziegen said he last heard from his mother on Saturday when they were texting during an assault on Be’eri, an Israeli kibbutz. She messaged him to say that assailants were in the house before going silent.

headline: I Ran While Pregnant. The Internet Had Thoughts.
abstract: When it comes to my pregnancy, the only opinion I’m interested in is my doctor’s.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to my pregnancy, the only opinion I’m interested in is my doctor’s.

headline: Why You Can’t Spell Hollywood Without Marvel
abstract: “MCU: The Reign of Marvel Studios” captures how movies based on comic-book properties came to dominate pop culture. At least until now.
lead_paragraph: Hollywood doesn’t believe in immortals. From Mary Pickford to the MGM musical, Golden Age cowboys to teenage wizards, the city worships its gods only until their box-office power dims. So it feels audacious — if not foolhardy — to open “MCU: The Reign of Marvel Studios” and find its authors, Joanna Robinson, Dave Gonzales and Gavin Edwards, declaring that it’s difficult to imagine a future where the Disney-owned superhero industrial complex “didn’t run forever.” Even Tony Stark, better known as Iron Man, has yet to engineer a perpetual motion machine.

headline: Her Insurance Refused to Pay for Wegovy, So She Sued
abstract: Many employers and government programs won’t cover costly obesity medications. A lawsuit is challenging one such policy.
lead_paragraph: Jeannette Simonton was a textbook candidate for the obesity drug Wegovy when her doctor prescribed it to her in February.

headline: In This Novel, Transphobia Is a Literal Parasite
abstract: In her new book, “Brainwyrms,” Alison Rumfitt reimagines contemporary anti-trans bigotry as a ravenous helminth that causes its hosts to go violently mad.
lead_paragraph: “She had worms in her brain,” a character in Alison Rumfitt’s “Brainwyrms” decides when faced with his mother’s increasingly transphobic zeal. “It was easier to think of it in those terms than to admit that his mother genuinely hated him.”

headline: A Master Anatomist of Ordinary People in Difficult Times
abstract: With the republication of “The Children’s Bach,” a 1984 novel, and “This House of Grief,” a 2014 account of a murder trial, the Australian writer Helen Garner is ripe for discovery by American readers.
lead_paragraph: I had never heard of the Australian writer Helen Garner when I started reading her novel “The Children’s Bach,” and the book puzzled me at first, before I got into the scatty, nonlinear rhythm of its prose. We are immediately introduced to a cluster of characters: Dexter; his wife, Athena; their two little boys, one of them developmentally disabled; the adult sisters Elizabeth and Vicki; Elizabeth’s lover Philip and his adolescent daughter, Poppy. How, I wondered, were the characters connected to one another, and why did Garner’s sentences seem to float through the air like random thoughts?

headline: Looking to the Dutch Masters for Answers to Life’s Big Questions
abstract: In “The Upside-Down World,” Benjamin Moser roams the galleries of the Netherlands in search of clues to the artists’ biographies.
lead_paragraph: When he moved from New York to the Netherlands in 2002, Benjamin Moser was at the beginning of both his career and a love affair — a triply tenuous situation. He found comfort in the country’s museums, in particular the artists of the 17th-century Dutch Golden Age, an era characterized by social mobility, scientific innovation and economic expansion (as well as rampant colonialism). In “The Upside-Down World,” Moser covers some 18 of the period’s painters, both the famous (Rembrandt, Vermeer, Frans Hals) and the lesser known (Adriaen Coorte, Hendrick Avercamp, Rachel Ruysch). He describes the book as the record of an education, learning about and from artists who guided him through “an uncertain life in a new land.”

headline: In This Novel, Opposites Don’t Attract. They Converge.
abstract: “The Leftover Woman” follows two struggling women living completely different lives. How do their paths overlap?
lead_paragraph: Jasmine, one of two protagonists in Jean Kwok’s intriguing fourth novel, “The Leftover Woman,” reveals little to the reader at first. Seeing her on the streets of Manhattan’s Chinatown, we quickly understand that she’s a woman with a complicated past. But like the frumpy clothes she wears to disguise her appearance, her thoughts and words are meant to throw us off the track. As Jasmine trudges from one job interview to the next, searching for work that will help pay off the “snakeheads” who helped her emigrate from China, she remains as invisible to readers as she is to her pursuers.

headline: We Need Better Narratives About Gender
abstract: Masha Gessen and Lydia Polgreen reflect on the backlash — both legislative and cultural — against L.G.B.T.Q. rights and what it means to understand queer life more expansively.
lead_paragraph: It’s a time of contrast and contradiction for gender queerness in America: At the same time that about 5 percent of Americans under 30 identify as transgender or nonbinary, over 20 states have passed some sort of restriction on gender-affirming care for children. In 2023 alone, over 550 anti-trans bills have been introduced across the country.

headline: Who Runs the Best U.S. Schools? It May Be the Defense Department.
abstract: Schools for children of military members achieve results rarely seen in public education.
lead_paragraph: Amy Dilmar, a middle-school principal in Georgia, is well aware of the many crises threatening American education. The lost learning that piled up during the coronavirus pandemic. The gaping inequalities by race and family income that have only gotten worse. A widening achievement gap between the highest- and lowest-performing students.

headline: How One Tiny Island Nation Is Replacing Fossil Fuels With Renewable Power
abstract: Countries like the Maldives want to move away from fossil fuels but have been stymied by the high cost of solar projects.
lead_paragraph: Weaning the developing world off fossil fuels is critically important to prevent the climate crisis from becoming a catastrophe. But a major sticking point is making that goal hard to accomplish.

headline: How Do My Calorie Needs Change as I Age?
abstract: Your body’s need for fuel shifts as you get older. Your eating habits should shift, too.
lead_paragraph: Q: I’m in my 50s, and I’ve heard that it’s normal to burn fewer calories as I get older. Is this true?

headline: For Sampha, Joy Comes After the Mourning
abstract: While the British singer’s last album unpacked the grief of his mother’s death, “Lahai,” due this month, is brighter and more expansive.
lead_paragraph: Sampha knows there’s sadness associated with his music. “Process,” his Mercury Prize-winning 2017 debut, was filled with down-tempo ballads made in the aftermath of his mother’s death from cancer. But six years have passed, and now the British singer, pianist and producer born Sampha Sisay is a father. So for his new album, “Lahai,” he wanted to explore different points of the life cycle.

headline: Breakers Grapple With Hip-Hop’s Big Olympic Moment
abstract: Largely left out of hip-hop’s 50th anniversary, breaking will get its stage at the Paris Olympics. Its pioneers wonder if their art will translate into sport.
lead_paragraph: The thumping music died to a whisper upon Alien Ness’s request. As the veteran breaker — never “break dancer” — stalked and snaked around the room, his many rings caught the spotlight that illuminated the dance floor.

headline: Where an Obsession With Election Integrity Can Lead
abstract: Years after the 2020 election, some red areas are considering counting their votes by hand. It’s a bad idea, and Republicans could and should fix it.
lead_paragraph: The Republican Party appears poised to stand by and say nothing while its most die-hard supporters risk disenfranchising themselves and others.

headline: For Sale: A Stamp So Famous It Appeared on ‘The Simpsons’
abstract: This “inverted Jenny” is valuable because it contains a mistake — one of the best-known errors in stamp history.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. We’ll look at one of the most famous mistakes ever made — a postage stamp with an upside-down airplane. We’ll also see what the guilty plea by Representative George Santos’s campaign treasurer might mean for Santos himself.

headline: No Better Than a Placebo
abstract: Unpacking the mystery of placebo.
lead_paragraph: An advisory committee for the Food and Drug Administration recently concluded that a popular oral decongestant sold over the counter was no better than a placebo. The agency now faces the question of whether to pull medications that use the ingredient, phenylephrine, off store shelves.

headline: I Ran While Pregnant. The Internet Had Thoughts.
abstract: When it comes to my pregnancy, the only opinion I’m interested in is my doctor’s.
lead_paragraph: ​​When you’re pregnant, there’s plenty to worry about. Your baby, for example. Your own health. And then there’s everyone else — the cadre of ordinary strangers who transform themselves into an ambient squad of the pregnancy police whenever they spot a woman who looks as if she’s about to have a baby. Are you sure you can eat that cheese? Is what you’re drinking safe? And when it comes to exercise, watch out. The world is going to have some thoughts.

headline: What Are the Must-Have Amenities for Today’s Pampered Pet?
abstract: Dogs may not absolutely need their own shower, but they’d appreciate it. And your cat expects nothing less than an architectural playground.
lead_paragraph: When you’re designing or decorating a home, you have to consider the needs of the occupants — and that means not just people, but any resident animals.

headline: 45 Seasons in, ‘Survivor’ Faces Realities of a Changing Planet
abstract: The CBS hit, along with fellow staple “The Amazing Race,” is learning to deal with climate change, globalization and other seismic shifts.
lead_paragraph: Since its premiere in 2000, the hit CBS reality game show “Survivor” has taken place across the globe, with each season set in an exotic island locale: Pulau Tiga in Malaysia, Ko Tarutao in Thailand, Efate in Vanuatu and many, many more.

headline: On a New ‘Frasier,’ James Burrows Has a Joke for You
abstract: Over nearly five decades, Burrows has directed a thousand sitcom episodes. Next up: the new Paramount+ series, which follows Frasier Crane’s return to Boston.
lead_paragraph: “You can’t learn how to be funny,” James Burrows said. “That has to be instinctual in you.”

headline: There’s a Reason Hasan Minhaj’s Lies Found Such a Big Audience
abstract: When you’re Muslim American, you’re very familiar with a particular kind of story. You might have even told a few yourself.
lead_paragraph: For years, whenever I’d hear a joke by the comedian Hasan Minhaj, I felt a pang of familiarity. The stories he told were ones I knew: about being called a terrorist or being stopped by security at the airport or navigating white America as a Muslim and South Asian person. And while these were interactions I knew well, it was also hard for me not to cringe when I saw his standup. All I could think was: Really? This again?

headline: The Places That Sam Bankman-Fried Left Behind
abstract: Before his FTX crypto exchange imploded and he went on trial for fraud, Mr. Bankman-Fried ran a global business empire spanning Berkeley, Calif., Hong Kong and the Bahamas.
lead_paragraph: Before it all collapsed last fall, the cryptocurrency mogul Sam Bankman-Fried was at the center of a global business empire.

headline: ‘Don’t Do That Again’: Sam Bankman-Fried’s Lawyers Under Fire From Judge
abstract: In the first week of Mr. Bankman-Fried’s fraud trial, Judge Lewis A. Kaplan repeatedly admonished the former crypto mogul’s lawyers, in an ominous sign for the defense.
lead_paragraph: Three days into Sam Bankman-Fried’s criminal trial in Federal District Court in Manhattan, Judge Lewis A. Kaplan’s warnings to the defense had become unmistakable.

headline: Why Culture Has Come to a Standstill
abstract: A Times critic argues that ours is the least innovative century for the arts in 500 years. That doesn’t have to be a bad thing.
lead_paragraph: At the Metropolitan Museum of Art, in its fall blockbuster show, “Manet/Degas,” is a painting from 1866 of a woman in the latest fashion. Victorine Meurent, Manet’s favorite model, stands in an empty room, accompanied only by a parrot on a bird stand. Her trademark red hair is tied back with a blue ribbon. Her head is slightly bowed as she smells a nosegay in her right hand: probably a gift from an absent admirer, just like the gentleman’s monocle in her left. She’s wearing a silk peignoir, which Manet has rendered in buttery strokes of pink and white. This is a full-length image, more than six feet tall, but Victorine hasn’t even put on her best clothes. She’s in a dressing gown, and the gown is amorphous. The gown is only paint.

headline: In Search of Kamala Harris
abstract: After nearly three years, the vice president is still struggling to make the case for herself — and feels she shouldn’t have to.
lead_paragraph: All the conditions seemed right for a chance to reset the narrative.

headline: The 25 Best Restaurants in Seattle Right Now
abstract: Stellar Pacific Northwest seafood, an irreverent Japanese gastro pub and a steakhouse like no other are among our favorites.
lead_paragraph: In the Where to Eat: 25 Best series, we’re highlighting our favorite restaurants in cities across the United States. These lists will be updated as restaurants close and open, and as we find new gems to recommend. As always, we pay for all of our meals and don’t accept free items.

headline: ‘Everyone Died’: How Gunmen Killed Dozens In Sderot
abstract: Videos filmed by residents in Sderot captured a grisly and indiscriminate shooting rampage by Palestinian gunmen in the town on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Videos filmed by residents in Sderot captured a grisly and indiscriminate shooting rampage by Palestinian gunmen in the town on Saturday.

headline: Peace Activists Are Among the Israelis Missing and Killed
abstract: Some of those caught up in the attack by Palestinian fighters lived in residential collectives whose members tend to support peace initiatives and Palestinian rights.
lead_paragraph: On the Israeli side of the Gaza border lie a number of residential collectives whose members tend to be left of center and supportive of peace initiatives and Palestinian rights. Many of those residents were among the missing or dead after Hamas’s assault on Saturday.

headline: How Much Do You Know About Honduras?
abstract: Can you find Honduras on a map? What else do you know about this Central American nation with about 10 million people?
lead_paragraph: Can you find Honduras on a map? What else do you know about this Central American nation with about 10 million people?

headline: Putin Offers Muted Response to Attack on Israel. That Speaks Volumes.
abstract: Vladimir Putin has long projected friendly ties to Israel. But his silence since Saturday’s assault illustrates how the war in Ukraine has strained the relationship between the two countries.
lead_paragraph: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia has long cast himself as a friend of Israel and the Jewish people.

headline: Israel Orders Gaza ‘Siege,’ Hamas Threatens to Kill Hostages, and More
abstract: Plus, support for Palestinians in the Middle East and Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s presidential bid.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

headline: The New Supreme Court Cases to Watch
abstract: After recent major victories for the conservative legal movement, the justices face a docket filled with unfinished business.
lead_paragraph: Last week, the Supreme Court began its new term, picking up where it left off on the most contentious issues of the day, with cases connected to government power, gun rights and abortion.

headline: The Nation’s Top-Performing Public School System
abstract: Schools run by the Defense Department educate 66,000 children of civilian employees and service members.
lead_paragraph: Improving America’s schools can sometimes seem like an impossible task. Politicians have been promising to do so for decades, yet the U.S. remains well behind many other countries in basic measures of learning. The Covid pandemic, with its extended school closures, aggravated the problems.

headline: ‘No Accident’ Review: Putting White Supremacists on Trial
abstract: A documentary chronicles the lawsuit filed against the leaders of the violent 2017 white supremacist rally in Charlottesville, Va.
lead_paragraph: Kristi Jacobson’s legal documentary “No Accident” opens with footage of the “Unite the Right” rally in August 2017 in Charlottesville, Va.: White supremacists march with tiki torches and shout slurs such as “Jews will not replace us.” The grotesque gathering remains unsettling and infuriating to watch, but plunging us into the proceedings has a way of stating the ugly facts upfront.

headline: Iran’s Supreme Leader Issues Tehran’s Latest Denial of Involvement in Israel Attacks
abstract: Ayatollah Ali Khamenei suggested that Tehran was not behind the assault in Israel and warned of consequences from retaliatory strikes in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: Iran’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, suggested on Tuesday that Iran was not behind the incursion in Israel, while praising what he called Israel’s “irreparable” military and intelligence defeat.

headline: Israeli Start-Ups Are on the Front Lines
abstract: The country is mobilizing 360,000 reservists as it prepares a major offensive in Gaza — including entrepreneurs and their young staff.
lead_paragraph: The Israel-Gaza war is intensifying, with Israeli forces having killed about 1,500 Palestinian fighters in retaliation for the deadly weekend attacks by Hamas. The government is mobilizing 360,000 reservists for a larger military campaign.

headline: Review: ‘Merrily We Roll Along,’ Finally Found in the Dark
abstract: Jonathan Groff, supported by Daniel Radcliffe and Lindsay Mendez, is thrillingly fierce in the first convincing revival of the cult flop Sondheim musical.
lead_paragraph: To be a fan of the work of Stephen Sondheim, as Frank Rich wrote in The New York Times, is “to have one’s heart broken at regular intervals.” He meant not only that Sondheim’s songs are so often crushingly poignant but that the experience of loving them can feel unrequited. The shows they are in — he was reviewing the original production of “Merrily We Roll Along” — don’t always love you back.

headline: ‘It’s a Massacre’: Inside an Israeli Village Raided by Palestinian Fighters
abstract: Kfar Azza, less than two miles from Gaza, was one of the villages overrun by Palestinian gunmen on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: The village of Kfar Azza looked normal from a distance — tidy terraces of one-story beige houses. I walked past the village dining hall, kindergarten and culture center, and turned left.

headline: ‘Damage and Distress’: Trump Sues Over Russia Dossier in London
abstract: Former President Donald J. Trump is arguing that the document known as the Steele dossier was calculated to embarrass him and that it breached data protection laws.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump has claimed in a lawsuit in a London court that Christopher Steele, a former British intelligence officer, inflicted “personal and reputational damage and distress” on him by leaking a dossier detailing unsavory, unproven accounts of links between him and Russia during the 2016 presidential campaign.

headline: What to Know About the Presidential Election in Liberia
abstract: George Weah, a former soccer superstar, is running for re-election amid doubts over his ability to tackle rampant corruption and fears of post-election violence.
lead_paragraph: A former soccer superstar won the presidential election in the West African nation of Liberia in 2017 by promising to fix the country’s economy, build more roads and address endemic graft.

headline: Saying Goodbye to a San Francisco Icon
abstract: Dianne Feinstein was as much a symbol of the city as the Golden Gate Bridge is.
lead_paragraph: Dianne Feinstein was laid to rest last week with a funeral service on the steps of San Francisco City Hall, a fitting backdrop for a woman who was as much a symbol of the city as the Golden Gate Bridge is.

headline: The Israel-Hamas War: A Forum for Young People to React
abstract: We invite teenagers to share what they have thought, felt, discussed and wondered in the days since Hamas’s attack on Israel and Israel’s response.
lead_paragraph: Please note: We ask that adults respect the intent of our Student Opinion questions and refrain from posting here. While there are many other places on nytimes.com for adults to have their say, this is the only forum that explicitly invites the voices of young people.

headline: San Francisco Police Kill Driver Who Crashed Into Chinese Consulate
abstract: The fatal shooting took place after the driver crashed into the visa office and posed “a serious threat to the life and safety of staff and people on site,” according to the Chinese Consulate General.
lead_paragraph: The fatal shooting took place after the driver crashed into the visa office and posed “a serious threat to the life and safety of staff and people on site,” according to the Chinese Consulate General.

headline: If Every Brand Is Funny Online, Is Anything Funny?
abstract: For a decade, marketers have found success on social media by roasting customers, and even flirting with them. But with Gen Z, and platforms like TikTok on the rise, the jokes may be wearing thin.
lead_paragraph: In the comments on a recent TikTok post by RyanAir, an exuberant traveler posted about flying the airline for the first time. In the past, the typical corporate response to this might have been something like, “We’re glad to have you!” or “Thanks for joining us!”

headline: Documenting the Recipes of Latin America, One Zoom at a Time
abstract: For her latest cookbook, “Latinísimo,” Sandra A. Gutierrez found creative ways to meet cooks to document the home cooking of Central and South America, and the Caribbean.
lead_paragraph: Just as Sandra A. Gutierrez was about to embark on a research trip to the 23 cities throughout Latin America that she planned to cover in her fifth cookbook, the coronavirus pandemic grounded international travel.

headline: Morgan Wallen Returns to No. 1 in a Slow Chart Week
abstract: With Drake’s “For All the Dogs” and Taylor Swift’s rerecording of “1989” waiting in the wings, Wallen’s “One Thing at a Time” has its 16th time at the peak.
lead_paragraph: In a relatively slow week of music sales before the arrival of blockbusters by Drake and Taylor Swift, the country star Morgan Wallen returns to the top of the Billboard album chart, notching a 16th time at No. 1 for his newest album, “One Thing at a Time.”

headline: Argentina’s Currency Plummets Under Attack from Far-Right Candidate
abstract: Javier Milei has become the favorite in Argentina’s election this month by pledging to dollarize the economy. In response, the Argentine peso is crashing.
lead_paragraph: Javier Milei is still just a candidate to be president of Argentina. But he is already single-handedly delivering one of Latin America’s biggest economies a financial shock.

headline: Zelensky Says Gaza War Furthers Russian Aims
abstract: The Ukrainian president said Moscow was aiming to sow division in the region and the attack on Israel could distract allies from his country’s conflict.
lead_paragraph: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine has accused Russia of wanting to precipitate conflict in the Middle East to undermine international support for Ukraine, in comments that reflect concern that the war between Israel and the militant group Hamas could distract attention from Kyiv’s fight.

headline: Well-Made, and Massively Weird: A New Theater Season in Berlin
abstract: Recent premieres in the city ranged from a spare take on the recent Broadway hit “Prima Facie” to a dose of sheer artistic lunacy.
lead_paragraph: It may be less polished and more rough-hewed than in New York, London or Paris, but Berlin’s theater scene is uniquely diverse, unpredictable and boundary-pushing. Buoyed by lavish public subsidies and boasting a fleet of remarkable actors and daring directors, it is also uncommonly accessible, thanks to low ticket prices and the growing popularity of English surtitles.

headline: Tom Suozzi Will Run to Take House Seat Back From George Santos
abstract: Mr. Suozzi held the House seat for six years, but left office to embark on an unsuccessful run for governor of New York.
lead_paragraph: Thomas R. Suozzi, the Long Island Democrat whose failed bid for governor in 2022 may have helped clear the way for Representative George Santos to get to Congress, announced on Tuesday that he would run to replace Mr. Santos and take back his seat in the House of Representatives.

headline: Easy Dinners That Make Good Use of Ketchup, Mustard and Mayonnaise
abstract: Think Chinese stir-fried tomatoes and eggs, miso-mustard salmon and mayo-marinated sheet-pan chicken thighs.
lead_paragraph: Hi, everyone! Mia here, your always-hungry New York Times Cooking newsletter editor. I’m delighted to fill in for Emily Weinstein today to talk weeknight dinners, because come 5 p.m. (or more like 3 p.m., if I’m honest), the only thing I can think about is what I’m going to eat when work is done.

headline: Scientists Use CRISPR to Make Chickens More Resistant to Bird Flu
abstract: A new study highlights both the promise and the limitations of gene editing, as a highly lethal form of avian influenza continues to spread around the world.
lead_paragraph: Scientists have used the gene-editing technology known as CRISPR to create chickens that have some resistance to avian influenza, according to a new study that was published in the journal Nature Communications on Tuesday.

headline: Illicit E-Cigarettes Flood Stores as F.D.A. Struggles to Combat Imports
abstract: Some vapes are appearing with increasing nicotine levels that approach those in a carton of cigarettes. U.S. regulators did not authorize them, but have failed to keep them off shelves.
lead_paragraph: Juul was once the cool vape, blamed for hooking teenagers on e-cigarettes, and it is set to pay billions of dollars in legal settlements.

headline: U.S. Envoy to NATO Says Aid to Israel Won’t Come at Ukraine’s Expense
abstract: Julianne Smith, the U.S. ambassador to NATO, said Washington could “stay focused on our partnership and commitment to Israel’s security” and still support Kyiv.
