Yet over the past year, many of those companies have walked back those commitments as they reaped outsize profits and made ambitious plans to expand their production of oil and gas.

headline: The Human Brain Has a Dizzying Array of Mystery Cells
abstract: Researchers identified some 3,300 types of brain cells, an order of magnitude more than was previously known, and have only a dim notion of what most of them do.
lead_paragraph: An international team of scientists has mapped the human brain in much finer resolution than ever before. The brain atlas, a $375 million effort started in 2017, has identified more than 3,300 types of brain cells, an order of magnitude more than was previously reported. The researchers have only a dim notion of what the newly discovered cells do.

headline: Columbia Closes Campus as Israel-Hamas War Protests Erupt
abstract: Tensions have risen around the city as supporters of each side stage protests and police investigate possible hate crimes.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of protesters gathered at Columbia University on Thursday for competing pro-Israel and pro-Palestinian demonstrations that earlier in day led school administrators to take the extraordinary step of closing the campus to the public.

headline: After Refusing to Fly, Climate Researcher Loses His Job
abstract: To reduce emissions, he took five trains, nine buses, two ferries, two taxis, one shared car and one police convoy to reach a research site.
lead_paragraph: Getting from the northern German city of Kiel to the South Pacific is a schlep no matter what. By commercial air, it takes about two days and several connecting flights.

headline: Israel, Gaza and the Laws of War
abstract: International law offers a framework for how to analyze what is happening.
lead_paragraph: It can be difficult to hold onto reason through the fog of grief that is the natural response to what has occurred in recent days in Israel and Gaza.

headline: Trump Plans Return to N.Y. Court for a Showdown With Michael Cohen
abstract: The former president’s former fixer is expected to testify next week in the trial accusing Mr. Trump of inflating the value of his assets.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump plans to return next week to the New York courtroom where his civil fraud trial is slowly proceeding, according to two people with knowledge of the matter, a reappearance that is likely to bring him face-to-face with his former fixer Michael D. Cohen.

headline: Overlooked No More: Omero C. Catan, Who Gained Fame as ‘Mr. First’
abstract: For a time, whenever a bridge, tunnel or highway opened around New York, he endeavored to beat others onto, into or along it.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of Overlooked, a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.

headline: As Deaths Soar in Gaza From Israeli Strikes, Egypt Offers Aid, but No Exit
abstract: Gazans are blocked from fleeing through Egypt, which has kept tight control of its border. An Israeli invasion of Gaza could test President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi’s approach.
lead_paragraph: As Israeli warplanes pound Gaza, killing more than 1,500 people and crushing buildings in response to last weekend’s unprecedented attack by Hamas, Israel’s leadership has repeatedly urged civilians to flee the territory while they can.

headline: Do We Need Album Reviews Anymore?
abstract: A conversation about the history — and future — of album reviews in an increasingly fraught environment for music journalism and criticism.
lead_paragraph: It is an increasingly fraught environment for music journalism and criticism. Recently, on Twitter, a conversation was initiated by the writer and musician Jamie Brooks about whether music journalism was too concerned with reviewing individual albums, and thereby focused less on more holistic, bigger-umbrella approaches to covering artists and scenes.

headline: An Economics Nobel for Showing How Much Women Matter
abstract: In praise of Claudia Goldin.
lead_paragraph: Technological progress is a key source of economic growth, but its effects aren’t always fully captured by its effects on gross domestic product. Sometimes a new technology changes everything — the way we work, the way we live, the way we relate to one another in society.

headline: For NATO, 3 Pressing Questions After This Week’s Meetings
abstract: Defense ministers went home without resolving the status of Sweden, determining who attacked a Baltic Sea pipeline or how to respond to Israel’s war with Hamas.
lead_paragraph: A surprise visit to NATO headquarters by President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine — his first — injected a bit of flair to high-level meetings this week among the alliance’s defense ministers. Beyond that, much of the rest of the two-day agenda was consumed with the kind of routine but necessary discussions that mark the semiregular gatherings: going over defense and deterrence plans, and getting updates on stability operations in Iraq, Kosovo, and Bosnia-Herzegovina.

headline: Sweden Sends a Message to Stockholm Drivers: Go Electric or Go Home
abstract: A new low-emission zone in the city center appears to be the most ambitious in Western Europe, and it is set to become law in little more than a year.
lead_paragraph: Starting in 2025, it will be much harder to find a tailpipe in a central district of Stockholm.

headline: What Teenagers Are Saying About Their Role in Fighting Climate Change
abstract: “Climate change shouldn’t be our problem, but that doesn’t mean we shouldn’t be the solution.”
lead_paragraph: In June, a group of young people in Montana won a landmark lawsuit related to climate change when, for the first time in the United States, a judge ruled that the state’s failure to consider climate change when approving fossil fuel projects was unconstitutional. Youth-led climate litigation is moving forward in other states too — and elsewhere around the world. With these lawsuits, along with social media activism and protests, Gen Z is making its voice heard.

headline: Listen: Israel-Gaza War Explained, Unpacking the Politics of Gender, Tupac Shakur’s Murder Solved?
abstract: Each week, we share the best of new audio journalism and storytelling.
lead_paragraph: Audiophiles,

headline: Blinken Stresses Support for Israel While Urging Restraint on Gaza Airstrikes
abstract: During a visit to Tel Aviv, Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken promised to help defend the country “as long as America exists.”
lead_paragraph: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken stood next to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel on Thursday at a military base in Tel Aviv and promised to help defend Israel “as long as America exists.”

headline: The Weekender
abstract: The return of Usher. Also: A profile of Kamala Harris and a mother navigating CrimeCon after her son’s murder.

headline: What It Would Mean to Treat Hamas Like ISIS
abstract: The rules of war are quite explicit about what has to happen.
lead_paragraph: The instant I understood the scale of Hamas’s attack on Israel, I understood the probable response. As I read reports of Hamas terrorists murdering entire families, raping Israeli women beside the bodies of their dead friends and dragging Israeli hostages into Gaza, it was apparent that Hamas had chosen to behave like ISIS, and if it behaved like ISIS, then the Israel Defense Forces were justified in treating Hamas in Gaza the same way the United States and its allies treated ISIS in Iraq.

headline: To Win a Senate Seat in Arizona, He’s Visiting All 22 of Its Tribes
abstract: Ruben Gallego, a Democratic congressman vying for one of the most competitive Senate seats in the country, is pitching himself to Native American voters.
lead_paragraph: State Highway 86 stretches west from Tucson, Ariz., past saguaros and desert peaks into Tohono O’odham Nation, the second largest reservation in the state. It is a road that tribal members say no Senate candidate in recent memory has ventured down.

headline: Scrolls That Survived Vesuvius Divulge Their First Word
abstract: Experts hope that the techniques used to retrieve hidden text on delicate papyrus could lead to the recovery of lost classic works.
lead_paragraph: From deep within a papyrus scroll that has not been read in almost 2,000 years and would crumble to pieces if unrolled, researchers have retrieved a handful of letters and a single word: “porphyras,” ancient Greek for “purple.”

headline: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Our recommended books this week can take you into the past, whether by way of new translations (of Homer’s “Iliad” and Elsa Morante’s 1948 novel “Lies and Sorcery”) or new looks back (an account of the New Deal’s banking regulations, a group biography of the first female astronauts, a novel about a real-life man who helped develop the atom bomb). They can take you into the future, whether it’s the future of the planet (in Ben Goldfarb’s “Crossings”) or the future of the species (in C Pam Zhang’s novel “Land of Milk and Honey”). And in Eliza Clark’s “Penance,” a novel that passes itself off as a true-crime story, and Daniel Clowes’s graphic novel “Monica,” they can get you thinking about narrative itself and the ways we consume it. Happy reading.

headline: Hospitals That Fail to Reopen Psychiatric Wards Risk Fines, Hochul Says
abstract: As New York tries to move people with severe mental illness off the streets and into treatment, the governor said some hospitals aren’t helping.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Kathy Hochul threatened on Thursday to fine several hospital systems if they did not quickly reopen psychiatric wards that had closed at the height of the pandemic, saying that those units were now urgently needed to provide treatment to homeless people with severe mental illness.

headline: As Israel Prepares for War in Gaza, Debate Is Over How and How Long
abstract: The country’s new unity government agrees that Hamas must be destroyed so it can never attack Israel again, but there is little appetite for a reoccupation.
lead_paragraph: Israel, already bombing intensively in Gaza, is gearing up for a major military operation there unlike any in the past, warning the world that for Israel, after the massacre of its citizens by Hamas on Saturday, the rules have changed.

headline: E.U. Probes Elon Musk’s X Platform Over Violent Israel-Hamas War Content
abstract: Regulators are examining whether X violated a new European law that requires large social media companies to stop the spread of illegal content, disinformation and other harmful material.
lead_paragraph: European Union regulators on Thursday opened an inquiry into X, the social media platform owned by Elon Musk, over the prevalence of gory videos and images, terrorism content and other illicit material it is carrying related to the Israel-Hamas war.

headline: Laszlo Solyom, a Transitional President of Hungary, Dies at 81
abstract: A noted legal scholar, he helped lead his country away from Communism after the fall of the Soviet bloc but could not stop its embrace of right-wing populism.
lead_paragraph: Laszlo Solyom, a legal scholar who helped guide Hungary in its transition to a free-market democracy after the fall of Communism in 1989, presiding over his country’s Constitutional Court and then serving as its president from 2005 to 2010, died on Oct. 8 in Budapest. He was 81.

headline: Hunting for the best duck in the city
abstract: A roundup of restaurants where the bird is the word, from the elaborate crown roast at Francie to the crunchy fried wings at Upland.
lead_paragraph: Hi, I’m Pete Wells, restaurant critic for the Times and unarmed duck hunter.

headline: As Warnings of Crisis in Gaza Mount, Palestinians Struggle to Find Room for the Dead
abstract: Israel’s latest strikes on Gaza have drawn warnings from aid workers and residents of a humanitarian catastrophe. “We are facing a huge disaster,” said one U.N. official.
lead_paragraph: Hospitals crowded with patients are running short on fuel. Fearful residents are racing to U.N.-run schools, seeking shelter from airstrikes. Water and electricity have been cut off, the borders are closed, and even the cemeteries do not have room to accommodate all the newly dead.

headline: Thousands Speak Out: ‘We as Students Are Sickened by the Actions of Hamas’
abstract: College students sign a letter condemning the silence of many university administrations.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
abstract: Our TV critic recommends a quirky American sitcom, a historical Canadian weeper and a sumptuous Argentine dramedy.
lead_paragraph: ‘Chad’

headline: Green Energy Builders Sought Billions More in Subsidies. New York Said No.
abstract: The developers will have to decide whether to absorb higher-than-expected costs or break their contracts with the state.
lead_paragraph: New York officials refused on Thursday to grant an additional $12 billion in subsidies to the developers of 90 renewable-energy projects, raising concerns about the state’s ability to cut its dependence on fossil fuels over the next decade.

headline: Ford Says It Won’t Raise Its Offer to Autoworkers Union
abstract: The company said it had reached the limit of what it could offer to the United Automobile Workers union, which has expanded its strike to Ford’s largest plant.
lead_paragraph: Ford Motor said on Thursday that it could not improve its contract offer to the United Automobile Workers union without hurting its business and its ability to invest in electric vehicles.

headline: Friday Briefing: The U.N. Warns of Disaster in Gaza
abstract: Plus a new comic book universe.
lead_paragraph: As Israeli troops moved toward the border with Gaza before a possible ground invasion to dismantle Hamas, a U.N. official warned of a humanitarian “disaster” in the blockaded territory.

headline: Star Witness Caroline Ellison Says Sam Bankman-Fried Made ‘Terrible Mistakes’
abstract: Mr. Bankman-Fried’s lawyers sought to poke holes in Ms. Ellison’s testimony, but her account remained largely consistent.
lead_paragraph: A lawyer for Sam Bankman-Fried on Thursday sought to undermine the testimony of Caroline Ellison, the prosecution’s star witness in his criminal fraud trial, as she continued to insist that the onetime crypto mogul was behind the misuse of billions of dollars in customer money at his FTX exchange.

headline: Vivek Ramaswamy Agrees to Debate Ro Khanna, a California Democrat
abstract: Mr. Ramaswamy becomes the second G.O.P. presidential candidate to agree to such a debate, with the governors of Florida and California also set to debate.
lead_paragraph: Vivek Ramaswamy, the entrepreneur and Republican presidential candidate, said on Wednesday that he would debate Representative Ro Khanna, Democrat of California.

headline: Israel Prepares for a Potential Invasion of Gaza
abstract: Also, House Republicans struggle to choose a leader. Here’s the latest at the end of Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Israel moved troops into position for a multipronged invasion of the Gaza Strip in an effort to dismantle Hamas, the militant group who massacred more than 1,200 Israelis in an attack over the weekend.

headline: Even With Flames Abroad, Biden Keeps One Eye on the Home Front
abstract: The president continued to hold events on economic issues while managing the conflict between Israel and Hamas, hoping to appeal to Americans focused on pocketbook concerns.
lead_paragraph: Less than 24 hours after condemning terrorism in the Middle East in one of the most powerful speeches of his tenure on Tuesday, President Biden was back before television cameras for another statement.

headline: Terminal 4 at J.F.K.: Center of a Wave of Support for Israel
abstract: As soldiers, reservists and volunteers head to Israel, supporters gathered near the El Al counter at Kennedy Airport to give them supplies and cheers.
lead_paragraph: Ilai Lichtental was in Houston at 2 p.m. on Tuesday when his cellphone rang. It was the commanding officer of his search-and-rescue brigade of the Israel Defense Forces, asking Mr. Lichtental to end his vacation in America, leave his family and report for duty, immediately.

headline: From Israel to Ukraine: How Much Support Can the U.S. Sustain?
abstract: How America should be thinking about its role in this “wildly dangerous and unpredictable time.”
lead_paragraph: On today’s episode of “Matter of Opinion,” the hosts discuss the global response to the war between Israel and Hamas. What domestic and international strings are attached to U.S. support in the region? And what will that support signal to rival hostile powers?

headline: California Moves Closer to Imposing First Limits on Groundwater Use
abstract: Officials will weigh whether to directly intervene, for the first time in state history, to stop aquifers from being wrung dry in the Central Valley.
lead_paragraph: California has put a water-stressed farming region on notice for having “inadequate” plans to curb its overuse of groundwater, bringing officials closer to directly intervening, for the first time in state history, in the way growers manage their underground water supplies.

headline: Judge Scolds Prosecution at Hearing on Conflicts in Trump Documents Case
abstract: Judge Aileen Cannon postponed a hearing on a government request involving a lawyer for one of the former president’s co-defendants. She said prosecutors were wasting her time.
lead_paragraph: The judge overseeing former President Donald J. Trump’s coming trial on charges of mishandling classified documents scolded federal prosecutors on Thursday as she postponed a hearing on whether one of Mr. Trump’s co-defendants understood that his lawyer might have conflicts of interest.

headline: Rudolph Isley, an Original and Enduring Isley Brother, Dies at 84
abstract: He provided harmony vocals and the occasional lead. He also helped write some of the group’s biggest hits, including “Shout,” “Fight the Power” and “That Lady.”
lead_paragraph: Rudolph Isley, who held dual roles in the influential vocal group the Isley Brothers as a mellifluous harmony singer and co-writer of many of their greatest hits, died on Wednesday at his home in Chicago. He was 84.

headline: With the World in Crisis, House Republicans Bicker Among Themselves
abstract: Despite conflicts overseas and an approaching deadline to avert a government shutdown, Republicans are unable to rise above their internal divisions.
lead_paragraph: Two key U.S. allies are engulfed in vicious wars. A disruptive government shutdown is looming in just over a month. Americans are held hostage overseas by hostile forces. Uncertainty ripples across the country.

headline: Florida Deputies Charged With Defrauding Covid Funds of Nearly $500,000
abstract: The 17 employees from the Broward Sheriff’s Office in Fort Lauderdale were accused, in separate cases, of falsifying paperwork to collect money from two relief programs.
lead_paragraph: Seventeen deputies at a South Florida sheriff’s office were charged with defrauding federal loan programs of nearly half a million dollars intended to help businesses that were struggling during the coronavirus pandemic, the authorities said.

headline: Israeli Billboards Thanking the U.S. Have a New Face on Them: Biden’s
abstract: After Donald J. Trump bound himself tightly to the Israeli right, and President Biden approached the divided nation gingerly, a warm presidential embrace has eased years of tension.
lead_paragraph: Not long ago, Donald J. Trump occupied enormous psychological space in Israel and among American Jews: His face draped skyscrapers alongside Benjamin Netanyahu’s during Israeli elections, and his politics drove a wedge between the Democratic Party and the Jews who have long called it their political home.

headline: Gaza Hospital Inundated With Wounded Patients
abstract: Al-Shifa Hospital, the Gaza Strip’s largest medical complex, has been overwhelmed with wounded patients since Israel launched airstrikes in Gaza in retaliation to Hamas’s attack.
lead_paragraph: Al-Shifa Hospital, the Gaza Strip’s largest medical complex, has been overwhelmed with wounded patients since Israel launched airstrikes in Gaza in retaliation to Hamas’s attack.

headline: The Missed Chance for Peace
abstract: It’s hard not to wonder whether today’s suffering could have been avoided if in 2000 Palestinians had taken the offer of a path toward statehood.
lead_paragraph: Throughout this horrible week, my mind has repeatedly flashed back to Dec. 23, 2000. That was the day the Palestinians were offered a path to having their own nation on roughly 95 percent of the land in the West Bank and 100 percent of the land in the Gaza Strip. Under that outline, Israel would also swap some of its own land to compensate the Palestinians in exchange for maintaining 80 percent of its settler presence in the West Bank.

headline: One Officer Convicted and Another Acquitted in Elijah McClain Death
abstract: The jury came back with a surprising split decision on two men who were tried together, holding the more experienced officer accountable in the first of three trials in the young Black man’s death.
lead_paragraph: A Colorado jury split its decision in the 2019 death of a young, unarmed Black man, convicting one police officer but acquitting the other on Thursday afternoon, in a case that drew national attention after the murder of George Floyd.

headline: Prosecutors Issued Error-Riddled Report in Menendez Car Crash
abstract: New Jersey prosecutors concluded that Nadine Menendez, Senator Bob Menendez’s wife, should not be charged after she killed a pedestrian with her Mercedes-Benz.
lead_paragraph: A week after a fatal car crash involving the soon-to-be wife of Senator Robert Menendez, a prosecutor’s office in New Jersey filed an official account of the incident that contained apparent factual errors quickly noted by relatives of the pedestrian who was killed.

headline: Oklahoma Judge Exchanged 500 Text Messages During Murder Trial
abstract: The state’s top jurist recommended that Traci Soderstrom, a district judge in Lincoln County, be removed from the bench after she and a bailiff mocked lawyers, jurors and witnesses.
lead_paragraph: An Oklahoma judge who exchanged 500 text messages with her bailiff during a murder trial — mocking the physical appearance of lawyers, jurors and witnesses and deriding prosecutors — should be removed from the bench, the state’s top judge said.

headline: Louisiana Public School Principal Who Punished Student for Dancing Apologizes
abstract: Jason St. Pierre cited religion to discipline a 17-year-old for what he deemed inappropriate dancing at an off-campus Homecoming after-party.
lead_paragraph: The principal of a public high school in Louisiana who cited religion as justification for punishing a student after a video of her dancing circulated on social media has apologized and asked for a leave for the rest of the school year.

headline: Humanitarian Crisis in Gaza Worsens as Israel Prepares a Possible Invasion
abstract: As Israel retaliates for the Hamas assault last weekend and plans a potential ground attack, its airstrikes have left Gazans without power, water and medical care.
lead_paragraph: Six days of Israeli airstrikes have left more than 300,000 Palestinians in the Gaza Strip homeless, with two million residents facing critical shortages of food, water and fuel, while Israeli troops prepared on Thursday for a possible ground invasion after Hamas’s deadly weekend assault.

headline: DeSantis, Voicing Support for Israel, Is Asked: What About Palestine?
abstract: On the campaign trail in New Hampshire, a prospective voter asked the Florida governor, who has issued statements of staunch support for Israel, about civilian casualties in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: Inside a convenience store in Littleton, N.H., Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida was confronted on Thursday with both sides of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

headline: Trump’s Remarks on Hezbollah and Netanyahu Prompt Bipartisan Outcry
abstract: Republican rivals and the White House were among those to roundly condemn the former president for his characterization of the Lebanese militant group.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump drew scorn from both sides of the political aisle on Thursday for remarks that he made one day earlier criticizing Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and referring to Hezbollah, the Iran-backed militant group, as “very smart.”

headline: 13 Conversation Starters Inspired by ‘Being 13’
abstract: Here are some questions to start discussions at dinner tables, in classrooms or with family or friends. We welcome responses from any reader who is 13 or older.
lead_paragraph: Over a year ago, The New York Times put out a call for teenagers who, with their parents’ permission, would let a reporter write about them. Of the hundreds who responded, three girls from three states — Addi, Anna and London — became the subjects.

headline: No Immediate Threat to U.S. Security Amid Hamas Call for Protests, Officials Say
abstract: Top American counterterrorism officials on Thursday said there was no credible or specific intelligence pointing to a current threat to the United States related to the Hamas terrorist attacks on Israel or the ensuing war.
lead_paragraph: Top American counterterrorism officials on Thursday said there was no credible or specific intelligence pointing to a current threat to the United States related to the Hamas terrorist attacks on Israel or the ensuing war.

headline: Lesson Plan: On ‘Being 13’
abstract: Students explore this immersive Times feature, engage in cross-generational conversations about the issues raised, and experiment with expert advice on healthy phone and social media habits.
lead_paragraph: Featured Article: “Being 13” by Jessica Bennett

headline: Where Early Tablets Were First Unveiled
abstract: John-Clark Levin opens our solving weekend.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues

headline: ‘Gutenberg! The Musical!’ Review: Revenge of the Broadway Nerds
abstract: The history of movable type is a terrible idea for a show. Which is why it’s so on brand for this satire of theater and its eternal hopefuls.
lead_paragraph: I know we could all use a good laugh nowadays. But would you settle for a thousand chuckles?

headline: Variety: Consonant Companions
abstract: Eric Berlin’s new creation lets us use the buddy system, but the relationship is complicated.
lead_paragraph: CONSONANT COMPANIONS — This is a new one for me, and a much more complex creation than I had first thought! That’s really Eric Berlin’s thing: He combines familiar variety puzzles, like Marching Bands and Spirals, and improvises with them, coming up with unique challenges that run surprisingly deep.

headline: For ‘Shucked,’ a Broadway Chapter Ends, and Its Future Is Uncertain
abstract: The show said Thursday that it would play a final performance at the Nederlander Theater on Jan. 14, but did not rule out continuing elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: “Shucked,” a musical comedy fueled by corn puns and country music, will end its run at Broadway’s Nederlander Theater on Jan. 14.

headline: Quotation of the Day: In Jamaica, a Debate Over Making Patois the Official Language
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Friday, October 13, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “We are teaching children to read in a foreign language.”

headline: Corrections: Oct. 13, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, Oct. 13, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Monday about allies of President Biden and their efforts to stop third-party and independent presidential candidacies referred incorrectly to Cornel West. He is a former Harvard professor, not a current one.

headline: Why Are There So Many Jacintas?
abstract: The relatively uncommon name of Jacinta or Jacinda is shared among many famous people in New Zealand and Australia, with most of them born in the 1970s.
lead_paragraph: Jacinda Ardern was a prime minister. Jacinta Allan is a state premier. Jacinda Barrett is an actress and model. Jacinta Coleman competed in road cycling at the Olympics. Jacinta John and Jacinta Stapleton are actresses. Jacinta Ruru is a professor of law, and Jacinta Price is a senator.

headline: Two ‘Extreme Extroverts’ Find Love in a Pandemic Bubble
abstract: Larry Handerhan and Donnelly McDowell had no plans to marry until the fourth of eight weddings they attended in 2022. They have Maggie Rogers to thank.
lead_paragraph: In July 2020, Lawrence James Handerhan walked from his home in Washington to a local brewery for a date — his first ever from the dating app Hinge.

headline: Going the Distance After a Nine-Month Backpacking Trip
abstract: Lizzie Rivard and Alec Woletz knew they wanted to be married. A nine-month backpacking trip through Southeast Asia and Europe proved it.
lead_paragraph: Elisabeth Claire Rivard rarely found anyone who spent as much time as she did in art museums and galleries. Alec Jason Woletz was one of those rare people.

headline: Jennifer Graham Likes Jennifer Graham
abstract: She shared my name. How could we not become friends? And how could I not have gone to see her when it mattered most?
lead_paragraph: She had Googled me.

headline: It All Started With a Press Pass
abstract: When Nancy Chen and Patrick McFawn started dating, she warned him that her broadcast journalism career could take her anywhere in the country. They fell in love anyway.
lead_paragraph: When Nancy Chen and Patrick Sheridan McFawn first met in September 2008, neither one was thinking much about romance. They were at trade talks between the United States and China, in Yorba Linda, Calif. Ms. Chen was a student journalist at the University of Southern California, and she had asked Mr. McFawn, a recent graduate of U.S.C. who was helping to recruit student volunteers for the event, for a press pass.

headline: Friday Briefing
abstract: Israel calls on people in north Gaza to evacuate.
lead_paragraph: Israel’s military has informed the U.N. that the entire population of northern Gaza should relocate to the southern half of the territory within 24 hours, a spokesman said, adding that such a movement — involving over one million people — would lead to “devastating humanitarian consequences.”

headline: A Prophetic Dream Sparked a Real-Life Romance
abstract: When Kendra Morris first met Randall Woodfin, the mayor of Birmingham, Ala., she didn’t think anything of it until she had a vision about their future.
lead_paragraph: The first time Kendra Nicole Morris met Randall Lee Woodfin, in May, 2021, she was at a charity golf tournament in her hometown, Birmingham, Ala. Ms. Morris’s real estate brokerage was sponsoring one of the holes, while Mr. Woodfin made an appearance in his capacity as the city’s mayor. The two chatted briefly, but the conversation, as they recall, was not remarkable. Ms. Morris had always thought the mayor “a handsome man” but didn’t pick up on his personality that day.

headline: Here is the latest on the war.
abstract: Frightened Palestinians, heeding Israel’s warnings to abandon their homes in northern Gaza, raced on Friday to flee to the south of the blockaded coastal strip, as aid groups warned that the evacuation of more than a million civilians would have “devastating consequences.”
lead_paragraph: Frightened Palestinians, heeding Israel’s warnings to abandon their homes in northern Gaza, raced on Friday to flee to the south of the blockaded coastal strip, as aid groups warned that the evacuation of more than a million civilians would have “devastating consequences.”

headline: Word of the Day: phonics
abstract: This word has appeared in 24 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word phonics has appeared in 24 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on June 1 in “Jacques Bailly, Spelling Bee’s Pronouncer, Has Tricks For Saying Words Correctly” by Remy Tumin:

headline: Jimmy Kimmel Chides George Santos for Choosing to Back Jim Jordan
abstract: “Santos likes Jordan because when Jim Jordan sees a crime, he keeps his mouth shut,” Kimmel joked.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: After Three Big Quakes, Too Scared to Sleep Anywhere but Outside
abstract: Seemingly unending earthquakes in Afghanistan have killed nearly 1,300 people and amplified already troubling times since the Taliban seized power.
lead_paragraph: The fear from a week of unrelenting earthquakes is palpable throughout the northwestern city of Herat in Afghanistan. Makeshift tents made of sticks and sheets have popped up across public parks, alleyways and grassy medians of main roads, the families within them too afraid to sleep in their homes.

headline: Microsoft Finally Closes In on Activision Deal After Key Approval
abstract: The $69 billion video game acquisition is expected to be finalized soon after the sign-off from British regulators.
lead_paragraph: British regulators on Friday gave final approval to Microsoft’s $69 billion acquisition of the video game publisher Activision Blizzard, the last major obstacle for a deal that at one point seemed to be falling apart because of government objections on both sides of the Atlantic.

headline: Police Seek Suspects in Fatal Shooting of Officer at Philadelphia Airport
abstract: Two officers were shot, one fatally, after confronting people breaking into a car in an airport parking garage, the police said. An 18-year-old suspect was also killed, the police said.
lead_paragraph: The Philadelphia police said on Friday that they were looking for as many as three people who were involved in a shooting on Thursday night that killed one officer and wounded another at a parking garage at Philadelphia International Airport.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Friday the 13th
abstract: How superstitious are you?
lead_paragraph: It’s Friday the 13th, and not only that, but Friday the 13th of October, the spookiest month of them all.

headline: Tagging Along With The New York Times’s Chief Theater Critic
abstract: At a recent performance of “Gutenberg! The Musical!” on Broadway, Jesse Green gave us an inside look at his review process.
lead_paragraph: At 7:40 on a humid Friday night in early October, Jesse Green, wearing a plaid suit coat and carrying a green laptop bag, arrived at the James Earl Jones Theater in Manhattan. The show he was there to see, “Gutenberg! The Musical!,” was starting in 20 minutes, but he was in no rush to enter the theater. As the chief theater critic for The New York Times, he knows Broadway performances usually begin about eight minutes late.

headline: How a Young Activist’s Murder Has Been Gleefully Distorted Online
abstract: Because Ryan Carson was a liberal activist, social media trolls blamed his own politics for his death.
lead_paragraph: It took only a few hours for the death of Ryan Carson, stabbed before dawn in a random assault as he waited for a bus in Brooklyn, to become an indictment of his politics so vitriolic that it threatened to overwhelm the grief. In the view of his online adversaries, Mr. Carson, a 31-year-old progressive activist, died at the hands of his own misbegotten ideology — “brainwashed” into believing he could help the poor and wayward.

headline: New York Has Issued 14 New Food Cart Permits. 10,000 Vendors Want Them.
abstract: More than a year after the city implemented reforms to the food vendor licensing process, few have received permits, even as enforcement picks up.
lead_paragraph: Elsayed Elgammal, who runs a cart called Mando Halal Food, has a loyal clientele that lines up for his signature chicken and rice dish.

headline: ‘United Because of This Disaster’: Israelis Rush to Volunteer After Hamas Attacks
abstract: A long-divided country is pulling together in a show of solidarity, donating everything from breast milk to high-tech help.
lead_paragraph: The message popped up at 10:55 a.m. on Thursday: “Looking for volunteers to help unload a truck of equipment for soldiers. We are at the Museum of Tolerance. Come, there is nobody here.”

headline: In the Beginning Were the Word Nerds
abstract: Sarah Ogilvie’s sprightly “The Dictionary People” pays tribute to the explorers, suffragists, murderers and ordinary citizens who helped create the Oxford English Dictionary.
lead_paragraph: According to the Oxford English Dictionarythe earliest known person to mention a sponge cake in writing was Jane Austen. Austen is also our earliest source for “doorbell,” not to mention “sprawly,” “fragmented” and “irrepressible.”

headline: Audiobook of the Week: ‘The Fraud,’ by Zadie Smith
abstract: The author reads her latest novel about literary prestige, empire and a case of false identity that captivated 19th-century England.
lead_paragraph: Who is the titular fraud in Zadie Smith’s sixth novel, about a Scottish housekeeper in the home of an aging novelist in the 19th-century London suburbs? Is it the novelist, William Ainsworth, whose fame and social status belie a critical reception of his work as “generally dull, except when it is revolting?” Is it the housekeeper, Eliza Touchet (pronounced “touché”), who has lived with William since his cousin, her husband, abandoned her decades earlier, and has since been romantically involved with both William and his own late wife? Or is it the so-called Claimant, the man presenting himself as Sir Roger Tichborne, the heir to a noble fortune who was believed to have died in a shipwreck, inspiring a yearlong court trial that captures the maniacal attention of the English media and public?

headline: A New Law Unites Northern Ireland — in Outrage
abstract: Catholics and Protestants alike say a commission created by the British Parliament to handle hundreds of sectarian crimes will do little to heal old wounds.
lead_paragraph: Robert McClenaghan was 13 years old, lying on a bunk bed at home in west Belfast, when he heard the bomb that killed his grandfather. It was Dec. 4, 1971, and a 50-pound bomb had detonated three miles away at McGurk’s Bar, killing 15 people, all of them Catholics.

headline: It’s Not Enough to Love Disney. They Want to Live Disney.
abstract: For some, a dream is a wish your heart makes at home.
lead_paragraph: The Mickey Mouse-shaped topiaries in front of Kelsey Hermanson’s house are the first hint at what visitors will find inside.

headline: The Importance of Looking at What (and Who) You Don’t See
abstract: To connect with strangers, try spending one minute drawing them. Really.

headline: The Wife Has Committed Murder but It’s the Husband Who Scares Her Lawyer
abstract: In Marie NDiaye’s new novel, “Vengeance Is Mine,” a woman is haunted by a decades-old trauma she feels, but cannot quite remember.
lead_paragraph: The characters in Marie NDiaye’s novels are an unsettling brood. They fret and pace around their homes, tormented by their pasts. Their minds trap and trick them. A daughter can’t shake memories of her mother’s murder; a man gropes for the truth about his imprisonment in a deserted vacation town; a chef pursues culinary perfection at any cost; a woman — reminded of a friend, a schoolteacher or was it her mother? — fatally chases an apparition in green.

headline: P.O.V.: You’re a Jane Austen Character in an Alternate Universe
abstract: Three new books by Malon Edwards, Melinda Taub and Karen Lord.
lead_paragraph: The point-of-view meme has had a steady presence in our social media landscape over the past few years. You’ve probably scrolled past posts that read “P.O.V.: You’re [a specific character doing something wacky],” accompanied by images or videos that supposedly capture said perspective. P.O.V.: You’re a spotted lanternfly sunbathing. (Close-up of shoe tread.) P.O.V.: It’s 1996 and you’re trying to teach kids about irony when Alanis Morissette drops a new single. (Video of cartoon heads exploding.)

headline: Raising Our Glasses to a Pianist Who Loves Vodka
abstract: Gary Graffman, who is turning 95, is a man of many enthusiasms, including citrus infusions.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Friday. Today we’ll find out about the drink of choice at a party for the pianist Gary Graffman, who turns 95 tomorrow. We’ll also see why Gov. Kathy Hochul is threatening to impose fines on some hospitals.

headline: Post-Punk Legend Leads Fight for Clean Water as Britain’s ‘Sewage Czar’
abstract: Feargal Sharkey, best known as the lead singer of the Undertones, has become one of the loudest voices demanding that Britain’s private water companies clean up their act.
lead_paragraph: For Britons of a certain age, Feargal Sharkey will be best known as the lean, raw and energetic lead singer of the Undertones, a band that burst onto the country’s music scene in the late 1970s in a vibrant postscript to the era of punk rock.

headline: I Study Climate Change. The Data Is Telling Us Something New.
abstract: There is increasing evidence that global warming has accelerated over the past 15 years rather than continued at a gradual, steady pace.
lead_paragraph: Staggering. Unnerving. Mind-boggling. Absolutely gobsmackingly bananas.

headline: Your Face May Soon Be Your Ticket. Not Everyone Is Smiling.
abstract: Facial recognition software is speeding up check-in at airports, cruise ships and theme parks, but experts worry about risks to security and privacy.
lead_paragraph: You may not have to fumble with your cellphone in the boarding area very much longer. As the travel industry embraces facial recognition technology, phones are beginning to go the way of paper tickets at airports, cruise terminals and theme parks, making checking in more convenient, but raising privacy and security concerns, too.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on the Soup Debate
abstract: Is it dinner?
lead_paragraph: Paul writes: I’m the cook in our house. As summer turns to fall, I like to make hearty soups. But my wife contends that soup is not a dinner food — unless she is sick. I say this is absurd.

headline: Across U.S., Chinese Bitcoin Mines Draw National Security Scrutiny
abstract: Microsoft reported one site in Wyoming because of its proximity to a data center and nuclear missile base. Records show other cryptocurrency facilities have ties to the Chinese state.
lead_paragraph: When a company with Chinese origins broke ground last year on a crypto-mining operation in Cheyenne, Wyo., a team at Microsoft that assesses national security threats sounded the alarm.

headline: Poem: fluid cupid
abstract: The mixed-up nature of life itself is the unforeseeable consequence of the mating of a good and bad time.
lead_paragraph: A longtime postcard poet, Buck Downs has been sending out monthly poems to readers since the 1990s, and his work, often unsigned, can also be found affixed to light poles and other urban surfaces, distributed via social media feeds or heard at the other end of the telephone line. His poetry often reflects the immediacy and wit demanded of its modes of distribution. In “fluid cupid,” the mixed-up nature of life itself is the unforeseeable consequence of the mating of a good and bad time. This is the zeitgeist as eavesdropped upon, then shaped up, given sonic punch, made resonant with the quirky agonies of the soul. Selected By Anne Boyer

headline: Help! I Was Denied Boarding on a Cruise, and I Wasn’t the Only One.
abstract: A Chinese scientist, an Egyptian grandmother and a Bangladeshi woman from Queens were all turned away and refused a refund despite having the U.S. government’s permission — and documents — to travel.
lead_paragraph: On Aug. 6, my wife, my two children and I arrived at the Brooklyn Cruise Terminal to board the MSC Meraviglia for a weeklong cruise that included a stop in the Bahamas. I am a scientist in the United States on a work visa and awaiting my green card, so I followed my lawyer’s instructions and presented my Chinese passport and my “combo card” — an American document that grants immigrants in my situation permission both to work in the United States and to travel abroad. But MSC Cruises refused to let me board, saying the card did not guarantee I would be readmitted to the country when the boat returned to Brooklyn. I soon met two other would-be travelers in the same, er, boat: Fadia, a 79-year-old Egyptian grandmother set to board with 19 relatives and friends, and Nargis, a Bangladeshi woman ready to cruise with her husband. After hours of pleading our case, even getting Fadia’s immigration lawyer to speak to staff by phone, we were all sent home. MSC refunded me about $500 in fees and taxes, but I’m still owed about $2,300 for the cruise fare for my family of four. Nargis and her husband have also not been reimbursed, nor have Fadia and her son (who stayed behind with her while the rest of the group sailed). Can you help? Heng, New Haven, Conn.

headline: Seeking Solace in ‘Sex and Rage’
abstract: Reading Eve Babitz, a “buttoned up” writer discovers she has more in common with the protagonist than she thinks.

headline: The Secret Art of Turning a Concert Into a Film (Taylor’s Version)
abstract: Movies like “Taylor Swift: The Eras Tour” rely on savvy tricks and sophisticated techniques to capture a semblance of the live experience.
lead_paragraph: Taylor Swift’s globe-spanning Eras Tour is one of the musical events of the year, drawing record-breaking crowds and making headlines the world over since it kicked off in Glendale, Ariz., in March. Rabid demand has made procuring a ticket notoriously difficult, if not practically impossible. But starting Friday, Swifties will have a more accessible opportunity to catch a glimpse of the live phenomenon, when the concert film “Taylor Swift: The Eras Tour” is released by AMC Theaters — a moviegoing event that is widely expected to be a box office smash.

headline: How Jesmyn Ward Is Reimagining Southern Literature
abstract: The novelist is competing with giants like William Faulkner, while mapping territory all her own.
lead_paragraph: Jesmyn Ward gestured with her eyes and a tilt of her face, hands on the wheel. “This crazy colored house right here? That’s my grandmother’s house. That’s the house I grew up in. And her sister lives there” — she pointed — “and then that little blue house? That’s my great-grandparents’ house.” She was driving me around DeLisle, Miss., her hometown and the inspiration for Bois Sauvage, the fictional setting of her first three novels. It is Deep South-in-August hot outside, and the air-conditioning was a relief. “My mom’s side of the family was all clustered around this road.”

headline: New York Is Starting to Act Like a Southern Border State
abstract: The influx of migrants is taxing the social safety net in the U.S. Will Democrats pay the price for it?
lead_paragraph: For far too long, too many Americans considered the border to be someone else’s problem — someone in Texas, maybe, or Arizona or California. People who didn’t live near the border might have condemned harsh tactics used there or offered their communities as sanctuaries for those who managed to slip across it. But for the most part, the challenges of the border remained at the border. Out of sight, out of mind.

headline: Retailers’ Seasonal Hiring Plans Signal a Cooling Labor Market
abstract: After scrambling to fill out work forces in recent years, many companies are reporting more modest goals for temporary employment.
lead_paragraph: As the most important selling season for retailers approaches, job applicants may feel a chill.

headline: Story Collections That Are Also Inventories of Catastrophes
abstract: New fiction by Chloe Aridjis, Ghassan Zeinnedine and Megan Kamalei Kakimoto ranges from the fabulist to the vaguely autofictional.
lead_paragraph: There are times when people need guides, rules, a system of being that results in predictable outcomes, leaving us satisfied and unbothered. Chloe Aridjis’ fourth book, DIALOGUE WITH A SOMNAMBULIST: Stories, Essays & a Portrait Gallery (Catapult, 264 pp., $27), has no interest in such a comfortable system of being.

headline: Behind the Most Famous Men in Economics There Have Always Been Women
abstract: Consider the case of Milton Friedman.
lead_paragraph: When the Nobel Committee awarded its prize in economics on Monday to the Harvard professor Claudia Goldin — the first woman to receive the award solo — it was both a vindication of a storied career and a reminder of how male-dominated economics remains. Ever since the early 1970s, when women first entered the field in significant numbers, they have faced discouragement, discrimination and harassment. Today fewer than a quarter of tenured economics professors are women.

headline: Hard-Line Republican Leads Race to Succeed Louisiana’s Democratic Governor
abstract: Should Jeff Landry, the state attorney general and front-runner, win, he will likely drive Louisiana further right on issues such as crime and L.G.B.T.Q. rights.
lead_paragraph: Jeff Landry, the hard-line conservative leading the race for governor of Louisiana, surveyed the crowd packed into a small restaurant in Monroe, where his staff had covered the tables and a lone Halloween skeleton in his blue-and-yellow campaign merchandise.

headline: Biden Administration Awards $7 Billion for 7 Hydrogen Hubs Across the U.S.
abstract: Clean hydrogen could help fight climate change, but it barely exists today. Now the administration wants to build an entire industry from scratch.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration announced plans on Friday to award up to $7 billion to create seven regional hubs around the country that will make and use hydrogen, a clean-burning fuel with the potential to power ships or factories without producing any planet-warming emissions.

headline: Growing Wariness of Aid to Ukraine Hangs Over Polish Election
abstract: Last year, Poland was one of Ukraine’s staunchest supporters. But pressure from the right to focus more on domestic problems is pushing that support to the center stage of Sunday’s election.
lead_paragraph: The radical right-wing candidate running for Parliament in Poland’s deep south wants to slash taxes, regulations on business and welfare benefits. Most striking, however, is his vow to remove a small Ukrainian flag that was hoisted last year on a town hall balcony as a gesture of solidarity with Poland’s eastern neighbor.

headline: Two Young Women Capture Life Under Siege Inside Gaza
abstract: Airstrikes in Gaza have destroyed entire neighborhoods and forced hundreds of thousands of people from their homes. Plestia Alaqad and Nour AlSaqqa, both in their early 20s, shared what life is like under siege.
lead_paragraph: Airstrikes in Gaza have destroyed entire neighborhoods and forced hundreds of thousands of people from their homes. Plestia Alaqad and Nour AlSaqqa, both in their early 20s, shared what life is like under siege.

headline: The Pathways to Peace Are Getting Darker
abstract: I fear the world’s commitment to peace is fading.
lead_paragraph: Like many Israelis right now, I’m inconsolable. I’ve watched for days as the pain over lost lives and hostages accumulates. This is hell, and the days ahead will be worse.

headline: Social Media in Wartime, Betting on the Future and A.I. Passes the Smell Test
abstract: The Israel-Hamas war highlights X’s moderation failures. What should be social media’s role in global conflict?
lead_paragraph: As the Israel-Hamas war broke out, misinformation and fake imagery surged on X, the platform formerly known at Twitter. Can Meta’s Threads fill the real-time news hole that X created? Should it?

headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
abstract: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including the concert film “Taylor Swift: The Eras Tour.”
lead_paragraph: A selection of entertainment highlights this weekend, including the concert film “Taylor Swift: The Eras Tour.”

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, Oct. 13, 2023
abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: How to Break Up With Your Therapist
abstract: Moving on can be a sign of growth, experts say. Step one: Try not to ghost.
lead_paragraph: If you’ve ever been in therapy, you know that the relationship is unique. You might tell your therapist things you wouldn’t share with your loved ones. “It’s the most intimate professional relationship you’ll ever have,” said John Norcross, a professor of psychology at the University of Scranton. So what should you do when you’re ready to move on?

headline: This Is How the Republican Party Got Southernized
abstract: Nixon’s Southern strategy, developed with Kevin Phillips, who died this week, ended up permanently changing the Republican Party.
lead_paragraph: In 1969 a young aide in the Nixon White House, 28-year-old Kevin Phillips, published “The Emerging Republican Majority.”

headline: I’m Going to War for Israel. Palestinians Are Not My Enemy.
abstract: This war could have been avoided, and no one did enough to prevent it.
lead_paragraph: I was in Austin, Texas, for work on Saturday when I received a call from my commander in the Israel Defense Forces to return to Israel and head to the front line. I didn’t hesitate. I knew that the citizens of my country were in real danger. My duty first and foremost is to join the fight against those who unleashed a massacre on my people. I boarded the first flight I found out of Austin to head home to join the I.D.F. reserves, where I serve as a brigade operations command officer.

headline: Airstrikes Intensify in Gaza, and More
abstract: Plus, Scalise withdraws as House speaker candidate and a look at Montana’s TikTok ban.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

headline: A U.K. University Will Confer a New Title: A Master’s Degree in the Occult
abstract: The postgraduate degree, to be offered at the University of Exeter starting next year, will focus on the history of magic, folklore and rituals.
lead_paragraph: In the ancient city of Exeter, three women were hanged for practicing witchcraft in the late 17th century, the last of such executions in England. Now, merely a short walk from where the hangings occurred, the University of Exeter will offer a postgraduate degree in magic and occult science, which the school says is the first of its kind at a British university.

headline: Hamas Attack on Israel Brings New Scrutiny of Group’s Ties to Iran
abstract: Officials from Iran and Hezbollah helped plan the attack, people familiar with the operation said, but the U.S. and its allies have not found evidence directly linking Tehran.
lead_paragraph: Follow live news updates on the Israel-Hamas war.

headline: Golan’s Story
abstract: A father’s account of survival in the attack on an Israeli kibbutz.
lead_paragraph: Warning: this episode contains descriptions of death.

headline: A Painting Stolen in Glasgow Returns More Than 30 Years Later
abstract: Thieves in Scotland made off with the painting “Children Wading” in 1989. The work was recently returned after showing up at an auction house in northern England.
lead_paragraph: The thieves who broke into a Glaswegian museum in 1989 kept the heist fairly simple.

headline: A Looming Invasion in Gaza
abstract: The war has the potential to become another case study in the strategic difficulties of urban warfare.
lead_paragraph: For years, Israeli officials have worried about the threat of Hamas in the Gaza Strip. Still, they viewed a full ground invasion of Gaza to be too dangerous and costly to try. Many Israeli soldiers would die. The widespread killing of Palestinian civilians would damage Israel’s global reputation. The invasion might fail to dismantle Hamas.

headline: Fierce Fighting Flares Around Eastern Ukrainian Town of Avdiivka
abstract: Russia’s assault there may be a sign that Moscow is trying to regain the initiative in the war, after it spent months defending against Ukraine’s southern counteroffensive.
lead_paragraph: Russian and Ukrainian forces were locked in fierce fighting around the eastern frontline town of Avdiivka for a fourth straight day on Friday, in one of Moscow’s biggest military offensives in months.

headline: Microsoft Beats the Antitrust Odds on Its Activision Deal
abstract: Approval from British regulators for the $69 billion takeover was the last hurdle left for the tech giant, which saw off serious challenges to the transaction.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft is poised to close its $69 billion takeover of the video game publisher Activision Blizzard, after British regulators signed off on the transaction on Friday.

headline: France Raises Terrorist Threat Level After Teacher Killed in Stabbing
abstract: President Emmanuel Macron said France had been “hit by the barbarity of Islamist terrorism” in an attack that recalled the brutal murder of another teacher by an Islamic extremist.
lead_paragraph: The French government raised its terrorist threat alert to the highest level on Friday after a knife-wielding man killed a teacher and injured three other people at a school in northern France in what officials described as an Islamist terror attack, deeply disturbing the country.

headline: Thousands Flee Northern Gaza as Israeli Evacuation Order Stirs Panic
abstract: Some residents fear a start of another permanent displacement. Gaza authorities said at least 70 people were killed when Israeli airstrikes hit some vehicles heading south.
lead_paragraph: Panic and chaos gripped the northern Gaza Strip Friday as thousands of people fled south in vehicles piled high with blankets and mattresses along two main roads after the Israeli military ordered a mass evacuation of half of the besieged coastal strip.

headline: Deep, Dark Spaghetti all’Assassina
abstract: Cook your pasta until its spicy sauce has almost completely evaporated and is just beginning to char, “as dark as polished ebony.”
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Bari, Italy, the capital of Puglia, is on the Adriatic coast. My friend and colleague Steven Raichlen was there not long ago to look into one of the city’s most notable pasta dishes: spaghetti all’assassina (above). That translates as the spaghetti of an assassin, killer spaghetti: spicy, singed strands of deeply burnished pasta cooked until its sauce has almost evaporated, until it has almost started to char.

headline: Kaiser Permanente Reaches Tentative Deal With Health Care Workers
abstract: The proposed settlement follows a three-day strike involving thousands of unionized workers in several states.
lead_paragraph: Kaiser Permanente reached a tentative deal with more than 75,000 of its health care workers Friday morning, a week after a three-day walkout that disrupted appointments and services at many hospitals and clinics.

headline: NASA Launches Psyche, a Mission to Explore a Metal Asteroid
abstract: The probe launched on a SpaceX Falcon Heavy rocket, beginning a six-year journey to one of the most enigmatic worlds in the asteroid belt between Mars and Jupiter.
lead_paragraph: Is the asteroid Psyche really a hunk of mostly metal? Is the object, which is nearly as wide as Massachusetts, the core of a baby planet whose rocky outer layers were knocked off during a cataclysmic collision in the early days of the solar system?

headline: Microsoft Closes $69 Billion Activision Deal, Overcoming Regulators’ Objections
abstract: The megadeal could strengthen Microsoft’s standing in the video game industry, after a year and a half of negotiations with regulators around the world.
lead_paragraph: Microsoft said on Friday that it had closed its $69 billion purchase of the video game giant Activision Blizzard, overcoming significant regulatory hurdles in Britain and the United States and signaling that the tech industry’s giants are still free to use their cash hoards to get even bigger.

headline: Scenes From Northern Gaza After Warning to Evacuate
abstract: Residents of northern Gaza began to flee hours after the Israeli military called for civilians to evacuate to the southern half of the territory.
lead_paragraph: Residents of northern Gaza began to flee hours after the Israeli military called for civilians to evacuate to the southern half of the territory.

headline: Bonds Have Been Awful. It’s a Good Time to Buy.
abstract: As interest rates rose over the past few years, bond prices plummeted, making high-quality bonds more attractive, our columnist says.
lead_paragraph: It’s impossible to survey the current bond market without shuddering. A team of analysts at Bank of America calls it “the greatest bond bear market of all time.”

headline: Gavin Newsom Approves Some Landmark Laws as Deadline Approaches
abstract: Laws establishing the country’s first “Ebony Alert” for missing Black children and a ban on some potentially toxic chemicals in cosmetics were signed by the governor this week.
lead_paragraph: Tomorrow is the last day for Gov. Gavin Newsom to sign or veto the roughly 900 bills that the State Legislature sent him before its session ended last month. He’s already torn through hundreds of measures this week, and as of Thursday evening, about 100 were still awaiting his decision.

headline: How to Take Advantage of a Health Savings Account
abstract: Insurance plans with high deductibles may seem unappealing, but the savings accounts that often come with them offer significant tax benefits.
lead_paragraph: Health insurance plans with high deductibles may, at first glance, seem unappealing because you’re likely to pay more out of pocket now for medical care. But such plans can also offer the option of investing for the future through special health savings accounts.

headline: A Comedy Advice Podcast Asks Listeners to ‘Believe in the Bit’
abstract: Jake Johnson and Gareth Reynolds have built a following for their podcast, “We’re Here to Help,” in a short time by blending counsel with comedy.
lead_paragraph: Gareth Reynolds and Jake Johnson went from acquaintances to friends at a dive bar in the Los Feliz neighborhood of Los Angeles.

headline: Trapped in Gaza, Palestinian Americans Say They Feel Abandoned
abstract: As bombs fall and phone batteries run low, Palestinian American families caught in the Israel-Hamas war wonder whether the U.S. government will help them escape.
lead_paragraph: Duaa Abufares, 24, a psychology student from Clifton, N.J., has been anxiously awaiting word from her father, Fares, each day this week. He had gone back to Gaza to visit relatives in early September.

headline: Dimon Warns of ‘Most Dangerous Time’ as Banks Report Big Profits
abstract: JPMorgan Chase, Wells Fargo and Citigroup said that consumers continued to borrow and spend, but their chiefs warned that geopolitical risks were intensifying.
lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase’s chief executive, Jamie Dimon, is as close as Wall Street has to a statesman, and on Friday he sounded a major alarm about the global effects of the conflict in Israel and Gaza.

headline: Republicans Tap Jordan for Speaker, but Delay Vote as Holdouts Balk
abstract: The Ohio congressman was his party’s second nominee this week to emerge from an internal fight. But with scores of Republicans refusing to back him, the party put off a House floor vote until next week.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live updates for the House speaker vote.

headline: Speaking Minionese and More: The Week in Reporter Reads
abstract: Articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
lead_paragraph: This weekend, listen to a collection of articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.

headline: Arab Citizens of Israel Were Not Spared in the Hamas-Led Massacres
abstract: About two million of Israel’s citizens are Arab. Many identify as Palestinian or share close family ties with those in the West Bank and Gaza.
lead_paragraph: The family of Awad Darawsheh spent five agonizing days waiting for news. Mr. Darawsheh, a paramedic in his 20s, had been working at a music festival in southern Israel when Palestinian gunmen stormed in, firing at fleeing attendees and dragging others away as hostages.

headline: For Jewish New Yorkers, Shared Grief Puts Divisions on Hold
abstract: Usually lively and often fractious, political conversations are set aside among the large community of Jews in the city.
lead_paragraph: New York’s Jewish community is the largest outside of Israel, and it is often polarized, particularly regarding Israel and its treatment of Palestinians. Since the brutal terror attacks on Israelis last Saturday, many New York Jews said they have put aside those differences.

headline: LeVar Burton to Host National Book Awards
abstract: The actor and literacy advocate will host the ceremony after the National Book Foundation dropped its original host, Drew Barrymore.
lead_paragraph: The National Book Foundation has tapped a new host for its 74th award ceremony next month: the actor and literacy advocate LeVar Burton.

headline: Review: Nicole Scherzinger Captivates in a Daring ‘Sunset Boulevard’
abstract: A stripped-back revival in London, directed by Jamie Lloyd, brings the classic musical into the present day, and gives Scherzinger a career-defining performance.
lead_paragraph: The 1993 Andrew Lloyd Webber musical “Sunset Boulevard” is about a former screen star’s descent into madness. So it seems appropriate that its bravura new West End revival should, in creative terms, itself be a bit mad: reckless and daring, stretching its source material to the limit and beyond.

headline: As Microsoft Completes Activision Deal, Gamers Celebrate Cautiously
abstract: They could save money if Activision’s titles are added to Xbox Game Pass, a monthly subscription service. But some are reserving judgment.
lead_paragraph: When Microsoft announced that it was spending $69 billion to buy the video game maker Activision Blizzard in January last year, Justin Kats was stunned.

headline: How Microsoft Turned the Tide in Its Regulatory Fight Over Activision
abstract: The company found a way to placate three of the most powerful regulatory bodies in the world, along with a federal judge in San Francisco.
lead_paragraph: The first call that Satya Nadella, Microsoft’s chief executive, made in early 2022 after his company announced a $69 billion deal to buy the video game publisher Activision Blizzard was to Kenichiro Yoshida, the chief executive of Sony.

headline: Russia Detains Navalny’s Lawyers in Move to Further Isolate Him, Allies Say
abstract: Attorneys for the jailed opposition leader, Aleksei A. Navalny, had been helping him maintain a significant public presence, even from prison.
lead_paragraph: Russian authorities on Friday detained three lawyers representing the jailed opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny in what his supporters said was a government-led attempt to continue to isolate him and further limit his ability to influence the country’s political life.

headline: Khaled Khalifa, Syrian Novelist ‘Exiled at Home,’ Is Dead at 59
abstract: His books, laced with humor and often banned in his country, chronicle centuries of strife in the Middle East, earning critical praise and an international readership.
lead_paragraph: Khaled Khalifa, a Syrian author whose sprawling novels made him an authoritative chronicler of his country’s decades of war and political upheaval and found readers around the world, died on Sept. 30 in his home in Damascus. He was 59.

headline: ‘Billions’ Season 7, Episode 10: Mutually Assured Destruction
abstract: Axe’s fixer skills are tested after Prince issues an order.
lead_paragraph: To borrow some terminology from professional wrestling, an art form much beloved by the traders and lawyers of “Billions” (to say nothing of the show’s writers), Mike Prince is a monster heel champion. He is a bad guy at the top of the heap, gold around his waist and his last defeat a distant memory. Seemingly impervious to attack, Prince steamrolls every babyface contender who comes his way. He is an effective villain because he has been booked to be unstoppable — all to better set up the moment when he is stopped.

headline: Five Horror Movies to Stream Now
abstract: Deranged siblings, a creepy voyeur and nasty tricksters are among this Halloween’s scary movie treats.
lead_paragraph: Martha (Eline Schumacher, magnetic) endures repeated sexual assaults by a worker at the factory where she’s a night janitor. She carries her trauma home to the weird Gothic mansion where she communes with a circle of creeps, including her overprotective serial-killer brother, Felix (Benjamin Ramon), sinister long-limbed creatures that lurk in the hallways and uncanny mirror images of herself. Then there’s the young woman that Felix brought home to be a “kitty,” as Martha calls her. I’ll stop there because to say more would give away too much of this depraved film’s sadistic surprises.

headline: Reflections on a Porch, and a Life
abstract: Turning 50 isn’t the end of youth or the start of old age. It’s a perch with a stable foundation and a great view.
lead_paragraph: “You’ll have to use your imagination,” our real estate agent said as she unlocked the front door of a mint green, vinyl-sided house on a quiet street in northern New Jersey.

headline: The Easiest Homemade Bread for an Irresistible Sandwich
abstract: A no-knead, no-fail dough that requires neither patience nor planning turns out delicious focaccia.
lead_paragraph: Making yeasted bread is one of the few acts of cooking where ingredients actually come to life. Dough expands in size and flavor when yeast feast on sugar to then release carbon dioxide gas. Seeing and smelling dough rise can be as restorative as eating the warm loaf, but only if the process feels foolproof and manageable.

headline: Moving a Masterpiece to La Guardia Is a High-Wire Act
abstract: A five-ton aerial sculpture created by Richard Lippold for Lincoln Center, where it hung for decades, has been reinstalled at an airport. Is it a win for New York?
lead_paragraph: For more than 50 years, “Orpheus and Apollo,” the constellation of gleaming metal bars conceived by the sculptor Richard Lippold, graced the grand lobby of Lincoln Center’s Philharmonic Hall like two friendly gods floating in space. It hung on steel wires from the ceiling until 2014, when it was taken down for safety concerns. This midcentury masterpiece has now, against all odds, been reassembled at another New York landmark — La Guardia Airport.

headline: Islamic State Attack Kills 17 at Shiite Mosque in Northern Afghanistan
abstract: The attack was a bloody reminder of the insecurity that persists in the region and which has spread to neighboring Pakistan since the end of the U.S.-led war.
lead_paragraph: A suicide attack by the Islamic State at a Shiite mosque in northern Afghanistan killed at least 17 people on Friday, according to hospital officials and eyewitnesses, in a bloody reminder of the insecurity that remains in the country and has spread to Pakistan two years after the end of the U.S.-led war.

headline: Review: ‘The Hunt’ Playfully Makes the Medieval Contemporary
abstract: Kate Soper’s latest stage work freely moves between legend and anachronism for a story about three virgins taking charge of their bodies.
lead_paragraph: “I was delighted to learn from this charming song all about the qualities, habits and foibles of the unicorn, or ‘monoceron,’” a character says near the start of “The Hunt,” Kate Soper’s latest work of music theater.

headline: Brooklyn Councilwoman Charged After Openly Carrying Gun at Protest
abstract: Inna Vernikov, a conservative Republican who represents a South Brooklyn district, was charged with criminal possession of a firearm after bringing a gun to a pro-Palestine rally.
lead_paragraph: A Republican councilwoman from Brooklyn was arrested on Friday and charged with criminal possession of a firearm after images posted on social media showed her carrying a gun in her waistband at a pro-Palestinian rally at Brooklyn College the previous day.

headline: Scenting Power, U.K. Business Flocks to the Labour Party
abstract: The governing Conservative Party was long seen as entrepreneurs’ natural ally and lobbyists’ most important target. With an election on the horizon, that’s changing.
lead_paragraph: It was impossible to miss: a large green, yellow and blue off-road vehicle parked in a prime spot in the exhibition hall at the Labour Party’s annual conference. The car belonged to Ineos, one of the world’s largest chemical companies, and its outsize presence, among dozens of businesses and organizations, marked the company’s first time attending the gathering.

headline: The Upshot of Microsoft’s Activision Deal: Big Tech Can Get Even Bigger
abstract: With the completion of the blockbuster acquisition, the notion that tech giants can grow through “vertical transactions” remains intact.
lead_paragraph: President Biden’s top antitrust officials have used novel arguments over the past few years to stop tech giants and other large companies from making deals, a strategy that has had mixed success.

headline: ‘Annika’ Review: The Detective Would Like to Have a Word With You
abstract: Nicola Walker plays a cop who works out her issues by talking to the audience in a “Masterpiece” mystery on PBS.
lead_paragraph: A detective whose unit investigates waterborne crimes walks onto a bridge, looks into the camera and says, “Call me Annika.” She then proceeds to chat with the audience about Ahab and his white whale while she watches a murder victim being pulled from the River Clyde.

headline: At 20, Frieze London Is a Different Fair for a Changed City
abstract: The event has become unashamedly commercial, and the quirky moments that defined earlier editions have gone.
lead_paragraph: The patch of park is the same. The design of the tent is similar and the people inside look familiar. But since it opened in 2003, a lot has changed at the Frieze London art fair, whose 20th anniversary edition opened to V.I.P. visitors on Wednesday. London is different, too. And the world isn’t the same, either.

headline: The Big Number: $1.48 Billion
abstract: Birkenstock went from a sandal worn by hippies and hikers to a favorite of celebrities. Now, anyone can buy the company's stock.
lead_paragraph: Birkenstock went from a sandal worn by hippies and hikers to a favorite of celebrities. Now, anyone can buy the company's stock.

headline: Have You Ever Seen an Elephant Twerk?
abstract: Ellie the Elephant, the mascot for the New York Liberty, has danced her way into the hearts of fans as the team has played its way into the W.N.B.A. finals.
lead_paragraph: Every mascot has its thing. Some dunk. Others flip. As for Ellie the Elephant, the mascot for the New York Liberty women’s basketball team? She twerks.

headline: U.A.W. Says Auto Strikes Will Become More Unpredictable
abstract: The United Automobile Workers union refrained from expanding the strikes at Ford, General Motors and Stellantis but said it could do so at any time.
lead_paragraph: Four weeks after starting limited strikes against three large automakers, the United Automobile Workers is shifting to a more aggressive strategy, suggesting that work stoppages could spread to more plants and possibly go on for some time.

headline: On View: A Painter Capturing Motion on Canvas
abstract: The artist Ludovic Nkoth, who has a new show at François Ghebaly gallery in L.A., discusses how migration influences his work.
lead_paragraph: The artist Ludovic Nkoth, who has a new show at François Ghebaly gallery in L.A., discusses how migration influences his work.

headline: U.S. Cities Bolster Security After Hamas Calls for Day of Protest
abstract: Officials increased patrols around religious institutions and public spaces across the country, as tensions in Jewish and Muslim communities mounted.
lead_paragraph: Cities across the United States took extra security precautions on Friday after Hamas called for a day of protest around the world, rhetoric that raised tensions in Jewish and Muslim communities.

headline: ‘Eras’ Comes to the Big Screen, a Day Ahead of Schedule
abstract: Many Swifties had bought their weekend tickets when the pop star made her announcement the movie would come out a day early, but fans still showed up for souvenirs, selfies and a chance to be first.
lead_paragraph: Sparkles, cowgirl boots and Taylor Swift souvenir popcorn buckets were the accessories for those who made it to the Thursday night movie screening of the singer’s highly anticipated film, “Taylor Swift: The Eras Tour.”

headline: Behind a Senator’s Indictments, a Foreign Spy Service Works Washington
abstract: The charges against Senator Robert Menendez and his wife highlight how Egypt’s powerful intelligence agency wields influence.
lead_paragraph: “What else can the love of my life do for you?” asked Nadine Arslanian, the girlfriend of Senator Robert Menendez.

headline: NASA Launches Mission to Explore a Metal Asteroid
abstract: A SpaceX Falcon Heavy rocket launched the probe from the Kennedy Space Center in Florida, beginning a six-year journey to explore an asteroid named Psyche.
lead_paragraph: A SpaceX Falcon Heavy rocket launched the probe from the Kennedy Space Center in Florida, beginning a six-year journey to explore an asteroid named Psyche.

headline: Protests Erupt Across the Middle East Over Israel’s Siege of Gaza
abstract: Friday is a day of prayer in the Middle East, and this Friday was also a day of protest in support of the Palestinian people.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of thousands of people took to the streets in Iraq on Friday. Imams leading prayers in Lebanon denounced the state of Israel. And in the island nation of Bahrain, videos shared by activists showed protesters walking on Israeli and American flags.

headline: Fact or Fiction? In This War, It Is Hard to Tell.
abstract: Social media is full of false and misleading posts. The rise in A.I. is making it worse. And the trust in traditional news sources has declined.
lead_paragraph: The major social media platforms, once heralded for their ability to document global events in real time, face a crisis of authenticity — one of their own making, critics say.

headline: Award Ceremony for Palestinian Author at Frankfurt Book Fair Is Canceled
abstract: The prize’s organizers cited the Israel-Hamas war as the reason for stepping back from an event honoring a novel about the 1949 murder of a Palestinian girl by Israeli soldiers.
