The phrase runs across a black-and-white close-up of a woman’s face as she lies in the grass, her hair merging with the ground, a slender leaf placed over each of her eyes, as if reductive binaries — whether they’re between nature and culture, female and male, the body and the mind — render us blind.

headline: She Burned It All Down, to Build the Perfect Dress
abstract: Mara Hoffman ditched her successful swimsuit business in order to prioritize sustainability. Nearly a decade later, she’s reaping the rewards.
lead_paragraph: It looked like a normal dress, a nice one. Something you might wear to a wedding if you wanted to be a bit sexy. It was floor-length, the V-neck plunging into a rosette that swirled and gathered under the bust, and the spaghetti straps crisscrossed on a low-cut back, kind of like a sporty, 1970s swimsuit.

headline: At an All-Ages Playground, an Art Collection Grows
abstract: City Museum in St. Louis, where visitors are invited to explore and get lost, is acquiring contemporary art and architectural works to offer them more.
lead_paragraph: The yellow school bus on the rooftop, the jumble of slides and climbers, and the castle in the parking lot loudly hint that City Museum in downtown here isn’t a typical museum.

headline: As War Rages On, a Museum of Russian Art Stands Up for Ukraine
abstract: Since the invasion in 2022, the Minneapolis institution has faced immense pressure. It has responded by curating bold antiwar exhibitions.
lead_paragraph: Overlooking Interstate 35, one of the main arteries that weaves through this city, is a tower painted in yellow and blue for the Ukrainian flag. It belongs to the Museum of Russian Art.

headline: Showcasing the Power of Women in Renaissance Italy
abstract: An exhibition at the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, examines how women faced barriers to equality but often overcame them to contribute to the culture of the era.
lead_paragraph: Platform shoes. Lush fabrics. Prolific selfies.

headline: The True Uniform of Los Angeles, According to Angelenos
abstract: It’s more than a Dodgers hat and jeans.
lead_paragraph: In the mythology of the West, Los Angeles is equal parts grit and glamour. The reality isn’t far-off: Impossibly pink bougainvillea blooms feet away from gray highways choked with round-the-clock traffic. Look to your left at a stoplight and you may see a bored Uber driver, tooling around for fares, or a young starlet going incognito with sunglasses leaving her local coffee shop.

headline: What Would Inspire Climate Action? Perhaps an Orange Sky.
abstract: A show at the Blanton Museum of Art set out to consider a world where greenhouse gasses turn the sky orange. Then a burning planet made it a reality.
lead_paragraph: What if people could see what is driving climate change? Months before fires raged across the globe, that question was posed by the Blanton Museum of Art at the University of Texas, leading to its group show, “If the Sky Were Orange: Art in the Time of Climate Change.”

headline: A Photographer’s House of Shadows
abstract: In his home and studio, as in his art, Bill Henson plays with the balance of light and dark.
lead_paragraph: In the Northcote suburb of Melbourne, Australia, an enclave known for its coffeehouses and music clubs, the residential streets are mostly lined with century-old wood houses. But one building stands out: the home and studios of the photographer Bill Henson and his partner, the painter Louise Hearman. A discreet black steel gate leads to a short cobblestone lane and then a towering wooden door, beyond which stands a two-story brick monolith covered in ivy.

headline: At Museums and Galleries, a Spirit of Togetherness
abstract: Across the nation, art exhibitions offer a look at the impact artists have on one another, their subjects and their communities.
lead_paragraph: The spirit of creative collaboration is on display in gallery and museum shows this fall and winter. Across the United States, exhibitions focusing on artists’ relationships with each other — such as Henri Matisse and André Derain, and Toshiko Takaezu and Lenore Tawney — and to their subjects — like that of Il Guercino or John Singer Sargent — offer new avenues for audiences to explore their work and contemporary impact. Here is a selection.

headline: Radicchio Is in Season — And in Style
abstract: Increasingly, the vegetable is becoming a mainstay of contemporary American cuisine.
lead_paragraph: A head of Rosa di Campo Rosso radicchio can, as its name suggests, look convincingly like a rose, with silken red leaves. It might also — depending on its genetic mix — resemble a crimson-speckled yellow orchid or a shocking pink peony. But it is, definitively, a vegetable: a herbaceous perennial descended from the ordinary blue chicory flower found by roadsides in Europe and North America. While chicory is also cultivated in the form of Belgian endive (the blanched, milky yellow root first harvested in Brussels in the 19th century) and puntarelle (spiny stalks famously beloved by Romans), radicchio is by far its most dramatic incarnation. “And the prettiest radicchios are the hardest to grow,” says Jessi Okamoto, one of the co-owners of Campo Rosso, the specialty vegetable farm in Pennsylvania that developed the Rosa di Campo Rosso. As with a handful of other varieties, the Rosa is beautiful, in part, because it has been lied to: In the fall, young plants are transferred from the field into a heated greenhouse, tricking them into a second round of growth and an overdressed debut amid December’s brassicas and tubers.

headline: Exhibitions Meant to Bridge Global Differences
abstract: Shows in New York, Cleveland and Los Angeles aim to educate the public about less-understood parts of the world.
lead_paragraph: “I think we’re hard-wired to be afraid of people who are different from us,” said Linda Komaroff, a curator of Islamic art at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art. “A show focused on dining makes it easier. We all eat, we all like food.”

headline: Making Connections With the Unseen
abstract: At the American Museum of Natural History, “Invisible Worlds” immerses visitors in systems and experiences hidden from the human eye.
lead_paragraph: Six years. Thousands of hours of data research. Dozens of interviews with scientists. Sixty-two audio speakers. Sixteen projectors.

headline: Tote Bags for Those Who Want to Have It All
abstract: Roomy, neutral accessories that go with everything.

headline: A Museum Takes a New, Unvarnished Look at a Massacre
abstract: A revised exhibit about the 1864 Sand Creek Massacre in Colorado drew heavily on the views of members of the Cheyenne and Arapaho tribes.
lead_paragraph: Just inside the lobby of the History Colorado Center — in front of the familiar “Welcome to Colorado” sign — stand two tepees.

headline: At the de Young, a Rousing Showcase for Bay Area Artists
abstract: A call for art went out. Almost 8,000 pieces were submitted. The 883 chosen works make up a dizzying, bursting-at-the-seams extravaganza of an exhibition.
lead_paragraph: One painting shows a too-sweet image of a Barbie face, a stream of honey oozing from a hole in her head. Nearby hangs a more detailed portrait of an Asian American woman with a pale complexion that appears to be cracking — shattering the stereotype of “porcelain” skin. Other artworks take images of American flags, or actual flags, and rework or reweave them. And a sculpture features Gen. Robert E. Lee in the form of a classic wooden toy, knocked flat on his back with sword limp at his side to evoke the way in which racial reckonings have toppled historical figures.

headline: Letting a Thousand Drones Rise on a Saturday in Central Park
abstract: A public art event based on a murmuration of starlings will resemble a silent display of fireworks, organizers say.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. We’ll find out about an unusual flight over Central Park that’s planned for Saturday. We’ll also look at what’s behind a Justice Department investigation of the police in Trenton, N.J.

headline: Jacqueline Woodson and Amber McBride Look Backward to Look Forward
abstract: “Remember Us” recalls the fires of 1970s Bushwick. “Gone Wolf” begins in a 2111 Southern breakaway nation after a second Civil War.
lead_paragraph: The remembrance of things past and the deconstruction of old traumas are at the heart of two exceptional new middle grade novels. “Remember Us,” by the National Book Award winner Jacqueline Woodson, and “Gone Wolf,” by Amber McBride, both draw from real-life events to imagine richly detailed worlds of pain and beauty.

headline: Adapting ‘All the Light We Cannot See’ for TV, and the Blind
abstract: In a new Netflix mini-series, the two actresses playing the Pulitzer Prize-winning novel’s protagonist, are blind, just like the character.
lead_paragraph: On a set on the outskirts of Budapest, as the crew reset cameras for the next take, Nell Sutton, 7, sat up in bed and asked her director, Shawn Levy, a question:

headline: The Landlords of Social Media Seem Happy to Play the Villain
abstract: Why are property owners on social media crowing about the least lovable parts of their job?
lead_paragraph: A trim, bearded landlord stands on the balcony of a high-rise, the Miami skyline extending hazily behind him, and squints into his phone to read a user-submitted question. “Have I ever evicted a single mother out of one of my properties?” he says. “Oh, yes, on multiple occasions!”

headline: If You’ve Ever Heard a Voice That Wasn’t There, This Could Be Why
abstract: With a ghostly finger in a lab, researchers coaxed people to hear phantom voices.
lead_paragraph: Some years ago, scientists in Switzerland found a way to make people hallucinate. They didn’t use LSD or sensory deprivation chambers. Instead, they sat people in a chair and asked them to push a button that, a fraction of a second later, caused a rod to gently press their back. After a few rounds, the volunteers got the creeping sense of someone behind them. Faced with a disconnect between their actions and their sensations, their minds conjured another explanation: a separate presence in the room.

headline: After Writing an Anti-Israel Letter, Harvard Students Are Doxxed
abstract: A truck with a billboard displayed their names and photos, and critics put out do-not-hire lists. The students say it’s a campaign to shut them up.
lead_paragraph: On a campus already bitterly divided, the statement poured acid all over Harvard Yard.

headline: This Southern Staple Is Pure Gold
abstract: Preparing fresh green beans may be a task, but it yields dividends in this dish.
lead_paragraph: When Scotty Scott was about 8 years old, his aunt Yvonne made him stem pounds and pounds of green beans for a big holiday dinner. Young Scotty figured that if he intentionally left on some of the ends and kept most of the pods long and floppy — in other words, did a bad job — he’d never again be tasked with such an arduous responsibility. But Aunt Yvonne caught on quickly. “What are you doing, man?” she asked when she saw his pile of odds and ends. “No, no, no, no — get back in there! You know how to snap beans.”

headline: Danny DeVito, His Daughter and a Lot of Baggage (Onstage)
abstract: The pair, starring in Theresa Rebeck’s Broadway comedy “I Need That,” have a chemistry that “comes with playfulness, love and a history of irritations.”
lead_paragraph: The first time Lucy DeVito acted onstage — an electrifying turn as an ant in a second-grade play about insects — her father, Danny DeVito, watched proudly from the back of the room. (DeVito, who had already starred in the television series “Taxi” and appeared in films like “Terms of Endearment” and “Throw Momma From the Train,” didn’t want to pose a distraction.)

headline: A Country Where ‘Some People Need Killing’ Was State Policy
abstract: The new book by the Philippine journalist Patricia Evangelista recounts her investigation into the campaign of extrajudicial murders under former President Rodrigo Duterte.
lead_paragraph: Before reading “Some People Need Killing,” a powerful new book by the Philippine journalist Patricia Evangelista, I had assumed that the definition of “salvage” was straightforward. The word comes from salvare, Latin for “to save.” You salvage cargo from a wreckage; you salvage mementos from a fire.

headline: Want to See the Eras Tour? Swifties Say ‘Grab Your Passport and My Hand.’
abstract: Fans are buying up seats for Taylor Swift’s international concerts, often finding that tickets, airfare and lodging combined cost less than just the tickets in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Even with traffic on the 405, it probably would have taken at most three hours for Victoria Pardo Uzitas to drive from her home in San Diego to SoFi Stadium in Los Angeles to see a performance of Taylor Swift’s Eras Tour. Instead, she and her teenage daughter crossed the border to Tijuana, flew to Mexico City, enjoyed classic tacos al pastor and churros, saw a Frida Kahlo masterpiece at the Museo de Arte Moderno, and yes, saw Taylor Swift.

headline: $2 Million Homes in Pennsylvania, Montana and California
abstract: An 1867 house in Doylestown, an Edwardian home in Livingston and a Tudor Revival house in San Francisco.
lead_paragraph: This house is a few blocks from the center of the borough, within walking distance of a movie theater, a live music venue and various coffee shops, pubs and restaurants. It is close to several museums, including Bucks County Civil War Museum and Library; Michener Art Museum, which has a sculpture garden; and Mercer Museum, which has a large collection of early American tools and vehicles.

headline: How Phoenix Fans Watch Their Teams May Change How You Watch Yours
abstract: Numerous franchises are expected to overhaul their local media deals, returning games to free networks. The transition is underway in Arizona.
lead_paragraph: Days after Mat Ishbia reached a deal in December to buy majority stakes in the N.B.A.’s Phoenix Suns and the Phoenix Mercury of the W.N.B.A., he met with top executives to learn more about the teams’ business operations, including how local fans were able to watch their games on TV.

headline: Hamas Is Barred From Social Media. Its Messages Are Still Spreading.
abstract: Hamas and Hamas-linked accounts are exploiting the challenge social media companies face in striking the right balance on moderation, experts say.
lead_paragraph: Hamas is barred from Facebook, removed from Instagram and run off TikTok. Yet posts supporting the group that carried out terrorist attacks in Israel this month are still reaching mass audiences on social networks, spreading gruesome footage and political messages to millions of people.

headline: Israel Is Giving Hamas What It Wants
abstract: Lessons for Israel from the American response to Sept. 11.
lead_paragraph: Oct. 7 was Israel’s Sept. 11. That’s been the refrain. I fear that analogy carries so much more truth than the people making it intend.

headline: What Does It Mean to Be a Kept Woman?
abstract: He wanted to pay for everything. Why couldn’t Deanna Fei accept his offer?
lead_paragraph: Deanna Fei did not need a man. She was in her 20s, living in Shanghai on a Fulbright scholarship, writing her first novel: a book about fiercely independent Chinese women, very much like Deanna herself.

headline: For Bill Ford, ‘Every Negotiation Is a Roller Coaster’
abstract: The executive chair of Ford Motor counsels patience as his company negotiates with the United Automobile Workers union, which has shut three of his company’s plants.
lead_paragraph: As a 25-year-old junior executive at the car company that bears his last name, William Clay Ford Jr. had a bracing introduction to labor negotiations when a union official demanded that he stand up and vouch that he was made of the same stuff as his great-grandfather Henry Ford.

headline: Do You Ever Feel Pressure to Post About Your Outrage Online?
abstract: When emotionally charged issues make headlines, do you feel the need to make your opinion known publicly?
lead_paragraph: These days, when tragedy strikes or a divisive political issue makes headlines, ordinary people, along with celebrities and corporations, are often expected to post their reactions on social media. Have you felt this pressure with any recent event, perhaps after a school shooting, during the Black Lives Matter protests or now, during the Israel-Hamas war?

headline: A Chill Has Been Cast Over the Book World
abstract: The organizers of the Frankfurt Book Fair are demonizing a fiction writer and stifling her viewpoint.
lead_paragraph: Last week the literary association Litprom canceled a celebration for the Palestinian author Adania Shibli’s book “Minor Detail” at the Frankfurt Book Fair, one of the publishing world’s biggest international book fairs. The novel, which was a finalist for the National Book Award and was longlisted for the International Booker Prize, was to be honored for having won the 2023 LiBeraturpreis, a German literary prize awarded annually to a woman from the developing world. A panel that Shibli, who splits her time between Jerusalem and Berlin, was to be on with her German translator, Günther Orth, was likewise canceled.

headline: Exxon Mobil’s Pioneer Acquisition Is a Direct Threat to Democracy
abstract: By doubling down on fossil fuels, Exxon Mobil is choosing to profit through the most harmful way to the rest of us.
lead_paragraph: Last week, Exxon Mobil agreed to buy Pioneer Natural Resources for $59.5 billion, in a move widely expected to set off a wave of consolidation throughout the oil sector. Combined, Exxon and Pioneer would be the largest producer of oil and natural gas in the Permian Basin, the field that produces more than 40 percent of America’s oil. If the deal goes through, other companies like Chevron could soon follow suit, buying up smaller companies as they come under pressure from investors to match Exxon’s size.

headline: Can an Unpopular Populist Still Damage Democracy?
abstract: The debate over how dangerous Trump is rages on.
lead_paragraph: “Democracy is a system in which parties lose elections,” Adam Przeworski, a political scientist at N.Y.U., wrote in 1991 — a definition that would prove prescient in the wake of the 2020 election.

headline: Are There Lessons for Israel From America’s Response to 9/11?
abstract: Demolishing Hamas’s terrorist capacities requires demolishing its capacity to rule in Gaza, and someone has to rule in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: If you compare the massacres carried out by Hamas in Israel with the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, as many observers have in recent days, you are offering Israel a tacit warning: Don’t repeat the kind of blunders that pervaded American policymaking after the trauma of Sept. 11.

headline: Biden Walks a Tightrope on Israel-Gaza as Democratic Tensions Smolder
abstract: The president has won bipartisan plaudits for his response to the war, and his trip to Israel offers a chance to appear statesmanlike. But anger on the left is growing as Israeli strikes pound Gaza.
lead_paragraph: As President Biden visited Tel Aviv on Wednesday to demonstrate American solidarity with Israel amid escalating violence after the deadliest attack it has faced in 50 years, Democratic rifts over the conflict were beginning to tear open, leaving him presiding over a party struggling to resolve where it stands.

headline: Republican Presidential Candidates on Israel
abstract: As the Republican presidential candidates campaign under the shadow of a front-runner facing dozens of felony charges, The New York Times examined their stances on 13 key issues.
lead_paragraph: As the Republican presidential candidates campaign under the shadow of a front-runner facing dozens of felony charges, The New York Times examined their stances on 13 key issues.

headline: Jim Jordan Is a Lousy Strongman
abstract: The endless votes for speaker show that the House Republican conference is failing as a democratic entity.
lead_paragraph: Update, Oct. 18: This essay has been updated to reflect the second round of voting in the House on Wednesday.

headline: Allied Spy Chiefs Warn of Chinese Espionage Targeting Tech Firms
abstract: F.B.I. officials say more than half of Chinese spying efforts aimed at stealing technology occurs in Silicon Valley.
lead_paragraph: The United States and its allies vowed this week to do more to counter Chinese theft of technology, warning at an unusual gathering of intelligence leaders that Beijing’s espionage is increasingly trained not on the hulking federal buildings of Washington but the shiny office complexes of Silicon Valley.

headline: A Deadly Blast at a Gaza Hospital, and More
abstract: Plus, Jim Jordan loses a bid to be speaker and scientists propose a new explanation for long Covid.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — it’s available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

headline: The Diplomatic Scramble to Contain the Israel-Hamas War
abstract: President Biden arrives in Israel facing a difficult mission of de-escalation.
lead_paragraph: A devastating blast at a hospital in Gaza on Tuesday killed hundreds and ignited protests across the broader Middle East, deepening the crisis in the region.

headline: New Global Divisions on View as Biden Goes to Israel and Putin to China
abstract: Washington’s strong support for Israel against Hamas is contrasted with Russian and Chinese efforts to align with the Palestinian struggle.
lead_paragraph: As President Biden visited Israel on Wednesday, seeking to display steadfast American support for the country, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia was in Beijing, seeking to display his “no limits” partnership with China’s top leader, Xi Jinping.

headline: Restitution Is Moving Quickly. The Pergamon Museum Is Taking It Slow.
abstract: The Berlin institution with a spectacular, but disputed, centerpiece closes next week for a refurbishment that won’t be complete until 2037.
lead_paragraph: Even wrapped in plastic, the Pergamon Altar is a striking sight. A monumental structure with ornate friezes depicting a battle between giants and gods, it was sculpted in what is now Turkey in the 2nd century B.C. and is one of the most imposing known examples of antique art. Housed in Berlin’s Pergamon Museum for over a century, the altar has long been one of the main attractions in the German capital.

headline: Biden’s Arrival in Israel
abstract: The president is visiting the country as the Middle East reels from an explosion at a Gazan hospital.
lead_paragraph: President Biden landed in Israel this morning as the world waited for evidence of whether a Hamas-linked group or Israel caused a devastating explosion yesterday at a hospital in Gaza City.

headline: ‘The Delinquents’ Review: Money for Nothing
abstract: A bank worker asks a colleague to watch the cash he has stolen in this low-key Argentine feature from Rodrigo Moreno.
lead_paragraph: To Morán (Daniel Eliás), who works at a bank, the scheme makes good economic sense. Over beers, he explains his idea to a colleague, Román (Esteban Bigliardi). Morán, you see, has robbed money from their employer. He hasn’t taken an unreasonable amount — merely what the two would earn in 25 more years of working there. Morán intends to turn himself in and go to prison for much less than that: With good behavior, he calculates he will spend three and a half years behind bars. In the interim, Román can watch the bag of cash, which they will split. If Román refuses to cooperate, Morán could easily frame him as an accomplice anyway.

headline: At NY Dog and Cat Film Festivals, Love, Licks and Looniness
abstract: Collections of short films, both documentary and fiction, make their annual visit to Manhattan, followed by tours around the country and Canada.
lead_paragraph: The cinematic events debuting at the Village East by Angelika this weekend won’t feature any of the acclaimed actors from the recently concluded New York Film Festival. Some of the major figures in these movies have been known to jump on their directors, fall asleep on the job, drool on camera and chew the scenery (in every sense).

headline: Putin Plays Down Threat Posed by Powerful U.S.-Supplied Missiles
abstract: Analysts say the long-range weapons could force Russia to move military assets further away from the front lines, undermining their operations.
lead_paragraph: One day after Ukraine used newly acquired, American-made missiles to launch a damaging attack on Russian air bases in occupied territories, President Vladimir V. Putin sought to play down the impact the weapons will have on the battlefield.

headline: Xi Jinping Greets Vladimir Putin at the Belt and Road Forum
abstract: The forum was centered on China’s foreign policy initiative, which aims to expand Beijing’s influence abroad with infrastructure projects.
lead_paragraph: The forum was centered on China’s foreign policy initiative, which aims to expand Beijing’s influence abroad with infrastructure projects.

headline: With Putin by His Side, Xi Outlines His Vision of a New World Order
abstract: China’s close ties with Russia in countering American dominance point to a geopolitical rift that could shape the conflict between Israel and Hamas.
lead_paragraph: The leaders of China and Russia hailed each other as “old” and “dear” friends. They took swipes at the United States and depicted themselves as building a “fairer, multipolar world.” And they marveled at their countries’ “deepening” trust.

headline: A Sudden Blast, Then Carnage in a Hospital Courtyard
abstract: “We’ve never lived through a war this intense,” said a Palestinian journalist who captured the aftermath of the blast in Gaza that killed hundreds.
lead_paragraph: Sameh al-Jaroosha was sitting on the edge of the grassy courtyard of the Ahli Arab Hospital in Gaza City on Tuesday night, talking to a new acquaintance who was among the thousands of Palestinian residents of the city seeking refuge there in hopes that it would be safer than staying at home.

headline: Lenient Grading Won’t Help Struggling Students. Addressing Chronic Absenteeism Will.
abstract: We need more K-12 policymaking that’s based on data, not feelings.
lead_paragraph: Two weeks ago, when I wrote about the proliferation of 50 percent grading floors in K-12 schools, I was shocked that there wasn’t more evidence available to have informed such a systemic change in the first place. The teachers I spoke to for that newsletter felt that this kind of policy — which prevents them from giving students zeros, including, in some cases, when they’ve skipped an assignment — coupled with policies that don’t allow them to factor attendance into grading, left them with few options for holding students accountable.

headline: Fresh Turmoil in the Middle East Puts Markets on Edge
abstract: Oil prices rose as President Biden arrived in Israel for high-stakes diplomatic talks in the wake of a deadly blast at a Gaza hospital.
lead_paragraph: President Biden landed in Israel on Wednesday for a high-wire diplomatic mission that is facing new challenges by the minute. A deadly blast on Tuesday at a Gaza hospital left Israelis and Palestinians trading blame, and led Jordan to cancel a meeting with Biden and Arab leaders meant to help tamp down tensions in the region.

headline: Should We Keep Paying for Our Ungrateful Son to Join Us on Family Vacations?
abstract: Unsatisfied with her middle-aged son’s meager displays of gratitude, a reader wonders whether to stop footing his bill for a yearly camping retreat.
lead_paragraph: Forty-five years ago, my husband and I started going to a lakeside camp for a week every summer. Our kids grew up there. Years ago, when our son got his first adult job, we paid for him to join us. He wasn’t earning much, and we were afraid he wouldn’t come if we didn’t pay. Now, he is pushing 40, married and has two kids. And we are still paying. (He can easily afford it, as can we.) Money is not the total issue: He shows little appreciation for our gift. The only comment we got this year was a “Thanks again” text three days after the vacation. This was odd since he never thanked us to begin with. And whenever I try to spend (a little) time with him at the lake, he blows me off or snaps at me. Should we cut him off and stop paying?

headline: Covid Cases Drop in California, but Experts Warn of a Winter Surge
abstract: Now is the time to get the updated Covid shot, as well as the flu and R.S.V. vaccines, health officials say, to avoid another “tripledemic.”
lead_paragraph: After a worrisome summer surge, Covid-19 cases have been dropping in California, and across the country, in recent weeks.

headline: ‘Suffs’ Heads to Broadway With Hillary Clinton as a Producer
abstract: The musical, about early-20th-century efforts to win the right to vote for women, will open in April at the Music Box Theater.
lead_paragraph: She has been a first lady, a United States senator, a secretary of state, a Democratic nominee for president, and, most recently, a podcaster and a Columbia University professor.

headline: Maybe We Will Finally Learn More About How A.I. Works
abstract: Stanford researchers have ranked 10 major A.I. models on how openly they operate.
lead_paragraph: How much do we know about A.I.?

headline: New York, Overwhelmed, Toughens Stance on Housing Migrant Families
abstract: The city will impose a 60-day limit on how long families with children can stay at any one shelter before having to leave and reapply to enter the system.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s homeless system is sheltering record numbers of people week after week, as an influx of migrants accelerates to its highest rate since the crisis began.

headline: The Israeli military puts forward its version of what happened at the hospital in Gaza.
abstract: The Israeli military presented on Wednesday a fuller explanation of why it blames an armed Palestinian group, rather than its own forces, for a catastrophic blast at a Gazan hospital on Tuesday night.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli military presented on Wednesday a fuller explanation of why it blames an armed Palestinian group, rather than its own forces, for a catastrophic blast at a Gazan hospital on Tuesday night.

headline: Bigfoot Is Back. (Bigfoot Never Left.)
abstract: Another potential sighting has captured the internet’s attention. Why does fascination with this mythical creature endure?
lead_paragraph: Stetson Parker and his wife, Shannon, recently took a trip through Colorado to celebrate their 10th anniversary. They boarded the Durango & Silverton Narrow Gauge Railroad, a vintage train that “provides historic and entertaining” rides, according to its website.

headline: Jordan Defeated Again for Speaker as Republican Stalemate Deepens
abstract: The number of Republicans opposing him grew as a bipartisan group discussed taking action to empower the temporary speaker to conduct legislative business on the House floor.
lead_paragraph: Representative Jim Jordan, the hard-line Republican from Ohio, lost a second bid for speaker on Wednesday after running headlong into opposition from a group of mainstream G.O.P. holdouts who vowed to block the ultraconservative from the leadership post.

headline: Gov. J.B. Pritzker of Illinois Starts Group to Promote Abortion Rights
abstract: Mr. Pritzker’s organization, Think Big America, will support ballot measures to codify or restore abortion rights, seeking to elevate an issue that has energized Democrats.
lead_paragraph: Gov. J.B. Pritzker of Illinois is starting an advocacy group to promote abortion rights around the country, seeking to blunt the impact of the Supreme Court’s decision overturning Roe v. Wade and to elevate an issue that has energized Democrats in elections.

headline: Still Mourning Takeoff’s Death, Quavo Steps Out Alone
abstract: The rapper, whose Migos group mate and nephew was killed last November, has released a solo album as he struggles to process the loss and prevent further gun violence.
lead_paragraph: It’s odd to hear Quavo have to search for the right words. As one-third of the rap group Migos, Quavious Marshall rose to chart-topping prominence in the last decade by verbalizing hip-hop’s stickiest choruses and most satisfyingly inane ad-libs, mostly extemporaneously. But he’s at a loss to describe how he’s gotten through the past year without his nephew, bandmate and best friend, Takeoff, who was shot to death at the age of 28 at an after-hours event in Houston last November.

headline: The Jim Jordan Seen in Congress Is the One Constituents Know in Ohio
abstract: The hard-right Republican has had a long career as an uncompromising figure in Ohio politics.
lead_paragraph: Six members of the Champaign County Preservation Alliance were touring the picturesque downtown in Urbana, the central Ohio town where Representative Jim Jordan has made his mark as a state champion wrestler, an aspiring politician and now a member of Congress.

headline: Camaraderie and Visibility: A Festival for Black Classical Musicians
abstract: “You feel like you’re home,” a bassoonist said of the Gateways Music Festival, which for 30 years has provided Black musicians with performing opportunities.
lead_paragraph: Monica Ellis vividly recalls her first impression of the Gateways Music Festival, a gathering of classical musicians of African descent, at the University of Rochester in upstate New York in 2019. Ellis, a bassoonist and founding member of the quintet Imani Winds, was no stranger to working in exclusively Black groups. But that hadn’t prepared her for playing with an entire orchestra made up of friends and colleagues from across the country.

headline: Severe Storm in Scotland Could Pose a ‘Danger to Life’
abstract: Britain’s weather agency warned that as much as a month’s worth of rain is expected to fall between Thursday and Friday.
lead_paragraph: Severe rainfall and winds pelted Britain on Thursday as the country’s national weather service warned that a storm moving through the region could prompt flooding and put lives at risk in eastern Scotland.

headline: Perfect Roasted Broccoli
abstract: Lidey Heuck’s new recipe is simplicity itself, with just a little minced garlic tossed in during the last two minutes of cooking so it doesn’t burn.
lead_paragraph: Sure, you can improve almost any vegetable by slicking it with oil and roasting it at high heat. But I think broccoli fares best of all, with its flowering tips turning crisp and brown while the stems soften and become especially sweet.

headline: Marie NDiaye Raises Questions She Has No Intention of Answering
abstract: She published her first book at 17 and has since become one of France’s best-known novelists. NDiaye is not interested in easy — and she expects her readers to work, too.
lead_paragraph: The French writer Marie NDiaye likes a mystery. An admirer of detective novels, she has often felt “a pang of disappointment at the resolution, no matter how brilliant,” she said recently at her home in Paris. “I hate to be taken by the hand.”

headline: Early U.S. and Israeli Intelligence Says Palestinian Group Caused Hospital Blast
abstract: U.S. officials cautioned that the analysis is preliminary and that the United States was continuing to collect and analyze evidence.
lead_paragraph: American and Israeli officials said their intelligence showed that the deadly blast at a Gaza hospital on Tuesday was caused by an armed Palestinian group, rebutting Palestinian claims that an Israeli strike caused the explosion.

headline: Strokes Are More Common and Serious in Women
abstract: And they’re on the rise overall. Here’s how to understand your risk.
lead_paragraph: Each year, more than 6.6 million people worldwide die from strokes, and researchers caution that the incidence is increasing, especially in young and middle-aged people and in low- and middle-income countries. In a report published last week, researchers predicted that stroke deaths would increase by about 50 percent, reaching 9.7 million deaths annually in 2050.

headline: Review: ‘Scavengers Reign’ Is a Gorgeous, Hypnotic Space Trip
abstract: Max’s animated sci-fi saga imagines a bizarre ecosystem in which humans are the invasive species.
lead_paragraph: “Weird” hardly begins to describe the extraterrestrial life-forms the viewer encounters on the planet Vesta in “Scavengers Reign.” These include: lamprey-like blobs you can slap on your face to use as breathing masks; herds of equine beasts with throat pouches that inflate when they bellow; spiky fruit (I think?) whose ropy innards double as electrical cables; and a rhino-esque critter whose digestive tract harbors bioluminescent sacs that are useful as torches. (You retrieve them, er, the hard way.)

headline: An Easy Way to Help Birds Migrate
abstract: Each year, hundreds of thousands of birds die in window strikes and not just from skyscrapers. Here's how you can help.
lead_paragraph: Each year, hundreds of thousands of birds die in window strikes and not just from skyscrapers. Here's how you can help.

headline: Roger Goodell Agrees to Contract Extension With N.F.L.
abstract: The new deal would keep Mr. Goodell in place as the league’s commissioner through 2027, when he will be 68.
lead_paragraph: The N.F.L. owners finalized a contract extension for Commissioner Roger Goodell on Wednesday that would keep him in the league’s top job through March 2027, halting speculation that he might step aside when his previous agreement ended in a year.

headline: Trump Lawyer Acknowledged Political Agenda in Election Suit, Emails Show
abstract: Kenneth Chesebro’s comments undercut assertions that Donald J. Trump’s lawyers were simply providing legal advice in challenging the 2020 results.
lead_paragraph: On Dec. 24, 2020, Kenneth Chesebro and other lawyers fighting to reverse President Donald J. Trump’s election defeat were debating whether to file litigation contesting Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s victory in Wisconsin, a key swing state.

headline: My Sister Hid $5,000 From Me, Then Her Husband Died. Do I Ask for the Money?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on whether extenuating circumstances should outweigh a reasonable request.
lead_paragraph: My only sister and I never speak, except at funerals — we’re on opposite planets when it comes to politics and religion. And I think we’re both fine with that; we were never close as kids, either. A year ago, I got an email from her saying God had told her to pay me the $5,000 she had hidden from my inheritance when our mother died. I never would have known about it had she not spilled the beans. I know she’s not wealthy, so I was very nice and said to her: “Whoa! Who knew? Send it any way that works for you — the whole thing, monthly payments, I’m easy.” I didn’t see any point in shaming her for stealing it, given that she seemed to want to make things right. In anticipation, I bought an expensive laptop.

headline: Humanitarian Aid Continues to Amass at Egypt’s Border as Crisis in Gaza Worsens
abstract: Though the U.S. and Israel say they have cleared the way for the aid to make its way into Gaza, truckloads of supplies remain in Egypt.
lead_paragraph: Israel said Wednesday it would not block aid to Gaza from Egypt, and there were already long lines of trucks parked in Egypt, at the Rafah border crossing, waiting to carry food, water and fuel to the enclave.

headline: Why Is the Rafah Border Crossing So Important for Gaza?
abstract: The access point, where aid trucks are waiting to enter from Egypt and people are waiting to leave, is the only land crossing into Gaza that is not controlled by Israel.
lead_paragraph: After Israel imposed a complete siege of the Gaza Strip in response to the deadly Oct. 7 attack by Hamas, the strip’s border crossing with Egypt became even more critical, as the only point not controlled by Israel where civilians can enter and leave Gaza by land.

headline: Popcast (Deluxe): Taylor Swift’s Eras Tour Movie + Bad Bunny Returns
abstract: A conversation about Swift’s concert film documenting her summer stadium sojourn. Plus: The new album “Nadie Sabe Lo Que Va a Pasar Mañana.”
lead_paragraph: This week’s episode of Popcast (Deluxe), the weekly culture roundup show on YouTube hosted by Jon Caramanica and Joe Coscarelli, includes segments on:

headline: It’s Probably Going to Rain in New York This Weekend. Again.
abstract: A coastal storm threatens to deliver brisk winds and significant rain across the Northeast this weekend. It’ll likely continue a run of miserable weekends for the region.
lead_paragraph: This has been the third wettest start ever to autumn in New York City, with rain pelting the pavement every weekend since early September. And now another potential coastal storm threatens to create a seventh consecutive dreary and wet weekend for people across the New York metropolitan region.

headline: What We Know About the Explosion at the Hospital in Gaza
abstract: Much is unclear about the strike that Palestinian authorities say killed hundreds.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of people were feared dead after an explosion at a hospital in the Gaza Strip on Oct. 17, a little over a week after the Palestinian group Hamas staged a terrorist attack on Israel that killed 1,400 people and led Israel to declare war and begin bombing the territory.

headline: Liberia’s Tightest Presidential Election in 2 Decades Heads to a Runoff
abstract: George Weah, a former soccer star who has been president since 2018, ran neck and neck with his main opponent in a rematch of the West African country’s last such contest.
lead_paragraph: Liberia’s closest election in two decades is heading to a runoff, according to official provisional results announced by the West African nation’s electoral commission, after neither the country’s president nor his main opponent secured a majority.

headline: Iran’s Call for Oil Embargo on Israel Roils Markets
abstract: A top Iranian official urged Islamic countries to halt oil shipments to Israel, briefly causing a jump in crude prices.
lead_paragraph: The prospect of an oil embargo arising from the conflict between Israel and militant groups contributed to a sharp but brief jolt in oil prices on Wednesday.

headline: American Household Wealth Jumped in the Pandemic
abstract: Pandemic stimulus, a strong job market and climbing stock and home prices boosted net worth at a record pace, Federal Reserve data showed.
lead_paragraph: American families saw the largest jump in their wealth on record between 2019 and 2022, according to Federal Reserve data released on Wednesday, as rising stock indexes, climbing home prices and repeated rounds of government stimulus left people’s finances healthier.

headline: Steven Lutvak, Whose Darkly Comic Show Won a Tony, Dies at 64
abstract: He wrote several musicals without attracting much notice. Then he struck Broadway gold with “A Gentleman’s Guide to Love & Murder.”
lead_paragraph: Steven Lutvak, a composer and lyricist whose only Broadway show, “A Gentleman’s Guide to Love & Murder” — a black comedy about a killer in London who bumps off the relatives who stand in the way of his becoming a wealthy royal — won the Tony Award for best musical, died on Oct. 9 at his work studio in Manhattan. He was 64.

headline: British Museum Announces Plan to Stop Thefts
abstract: The museum will overhaul its record keeping, but its leaders said that millions of items still would not be individually documented.
lead_paragraph: Two months after it announced the firing of a curator suspected of stealing artifacts from its stores, the British Museum on Wednesday unveiled a $12-million project to plug holes in its records and its online catalog.

headline: Women of ‘Groundswell’: Thinking Outside the Spiral
abstract: Revisiting the land artists at the Nasher Sculpture Center, a critic finds their work was never more relevant than it is today.
lead_paragraph: The land art movement, which flourished in the ’70s amid enormous media attention, at times seemed like a boys’ club. When Michael Heizer dynamited the Nevada earth to create his “Double Negative,” or when Robert Smithson built his “Spiral Jetty” from a 1,500-foot coil of basalt rocks on the shore of the Great Salt Lake, they expanded the proportions of contemporary art to a scale that owed as much to ancient sites like Stonehenge as to the cowboy fantasy of the infinitely expandable frontier.

headline: Review: Laurie Anderson Gets Back to Having a Good Time
abstract: With the jazz combo Sexmob, this enduring avant-gardist revisited vintage and recent songs with a grooving spirit.
lead_paragraph: Laurie Anderson sounds like she’s ready to have fun again.

headline: Who Has Qualified for the Third G.O.P. Debate?
abstract: Just four candidates appear to have qualified so far for the third Republican debate on Nov. 8. Donald J. Trump is not likely to participate.
lead_paragraph: Just four candidates appear to have qualified so far for the third Republican debate on Nov. 8. Donald J. Trump is not likely to participate.

headline: Gov. Hochul Makes Wartime Visit to Israel to Show New York’s Support
abstract: The governor consoled Israeli families that were displaced or impacted by the attacks. She did not join President Biden during his trip.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York embarked Wednesday on an impromptu trip to Israel that she acknowledged would have no geopolitical impact on an escalating war 5,700 miles away from the state she leads.

headline: Pence’s 2024 Bid Confronts Murky Future, as Campaign Cash Dwindles
abstract: Mike Pence has still not resolved some of the contradictions at the core of his candidacy, and his campaign has struggled with financial problems, including running up a debt of $620,000.
lead_paragraph: At a town hall-style event hosted by the right-wing broadcaster Newsmax on Tuesday, Mike Pence was asked questions about Israel, Ukraine and the disarray among House Republicans — all of which he answered in familiar ways.

headline: Review: A Mezzo-Soprano Brings Women’s Tales to the Armory
abstract: Kate Lindsey, accompanied by the pianist Justina Lee, programmed cycles of life, love and creation by Schumann and Fauré.
lead_paragraph: At her recital at the Park Avenue Armory on Monday night, the mezzo-soprano Kate Lindsey told the stories of two women, each in her own way an originator.

headline: Stephen Rubin, 81, ‘Quintessential Hitmaker’ of the Book World, Dies
abstract: He entered publishing when he was 43, then published many of the most popular books of recent decades, including “The Da Vinci Code.”
lead_paragraph: Stephen Rubin, a book-business fortune seeker who helped make John Grisham and Dan Brown famous writers and who published Michael Wolff’s 2018 chronicle of the Trump White House, “Fire and Fury,” died on Friday in Manhattan. He was 81.

headline: ‘What the Constitution Means to Me’ Is This Season’s Most-Staged Play
abstract: Heidi Schreck’s play will have at least 16 productions around the country; last season’s most-produced play, “Clyde’s,” came in second.
lead_paragraph: “What the Constitution Means to Me,” a challenging exploration of American legal history sparked by a student oratory competition, will be the most produced play at U.S. theaters this season, according to a survey released on Wednesday.

headline: Confession Brings Natalee Holloway Case to an End After 18 Years
abstract: Joran van der Sloot admitted that he brutally attacked the American teenager on a beach in Aruba, bringing a close to a case that had fascinated the American public since she vanished in 2005.
lead_paragraph: In 2005, an American teenager, Natalee Holloway, disappeared on a senior high school class trip to Aruba. Her case inspired countless hours of cable TV programming, more than half a dozen nonfiction books, multiple episodes in the “Law & Order” franchise and at least one stage production. The obsessive attention stoked a backlash of media criticism.

headline: ‘Helen.’ Review: A Restless Heroine Tired of Abiding by Gender Roles
abstract: At La MaMa, Caitlin George’s new play uses comedy to counter the legend of Helen of Troy.
lead_paragraph: The play is called “Helen.,” as in Helen of Troy, but her twin sister, Klaitemestra, is the one who steals the show.

headline: Man Who Spread Misinformation on Trump’s Behalf Sentenced to 7 Months
abstract: The man, Douglass Mackey, spread internet memes meant to fool people into not voting for Hillary Clinton in 2016.
lead_paragraph: A digital-age dirty-trickster who used Twitter posts that looked like Hillary Clinton ads to spread false information before the 2016 presidential election was sentenced on Tuesday to seven months in prison.

headline: Biden’s Visit to Israel After the Gaza Hospital Tragedy
abstract: Readers discuss the president’s trip and the Gaza hospital blast. Also: Speaking out, or not; children and war; standards for students; music diplomacy.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A New Report Documents How Easily Children Can Access Graphic Images of the War
abstract: On Instagram, Snapchat and Tiktok, researchers were able to find graphic posts, even with the apps’ sensitivity features turned on.
lead_paragraph: Violent, distressing imagery related to the conflict between Hamas and Israel, including graphic posts showing dead children and adults, are easily accessible to young users on platforms such as Instagram, researchers have found.

headline: Ann Philbin, Who Remade L.A.’s Hammer Museum, to Step Down
abstract: In nearly 25 years at the helm, Philbin helped transform the museum and elevate its reputation, and left a mark on the cultural landscape of Los Angeles.
lead_paragraph: Ann Philbin, who turned the Hammer Museum into a destination for contemporary art during nearly 25 years as its director and helped transform the cultural landscape in Los Angeles, will step down next year, the museum announced on Wednesday.

headline: Texas Has Bused 50,000 Migrants. Now It Wants to Arrest Them Instead.
abstract: The migrant busing program altered the debate over immigration. Gov. Greg Abbott wants to give Texas police expanded powers over border enforcement.
lead_paragraph: A year and a half after Gov. Greg Abbott began busing newly arrived migrants from Texas to large Democratic cities whose leaders had pledged to provide sanctuary, the state has now sent more than 50,000 migrants to destinations across the United States, helping to provoke a shelter crisis in several cities that has reshaped the debate over immigration.

headline: Why Are So Many Americans Dying?
abstract: Our mortality crisis is much larger than “deaths of despair.”
lead_paragraph: Since it was first introduced by the economists Anne Case and Angus Deaton in 2015, the phrase “deaths of despair” has become a sort of spiritual skeleton key that promised to unlock the whole tragic story of a new American underclass.

headline: Protests Erupt After Gaza Hospital Explosion
abstract: Outrage over a blast that killed hundreds of people at a Gaza City hospital set off protests across the Middle East and elsewhere. President Biden backed Israel’s assertion that it had nothing to do with the explosion.
lead_paragraph: Outrage over a blast that killed hundreds of people at a Gaza City hospital set off protests across the Middle East and elsewhere. President Biden backed Israel’s assertion that it had nothing to do with the explosion.

headline: You Snooze, You … Win?
abstract: A new study suggests smashing that alarm button may not be all that bad. But sleep experts say there may be better ways to wake up.
lead_paragraph: Just how bad is it, really, to smash the snooze button when your alarm blares? What about doing it a second time, or a third?

headline: Republicans Fear Speaker Fight Could Cost Them House Majority
abstract: The chaos and infighting inside the G.O.P. has damaged the party brand, and many worry the candidacy of the hard-line Representative Jim Jordan has sealed the fate of some Republicans who backed him.
lead_paragraph: In California’s 45th Congressional District, along Western Avenue in Buena Park, a giant billboard is set to display a photograph of Representative Michelle Steel next to former President Donald J. Trump and Representative Jim Jordan, the Republican hard-liner from Ohio she voted for twice this week for speaker.

headline: As Speaker Chaos Grows, So Does Talk of Empowering McHenry
abstract: Several lawmakers were discussing granting Patrick McHenry, a North Carolina Republican acting as temporary speaker, the power to run the House until a permanent speaker is chosen.
lead_paragraph: The second failed effort on Wednesday by Representative Jim Jordan of Ohio to be elected House speaker added momentum to an idea that has been floated by lawmakers in both parties in recent days: Give Representative Patrick T. McHenry, the interim speaker, explicit power to conduct legislative business.

headline: The Passion of Adèle Haenel, an Artist of Fierce Political Conviction
abstract: Haenel, working with the choreographer-director Gisèle Vienne in “L’Étang,” is trying to “pierce through the surface of things.”
lead_paragraph: The actress Adèle Haenel bristled when asked what drew her to radical art and politics. “The term ‘radical’ is used as a way to discredit protest discourse,” said Haenel, who is best known in the United States for the 2019 art-house hit “Portrait of a Lady on Fire.” That was also one of the last feature films she worked on. Since then, she has opted to dramatically alter the course of her life and career.

headline: In Antitrust Trial, Google Argues That Smart Employees Explain Its Success
abstract: While the Justice Department says Google has squeezed partners and made expensive deals to maintain its search dominance, the company has a more genteel story to tell.
lead_paragraph: In its antitrust confrontation with the government, the pillar of Google’s defense has been that innovation — not restrictive contracts, backed by billions in payments to industry partners — explains its success as the giant of internet search.

headline: George Wayne Is ‘Still Hustling’
abstract: The celebrity chronicler is working to bring back R.O.M.E., his dishy zine of pre-internet New York.
lead_paragraph: The lifestyle journalist George Wayne finds himself in an odd position. Because of money troubles, he says he takes out no more than $20 at a time from A.T.M.s. And yet he’s a regular at high-end restaurants like Cucina 8 ½ in Midtown Manhattan, where he was sipping a martini at the bar on a September evening toward the end of New York Fashion Week.

headline: Israel-Hamas War Brings Tensions to Europe: What Travelers Need to Know
abstract: The intensifying war in the Middle East has led to demonstrations in London, Paris, Rome and beyond. Here’s what to expect amid the disruptions.
lead_paragraph: As the war between Hamas and Israel intensifies in the Middle East, tensions are spilling over into Europe, where demonstrations and terrorist attacks are causing disruptions for locals and visitors alike.

headline: What to Know About the 4 Food Additives Banned by California
abstract: The chemicals, found in everything from candy corn to sodas to tortillas, have been linked to a number of serious health issues.
lead_paragraph: California has banned four common food additives — Red Dye No. 3, potassium bromate, brominated vegetable oil and propylparaben — through the California Food Safety Act.

headline: Netflix Adds 9 Million Subscribers in Third Quarter
abstract: The streaming service also said its premium ad-free service will now cost $22.99 a month. Its option with ads costs $6.99 a month.
lead_paragraph: Netflix added nine million subscribers in the third quarter and saw a year-over-year increase in revenue despite strikes by Hollywood writers and actors that brought the entertainment industry largely to a standstill.

headline: Tesla’s Profits Plunge 44% After Big Price Cuts
abstract: The automaker reported a sharp drop in profits in the third quarter after slashing car prices by around 25 percent in an attempt to compete.
lead_paragraph: Tesla’s profit slumped in the third quarter, disappointing Wall Street expectations, after the carmaker cut prices to maintain its dominance of the market for electric vehicles.

headline: Infiltrating the Ultimate Boys’ Club — With Spycraft
abstract: In “The Sisterhood,” the journalist Liza Mundy chronicles the frustrations, triumphs and compromises of the women of the C.I.A.
lead_paragraph: In the 1970s, the keepers of the sensitive information held in the windowless vaults of the Central Intelligence Agency earned themselves a nickname.

headline: Tracking Post-Tropical Cyclone Norma
abstract: See the likely path and wind arrival times for Norma.
lead_paragraph: See the likely path and wind arrival times for Norma.

headline: Can You Spot Ways Our Culture Has Changed Over the Past 25 Years?
abstract: Fashion, music, sports, food and even the words we use have all changed since The Learning Network first began. Can you figure out how?
lead_paragraph: Fashion, music, sports, food and even the words we use have all changed since The Learning Network first began. Can you figure out how?

headline: Thursday Briefing: Biden Backs Israel on the Hospital Blast
abstract: Plus how much do we know about A.I.?
lead_paragraph: During a wartime visit to Israel, President Biden said yesterday that U.S. intelligence showed that the deadly explosion at the Ahli Arab Hospital in Gaza City yesterday was caused by Palestinian fighters.

headline: Woman in Critical Condition After Man Pushes Her Into Subway Train
abstract: The 30-year-old woman was attacked at random, the police said. Officers were seeking a suspect.
lead_paragraph: A 30-year-old woman was in critical condition on Wednesday after a man described by law enforcement officials as emotionally disturbed pushed her into a moving subway train in an apparently random attack at a Manhattan station.

headline: Clearview AI Successfully Appeals $9 Million Fine in the U.K.
abstract: A court ruled that a British agency does not have jurisdiction over how foreign law enforcement agencies use citizens’ data.
lead_paragraph: Clearview AI, a New York company that scraped billions of photos from the public internet to build a facial recognition app used by thousands of U.S. law enforcement agencies, will not have to pay a fine of 7.5 million pounds, or $9.1 million, issued by Britain’s chief data protection agency. A British appeals court ruled this week that the agency does not have jurisdiction over how foreign law enforcement agencies use British citizens’ data.

headline: Devastation in Gaza After Hospital Blast
abstract: Still reeling from an explosion outside Ahli Arab Hospital in Gaza City, medical workers spoke of the destruction that left hundreds there dead. “We haven’t seen anything like this in our lives,” said one doctor.
lead_paragraph: Still reeling from an explosion outside Ahli Arab Hospital in Gaza City, medical workers spoke of the destruction that left hundreds there dead. “We haven’t seen anything like this in our lives,” said one doctor.

headline: Tracking Post-Tropical Cyclone Tammy
abstract: See the likely path and wind arrival times for Tammy.
lead_paragraph: See the likely path and wind arrival times for Tammy.

headline: Across Mideast, Protests Erupt Over ‘Horrific Scenes’ in Gaza
abstract: Not only Arabs in the street but, strikingly, also their rulers nearly uniformly condemned Israel for the Gaza hospital explosion and other violence affecting Palestinians.
lead_paragraph: They donned the black-and-white checkered Palestinian scarf known as the kaffiyeh in Tunis, unfurled giant Palestinian flags in downtown Cairo and chanted against Israeli occupation in the normally sleepy Oman capital of Muscat. In Morocco and Bahrain, they demanded a reversal of their government’s normalization with Israel, the country they consider responsible for oppressing their Palestinian brethren.

headline: U.S. Says Israel Didn’t Cause Hospital Blast, as Biden Promises Aid to Gaza
abstract: President Biden backed Israel’s claim that a Gaza City explosion that killed hundreds, which Hamas blamed on Israel, had come from a failed rocket launch by an armed Palestinian group.
lead_paragraph: President Biden on Wednesday backed Israel’s contention that a Palestinian group had caused an explosion at a Gaza hospital that killed hundreds of people. He also announced that the Israeli government would allow critically needed aid into the besieged Gaza Strip.

headline: Biden Blamed a Palestinian Group for the Hospital Blast
abstract: Also, Jim Jordan loses a second speaker vote. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: President Biden, who made a high-profile wartime visit to Israel today, said American intelligence showed that the deadly explosion that ripped through a hospital in Gaza yesterday was caused by Palestinian fighters.

headline: How the Interim Speaker Patrick McHenry Could Actually Govern
abstract: The House is deadlocked at a time of international chaos. There are paths forward for Patrick McHenry as a more permanent interim speaker.
lead_paragraph: In the first nearly 10 months of their majority, Republicans have nominated three different people to serve as speaker of the House, and not one of them currently holds the gavel. Jim Jordan’s defeat at the hands of mainly centrists, following the demise of Steve Scalise and Kevin McCarthy at the hands of conservatives, cements the idea that there may be no person who can unify the Republican conference.

headline: David Shaffer, Medical ‘Detective’ in Suicide of Youths, Dies at 87
abstract: At a time when teen suicide was seen as random and unpredictable, Dr. Shaffer, a psychiatrist, led investigations that proved that it was not.
lead_paragraph: Dr. David Shaffer, a psychiatrist who spent decades studying children and teenagers who died by suicide, constructing a framework for screening and laying the groundwork for modern prevention efforts, died on Sunday in Mastic Beach, N.Y., on Long Island. He was 87.

headline: Videos Show Georgia Deputy Fatally Shooting Man Who Had Been Wrongfully Imprisoned
abstract: A confrontation between the officer and Leonard Cure during a traffic stop rapidly turned violent and then deadly, footage released by the Camden County Sheriff’s Office shows.
lead_paragraph: Dash-camera and body-camera videos released on Wednesday show how a traffic stop in Georgia turned violent and then deadly in less than three minutes when a sheriff’s deputy shot a Black man who had been wrongfully imprisoned for more than 16 years.

headline: The U.S. vetoes a Security Council resolution on the Israel-Hamas conflict.
abstract: The American ambassador said the U.S. couldn’t support a measure that didn’t mention Israel’s right to self-defense.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations Security Council displayed deep divisions on Wednesday when it failed to pass a resolution on the Israel-Hamas war as the humanitarian situation in Gaza deteriorated and the conflict risked spreading to the region.

headline: U.S. Issues New Sanctions Targeting Iran’s Missile and Drone Programs
abstract: The Biden administration announced the measures as U.N. restrictions approved with the 2015 nuclear deal expired.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration on Wednesday imposed new sanctions aimed at Iran’s ballistic missile and drone programs, acting to keep up pressure on Tehran after the expiration of United Nations restrictions on those activities.

headline: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. Is Not Ready for Prime Time
abstract: Third parties are always one too many.
lead_paragraph: I know you have a lot on your mind, people. But if you’ve got a few minutes to spare, let’s talk about Robert F. Kennedy Jr.

headline: An Evolving Moral High Ground in the Israel-Gaza War
abstract: In this war, a gloves-are-off, by-any-means-necessary retaliation is unacceptable, regardless of who is engaged in it.
lead_paragraph: The terrorist attack by Hamas against Israelis — the worst massacre of Jewish people since the Holocaust — was horrid, barbaric and inexcusable. Israel has a right to defend itself and pursue the perpetrators.

headline: Biden’s Nominee for U.S. Ambassador to Israel Is Grilled by Senators
abstract: Republicans on the Senate Foreign Relations Committee accused Jacob Lew of having enabled the rise of Iran-backed terror groups as President Obama’s Treasury secretary.
lead_paragraph: As President Biden visited Israel on Wednesday to pledge U.S. support in its fight against Hamas, his nominee to fill the conspicuously empty American ambassador’s post to the country faced Republican opposition at home.

headline: After Hospital Blast, Headlines Shift With Changing Claims
abstract: The fast-moving events highlighted the difficulty of covering the war between Israel and Hamas.
lead_paragraph: The shifting coverage about a deadly explosion at a hospital in Gaza highlighted the difficulties of reporting on a fast-moving war in which few journalists remain on the ground while claims fly freely on social media.

headline: Burt Young, ‘Rocky’ Actor Who Played Complex Tough Guys, Dies at 83
abstract: A former boxer from the streets of Queens, he became a scene stealer with his portrayals of mobsters, cops and working men with soul.
lead_paragraph: Burt Young, a burly Queens-bred actor who leveraged a weary gravitas and bare-knuckled demeanor to build a prolific career as a Hollywood tough guy in films like “Chinatown,” “Once Upon a Time in America” and, most notably, “Rocky,” for which he was nominated for an Academy Award, died on Oct. 8 in Los Angeles. He was 83.

headline: Biden is expected to request $100 billion for Israel, Ukraine and other crises.
abstract: The emergency funding request to Congress, which would also include funds to fortify border security, is expected by Friday.
lead_paragraph: President Biden is expected to ask Congress in the coming days to approve about $100 billion in emergency funds to arm Israel, Ukraine and Taiwan and fortify the U.S.-Mexico border, according to multiple people familiar with the plan.

headline: Trump Endorses Gov. Jim Justice in West Virginia Senate Race
abstract: The endorsement is a blow to the governor’s rival for the Republican nomination as the Democrat, Senator Joe Manchin III, weighs whether to seek re-election.
lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump endorsed Gov. Jim Justice of West Virginia for senator, in a race that is widely viewed as a prime pickup opportunity as Republicans seek to reclaim control of the Senate.

headline: About 300 protesters pleading for a cease-fire were arrested on Capitol Hill, organizers say.
abstract: Rallies over the Israel-Hamas war have continued to be held across the country and in world capitals.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of demonstrators descended on a congressional building in Washington on Wednesday afternoon to demand a cease-fire in the Israel-Hamas war, resulting in an estimated 300 arrests and restricting access to Capitol Hill.

headline: Quotation of the Day: In China, the Cheaper the Better
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, October 19, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “We don’t want to see consumers hesitating over price when they want coffee.”

headline: First Venezuelans Sent Back Under New U.S. Policy Arrive in Caracas
abstract: The deportation of migrants who had entered the U.S. illegally came as the Biden administration lifted some sanctions against Venezuela.
lead_paragraph: The United States, marking an end to a four-year suspension of returning Venezuelan migrants home, sent its first deportation flight to Caracas on Wednesday, with 127 people on board.

headline: Modern-Day Provocateur
abstract: Colin Ernst is not one to back away from a challenge.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Families of Hamas Hostages Split on Invasion of Gaza
abstract: The families are torn between wanting their loved ones returned safely at any cost and concern about more loss of life.
lead_paragraph: As Israel prepares for a possible ground offensive in the Gaza Strip, some Israelis whose family members were kidnapped by Hamas gunmen during the Oct. 7 terrorist attacks are split over the idea of sending troops into the enclave.

headline: Nebraska Governor Is Criticized for Comments on Reporter’s Chinese Nationality
abstract: Jim Pillen said in a radio interview that he refused to read an investigation into his hog farms by a reporter who he said is from “Communist China.”
lead_paragraph: Gov. Jim Pillen of Nebraska is facing criticism after he dismissed a news article about environmental concerns at his hog farms, saying that the reporter who wrote it was from “Communist China.”

headline: Corrections: Oct. 19, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, Oct. 19, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Wednesday about a change in United Airlines’ boarding process misstated the timing of United’s use of the WILMA method. United stopped using it in 2017.

headline: Ukraine’s Economy Starts to Rebound as It Adapts to War
abstract: Economists predict a return to growth, but many challenges lie ahead, including the rebuilding of war-torn cities and labor shortages.
lead_paragraph: When Russian forces closed in on Kyiv at the start of their invasion last year, the staff at Zavertailo, a popular bakery in the Ukrainian capital, shut up shop and began preparing free salads for the soldiers defending the city. Supplies dwindled as fighting raged around Kyiv, and the bakery’s finances collapsed as managers continued to pay staff salaries.

headline: The 5 Clones in Argentina’s Election
abstract: Javier Milei, a far-right libertarian, might soon be Argentina’s next president. He credits his cloned “four-legged children.”
lead_paragraph: After finishing a surprising first in Argentina’s presidential primaries in August, Javier Milei grabbed a microphone in front of a raucous crowd and thanked Conan, Murray, Milton, Robert and Lucas.

headline: Country Garden, Facing Debt Deadline, Says Executives Have Not Left China
abstract: The company, one of China’s biggest property developers, took the unusual step of stating that the company’s founder and its chairwoman were “working normally.”
lead_paragraph: Facing a potential financial collapse, the embattled Chinese property developer Country Garden on Thursday denied rumors that its two most prominent executives had fled China.

headline: Thursday Briefing
abstract: President Biden’s wartime visit to Israel.
lead_paragraph: Outrage has rippled through the Arab world over a blast that killed hundreds at a hospital in Gaza. President Biden, on a wartime trip to Israel, firmly backed the Israeli government’s assertion that Israel did not cause the hospital explosion, which U.S. and Israeli intelligence officials said appeared to be the result of an errant rocket fired by Palestinian fighters.

headline: Why South Korea Has So Many Protests, and What That Means
abstract: Part rock concert, part revival meeting, the rallies reveal a country increasingly polarized over its leader, Yoon Suk Yeol.
lead_paragraph: A recent rally in Seoul carried the sound of a rock festival — high-amp speakers throbbing with the K-pop hit “Gangnam Style” — if not the look of one. The crowd of mostly elderly people waved South Korean and American flags to the song’s revised refrain: “Anti-communist style!” When speaker after speaker revved up the crowd with pro-American, anti-communist chants, the crowd shouted, “Hooray for President Yoon Suk Yeol!”​

headline: State Department Official Resigns Over Arms Transfers to Israel
abstract: Josh Paul spent more than 11 years as the director of congressional and public affairs at the bureau that oversees arms transfers to foreign nations.
lead_paragraph: A State Department official in the bureau that oversees arms transfers resigned this week in protest of the Biden administration’s decision to continue sending weapons and ammunition to Israel as it lays siege to Gaza in its war with Hamas.

headline: Rite Aid Is Closing 154 Stores as It Starts to Shed Debt
abstract: The pharmacy chain, once the largest in the United States, detailed a batch of store closures in a bankruptcy court filing.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday, Rite Aid, once the largest U.S. pharmacy chain, filed for bankruptcy court protection from its creditors and vowed to remake the company as a “modern neighborhood pharmacy.”

headline: Jimmy Kimmel Recaps Biden’s Big Day in Israel
abstract: Kimmel joked that President Biden and Israel “go way back”: “You know how Moses parted the Red Sea? Joe was the guy who dared him to do it.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Word of the Day: oeuvre
abstract: This word has appeared in 112 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word oeuvre has appeared in 112 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on July 19 in “Our Favorite Magical Creatures Live at Ghibli Park, So We Had to Go” by Mike Ives:

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: The Connections Companion
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections Companion, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: What’s Driving New York’s Parking Problem? A Reporter Explains.
abstract: Sarah Maslin Nir, a journalist for the Metro section, set out to learn about the forces fueling the city’s scarcity of parking spots.
lead_paragraph: In New York, where roughly 7.7 million people flowed through the southern half of Manhattan every weekday before the pandemic — almost a quarter of them by motor vehicle — finding a place to park is not exactly easy.

headline: How 100,000 Apartments in New York City Disappeared
abstract: An analysis finds the city has lost more than 100,000 homes through smaller apartments being combined into larger ones.
lead_paragraph: About a decade ago, Timon Malloy encountered a problem familiar to families trying to raise two children in New York City: His apartment started to feel too small.

headline: Exercise
abstract: What do you think this image is communicating?
lead_paragraph: What do you think this image is saying? How does it relate to or comment on society? Can you relate to it personally? What is your opinion of its message?

headline: Don’t Call These Clothes Minimalist. Or Quiet Luxury for That Matter.
abstract: Warning: The versatile, sumptuous pieces at Attersee may telegraph “stealth wealth,” but that’s not the point.
lead_paragraph: “Quiet luxury, oh God,” Isabel Wilkinson Schor, the designer of Attersee, said with a small sigh. “I don’t consider us a part of that trend at all. It’s been around for a very long time, and it’s equated with minimalism. I don’t see what we are doing as minimalism.”

headline: How the G.O.P. Speaker Mess Has Divided N.Y. House Republicans
abstract: In the fight over Representative Jim Jordan’s bid for speaker, moderate Republicans are racing to outrun the chaos their party unleashed.
lead_paragraph: If there is one thing Representative Mike Lawler of New York wants his constituents to know these days, it is that his political party is an absolute mess.

headline: Russia Detains a U.S. Journalist
abstract: Alsu Kurmasheva, who holds dual U.S.-Russian citizenship and works in Prague, was charged with failing to register as a foreign agent after going to Russia for family reasons.
lead_paragraph: The Russian authorities have detained an editor working for Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty, an American broadcaster funded by the United States government, on charges of failing to register as a “foreign agent,” the media company said on Thursday.

headline: Why Your Grip Strength Matters, and How to Improve It
abstract: The muscles in the wrist and hands have been tied to longevity and quality of life. Why is that, and how can you strengthen them?
lead_paragraph: A solid grip is a huge help when playing sports or doing household chores — but it’s also been repeatedly tied to a longer, healthier life. Partly this is because people with strong hands tend to be more physically active, which itself is associated with longevity.

headline: The Troubled-Teen Industry Offers Trauma, Not Therapy
abstract: Tough regulation is needed to combat abusive practices.
lead_paragraph: In 1994, the 15-year-old Liz Ianelli was sent by her parents to the Family Foundation School in Hancock, N.Y., which claimed to treat her disruptive behavior. But she said her “therapy” for most of the next three years consisted of daily emotional attacks by staff and fellow students, forced labor, food deprivation and other assaults. While there, she was also raped by a kitchen employee, she said. Then, as punishment for “lying” about it, she was bound in a blanket with duct tape and left in a boiler room for eight days.

headline: 36 Hours in Glasgow
abstract: Take in Gothic architecture, green riverside walks and a global banquet in Scotland’s largest city, which crackles with character. Just be waterproof.
lead_paragraph: Take in Gothic architecture, green riverside walks and a global banquet in Scotland’s largest city, which crackles with character. Just be waterproof.

headline: When Courtly Love Goes Wrong, It’s Deadly
abstract: In “Hunting the Falcon,” the historians John Guy and Julia Fox take a fresh look at an infamous Tudor marriage — and find there is indeed more to know.
lead_paragraph: Anne Boleyn glanced over her shoulder repeatedly as she waited at the Tower of London for her executioner, a specialist swordsman who had been summoned from France. Would Henry VIII, who could spare lives as casually as he snuffed them out, spare her life on the scaffold as he’d been known to do before?

headline: A South Florida Museum Showcases Burgers, Fries and Beers, Made of Glass
abstract: An exhibit at the Lowe Art Museum will feature fun and nostalgic works by the artist John Miller. Just don’t take a bite.
lead_paragraph: John Miller makes supersize cheeseburgers and French fries — crinkle-cut or curly.

headline: In Santa Fe, a New Museum Brings the Local Art Scene Up to Date
abstract: The first show at the new Vladem Contemporary, which opened last month, spotlights works from 1970 to 2000 and centers on New Mexico artists.
lead_paragraph: In some ways, the original New Mexico Museum of Art was too much of a good thing. The building, located just off the historic Santa Fe Plaza, is a prime example of the Pueblo Revival style of architecture that defines the capital and makes it a popular destination for tourists. Covered in earthy, brown stucco, and with roof timbers protruding through its exterior walls, the 1917 structure is decorated along doorways, stairs and ceilings with intricately carved wood trim.

headline: Reframing the American Landscape
