abstract: When Jirair Ratevosian, a Congressional candidate, and Micheal Ighodaro, an activist and filmmaker, first met, both were so busy with work that sometimes a date meant meeting in an airport lounge.
lead_paragraph: Jirair Ratevosian and Micheal Osa Ighodaro orbited around one another for six years through their work in global health policy and H.I.V. advocacy before ever meeting.

headline: Friday Briefing
abstract: An address by President Biden.
lead_paragraph: In a prime-time address last night, President Biden sought to convey to Americans what is at stake as wars rage in the Middle East and Ukraine, before his expected request to Congress for $14 billion in emergency assistance for Israel and $60 billion for Ukraine. He argued that providing the aid was in the interest of global stability and the national security of the U.S.

headline: Police Search for Gunman in Killing of Maryland Judge
abstract: Judge Andrew F. Wilkinson was found in his driveway with apparent gunshot wounds. He was presiding over a divorce case involving the suspect, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: The authorities in Maryland were investigating the killing of a judge at his home on Thursday night, and identified the suspect as a man who had been a plaintiff in an ongoing divorce case that the judge was handling.

headline: Why These 11 Republican Voters Like Trump But Might Bail on Him
abstract: The group discusses what it would take for a candidate other than Trump to win their vote.
lead_paragraph: The group discusses what it would take for a candidate other than Trump to win their vote.

headline: U.S. Soldier Who Entered North Korea Is Charged With Desertion
abstract: The Army is also accusing Pvt. Travis T. King of other crimes including assaulting other soldiers and child pornography, according to a charging document.
lead_paragraph: Pvt. Travis T. King, the American soldier who returned to the United States last month after crossing into North Korea in July, has been charged in military court with multiple offenses, including desertion, assaulting other soldiers and child pornography.

headline: Word of the Day: ostensible
abstract: This word has appeared in 58 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word ostensible has appeared in 58 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on May 2 in the book review “A Novel Depicts One Disordered Night in the Life of a Teenager” by Hermione Hoby:

headline: Late Night Sums Up Sidney Powell’s Plea Deal
abstract: The former Trump lawyer could testify against the ex-president in one of his cases — “and you don’t even know which one I’m talking about,” Seth Meyers marveled.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Spying
abstract: Tell us a story, real or made up, that is inspired by this image.
lead_paragraph: Use your imagination to write the opening of a short story or poem inspired by this illustration or, describe a memory from your own life that this image makes you think of.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: The Connections Companion
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections Companion, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Since When Does Eric Adams Speak Spanish, Yiddish and Mandarin?
abstract: He doesn’t. But New York City is using artificial intelligence to send robocalls featuring the mayor’s voice in many languages.
lead_paragraph: The calls to New Yorkers have a familiar ring to them. They all sound like Mayor Eric Adams — only in Spanish. Or Yiddish. Or Mandarin.

headline: On Elite Campuses, a New Protest Demand: Unwavering Support
abstract: Past student demonstrations sought to challenge the power structure. Now students also want validation.
lead_paragraph: In what has become a familiar paradigm on college campuses around the country since the start of the war in Israel, hundreds of students at New York University faced one another late Tuesday afternoon in an exchange of chants, accusations and disparagements.

headline: The Most Australian Story to Ever Come Out of Vietnam
abstract: Hotels hold secrets, and some of them are a little stranger than others.
lead_paragraph: The first hotel I ever fell in love with was the Metropole, an old-world gem in Vietnam’s capital, Hanoi. My wife and I stayed there in 2007 on a break from covering the war in Iraq, and between the plush beds, the deep-ended pool in a quiet courtyard, and the rich history of the place as a hub of activity during the Vietnam War, we were smitten.

headline: Prospect of Prolonged Israel-Gaza War Adds Economic Havoc to Human Toll
abstract: A widening conflict would test Israel’s economic resilience while worsening an already bleak outlook for the Palestinian economy.
lead_paragraph: As the fighting between Israel and Hamas risks bursting into regionwide chaos, the prospect of a long and potentially widening war could pile economic havoc atop a devastating human toll.

headline: Giving the Gift of Calder
abstract: A trove of the artist’s works, collected by a former Microsoft executive, will be on exhibit and later donated to the Seattle Art Museum.
lead_paragraph: Jon Shirley discovered Alexander Calder in a book for a high school humanities class, and then saw his work in person on a school trip to the Philadelphia Museum of Art.

headline: American Museums Keep the Spotlight on Korean Art
abstract: There are at least five exhibitions of Korean art at major U.S. museums this fall. The featured works vary from early 12th-century stoneware to a sculpture made from soap.
lead_paragraph: When Hyunsoo Woo arrived in the United States in 1996, she was, in her words, “fresh off the boat” from South Korea. And she noticed something right away.

headline: Rocking the Art World at 80
abstract: Marta Minujín is about to get her due at a Jewish Museum solo exhibition — her first major show in the United States.
lead_paragraph: At 80, Marta Minujín is still as stylishly bold as her art has been over her long career. She fashions platinum blonde hair and signature bangs. Aviator sunglasses usually cover her eyes; bold rings cover her fingers. Her ultra-colorful jumpsuits are an extension of her art, as if she is wearing a live piece of the striped mattresses and paintings that have become synonymous with her name.

headline: “Small/Cool NYC”: Where Tiny Is the New Cool
abstract: Apartment Therapy’s pop-up exhibition is open consecutive weekends in October, in Sunset Park, Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Apartment Therapy’s pop-up exhibition is open consecutive weekends in October, in Sunset Park, Brooklyn.

headline: What Makes a Tiny Home Cool? Apartment Therapy Has Some Ideas.
abstract: The “Small/Cool NYC” pop-up exhibition in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, offers rooms you can explore created by designers you know — and some you may not.
lead_paragraph: “Likely, when we close our eyes and think of a small space, it’s white walls, no lighting and bad storage,” said Nate Berkus.

headline: He Warned Canada About Climate Change but Says, ‘We’ve Failed Big Time’
abstract: After cautioning about environmental damage on TV for decades, David Suzuki, 87, one of Canada’s most famous scientists, felt a sense of defeat as he watched forests burn and temperatures soar this summer.
lead_paragraph: Lifelike prints of fish caught by his young grandchildren adorned the walls of David Suzuki’s vacation home — finely detailed images of rock cods and salmon created by pressing the animals into white paper layered with black ink, following the traditional Japanese art form of gyotaku, or fish rubbing.

headline: The Art World Opens Up to an Underrepresented Group
abstract: Museums and collectors are showing interest in works by developmentally and intellectually challenged artists, many of whom were nurtured in a vibrant Oakland, Calif., center.
lead_paragraph: It was 2:15 on a late-summer Friday afternoon, time for Creative Growth’s weekly dance party. The artists gathered in the lunch area and began gyrating to tunes from a boom box. Soon, a conga line formed. Chugging along, they snaked their way through their work spaces, then out the front door and back, synchronicity more evident in happy faces than footwork. It was a joyous way to celebrate another week of artistry.

headline: In Jesmyn Ward’s New Novel, Slavery Is Hell and Dante Is Our Guide
abstract: “Let Us Descend,” by the two-time National Book Award-winning novelist, takes its title from the “Inferno” and its subject from American history.
lead_paragraph: After Annis, the enslaved teenage girl at the center of Jesmyn Ward’s new novel, “Let Us Descend,” finishes her morning tasks — laundry and dusting in her plantation’s manor home — she lingers outside a doorway. Inside the room, the slave owner’s white daughters, Annis’s half sisters, are having their lessons. “The tutor,” Annis recounts, “is telling a story of a man, an ancient Italian, who is walking down into hell. The hell he travels has levels like my father’s house.” The tutor quotes this ancient Italian — Dante: Let us descend and enter this blind world.

headline: Portraits in Unlikely Spaces
abstract: This fall, work by a trio of Black portraitists, Mickalene Thomas, Renee Cox and Lyle Ashton Harris, is in the spotlight at Yale, Princeton and Duke.
lead_paragraph: Three groundbreaking Black portraiture artists have exhibitions this fall at university art museums, two of which are Ivy League schools — historically white spaces with pasts that are entangled with slavery.

headline: One of the World’s Biggest Museums Is Making Big Changes
abstract: U.S. museums are working to accommodate more art and visitors. At the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the projects come with a $2 billion price tag.
lead_paragraph: “By the end of this, more than a quarter of our galleries will have changed,” Max Hollein, director and chief executive of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, said of the New York City institution’s many huge capital projects. “And we’re not closing the museum to do it. It’s open-heart surgery and the patient is awake.”

headline: The National Museum of Women in the Arts, Transformed
abstract: Two years ago, the institution in Washington closed for renovations. Now, it’s reopening, with expanded galleries and an eye-popping exhibition.
lead_paragraph: The Sky’s the Limit.

headline: Yes, Maui Is Open. But the Loss of Lahaina May Reshape Tourism.
abstract: The entire island of Maui is bracing for the return of tourism even as disaster relief efforts continue. The path to recovery is uncertain.
lead_paragraph: The loss of Lahaina remains a wound felt across all of Maui.

headline: Uncanny Art for the Post-Truth Era
abstract: As deepfakes and A.I. images proliferate, hyperrealist sculpture has taken on an eerie new relevance.
lead_paragraph: THIS PAST SUMMER, a naked man was suspended from the wall of Galerie Georges-Philippe & Nathalie Vallois in Paris, his arms spread-eagle, resembling something between a crucified person and a cadaver. Onlookers couldn’t help but wince. One aghast couple seemed to turn their heads away. But like the dangling body, they, too, were unclothed sculptures — lifeless yet eerily lifelike.

headline: Fall Fashion Has the Spirit of Adventure
abstract: This season, be ready for anything with a mix of runway looks and outdoor gear.

headline: How Israeli Civilians Are Using A.I. to Help Identify Victims
abstract: Brothers and Sisters for Israel formed initially to protest judiciary reform. After Oct. 7, they shifted their mission to helping victims of the attacks, and together with volunteers from Israel’s leading tech companies, created a sophisticated data operation to help find out more about those missing, taken hostage or killed.
lead_paragraph: Brothers and Sisters for Israel formed initially to protest judiciary reform. After Oct. 7, they shifted their mission to helping victims of the attacks, and together with volunteers from Israel’s leading tech companies, created a sophisticated data operation to help find out more about those missing, taken hostage or killed.

headline: For Annie Leibovitz, an Opportunity to Work and Build on the Past
abstract: After receiving a commission for new works, the photographer agreed to a show that she regards as a ‘classroom’ for those who want to follow in her path.
lead_paragraph: Annie Leibovitz often says she is obsessed. In a recent video interview from her Manhattan studio, she related how obsessed she was with space exploration. She also described her obsession with Abraham Lincoln and how she “cleared rooms” one Thanksgiving by incessantly talking about the Civil War and Gettysburg. But most of all, she is obsessed with photography, which has been her calling for more than 50 years. It requires drive, she said, and “you have to be obsessed.”

headline: When You Think About Your Credit Card, Does a Fragrance Come to Mind?
abstract: Corporations are now mimicking fashion designers and hiring development firms to create a signature scent that clients won’t forget.
lead_paragraph: Dora Baghriche grew up in Algiers, where the scents of jasmine, pine, orange blossom and Mediterranean salt spray swirled around her, wafting into her memory.

headline: A Treehouse Builder Who Celebrates Impermanence
abstract: Japan’s Takashi Kobayashi has found freedom in the canopies.
lead_paragraph: “CAN YOU FEEL it swaying?” Takashi Kobayashi asks, 30 feet or so up a camphor tree growing in the cramped back lot of a shop in Tokyo. The wind theoretically shouldn’t be a factor, as we are hemmed in by buildings on all sides, but this tree, some 60 years old, has strained skyward in search of sunlight. With its canopy cresting the surrounding rooflines, its uppermost leaves catch the wind and everything below gently moves. The sensation is a bit unnerving and invokes one of the laws of treehouse building: Heights you wouldn’t think twice about in a concrete structure suddenly become imposing when you’re on a branch.

headline: A Small Country Far From Ukraine Is Sending Hundreds toWar, on Both Sides
abstract: Scores of young Nepali men have gone to fight, some lured by Russia’s promise of work, others to fight for Ukraine, raising the prospect of Nepalis fighting one another in a distant war.
lead_paragraph: Several months ago, Sandip Thapaliya, an out-of-work lab technician, called his sister in Kathmandu to share some exciting news.

headline: Cities Foster Serendipity. But Can They Do It When Workers Are at Home?
abstract: Revisiting a theory about chance collisions and innovation.
lead_paragraph: There is a thing that happens in cities — that we think happens in cities — when people with lots of different ideas bump into each other on the sidewalk, or at the bar or the grocery store or the gym. Together, they think up things that would never come out of a conference room or the kind of coffee meeting that has a calendar invite. Weird new ideas take root. Innovation follows.

headline: A Bridal Fashion Newcomer Stages a Grand Debut
abstract: Anifa Mvuemba, the founder of the clothing brand Hanifa, presented her first bridal collection, inspired by a luxury wedding complete with a cocktail hour and after-party in Middleburg, Va.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday, at a grandiose country resort, some 200 guests were seated inside a massive tent draped with white curtains, the sun peaking through the ceiling and onto their faces. They had flown in from New York, Miami, Atlanta, Dallas and Los Angeles, which is not unusual for the typical big city fashion show. But this was in Middleburg, Va., an hour away from the Washington airport.

headline: How Does Gotham F.C. Fit Into New York?
abstract: The club made the playoffs in the National Women’s Soccer League. It’s trying to raise its profile in the city.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Friday. Today we’ll meet the executive in charge of the one New York area team that still has a chance at a championship.

headline: What to Know About ‘Killers of the Flower Moon’: A Guide to the Osage Murders
abstract: Martin Scorsese’s epic traces a real plot by white men to kill dozens of Native Americans who held oil rights in 1920s Oklahoma. Here is the back story.
lead_paragraph: In the 1920s, at least 60 Osage people were murdered or went missing in Oklahoma. Their white killers often married the victims before dispatching them. With shares of the tribe’s immense oil profits at stake, the scheme made them rich.

headline: The Federal Deficit Is Growing. This Is Why.
abstract: Tax receipts dipped unexpectedly last year. The Biden administration blames Republican tax cuts, but the truth is more complicated.
lead_paragraph: America’s federal budget deficit effectively doubled over the year to $2 trillion, a surprising jump given the strength of the economy.

headline: ‘Oof’: Sam Bankman-Fried’s Trial Reveals Inside Details of How FTX Died
abstract: Prosecutors in the criminal fraud case have built the most intricate account to date of the cryptocurrency exchange’s frantic final days.
lead_paragraph: On the morning of Nov. 6, Nishad Singh, a top executive at the cryptocurrency exchange FTX, sent a message in a group chat with two senior colleagues. Customers were rushing to withdraw funds from the exchange, he wrote. Within the last day, they had tried to move $1.25 billion off the platform, and $120 million in withdrawal requests had come in over the last hour.

headline: The Restaurant Revolution Has Begun
abstract: Many restaurants are fundamentally changing how they do business after the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: Like so many other chefs, I was drawn to the restaurant business because it is exciting. I ignored its dysfunction and accepted that I’d forgo higher education, financial stability and holidays with family in order to share my craft with others.

headline: The True Story Behind ‘Killers of the Flower Moon’ Is Being Erased From Oklahoma Classrooms
abstract: The facts behind a new film offer crucial lessons about American history. Why aren’t students in Oklahoma learning about this story in school?
lead_paragraph: During the early 20th century, members of the Osage Nation in Oklahoma were systematically murdered by white settlers. Yet outside the Osage Nation, the history of this racial injustice — one of the worst in American history — was distorted and then largely erased from memory.

headline: An Indian Artist Questions Borders and the Limits on Free Speech
abstract: In hauntingly spare artworks, Shilpa Gupta grapples with questions of censorship, born from her own experiences with authoritarian limits.
lead_paragraph: In 2013, after years trying to get permission from layer upon layer of authorities in India to put up an outdoor light work, the artist Shilpa Gupta finally got the OK — with the caveat that she take down the piece within 24 hours. That would have been impossible, but she signed the papers anyway, knowing that once the piece was up, it would take some time before anyone would come around to make her remove it.

headline: Thomas L. Friedman on Israel’s ‘Morally Impossible Situation’
abstract: What kind of war should we expect in the weeks to come?
lead_paragraph: This week, the Opinion columnist and former New York Times Jerusalem bureau chief Thomas L. Friedman joins the “Matter of Opinion” hosts to discuss the rapidly evolving situation in the Middle East and the mistakes that led to this moment. (He’s looking at you, Benjamin Netanyahu.)

headline: The Pianist Vikingur Olafsson on ‘History’s Greatest Keyboard Work’
abstract: Bach’s “Goldberg” Variations, which Olafsson recorded for Deutsche Grammophon and is touring this season, is “like a life cycle.”
lead_paragraph: Vikingur Olafsson calls it “a workaholic’s sabbatical”: The Icelandic pianist, 39, is dedicating almost all his performances this season to Bach’s “Goldberg” Variations.

headline: Crypto Influencers and ‘Degenerates’ Flock to Sam Bankman-Fried’s Trial
abstract: The presence of crypto YouTubers, podcasters and commentators at the FTX founder’s fraud trial has created something of a culture clash in the courtroom.
lead_paragraph: A parade of powerful legal minds has gathered over the last three weeks at the criminal trial of Sam Bankman-Fried, the disgraced cryptocurrency mogul. Damian Williams, the top federal prosecutor in Manhattan, has sat for hours in the 26th-floor courtroom, alongside partners at prestigious law firms and a former deputy to Robert Mueller III, who served as special counsel in an investigation of President Donald J. Trump.

headline: Are You There for Your Friends When They Need You?
abstract: Are your friends there for you?
lead_paragraph: What do you value most in a friend? Honesty? Loyalty? Humor? Shared interests? Listening skills? Empathy?

headline: Halloween Is for Kids. ‘Kidults’ Too.
abstract: Grown-ups are finding joy in buying toys, going to see movies about toys or dressing up as them to recapture the feeling of being a kid, and businesses are capitalizing on it.
lead_paragraph: Grown-ups are finding joy in buying toys, going to see movies about toys or dressing up as them to recapture the feeling of being a kid, and businesses are capitalizing on it.

headline: On Israel, Progressive Jews Feel Abandoned by Their Left-Wing Allies
abstract: Jewish leaders and voters said they were taken aback to discover that many of their ideological allies saw them as oppressors who deserved blame following the Israel attacks.
lead_paragraph: Progressive Jews who have spent years supporting racial equity, gay and transgender rights, abortion rights and other causes on the American left — including opposing Israeli policies in Gaza and the West Bank — are suddenly feeling abandoned by those who they long thought of as allies. This wartime shift represents a fundamental break within a liberal coalition that has long powered the Democratic Party.

headline: Why Egypt Can’t Solve Gaza’s Problems
abstract: Egypt has appeared hesitant to help relieve the humanitarian distress affecting Palestinian civilians. Why?
lead_paragraph: In this period of intense Israeli military preparation following Hamas’s horrific terror attack on Oct. 7, and equally intense diplomatic activities surrounding the humanitarian crisis in the Gaza Strip, a crucial question has centered on Egypt’s role.

headline: A Thaw Between U.S. and Venezuela Ahead of a Key Vote
abstract: The release of political prisoners and the lifting of some U.S. sanctions comes as Venezuela’s opposition prepares to elect a candidate to challenge the country’s leader.
lead_paragraph: When the Venezuelan government released five political prisoners late Wednesday to cheers from the country’s opposition, it was the most emotional in a rapid series of policy shifts in the South American country that together represent the most significant softening of relations between Venezuela and the United States in years.

headline: Javier Milei, a ‘Mini-Trump,’ Could Be Argentina’s Next President
abstract: The global far-right movement faces an important test in Argentina’s election on Sunday.
lead_paragraph: He made his name disparaging people on television. He levels harsh attacks against critics online. He sports an unruly hairdo that has become a meme. And he is now the leader of his country’s far right.

headline: 7 New Paperbacks to Read This Week
abstract: Including titles by Siddhartha Mukherjee, Jemele Hill, Kelly Link and more.
lead_paragraph: Including titles by Siddhartha Mukherjee, Jemele Hill, Kelly Link and more.

headline: Why You Should Make Time for Oddball Rituals
abstract: Even the small ones add richness to our lives, experts say.
lead_paragraph: My husband and I have developed a little ritual over the years. When one of us takes a trip, the other will make enchiladas when we’re reunited.

headline: The New York Times News Quiz, Oct. 20, 2023
abstract: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.
lead_paragraph: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

headline: 5 Things to Do This Weekend
abstract: Selections from the Weekend section, including a review of Martin Scorsese's “Killers of the Flower Moon.”
lead_paragraph: Selections from the Weekend section, including a review of Martin Scorsese's “Killers of the Flower Moon.”

headline: It Is Impossible to Know What to Believe in This Hideous War
abstract: An explosion at a Gaza hospital reveals the danger of leaping to conclusions.
lead_paragraph: As a few bleak anecdotes illustrate, it is often impossible, in real time, for outsiders to know what is happening in the ceaselessly reigniting war between Israel and the Palestinians. This was true even before social media and before Elon Musk acquired Twitter and turned it into the cesspool of misinformation, trolling and hysteria now called X. But today countless people are plugged into a frantically churning news cycle, trying to instantly metabolize a conflict that is a hall of mirrors in the best of times and is now careening toward a possible regional war, with all the propaganda and mass panic that entails. It’s an epistemological catastrophe that is putting people’s lives in danger.

headline: The Only Question to Ask About These House Republicans
abstract: How the party of limited government became the party of no government at all.
lead_paragraph: The collapse of the House Republican majority into chaos is the clearest possible evidence that the party is off the rails.

headline: Peering Into A.I.’s Black Box, Who’s the Real Techno-Optimist? and Reading Ancient Scrolls With A.I.
abstract: New ways we’re understanding A.I. models, the musings of a billionaire venture capitalist, and the first word from an ancient scroll.
lead_paragraph: A.I. models are black boxes. You input a prompt and the model outputs nearly anything: a sonnet, an image or a legal brief riddled with lies. Today, a look at three ways that researchers are unlocking that black box in hopes of bringing transparency to A.I.

headline: A Deal for Aid Into Gaza, and More
abstract: Plus, President Biden’s speech to Congress and how the Texas governor’s bus program has altered the immigration debate.
lead_paragraph: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.

headline: Hamas Took Her Son
abstract: The story of a mother whose son is being held hostage in the Gaza Strip.
lead_paragraph: Warning: This episode contains strong language and descriptions of violence.

headline: Gaza and the Trudeau Problem
abstract: Canada’s accusations against India offer some insights into how the world might get some clarity about the Gaza explosion.
lead_paragraph: The explosion at a hospital in Gaza on Tuesday evening — the source of which remains unclear — hasn’t been the only international mystery in recent weeks. Last month, Justin Trudeau, Canada’s prime minister, suggested that Indian government agents had helped murder a Canadian citizen near Vancouver in a political attack.

headline: ‘The Persian Version’ Director Has Always Lived in the In-Between
abstract: In her new film, Maryam Keshavarz finds both gravity and levity in the struggle to reconcile her Iranian heritage and her life in the United States.
lead_paragraph: When Leila, the central character in the new comedy-drama “The Persian Version,” sashays across the Brooklyn Bridge and into a Halloween party carrying a surfboard and wearing a burkini — niqab on top, bikini on the bottom — while Wet Leg’s cheeky anthem “Chaise Longue” plays, it’s clear that what’s to come will be a boundary-pushing take on straddling cultures that are at odds in the real world.

headline: A Cannes Winner Asks: What if the Powerful Woman Isn’t Punished?
abstract: The French director Justine Triet’s movies explore the anxieties of women who work and play hard. Her latest, “Anatomy of a Fall,” won the Palme d’Or.
lead_paragraph: Justine Triet, the writer and director behind this year’s Palme d’Or winner, “Anatomy of a Fall,” makes movies about the misadventures of working girls and the double standards faced by mothers who have the audacity to be, well, unmotherly. Triet has directed romcoms, relationship dramas and now, a courtroom whodunit: all magnify the fears and anxieties of women who work and play hard.

headline: The New Darling of the European Art Trade? Paris.
abstract: At the Paris+ fair and its satellites, there was plenty of talk about the art world’s center of gravity in Europe shifting from Britain to France.
lead_paragraph: “Something is going on. People want to come to Paris now, ” said the London-based contemporary art dealer Niru Ratnam, who this week was exhibiting at the Paris Internationale fair for emerging galleries.

headline: Chicken Souvlaki for Dinner, Strawberry Granola for Breakfast and Jalapeño Poppers for Halftime
abstract: Inspiration — and recipes — for every eating opportunity.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. A number of years ago, on a sunny afternoon in Melbourne, Australia, I ate a pork gyro, a species of gyro I had never encountered before. I’d grown up eating lamb gyros at Mr. Souvlaki on Montague Street in Brooklyn, but never pork ones. Maybe beef ones, too, occasionally. But mostly lamb: the meat shaved onto pita and then topped with salad, tzatziki and a red sauce of ketchup deeply cut with hot sauce. The pork version was a revelation. When I got home I made the dish again and again until the recipe was good enough to share.

headline: Middle East Conflict Threatens Global Growth
abstract: Oil prices climbed again on Friday as armed clashes intensify in Israel and, increasingly, beyond.

headline: When a Car Is Affordable Housing and More: The Week in Reporter Reads
abstract: Articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
lead_paragraph: This weekend, listen to a collection of articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.

headline: Violence Surges in West Bank, With 13 Palestinians and an Israeli Killed
abstract: The deadliest fighting occurred in the Nur Shams refugee camp, where Israeli forces also carried out a rare drone strike.
lead_paragraph: Deadly violence is surging across the Israeli-occupied West Bank, where 13 Palestinians and one Israeli officer were killed in clashes on Thursday, according to Palestinian and Israeli officials.

headline: Republicans Vote Out Jordan as Speaker Nominee, Continuing Chaos in House
abstract: House Republicans will meet again on Monday in an effort to find a new speaker from among a flurry of new candidates.
lead_paragraph: Republicans cast aside their latest nominee for House speaker on Friday, rejecting Representative Jim Jordan of Ohio during a secret ballot vote, leaving them once again to search for a new leader amid raging personal and political recriminations.

headline: What Has Brought You Joy in 2023
abstract: You grew bushels of tomatoes, watched a solar eclipse and married your best friend, among other delights.
lead_paragraph: With the end of October fast approaching, I’m starting to feel as if 2023 is going to be over before I know it.

headline: The Gems Hiding in Plain Sight in the Treasury Market
abstract: Back in 1994, bonds with fabulous yields were there for the taking. Our columnist doesn’t see treasures like that now, but there are solid buys.
lead_paragraph: You didn’t have to be a financial wizard to get a safe return of more than 7 percent on your money for decades to come. All you had to do was buy a 30-year U.S. Treasury bond in the last nine months of 1994.

headline: 1948: Lateness of Yugoslav Trains is Laid to a Negative Attitude
abstract: The country’s Communist government blamed crews for the increasing number of costly railroad delays.
lead_paragraph: BELGRADE, Oct. 19 — An investigation into the dilatory habits of Yugoslav railroad trains has exposed a negative attitude on the part of some train personnel, the Communist organ “Borba” revealed today.

headline: With Raids Across Dnipro River, Ukraine May Be Seeking New Front in War
abstract: Military experts are reporting extensive strikes on Russian-held territory in the south, potentially with the goal of establishing a bridgehead on the east bank of the Dnipro.
lead_paragraph: Ukrainian forces have stepped up assaults across the Dnipro river near the southern city of Kherson, carrying out raids into Russian-controlled territory on the eastern bank. The increased activity has prompted speculation among analysts and in Russian military circles that Kyiv might be planning a more ambitious effort to open a new front in the war.

headline: A Filmmaker’s Fraught Specialty: Women at Work and the Men Who Scare Them
abstract: Kitty Green’s movies, “The Assistant” and now “The Royal Hotel,” address gender dynamics in familiar, but menacing, environments.
lead_paragraph: In her feature debut, “The Assistant” (2020), the Australian filmmaker Kitty Green followed an underling (Julia Garner) at a film company run by a toxic male boss, tracking her growing understanding of his harassment. The taut drama was quickly understood to be a prescient take on gender dynamics in the nascent #MeToo era.

headline: Movement and Memory: Dance Love and Dance Rejection in Ireland
abstract: Michael Keegan-Dolan has collaborated with his partner Rachel Poirier on “How to Be a Dancer in 72,000 Easy Lessons,” coming to St. Ann’s Warehouse.
lead_paragraph: “For some reason I wanted to be a dancer,” Michael Keegan-Dolan said of his younger self. “And then I realized I was really bad at it.” Keegan-Dolan, a choreographer and director, was talking on a video call from his home in Dingle, a remote spot on the southwest coast of Ireland where he lives with the dancer Rachel Poirier, and where his dance company Teac Damsa is based. “I was this kind of tragic character.”

headline: Apple’s New Film Strategy Debuts With ‘Killers of the Flower Moon’
abstract: Martin Scorsese’s three-and-a-half-hour epic is the first of three high-profile movies the tech company will give wide theatrical releases in the coming months.
lead_paragraph: The box office results for Martin Scorsese’s new film, “Killers of the Flower Moon,” will be revealed on Sunday and analyzed by reporters and industry insiders. Did the movie perform well? Did it fall short? Did Leonardo DiCaprio’s inability to promote the film because of the actors’ strike ultimately mean fewer people went to see it?

headline: Britney Spears, From the Conservatorship’s Demise to ‘The Woman in Me’
abstract: Before the pop star releases her memoir next week, here’s a look back at her life since the guardianship controlling her affairs was terminated in 2021.
lead_paragraph: In June 2021, Britney Spears spoke to a Los Angeles courtroom, giving an impassioned 23-minute statement about her struggles under the conservatorship that had controlled her personal and business decisions for 13 years.

headline: To Combat the Opioid Epidemic, Cities Ponder Facilities for Drug Use
abstract: Philadelphia is again the focus of a national campaign to open — or restrict — sites where people use drugs under medical supervision.
lead_paragraph: Quetcy M. Lozada, a first-term Philadelphia City Council member, stood on a September evening near an elementary school just off Kensington Avenue, the epicenter of a sprawling fentanyl market in a city that saw a record 1,413 drug overdose deaths last year.

headline: Storm Brings ‘Exceptional’ Amount of Rain to Scotland, and More Is on the Way
abstract: Storm Babet has already dumped more than 26 inches of rain on the region, far more than is normal for this time of year.
lead_paragraph: Britain’s weather agency has once again issued a rare “red weather warning” in Scotland because of “exceptional” levels of rain, its second such warning in less than three days, as Storm Babet continues to wreak havoc over the region.

headline: Giorgia Meloni Tells Italy She Is Dumping Her Longtime Partner
abstract: On social media, the prime minister said her 10-year relationship with a news anchor “ends here,” after a hot mic and video footage picked him up apparently hitting on other women.
lead_paragraph: There is a war raging in the Middle East. The specter of terrorism is returning to Europe. A new China and Russia alliance is raising questions about the breakup of the world order.

headline: Audiobook of the Week: A Rich Family Saga Set in 1950s Maine
abstract: In Rachel Eliza Griffith’s debut novel, “Promise,” the Kindreds find they can’t escape past mistakes.
lead_paragraph: A deadly mistake is hard to escape, especially in a tight-knit community like Damascus, Del. Thus in need of a fresh start, Heron and Jolene Kindred have taken their newborn and fled, settling in the remote coastal village of Salt Point, Maine.

headline: Biden Requests $105 Billion Aid Package for Israel, Ukraine and Other Crises
abstract: The conflict in the Middle East has given President Biden a path to approving Ukraine aid that otherwise might have remained stalled.
lead_paragraph: President Biden on Friday delivered to Congress a $105 billion request for military aid, mostly for Israel and Ukraine, essentially daring lawmakers who oppose parts of the proposal to vote against an overall package that he said will ensure “American security for generations.”

headline: Food and Water Into Gaza Are Delayed as Talks Drag On, Officials Say
abstract: Egypt, Israel, the United States and the United Nations were still negotiating over thorny issues, including who would inspect the shipments for weapons, officials said.
lead_paragraph: Hopes that humanitarian aid would begin to trickle into Gaza from Egypt on Friday were fading as Egyptian, Israeli, U.S. and United Nations officials were still hammering out thorny issues, including who will inspect the shipments for weapons, several U.N. and European officials and diplomats familiar with the talks said.

headline: Kenneth Force, the ‘Toscanini of Military Marching Bands,’ Dies at 83
abstract: Captain Force was part of the pomp and ceremony at 10 presidential inaugurations, and for 45 years he taught midshipmen to revere traditional military music.
lead_paragraph: Kenneth Force, who as the leader of the Merchant Marine Academy Regimental Band from 1971 to 2016 was one of the nation’s foremost experts in the art of military pomp, died on Oct. 7 in Rye, N.Y. He was 83.

headline: When Saying Nothing Is Saying Something
abstract: Leagues and teams probably would have preferred not to take a public position on the Israel-Hamas war. That they could not avoid doing so is their own fault.
lead_paragraph: By the end of last week, England’s Football Association doubtless felt that it had done the best it could, that after hours and hours of talks, it had settled on what might best be described as the least worst option.

headline: Israeli Airstrike Hits Greek Orthodox Church Compound in Gaza City
abstract: Israel’s military acknowledged it had damaged the church site while targeting what it said was a Hamas command center nearby.
lead_paragraph: An Israeli airstrike hit the grounds of the historic Saint Porphyrius Greek Orthodox Church in Gaza City, which was sheltering displaced people, on Thursday night, according to church officials and witnesses.

headline: Review: An African Choir’s Disillusioning Journey to the West
abstract: Gregory Maqoma and Thuthuka Sibisi’s “Broken Chord” considers the 19th-century tour of a group of South African singers to England and North America.
lead_paragraph: In the dimness, something is spinning. As the lights slowly rise, that something turns out to be a man whirling a ropelike tube over his head like a lasso, a tube that makes a sound like singing. As the stage grows brighter, we see that the man is surrounded by four vocalists. It is their song we are hearing, and it is glorious.

headline: ‘Scary Movie 3’ at 20: Still Kills
abstract: The horror parody’s threequel remains the smartest dumb movie of its era.
lead_paragraph: Just before Halloween 20 years ago, the slasher spoof “Scary Movie” released its third installment, a truly unserious sendup of “The Ring,” “8 Mile,” M. Night Shyamalan and pop culture at large. I died of laughter watching it as a preteen — that it was immature and in bad taste was entirely the point. Two decades and a college degree later, I’m afraid to say, “Scary Movie 3” still kills me.

headline: Review: The Philharmonic Welcomes Back an Old Friend
abstract: David Robertson returned to the podium to lead the orchestra’s first in a series of performances to celebrate the centennial of Gyorgy Ligeti’s birth.
lead_paragraph: It’s always a good sign when an orchestra’s players light up with smiles at a conductor.

headline: A Plea From Native Hawaiians: The Future of Maui Rests on Honoring Its Past
abstract: The wildfire that devastated Lahaina wiped out many vestiges of the town’s past. Conservators are racing to recover what they can.
lead_paragraph: To the outside world there has been no more vivid symbol of the storied history of Lahaina, and its potential for rebirth, than a 150-year-old banyan tree in the center of town whose scarred branches are now, two months after a devastating wildfire, sprouting new, green leaves.

headline: Cameo to the Moon, and Back
abstract: A start-up that offers fans a way to buy personalized videos from celebrities was supercharged by pandemic boredom and venture capital. All it had to do was grow forever.
lead_paragraph: Kenny G opened a meeting with a saxophone serenade. Paula Abdul judged an “American Idol”-style talent contest. “Hamilton” cast members performed. Lance Bass was there, hanging out. And when Robert Van Winkle, better known as Vanilla Ice, sang his 1990 hit, “Ice Ice Baby,” flanked by 10-foot sparklers, he pulled the Sugar Ray frontman Mark McGrath onstage.

headline: DeSantis Super PAC Helps Pay for Private Flights, in Unusual Move
abstract: The Florida governor’s campaign, facing a cash crunch, has found a way to offload the steep costs of private air travel. Campaign finance experts say the arrangement could test the limits of the law.
lead_paragraph: Short on cash, Gov. Ron DeSantis’s presidential campaign has found an unusual way to pay for his habit of flying in private planes: passing the cost to the better-funded super PAC that is increasingly intertwined with his operation.

headline: The Rolling Stones’ Ragged Plea, and 8 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Kali Uchis, Helena Deland, Olof Dreijer and others.
lead_paragraph: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the week’s most notable new tracks. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage, and The Amplifier, a twice-weekly guide to new and old songs.

headline: As Movie Theaters Embrace Swift, One Showcases Her Exes
abstract: In addition to “Taylor Swift: The Eras Tour,” a Milwaukee theater is programming films that feature some of her starry boyfriends.
lead_paragraph: Like movie theaters across the country that are facing the fallout of an actors’ strike and the shift to streaming, the Oriental Theater in Milwaukee was quite pleased to have Taylor Swift’s concert film coming to its screens.

headline: A Sweet Squash Offering for Día de los Muertos
abstract: In many Latin American countries, families attract their ancestors in cemeteries with the spiced, syrupy dessert ayote en miel.
lead_paragraph: It’s not fall for Alicia Maher until she smells the warm spices from her slow-cooked squash dessert at her home in Los Angeles.

headline: 25 Classic Horror Movies to Stream
abstract: From silent monsters to digital-age demons, these scary-movie cornerstones are available to scream — sorry, stream.
lead_paragraph: When people ask me what my favorite horror movie is, John Carpenter’s groundbreaking shocker comes out on top. Jamie Lee Curtis plays a high schooler who gets stalked on Halloween night by an escaped lunatic named Michael Myers. Today it sounds like any old horror movie. But Carpenter was prophetic with narrative choices that horror now takes for granted: a masked killing-machine villain, a strong-willed final girl next door, creatively depicted deaths, touches of dark comedy. (And a score that sounds like a chase.) Together they make “Halloween” my top Halloween treat.

headline: OpenAI in Talks for Deal That Would Value Company at $80 Billion
abstract: The San Francisco start-up’s valuation could triple in less than six months.
lead_paragraph: OpenAI is in talks to complete a deal that would value the company at $80 billion or more, nearly triple its valuation less than six months ago, according to a person with knowledge of the discussions.

headline: Five International Movies to Stream Now
abstract: This month’s picks include a comedic Swedish slasher, a Tunisian noir, an Austenian take on the Indian wedding melodrama and more.
lead_paragraph: This Swedish slasher, arriving on Netflix right on time for Halloween, is about one of the great horrors of modern life: work retreats. A group of municipal employees gather at a resort to get back in touch with nature, build team spirit and discuss plans for a controversial project that requires the appropriation of local farmland. The strained smiles of the leaders of the project — and their circular corporate-speak whenever any colleague raises ethical qualms — are sinister in their own way. But when the resort staff and guests are killed one by one in spectacularly disgusting fashion, the group’s ability to work together — and traverse zip-lines and make D.I.Y. rafts — acquires life and death stakes. The director Patrik Eklund crafts a lean thriller out of this premise, serving up sharp satire about corporate greed with a generous splattering of blood and gore.

headline: The Big Number: 37 Percent
abstract: New Federal Reserve data showed that Americans' wealth jumped by the most on record during the pandemic.
lead_paragraph: New Federal Reserve data showed that Americans' wealth jumped by the most on record during the pandemic.

headline: Man Poses as Mannequin to Steal Jewelry
abstract: A 22-year-old man in Warsaw posed motionless, carrying a shopping bag, beside mannequins in a storefront window, the police said. Security officials caught him.
lead_paragraph: In a storefront window in Warsaw stood at what first glance appeared to be a mannequin in a mustard-colored sweatshirt.

headline: Kenneth Chesebro, a Trump-Aligned Lawyer, Pleads Guilty in Georgia
abstract: Mr. Chesebro’s plea deal comes a day after Sidney Powell, another of Donald Trump’s co-defendants in the Georgia election interference case, took a guilty plea.
lead_paragraph: Kenneth Chesebro on Friday became the second lawyer in two days to plead guilty in a criminal racketeering indictment that also named Donald J. Trump.

headline: The Multimillion-Dollar Machines at the Center of the U.S.-China Rivalry
abstract: The United States is taking unusual action to clamp down on sales of chip-making machinery to China, even as Chinese firms are racing to stockpile the equipment.
lead_paragraph: They are smooth white boxes, roughly the size of large cargo vans, and they are now at the heart of the U.S.-Chinese technology conflict.

headline: Turmoil Over Student Support for Hamas
abstract: Readers discuss tensions at Harvard, Columbia and other campuses over the Israel-Gaza war. Also: Sidney Powell’s plea deal.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Watch the Orionids Meteor Shower Reach Its Peak Tonight
abstract: The latest potential supply of fireballs in the night sky comes from the trail left by Halley’s comet.
lead_paragraph: On any given night, far from bright city lights, there’s a chance that you’ll see a beautiful streak shoot across the sky as a meteor flies overhead. But on special dates scattered throughout the year, skywatchers can catch a multitude of flares as meteor showers burst in the darkness.

headline: How Superheroes Took Over the Multiplex
abstract: Dave Gonzales and Joanna Robinson, who collaborated with Gavin Edwards on the new book “MCU,” talk about Marvel Studios and the reign of the Marvel Cinematic Universe.
lead_paragraph: In 2008 — the same year that Robert Downey Jr. appeared in the action comedy “Tropic Thunder,” for which he would earn his second Oscar nomination — he also appeared as the billionaire inventor and unlikely superhero Tony Stark in “Iron Man,” the debut feature from the upstart Marvel Studios.

headline: Drake Takes on All Comers
abstract: The rapper’s new album, “For All the Dogs,” has stirred debate about maturity and misogyny, and led to questions about the next phase of his career.
lead_paragraph: The new Drake album, “For All the Dogs,” isn’t an innovation in the Drake oeuvre. It’s not a home for stylistic experimentation, or a collection of forward-looking lyrics. Instead, it’s an extension and distillation of what he’s been doing for a decade and a half: tell personal stories cut with boasting, providing a view into the broken heart of a superstar.

headline: Why Big Money Can’t Easily Change Campus Politics
abstract: Some unsolicited advice for wealthy donors.
lead_paragraph: The author of this newsletter takes a generally dim view of wealthy donors who give lots of money to America’s richest universities, and an especially critical view of those who do so despite harboring strong objections to the leftward ideological drift of those same institutions.

headline: In Chloé Show, an Unseen Legacy With Quiet Jewish Roots
abstract: Gaby Aghion, Chloé’s founder, didn’t just make a brand for herself, she made one for all women.
lead_paragraph: For only the second time in its almost 120 years, the Jewish Museum is holding a fashion exhibition — and it is the first in New York dedicated to Chloé, the French ready-to-wear brand founded in 1952 by the Egyptian-born designer Gaby Aghion. “Mood of the Moment: Gaby Aghion and the House of Chloé” seeks to rectify both oversights, while introducing its founder, and her connection to her own Jewish identity, to the broader public.

headline: What the Republican Votes Against Jim Jordan Mean
abstract: “Is this a crack in the MAGA armor?” a reader asks.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
abstract: Our TV critic recommends an afterlife comedy, an intriguing documentary and a five-in-one British murder show.
lead_paragraph: ‘Upload’

headline: Passion for Palestinian Cause Had Faded, but Violence in Gaza Reignited It
abstract: The Israeli bombardment of Gaza, in retaliation for a deadly Hamas attack on southern Israel, brought a new outpouring of support in the Arab world for the Palestinian quest for a state.
lead_paragraph: As the Israeli bombardment of Gaza has intensified in recent days, large protests have erupted across the Arab and Muslim worlds in support of the Palestinian cause, a reminder of the profound resonance the issue still holds for many.

headline: Hedi Slimane Drops a Surprise Celine Show
abstract: It has been almost a year since his last women’s wear collection. Why? It’s an open book.
lead_paragraph: Of all the designers who stepped off the fashion wheel during the pandemic-induced show hiatus, Hedi Slimane of Celine is one of the very few who has not returned to the same-old-same-old runway system. Instead he offers up his collections when and how he wants.

headline: The Holmdel Horn, a Cosmic Shrine in New Jersey, Stays Put
abstract: The radio telescope that discovered the Big Bang has survived a real estate battle — for now.
lead_paragraph: A radio telescope that discovered evidence of the Big Bang in 1964, revolutionizing the study of the universe, will remain in its original place on Crawford Hill in Holmdel, N.J, town officials announced last week.

headline: The Weekender
abstract: The five cloned dogs in Argentina’s election. Also: an interview with Jada Pinkett Smith and  “The Exorcist” at 50.

headline: In Praise of the Ever-Evolving Lauryn Hill
abstract: Celebrating the 25th anniversary of “The Miseducation of Lauryn Hill,” as well as her legacy with the Fugees, the singer and rapper reveled in the power of reinvention.
lead_paragraph: “She is having so much fun onstage” was the surprised thought that ran through my mind as Lauryn Hill kicked off her Ms. Lauryn Hill & Fugees: “Miseducation of Lauryn Hill” 25th Anniversary Tour at the Prudential Center in downtown Newark on Tuesday night.

headline: Brace Yourself for Lots of Taylor Swifts and Travis Kelces This Halloween
abstract: Move over, Barbie and Ken, another couples costume has entered the zeitgeist in the fourth quarter.
lead_paragraph: Within 24 hours of Taylor Swift’s surprise appearance at a Kansas City football game in September, Ashlee Hartley and her husband, Charlie Tighe, began gathering materials for their Halloween costumes.

headline: How to Wash a Comforter
abstract: Yes, you can do it at home.
lead_paragraph: Yes, you can do it at home.

headline: Investors Fret as Daunting Bond Market Milestone Comes Into View
abstract: The 10-year U.S. Treasury yield has threatened to break above 5 percent for the first time in 16 years, rattling the markets.
lead_paragraph: One of the most important interest rates in the world this week flirted with a level it hadn’t reached in more than 16 years, putting pressure on the economy and the stock market.

headline: Maryland Police Officer Charged in Jan. 6 Capitol Attack
abstract: The officer, Justin Lee, joined the force a year after the attack. He had been on leave since July because of an unrelated case in which he fatally shot an armed man.
lead_paragraph: A Maryland police officer was arrested Thursday on charges related to his participation in the riot at the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, including assaulting law enforcement.

headline: Dutch Royals Confront Their Country’s Colonial Legacy in South Africa
abstract: The king has previously apologized for his family’s role in slavery, but some South Africans seek a direct apology and reparations from the Netherlands.
lead_paragraph: On their first visit to an African country since ascending the throne a decade ago, the king and queen of the Netherlands made a symbolic visit on Friday to the Slave Lodge in Cape Town, South Africa, where Dutch colonists once enslaved thousands of Africans and Asians.

headline: Dressed for Success: 7 Bands in Uniform
abstract: Hear songs by the White Stripes, Destiny’s Child and more.
lead_paragraph: Today’s Amplifier is based on an idea my colleague Jon Pareles mentioned when he was working on a profile of Devo: How about a playlist of bands that wear uniforms?

headline: Kenneth Chesebro Pleads Guilty in Georgia Interference Case
abstract: Mr. Chesebro was criminally charged in Georgia for his role in what prosecutors described as a conspiracy to overturn the 2020 election in favor of Donald J. Trump.
lead_paragraph: Mr. Chesebro was criminally charged in Georgia for his role in what prosecutors described as a conspiracy to overturn the 2020 election in favor of Donald J. Trump.

headline: The Glowing Secret That Mammals Have Been Hiding
abstract: Fluorescent anatomy, which recently seemed to be a quirk in unusual animals such as platypuses and opossums, was found in most living families of mammals.
lead_paragraph: At first, it seemed to be another caprice of two already unusual animals: Flying squirrels and platypuses were found to be fluorescent, absorbing invisible ultraviolet light and re-emitting it in shocking pink or bright cyan.

headline: ‘Billions’ Season 7, Episode 11: Courting a Centrist Candidate
abstract: Prince and Axe jostle for the attentions of Gov. Nancy Dunlop.
lead_paragraph: “So, well, there’s that.” You said it, Axe. The penultimate episode of “Billions” has now come and gone, and with it one of the show’s final opportunities to really blow us away with a patented five-steps-ahead scheme that ends in a sudden twist turning everything on its ear. That is … not what we got.

headline: Forging Their Own Paths
abstract: Memoirs by Meg Kissinger, Athena Dixon, McKenzie Wark and Xiaolu Guo tackle loneliness, self-reinvention and family legacy.
lead_paragraph: In WHILE YOU WERE OUT: An Intimate Family Portrait of Mental Illness in an Era of Silence (Celadon, 303 pp., $30), Meg Kissinger’s family of eight siblings and two exhausted parents looks, at first, like a robust, love-infused household in the North Shore neighborhood of Chicago. But as early as age 5, Kissinger remembers her beloved mother disappearing for days at a time. By her 40s Kissinger has lost two siblings to suicide, and her alcoholic mother has survived several attempts. Silence was the vessel in which all of her family’s desperate ululations were contained.

headline: Holloway’s Mother Talks About Finding ‘Justice for Natalee’
abstract: “His hold over me is gone,” Beth Holloway said of Joran van der Sloot, the longtime suspect, who confessed to killing her daughter after she resisted his advances on a beach in Aruba in 2005.
lead_paragraph: It was May 31, 2005, at 4 a.m., when Beth Holloway first confronted Joran van der Sloot, a Dutch student who was one of three people who had been seen, just hours earlier, leaving a nightclub in Aruba with her daughter, Natalee Holloway.

headline: What to See, Eat and Buy in Porto, Portugal’s Creative Hub
abstract: Four insiders share their favorite spots, from old-school seafood restaurants to ceramics studios.
lead_paragraph: When the Danish architect Signe Bindslev Henriksen first visited Porto a decade ago, she was struck by its neglected grace. Touring late-19th-century houses, she noted the high ceilings, inlaid wood floors and carved moldings, all of which were beginning to buckle. “It felt like there had been a past that was so much more beautiful and vibrant,” Bindslev Henriksen says. That past is now the present: In short order, Portugal’s second-largest city has transformed from a quiet, industrious town into a lively creative hub. It is flush with concept shops and casual fine-dining restaurants. Young winemakers and sommeliers are bringing a fresh perspective to old vineyards. Expats are returning home to be part of the revival. Attribute some of it to the costs and crowds in other European destinations. But chefs and designers are also drawn to the innate charms of the city, whose roots go back thousands of years. The settlement on the Douro River near the Atlantic Ocean became an important port for the Romans, who dubbed it Portus Cale and are believed to have made wine along the riverbanks. The centuries brought other conquerors, including the Visigoths, the Spanish, the Moors and the French, and a wide range of architectural styles. The city’s historic center is a collection of medieval, Baroque, Gothic, and neo-Classical buildings, many with a through-line of local granite that continues into the present day.

headline: What Are Your Obligations When Your Dog Impregnates Another One?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on the unplanned consequences of pet ownership.
lead_paragraph: I have a good friend whose dog is unneutered for health reasons. At the dog park, his dog had intercourse with a dog that was unspayed. It all happened very quickly, and by the time he had his eyes on his dog the deed was done, and the dogs were locked together. A few weeks later, he learned from the owner of his dog’s sexual partner that the dog was pregnant. The owner insisted that it had been his unneutered dog. She then demanded that my friend share the financial burdens of the pregnancy and the care of the puppies until they were 8 weeks old.

headline: The Whimsical Yet Edgy Jewelry Brand That Celebrities Love
abstract: At Outhouse Jewelry, Kaabia and Sasha Grewal are reeling in big names with bird stud earrings, silver chokers and celestial motifs.
lead_paragraph: The Bollywood actress Alia Bhatt walked into this year’s Met Gala in a Prabal Gurung dress woven with swaths of pearls, sporting a single fingerless glovelette — reminiscent of Karl Lagerfeld’s personal style. Studded with pearls, the leather glovelette carried an OH V monogram with a stallion head, surrounded by an onyx dragonfly, imago butterflies and a Kaputt crystal. The monogram is a signature house aesthetic for Outhouse Jewelry, a brand created by two sisters: Kaabia and Sasha Grewal.

headline: Listen: Voices From the Israel-Hamas Conflict; Kamala Harris; Music to Move To
abstract: Each week, we share the best of new audio journalism and storytelling.
lead_paragraph: Audiophiles,

headline: Details of Biden’s $105 Billion Funding Request for Israel and Ukraine
abstract: The package also includes money for border security, humanitarian aid and Taiwan.
lead_paragraph: President Biden has argued that American aid for crises overseas, primarily in Ukraine and Israel, is vital to protecting U.S. national security. On Friday, he laid out the details of what he believes the United States needs to provide to its allies.

headline: Trump Fined $5,000 for Breaking Gag Order by Leaving Abusive Post Online
abstract: The former president used social media to attack a clerk for the judge in his civil fraud case, and left a copy of the post online for weeks.
lead_paragraph: The judge presiding over the civil fraud trial of Donald J. Trump fined the former president $5,000 on Friday for a “blatant violation” of a gag order imposed this month.

headline: Hamas Releases Two U.S. Hostages, a Mother and Daughter
abstract: Judith Raanan and her daughter, Natalie Raanan, were kidnapped from a kibbutz near the Gaza border during the Oct. 7 attacks.
lead_paragraph: Two Americans held captive in Gaza by Hamas, a woman and her teenage daughter, were released on Friday, nearly two weeks after they were taken hostage along with 200 others during terrorist raids in southern Israel that ignited a war, leaving thousands of people dead.

headline: Shoving Attack Renews Calls for M.T.A. to Make Subway Platforms Safer
abstract: The transit system had been enjoying a recovery from the height of the coronavirus pandemic. A random attack is now threatening its progress.
lead_paragraph: It appeared to be the season that the New York City subway would finally rebound from the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: The Best of Late Night This Week
abstract: The late night hosts had a glut of news to discuss this week, including House Republicans’ struggle to find a new speaker and Sidney Powell pleading guilty in the Georgia election interference case. Here’s what the hosts had to say.
lead_paragraph: The late night hosts had a glut of news to discuss this week, including House Republicans’ struggle to find a new speaker and Sidney Powell pleading guilty in the Georgia election interference case. Here’s what the hosts had to say.

headline: With a Chuckle and a Cool-Girl Smirk, Beth Stelling Moves Up a Comic Class
abstract: The stand-up, who has a new Netflix special, delights in inappropriate laughs — none more so than in her bits about aging and childhood.
lead_paragraph: The stand-up Beth Stelling reminds me so much of my best friend from high school.

headline: U.S. Deficit, Pegged at $1.7 Trillion, Effectively Doubled in 2023
abstract: The widening gap between what the government spends and what it earns comes as Congress continues to spar over the proper levels of federal spending.
lead_paragraph: America’s federal budget deficit effectively doubled in the 2023 fiscal year as slumping tax receipts, rising interest rates and persistent demand for expiring pandemic relief benefits strained the nation’s finances.

headline: Justices Reject, for Now, Missouri’s Effort to Override Federal Gun Laws
abstract: The move blocked an expansive state law, the Second Amendment Preservation Act, and let stand a ruling that it was an unconstitutional attempt to nullify federal laws.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court refused on Friday to reinstate an expansive Missouri law that restricted state and local law enforcement agencies from enforcing federal gun laws and allowed private lawsuits against law enforcement agencies that violated the state’s understanding of the Second Amendment.

headline: Alan Eisenberg, Forceful Head of Actors Union, Dies at 88
abstract: Over 25 years in that role, he helped build Equity Fights AIDS and challenged the racial casting of the top roles in the hit musical “Miss Saigon.”
lead_paragraph: Alan Eisenberg, a lawyer who as the top executive of Actors’ Equity Association for 25 years helped expand its membership, played a leading role in its response to the AIDS crisis and dealt with controversy involving the racial casting of the hit musical “Miss Saigon,” died on Oct. 7 in Rhinebeck, N.Y. He was 88.

headline: Halloween Is Tricky for Actors on Strike
abstract: The SAG-AFTRA union told its members not to dress as characters from major productions and post pictures, which could be seen as promoting the work of companies they are negotiating with.
lead_paragraph: Barbie, Ken and Wednesday Addams costumes are out. Ghosts and zombies are in.

headline: What to Know About the Link Between Red Meat and Type 2 Diabetes
abstract: New research suggests making small changes to your diet is associated with a lower risk of Type 2 diabetes.
lead_paragraph: People who regularly eat red meat may have a higher risk of Type 2 diabetes later in life, according to a large study published on Thursday in The American Journal of Clinical Nutrition. Those who often consume processed meats, like bacon, hot dogs and lunch meat, have an even greater risk.

headline: Junta Says Niger’s Ousted President Tried to Escape. His Lawyer Says, No Way.
abstract: Mohamed Bazoum, who was toppled in a coup, has been under house arrest with his family for nearly three months while leaders in Africa, the United States and Europe have pushed for his release.
lead_paragraph: The military junta in the West African country of Niger claimed that it had disrupted an attempt by the ousted president, Mohamed Bazoum, to escape on Thursday from the presidential residence, where he has been detained since he was overthrown in a coup nearly three months ago.

headline: Supreme Court Lifts Limits for Now on Biden Officials’ Contacts With Tech Platforms
abstract: The court also agreed to hear the administration’s appeal, paving the way for a major ruling on how far government can go to encourage sites to delete asserted misinformation.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court on Friday allowed Biden administration officials to continue to contact social media platforms to combat what the officials say is misinformation, pausing a sweeping ruling from a federal appeals court that had severely limited such interactions.

headline: Flashback: Your Weekly History Quiz, October 22, 2023
abstract: Can you sort 8 historical events?
lead_paragraph: Can you sort 8 historical events?

headline: Israel Prepares to Invade the Gaza Strip
abstract: The latest from the Israel-Hamas war. Weekday afternoons with Lulu Garcia-Navarro, and Times journalists on the ground.
lead_paragraph: In the nearly two weeks since Hamas attacked Israel, a ground invasion of the Gaza Strip by the Israeli military has seemed inevitable. As Israeli troops and tanks mass near Gaza, Patrick Kingsley, our Jerusalem bureau chief, speaks to Lulu Garcia-Navarro about the expected invasion.

headline: Eva Kollisch, Lesbian Rights Advocate and Memoirist, Dies at 98
abstract: A former refugee from Nazi-occupied Austria, she became an openly lesbian voice in the women’s movement and a key leader in feminist studies.
lead_paragraph: Eva Kollisch, who escaped Nazi-occupied Austria when she was a teenager to become an American professor and memoirist who broke new ground in feminist studies and championed equal rights for lesbians, died on Oct. 10 at her home in Manhattan. She was 98.

headline: Hamas Released Two American Hostages
abstract: Also, America’s deficit doubled. Here’s the latest at the end of Friday.
lead_paragraph: Hamas released an American mother and daughter who were kidnapped by the Palestinian group during its deadly Oct. 7 attack and held hostage for almost two weeks in Gaza. The Israeli military received them at the border and took them to an army base in central Israel to be reunited with family members.

headline: Since the War, Events About Palestinian Culture Have Been Called Off
abstract: Some fear that the raft of cancellations at this moment of war and tragedy is limiting opportunities to foster dialogue and greater understanding.
lead_paragraph: Nathan Thrall had planned to visit several cities this fall promoting his new book, “A Day in the Life of Abed Salama,” a reported look at Israel’s occupation of the West Bank. But after Hamas launched its deadly attacks on Israeli civilians, days after the book’s release this month, readings in London, New York, Los Angeles and Washington were postponed or canceled.

headline: Chesebro’s Plea Deal Could Undermine a Possible Trump Defense in Two Cases
abstract: The lawyer Kenneth Chesebro pleaded guilty in the Georgia election tampering case and is an unindicted co-conspirator in the federal election case.
lead_paragraph: Just before Christmas 2020, as President Donald J. Trump was running out of options to stave off losing the election, Kenneth Chesebro wrote an email to a group of other lawyers who were thinking of filing a last-ditch lawsuit to reverse Mr. Trump’s defeat.

headline: ‘Lessons in Chemistry’ and TV History
abstract: Brie Larson plays the fictional host of a 1950s cooking show in this period drama. But the story is inspired by the real TV homemakers who flourished back then.
lead_paragraph: In a scene in the Apple TV+ period drama “Lessons in Chemistry,” Elizabeth Zott (Brie Larson) prepares for her new job as host of a local cooking show with scientific rigor. Poised with pad in hand, Elizabeth, a chemist, concentrates keenly on her home television set, as if she were observing a chemical reaction.

headline: Roland Pattillo Dies at 89; Doctor Championed Henrietta Lacks
abstract: He wanted to put a face on the source of cells that led to striking medical advances, and through him a best seller and a movie did just that, telling Mrs. Lacks’s story.
lead_paragraph: Roland A. Pattillo, a gynecologic oncologist who had been treating and researching female cancers for decades, had long been haunted by the curious case of Henrietta Lacks, a young, impoverished Black woman who died of cervical cancer in 1951 yet whose cells lived on and made medical history.

headline: Trump Seeks Freeze of Gag Order in Election Case During Appeal
abstract: Judge Tanya S. Chutkan, who imposed the order, agreed to put it on hold for eight days as the parties filed additional papers.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for former President Donald J. Trump on Friday asked the judge overseeing his federal election interference case to temporarily put on hold the gag order she imposed on him in Washington this week, until an appeals court can decide whether it was warranted.

headline: Ex-Florida Lawmaker Gets 4 Months in Prison for Covid-19 Relief Fraud
abstract: Joe Harding, 36, last year sponsored the legislation that critics called “Don’t Say Gay.” He pleaded guilty to federal charges in March.
lead_paragraph: A former Florida state lawmaker who sponsored a law that critics nicknamed “Don’t Say Gay” was sentenced on Thursday to four months in federal prison, federal prosecutors announced.

headline: Promised Aid to Gaza Is Stalled by Wrangling, as Conditions Worsen
abstract: Israel, Egypt, the United Nations and others are still working out the details of delivering food, water and medicine, as Israel prepares a possible ground invasion.
lead_paragraph: Two days after President Biden said he had secured Israel’s agreement to allow food, water and medicine into the besieged Gaza Strip, and a day after aid groups were told their trucks would cross the border on Friday, nothing budged, as the powers involved continued to haggle over the details, while conditions within Gaza grew more dire.

headline: Trump Co-Defendant Says He Wants to Keep Lawyer Despite Possible Conflicts
abstract: A hearing brought to an apparent end the back and forth over whether a co-defendant in the classified documents case, Walt Nauta, understood that his lawyer might have conflicts.
lead_paragraph: A personal aide to former President Donald J. Trump and co-defendant in the classified documents case told a federal judge on Friday that he wanted to keep his lawyer despite a potential conflict of interest that could be problematic for his defense.

headline: DeSantis-Haley Rivalry Heats Up, With Attacks Focused on Israel
abstract: As they vie to be the race’s Trump alternative, the two Republican rivals have been trading barbs, zeroing in on each other’s response to the Israel-Hamas conflict.
lead_paragraph: Once distant rivals in the 2024 presidential race, Ron DeSantis and Nikki Haley are now locked in a heated battle to become the most viable Republican alternative to former President Donald J. Trump, seizing on the Israel-Hamas conflict to hurl broadsides at each other.

headline: Biden and Aides Advise Israel to Avoid Widening War With Hezbollah Strike
abstract: U.S. officials learned that the Israeli defense minister and other military officials supported a pre-emptive strike on Hezbollah. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has been cautious.
lead_paragraph: President Biden and his top aides have been urging Israeli leaders against carrying out any major strike against Hezbollah, the powerful militia in Lebanon, that could draw it into the Israel-Hamas war, American and Israeli officials say.

headline: Chaos and Frustration Rule as Republicans’ Bitter Speaker Fight Deepens
abstract: With the House G.O.P. back to square one on electing a new speaker, tempers flared and uncertainty over how the impasse might be resolved only grew.
lead_paragraph: Leaving the House floor shortly after delivering the opening prayer on Friday morning, the House chaplain, Margaret G. Kibben, turned to the sergeant-at-arms flanking the entrance and whispered, “Godspeed.”

headline: Some Contractions
abstract: Kelly Morenus makes a well-crafted Saturday puzzle debut.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — There are so many neat details in this puzzle, Kelly Morenus’s first construction for The New York Times. The long entry triplets at the top and bottom are imposing but not obscure, almost without exception; the middle of the grid has interesting tidbits everywhere. I think it’s a legitimate Saturday crossword, but one that solves in a smooth, pleasant way, with plenty of clues that kept me on my toes, searching for a second or third option, but no really intractable stumpers.

headline: 10 Charged in $20 Million Scheme to Sell Black-Market H.I.V. Drugs
abstract: Federal prosecutors said the defendants encouraged low-income patients to sell their medication to them, then resold the drugs and used the money to buy luxury goods.
lead_paragraph: Federal prosecutors have accused 10 people of orchestrating a $20 million scheme to “get rich” by buying and selling black-market H.I.V. medications that in some cases had been purchased from low-income patients who risked their lives by selling it.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Emerging Radiant Through the Chaos
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, October 21, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “I was never quite sure what all these critics thought I was supposed to be doing — a Bob Dylan impression?”

headline: Corrections: Oct. 21, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Oct. 21, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Page 4 this weekend about a Broadway play starring Danny DeVito and his daughter, Lucy DeVito, misstates the title of the audio play that Danny and Lucy DeVito collaborated on. It is “I Think It’s Worth Pointing Out That I’ve Been Very Serious Throughout This Entire Discussion or, Dave and Julia Are Stuck in a Tree,” not “I Think It’s Working Pointing Out…”

headline: DeSantis Says He Would Cancel Student Visas of Hamas Sympathizers
abstract: At a G.O.P. candidate showcase in Iowa, Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida and his rivals repeatedly sought to one-up one another on support for Israel.
lead_paragraph: In a competition of hawkish messages on Israel, Ron DeSantis pledged on Friday night to revoke the student visas of Hamas sympathizers if elected president, while Tim Scott said he would withhold Pell grants from universities that failed to stamp out antisemitism.

headline: Little Punishment or Change After South Korea’s Halloween Calamity
abstract: Families of the 159 people crushed to death last year say the government has never acknowledged its mistakes or accepted responsibility.
lead_paragraph: From the beginning, with the grief still raw and anguished questions unanswered, the South Korean government distanced itself from the disaster that unfolded last year on a Halloween weekend in Seoul.

headline: Returning to Pakistan, Nawaz Sharif Aims for a Splashy Comeback
abstract: After nearly four years in exile, Mr. Sharif, a three-time prime minister, held a big gathering before an upcoming election.
lead_paragraph: Nawaz Sharif, a three-time prime minister, made a noisy return to Pakistan on Saturday after years of self-imposed exile, seizing an opening in the country’s turbulent politics and economic disarray to attempt another dramatic comeback.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: The Connections Companion
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections Companion, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Got a Mouse in Your Apartment? These Scientists Will Take It.
abstract: A research study is examining how mice that live in cities, close to humans, may have evolved differently from their country cousins.
