headline: California Boosts Minimum Wage for Health Care and Fast-Food Workers
abstract: Sector-specific pay bumps are a new twist in a state that already has one of the highest hourly minimum wages in the nation.
lead_paragraph: For thousands of Californians, wages are going up.

headline: Do You Recognize These Passages From Classic Books?
abstract: This short quiz challenges you to identify memorable lines from five novels.
lead_paragraph: This short quiz challenges you to identify memorable lines from five novels.

headline: Iranian Teenager Reported Brain Dead by State Media
abstract: What happened to Armita Geravand, who entered a subway car and was carried out minutes later, is unclear. But her case evoked parallels to that of Mahsa Amini.
lead_paragraph: Armita Geravand, the Iranian girl who was dragged out of a subway car unconscious shortly after entering with her hair uncovered, has been pronounced brain dead, Iran’s state-owned media reported on Sunday.

headline: War Has Smashed Assumptions About Israeli-Palestinian Conflict
abstract: Some paradigms taken for granted about Israel and the Palestinians, both in Gaza and the West Bank, have been broken. So has the idea that Washington can ignore the Middle East.
lead_paragraph: The sudden and unexpected terror attack by Hamas into Israel has been a crushing blow to a host of assumptions that have defined the Israeli-Palestinian conflict for years.

headline: Tracking the Remnants of Otis
abstract: See the likely path and wind arrival times for Otis.
lead_paragraph: See the likely path and wind arrival times for Otis.

headline: As Abortion Access Shrinks, Hospitals Fill in the Gaps
abstract: Hospitals are playing a growing role in abortion access, as pregnant women with certain health issues travel to seek care that clinics can’t provide.
lead_paragraph: Hospitals are playing a growing role in abortion access, as pregnant women with certain health issues travel to seek care that clinics can’t provide.

headline: Nonunion Workers Are Playing a Big Role in the Autoworkers’ Strike
abstract: The three U.S. automakers say they are already at a disadvantage to nonunion rivals while labor leaders hope that big gains in negotiations will inspire workers in Southern states to unionize.
lead_paragraph: Tens of thousands of people who work for Toyota in Kentucky, Mercedes-Benz in Alabama or Tesla in Texas are technically not involved in the high-stakes negotiations taking place between labor and management in and around Detroit.

headline: Women in Iceland Go on Strike Against Gender Inequality
abstract: Organizers urged women and nonbinary people to stop all work on Tuesday. Even the prime minister said she would take part.
lead_paragraph: Tens of thousands of women and nonbinary people in Iceland were expected to join a one-day strike on Tuesday, which organizers called the country’s largest effort to protest workplace inequality in nearly five decades.

headline: Aleksei Navalny Forcibly Removed From Jail Cell After Protest
abstract: The Russian opposition leader had refused to leave his cell in protest after prison authorities took his writing tools, allies say.
lead_paragraph: The Russian opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny was forcibly removed from his cell by law enforcement officers on Monday after he had refused to leave it to protest a decision by prison authorities to take away his writing tools, his political allies said.

headline: U.A.W. Expands Strike to a Ram Plant in Michigan
abstract: The United Automobile Workers union called on 6,800 workers to walk off the job at a large factory that makes one of Stellantis’s most profitable vehicles.
lead_paragraph: In a major escalation of its six-week strike at the three large U.S. automakers, the United Automobile Workers union on Monday told 6,800 workers at a large Ram pickup truck plant in Michigan to walk off the job.

headline: Our Beloved Lemony Shrimp and Bean Stew
abstract: “Made this exactly according to the recipe and it may be the best thing I ever cooked in my life — I’m 71.”
lead_paragraph: One of my favorite literary pastimes is reading your notes in our New York Times Cooking recipes. They’re savvy and full of smart tips and substitutions. They’re often hilarious (“How r y’all having problems with this I am eleven and I can do it easy peasy”) and sometimes poignant (“I hate this dish. I made it for my ex-boyfriend and he left me again. He said it was too salty and he didn’t like my parents.”) For proof that I’m not the only notes stan, here’s an Instagram account dedicated to the pursuit.

headline: The Doyenne of Classical Publicists Takes on a Final Client: Herself
abstract: Mary Lou Falcone is stepping out of the background to raise awareness of Lewy body dementia, the neurodegenerative disease that claimed her husband.
lead_paragraph: Mary Lou Falcone has lived most of her life away from the spotlight. “I made a conscious decision that I wanted to be behind the scenes,” she said over a recent lunch at Café Luxembourg, a few blocks from Lincoln Center on the Upper West Side of Manhattan.

headline: Rapid Antarctic Melting Looks Certain, Even if Emissions Goals Are Met
abstract: It may be too late to halt the decline of the West Antarctic ice shelves, a study found, but climate action could still forestall the gravest sea level rise.
lead_paragraph: At the bottom of the world, the floating edges of one of the enormous ice sheets covering Antarctica are facing an invisible threat, one that could add to rising sea levels around the globe. They are melting from below.

headline: The Stratospheric Rise of Lionel Messi’s Pink Jersey
abstract: In the span of three months, the soccer superstar has made Inter Miami’s eye-catching jersey the hottest piece of sports merchandise on the planet.
lead_paragraph: All of a sudden, after a single summer, the pink jersey is everywhere. It has become almost impossible to acquire, yet there it is, paradoxically, on the backs of thousands of fans thronging American stadiums, hanging from market stalls in Buenos Aires and Bangkok, a vivid flash on almost every field where children gather to play soccer in England.

headline: Lying All the Way to the Bank in ‘America Fantastica’
abstract: Tim O’Brien’s manic satire follows a disgraced journalist on a criminal road trip through a myth-addled nation.
lead_paragraph: When scientists take a core sample of fiction from the post-Trump era, they will discover American novelists struggling to unpack the political and social repercussions of his reign. Just as historians work to document the facts of the last 10 years, so, too, do novelists try to reveal their meaning. Tim O’Brien’s diagnosis of what ails America in 2023 is “mythomania,” which he defines as an epidemic of lying that swept our nation during the Trump presidency, infecting man and, he writes, bird alike.

headline: Were the Fake Trump Signs a Prank? Or a Political Dirty Trick?
abstract: The placards were up in a wealthy town for less than a day. The fight over them lasted years.
lead_paragraph: The sudden sprouting of red-and-white campaign signs upended one autumn morning in the affluent Connecticut town of Greenwich. It was as if the valuable ground had been sprinkled overnight with political pixie dust.

headline: Flight of the Drones Lights Up Central Park
abstract: The Drift collaborative orchestrated a performance art piece with light-emitting drones that mimic swarming starlings or fish — but mostly slow-motion fireworks.
lead_paragraph: It began with a sudden, breathtaking emergence over the trees to the south — a thousand points of blue light that expanded and dispersed into the sky. They organized into a kind of butterfly formation and set off in a northerly direction — and then the flotilla vanished, as if at the flip of a switch. Several beats later, it reappeared, to loud oohs and aahs from the crowd, as a stunning grid of white, pink and ruby luminosity.

headline: Turkey’s President Sends Sweden’s NATO Bid to Parliament for Ratification
abstract: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan had been holding out on approval of Sweden’s application. It’s unclear why he is now moving it forward.
lead_paragraph: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey on Monday signed and sent to Parliament a measure approving Sweden’s bid to join the NATO military alliance, according to a brief statement from his office.

headline: Review: The Great Emerson String Quartet Takes Its Final Bow
abstract: A pillar of chamber music for nearly a half-century, the Emerson players bid farewell with Beethoven’s Opus 130 and Schubert’s String Quintet.
lead_paragraph: Farewell to the Emerson String Quartet, a group that has beaten at the heart of chamber music in the United States, and far beyond, for almost half a century.

headline: Thelma Golden Wins Gish Prize
abstract: The annual prize is given to someone who has “pushed the boundaries of an art form.” Golden, the director and chief curator of the Studio Museum in Harlem, said it was a “total surprise.”
lead_paragraph: Thelma Golden, the director and chief curator of the Studio Museum in Harlem, was awarded the Dorothy and Lillian Gish Prize, the Gish Prize Trust announced on Monday.

headline: Review: Years Late, a Young Pianist Finally Gets to Carnegie
abstract: Alexandre Kantorow made his Carnegie Hall recital debut after winning both the International Tchaikovsky Competition and the Gilmore Artist Award.
lead_paragraph: The French pianist Alexandre Kantorow was supposed to make his Carnegie Hall recital debut on March 25, 2020, as a late replacement for the ailing Murray Perahia. We know what happened with that.

headline: Face Search Engine PimEyes Blocks Searches of Children’s Faces
abstract: The change came in response to worries that the service could be used nefariously by a stranger.
lead_paragraph: Concerns about children’s privacy have led PimEyes, the public face search engine, to ban searches of minors. The PimEyes chief executive, Giorgi Gobronidze, who is based in Tbilisi, Georgia, said that technical measures had been put in place to block such searches as part of a “no harm policy.”

headline: How the Israel-Hamas War Imperils Action Against Global Warming
abstract: Oil prices could surge. Disagreements between nations could worsen. The conflict complicates already fragile global diplomacy ahead of crucial climate talks.
lead_paragraph: Global efforts to address climate change are already clouded by bitterness and distrust among countries of the world.

headline: Off-Duty Pilot Accused of Trying to Cut the Engines on an Alaska Airlines Flight
abstract: The flight was diverted to Portland, Ore., because of a “credible security threat” inside the cockpit, the airline said. An off-duty pilot was charged with attempted murder.
lead_paragraph: An off-duty pilot who was in a jump seat in the cockpit of an Alaska Airlines flight on Sunday was charged with more than 80 counts of attempted murder after he tried to cut fuel to the engines, prompting the plane to divert to Portland, Ore., the authorities said.

headline: Chicago’s Newest Must-Have Fashion Accessory
abstract: Before Connor Bedard had taken the ice for the Blackhawks, the 18-year-old hockey phenom’s No. 98 jersey had already taken over the Windy City, and beyond.
lead_paragraph: Before Connor Bedard had laced up his skates for a regular season game, the 18-year-old hockey phenom had already caused a surge in the Chicago Blackhawks’ season ticket sales. He had fans talking about a return to glory for a team that had fallen on hard times. And he was drawing audacious comparisons to some of the sport’s greatest stars.

headline: Read the document
abstract: In this 2017 internal Google document, an executive compares the search ads business to that of selling cigarettes or drugs. The executive testified at the trial that he produced the document during a communications training where he was practicing how to use hyperbole to get someone’s attention.
lead_paragraph: In this 2017 internal Google document, an executive compares the search ads business to that of selling cigarettes or drugs. The executive testified at the trial that he produced the document during a communications training where he was practicing how to use hyperbole to get someone’s attention.

headline: Federal Investigators Widen Tesla Inquiry, Company Says
abstract: The Department of Justice has sought documents related to vehicle range and “personal benefits,” Tesla said.
lead_paragraph: The Department of Justice has expanded its inquiry into Tesla’s business practices to include how far its vehicles can travel on a full charge and “personal benefits” to high-ranking executives or large shareholders, the company said without elaborating.

headline: War With Hamas Hits Israel’s Economy, Central Bank Says
abstract: The debt and deficit are expected to jump as the country raises military spending and increases support for businesses and civilians.
lead_paragraph: The war between Israel and Hamas will abruptly slow the Israeli economy this year and next and send the nation’s budget deficit soaring as the country ramps up spending to support the military, civilians and businesses during the conflict, the Bank of Israel said on Monday.

headline: Love Letter: When Google Search Reveals Too Much
abstract: “One glimpse at my boyfriend’s recent searches caused our already precarious relationship to topple.”
lead_paragraph: In the most recent Modern Love essay, “When Your Search History Says What You Can’t,” Kassia Oset shares a cautionary tale of the heart and the browser.

headline: In ‘Seafood Simple,’ Eric Ripert Includes Techniques and Not-So-Simple Recipes
abstract: Cream puff decorating classes for the holidays, a Phony Mezcal Negroni from St. Agrestis and more food news.
lead_paragraph: Eric Ripert’s previous cookbook, “Vegetable Simple,” lived up to its title with some recipes needing but two or three ingredients. His new book, “Seafood Simple”? Not so simple. Effortless wonders include salmon and tomato à la Gilbert (for Gilbert Le Coze, a founder of Le Bernardin, whom Mr. Ripert succeeded as an owner and the executive chef), a crispy black bass Basquaise, a pristine scallop ceviche, and a quick toss of shrimp, sweet garlic and extra-virgin olive oil. There are more demanding dishes worth tackling: monkfish Bourride with aioli and skate with sambal. Halibut with warm herb vinaigrette, which is based on an original Le Bernardin preparation, requires not just a vinaigrette, but a velouté, the secret to the dish’s success  — and something I wish I’d known when I tried to replicate it at home years ago. The recipe chapters are divided according to techniques, nine of them. The book begins with step-by-step photos of preparing seafood, including filleting, shucking, skinning and so forth. Shopping and storage tips are included.

headline: Taylor Swift’s ‘Cruel Summer’ Hits No. 1 After Four Years
abstract: The song from Swift’s 2019 album, “Lover,” is a fan favorite that took on new life during her record-breaking Eras Tour. On the album chart, Bad Bunny debuts at the top.
lead_paragraph: Four years ago, Taylor Swift included the song “Cruel Summer” on her album “Lover.” It became a fan favorite, and had been in line to be released as a single in 2020, before the Covid-19 pandemic changed all plans. “That is something that happened that stopped ‘Cruel Summer’ from ever being a single,” the singer said a few months ago.

headline: Leftist Upstart Threatens to Shake Up German Politics
abstract: Sahra Wagenknecht has announced a new party, which could become another populist force scrambling German politics.
lead_paragraph: Germany’s political landscape has been fracturing for a decade or more as traditional parties lose ground to populist elements, forcing the establishment of a three-way coalition government for the first time in the country’s modern history.

headline: Gavin Newsom Wants to Export California’s Climate Laws to the World
abstract: The Democratic governor is supercharging climate policy and eyeing a future White House run. But critics say some of his constituents could be left behind.
lead_paragraph: Gavin Newsom, the California governor, packed his bags and his ambition Monday and flew to Chinese provinces on a weeklong mission to negotiate climate agreements.

headline: Israel’s Moral and Political Dilemmas
abstract: Responses to columns by Thomas L. Friedman, Nicholas Kristof and Bret Stephens. Also: A Palestinian author; regulating airlines; presidential ballots.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Review: These Art-Historical Nudes Become Bodies in Time
abstract: Spare and simple, “Aging Prelude” at the Chocolate Factory is a new beginning for the choreographic duo Chameckilerner.
lead_paragraph: Nine naked people pose on a grassy lawn, like statues in a sculpture garden: standing, sitting, squatting, reclining in stillness. The light is warm, and bright but melancholy music plays. This is the scene that greets you as you enter “Aging Prelude,” a brief and delicately composed new work by the choreographic duo Chameckilerner (Rosane Chamecki and Andrea Lerner), which had its premiere at the Chocolate Factory Theater on Friday.

headline: Who Is Jackson Mahomes, and Why Are Swifties Concerned?
abstract: Taylor Swift spent Sunday’s game in Kansas City, Mo., in a suite with Mr. Mahomes, an influencer known for problematic behavior and a sexual battery arrest.
lead_paragraph: As Taylor Swift and Brittany Mahomes, the wife of Patrick Mahomes, quarterback of the Kansas City Chiefs, slapped hands and bumped hips in a touchdown celebration that took over social media on Sunday night, a man in a white T-shirt and a backward baseball cap clapped behind them. The handshake, which was shown during the broadcast of a game between the Kansas City Chiefs and the Los Angeles Chargers, finished with both women turning around and celebrating with the man, who bent down to their level with a broad smile.

headline: 5 Takeaways From Argentina’s Election
abstract: Javier Milei, a libertarian economist often compared to Donald Trump, will face off against Sergio Massa, Argentina’s economy minister, in a runoff next month.
lead_paragraph: After two votes, Argentina’s presidential race now heads into its decisive round with the final two political survivors vying to lead a country where people are desperate for a financial turnaround.

headline: Biden Administration Moves to Ban a Solvent Linked to Cancer
abstract: The chemical, trichloroethylene, is used in some adhesives and cleaning products.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration has proposed to ban all uses of trichloroethylene, an industrial solvent used in glues, other adhesives, spot removers and metal cleaners, saying exposure to even small amounts can cause cancer, damage to the central nervous system and other health effects.

headline: The Rock’s Wax Figure Will Get Redo, Museum Says
abstract: The Grévin Museum in Paris said it is “improving” a likeness of Dwayne Johnson that one online critic called “melanin deficient.”
lead_paragraph: A wax museum in Paris said it would change its recently unveiled statue of Dwayne Johnson, better known as the Rock, after a week of ridicule on social media and a plea from the actor himself.

headline: ‘I Have Your Back’: Doug Emhoff Draws on His Faith After Hamas Attack
abstract: Mr. Emhoff, the husband of Kamala Harris, is the first Jewish spouse of a president or vice president. He has focused on providing comfort to people in pain after the Hamas attack.
lead_paragraph: Doug Emhoff has spent the weeks after the Hamas attack on Israel acting as a touchstone for some of the anguish, fear and anger felt by Jewish Americans.

headline: Plea Hearing Set for 2024 in Indonesian Bombings Case
abstract: Two Malaysian prisoners at Guantánamo Bay were charged in terrorist attacks in Bali and Jakarta that killed more than 200 people two decades ago.
lead_paragraph: A military judge at Guantánamo Bay on Monday scheduled a Jan. 15 plea hearing for two Malaysian prisoners who are accused of committing war crimes as accessories to deadly terrorist attacks in Indonesia two decades ago.

headline: Israel Shares Raw Footage of the Oct. 7 Attacks
abstract: The Israeli military showed the compilation to foreign reporters on a day when Israel continued to bombard Gaza with heavy airstrikes.
lead_paragraph: Bloodied corpses lying in a bedroom, a bathroom, on the roads by their cars. An emergency medical worker pouring mineral water from a bottle to douse the smoldering remains of charred bodies. A dead baby whose body bore signs of violence.

headline: 92NY Halts Literary Series After Pulling Author Critical of Israel
abstract: The organization put the series on pause after several writers withdrew from events to protest its decision not to hold a reading last week with an author who had criticized Israel.
lead_paragraph: 92NY, one of the city’s leading cultural organizations, announced Monday that it was putting its prestigious literary reading series on pause, following an outcry over its decision to cancel an appearance last week by a prominent writer who had been critical of Israel.

headline: Train Collision in Bangladesh Leaves at Least 17 Dead
abstract: The accident, between a passenger train and a freight train, also injured over 100 people.
lead_paragraph: At least 17 people were killed when a passenger train and a freight train collided outside Bangladesh’s capital, Dhaka, during a busy holiday season.

headline: Trance Music Is Coming Back. Evian Christ Is Part of the Revival.
abstract: The producer got his start in the 2010s connecting underground electronic sounds and hip-hop. His first album, “Revanchist,” embraces a long-derided genre of dance music.
lead_paragraph: It was the seventh soggy weekend in a row in New York, but a throng of 20-something club kids with chunky boots and shaggy mullets still made the pilgrimage to a punk venue in an industrial stretch of Brooklyn where the British producer Evian Christ was performing a four-hour D.J. set to celebrate the release of his debut album, “Revanchist.”

headline: Natalie Zemon Davis, Historian of the Marginalized, Dies at 94
abstract: She wrote of peasants, unsung women, border crossers and, most popularly, Martin Guerre, a 16th-century village impostor recalled in a 1980s movie.
lead_paragraph: Natalie Zemon Davis, a social and cultural historian whose imaginative and deeply researched investigations of the lives of marginalized figures — peasants, long-forgotten women, border crossers of all sorts — profoundly influenced the discipline, died on Saturday at her home in Toronto. She was 94.

headline: ‘5 Families’ and Factions Within Factions: Why the House G.O.P. Can’t Unite
abstract: The Republican free-for-all for speaker reflects a web of overlapping blocs that have made the party nearly ungovernable.
lead_paragraph: Follow our live updates for the House speaker nominee vote.

headline: ‘Persons of Interest’ Identified in Killing of Detroit Synagogue Leader, Police Say
abstract: The city’s police chief emphasized that the attack did not appear to be related to antisemitism. No arrests have been made.
lead_paragraph: The authorities in Detroit said on Monday that they had identified “some persons of interest” in the killing of Samantha Woll, 40, the president of a downtown synagogue who was found stabbed to death outside her home early Saturday.

headline: Tuesday Briefing: Israel Intensifies Gaza Strikes
abstract: Plus the worldwide popularity of Lionel Messi’s pink jersey.
lead_paragraph: The death toll in Gaza rose sharply yesterday, according to the Hamas-run health ministry, after Israel said it had struck hundreds of targets in the territory in one of the biggest barrages of airstrikes in recent days.

headline: A Push for Tech Hubs in Overlooked Places Picks 31 to Vie for Money
abstract: A new federal program will be a test of whether spreading funds outside of big cities will result in economic gains, or in inefficiencies.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration said on Monday that it had chosen 31 regions as potential recipients of federal money that would seek to fund innovation in parts of the country that government investment overlooked in the past.

headline: Mary Lou Retton Is Released From Hospital, Daughter Says
abstract: The former gymnast’s family said this month that Retton had been hospitalized with pneumonia and that she was “fighting for her life.”
lead_paragraph: Mary Lou Retton, the decorated Olympic gymnast, has been released from a hospital, one of her daughters said on Monday, about two weeks after her family reported that the gold medalist had a rare form of pneumonia and was in an intensive care unit “fighting for her life.”

headline: Menendez Pleads Not Guilty to Plotting to Be an Agent of Egypt
abstract: Senator Robert Menendez, a Democrat, was arraigned on Monday in Manhattan federal court. It was his second appearance there in a month.
lead_paragraph: Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey pleaded not guilty on Monday to a new federal charge that accused him of illegally plotting to be an agent of Egypt while serving as chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

headline: No Longer Scotland’s Leader, Sturgeon Focuses on Learning to Drive
abstract: The former first minister, who resigned and quit as leader of the Scottish National Party before her arrest in June, said seeking a driver’s license at 53 had taken her out of her comfort zone.
lead_paragraph: Scotland’s former first minister, Nicola Sturgeon, who unexpectedly resigned this year and later became the subject of a police investigation, made another unusual announcement on Monday.

headline: Israel Intensifies Airstrikes on Gaza
abstract: The increased strikes across Gaza came amid international efforts to move humanitarian aid into the besieged territory.
lead_paragraph: The increased strikes across Gaza came amid international efforts to move humanitarian aid into the besieged territory.

headline: Hamas Released Two More Hostages
abstract: Also, Stephen Sondheim’s last musical opens in New York. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
lead_paragraph: Hamas released two women who were taken hostage by the Palestinian group during its Oct. 7 attack on Israel. The Red Cross confirmed their release, saying that it had helped to transfer the women out of Gaza this evening.

headline: Park Seo-Bo, Whose Quiet Paintings Trumpeted Korean Art, Dies at 91
abstract: With monochromatic works and the instincts of an avid self-promoter, he helped introduce his country’s art to the world, but not without personal struggle.
lead_paragraph: Park Seo-Bo, a painter whose elegantly furrowed monochromes and indefatigable drive made him a pillar of the Korean art world, died on Oct. 14 in Seoul. He was 91.

headline: Death Toll in New Orleans ‘Super Fog’ Pileups Rises to Eight
abstract: The combination of marsh fire smoke and moisture in the air created what a meteorologist called a “perfect storm.” Low visibility contributed to the traffic accidents.
lead_paragraph: A dense “super fog” hovered over New Orleans on Monday, shrouding the area in an impenetrable mist that led to traffic pileups involving dozens of vehicles and leaving at least eight people dead, the authorities said.

headline: Behind the Editors’ Note on Gaza Hospital Coverage
abstract: Joe Kahn, the executive editor of The New York Times, speaks to Lulu Garcia-Navarro about The Times’s early coverage of an explosion at a hospital in Gaza City, and where the paper fell short.

headline: Writers Guild Faces Backlash for Not Condemning Hamas Attack
abstract: A union leader told members that the board’s viewpoints were varied and that a consensus could not be reached.
lead_paragraph: Just weeks after the Writers Guild of America displayed solidarity by ending a monthslong strike and voting overwhelmingly in favor of a new contract with the major entertainment companies, the union is being roiled by a fight over its lack of a public statement condemning the Hamas attack on Israel.

headline: The Secret of America’s Economic Success
abstract: We’ve done amazingly well, even if people won’t believe it.
lead_paragraph: When Covid-19 struck, the initial economic impact was devastating. Large parts of major economies shut down, both because of official lockdowns and because people feared that in-person interaction would expose them to infection. In the United States, 20 million jobs suddenly disappeared.

headline: With Their Soldiers Poised to Attack, Israelis Try to Decipher the Delay
abstract: So pervasive is the pall of chaos in Israel’s government that top officials saw fit to assure a traumatized public that they are “working in close and full cooperation, around the clock.”
lead_paragraph: For 17 days, Israeli ground troops and tanks have been on standby, idling in the dusty fields around Gaza. Their stated mission: to invade the Palestinian coastal enclave and destroy the military capabilities of Hamas, the armed Islamist group, and its ability to rule there.

headline: With War in Israel, the Cancel Culture Debate Comes Full Circle
abstract: We’re in an especially repressive period for free speech.
lead_paragraph: Nathan Thrall’s searing new book, “A Day in the Life of Abed Salama,” struck me as important even before the obscene massacres and mass kidnappings committed by Hamas this month lit the Middle East on fire. Today, with people still struggling to understand the contours of this deeply complicated conflict, the book seems essential.

headline: U.S. Raises Concerns About Israel’s Plan of Action in Gaza, Officials Say
abstract: The Pentagon has sent officers to help the Israelis with the challenges of fighting an urban war.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration is concerned that Israel lacks achievable military objectives in Gaza, and that the Israel Defense Forces are not yet ready to launch a ground invasion with a plan that can work, senior administration officials said.

headline: Israel Intensifies Strikes on Gaza as Its Allies Call for More Palestinian Aid
abstract: As two more hostages are released, American officials have urged Israel to delay a ground invasion, to allow time for negotiations and for more humanitarian aid to enter Gaza.
lead_paragraph: Israel’s military struck hundreds of targets in Gaza on Monday, in one of the biggest barrages yet of its war with Hamas and as a trickle of aid arrived for desperate Palestinians in the strip, where the lack of clean water, medicine and other critical supplies is fueling a dire humanitarian crisis.

headline: All In on Iowa and a Speech on Race: Tim Scott Looks to Revive Struggling Campaign
abstract: Senator Tim Scott of South Carolina gave his speech as his struggling presidential campaign said it would move most of its staff to Iowa.
lead_paragraph: Senator Tim Scott, struggling to gain traction less than three months before the first Republican primary ballots are cast, came to the South Side of Chicago on Monday to rebuke the welfare state and the liberal politicians he dismissed as “drug dealers of despair.”

headline: How to Win the Restaurant Reservation Game
abstract: Scoring a table in New York can seem impossible, but may be easier than you think. Here’s how the competition played out for one dinner, with tips from the winning players.
lead_paragraph: Scoring a table in New York can seem impossible, but may be easier than you think. Here’s how the competition played out for one dinner, with tips from the winning players.

headline: Light Spray
abstract: Daniel Grinberg is driven by a single-minded love of Halloween.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: 13 Law Enforcement Officers Killed in Ambush in Mexico
abstract: The attack was in the Mexican state of Guerrero, which has been plagued by turf wars between drug cartels.
lead_paragraph: An armed group ambushed and killed more than a dozen law enforcement officers in southwestern Mexico on Monday, including a local security secretary and a police chief, adding to a soaring number of deadly attacks against the police in the region.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Borrowers Start to Process High Rates Won’t Fall Soon
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, October 23, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “If you go around and talk to developers about ‘Hey, what’s your next project?’ it’s crickets.”

headline: Quotation of the Day: Assumptions on Israel and the Palestinians Are Smashed by War
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, October 24, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “I’m sorry, America, but the Middle East is not done with you. Geopolitical facts cannot be ignored.”

headline: Corrections: Oct. 24, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, Oct. 24, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Thursday about the impact of voting rights legislation on the governor’s race in Mississippi misstated the status of a law that had stripped voting rights from people convicted of a range of felonies in Mississippi. While a court had overturned the law in August, that decision was vacated and an appeal is currently pending; it is not the case that the law has fallen.

headline: Energy Agency Sees Peaks in Global Oil, Coal and Gas Demand by 2030
abstract: The prediction, which has stirred controversy among oil producers, is a sign of a sweeping transformation in the global energy landscape.
lead_paragraph: For more than a century, the world’s appetite for fossil fuels has been expanding relentlessly, as humans have continued burning larger amounts of coal, oil and natural gas almost every year to power homes, cars and factories.

headline: Jamaica Fears Brain Drain as Teachers Leave for U.S. Schools
abstract: Severe teacher shortages in the United States are prompting schools to recruit foreign teachers, sparking fears that education in Jamaica will suffer.
lead_paragraph: Okeef Saunders loves his job teaching history to high school students in Jamaica’s capital. But he is getting ready to leave for the United States, where a teaching job with a much bigger paycheck in North Carolina awaits him.

headline: What It’s Like to Be Young in Ukraine Now
abstract: Each age group has suffered through the war, but for young adults it has been particularly hard — and not just for those who have served on the frontline.
lead_paragraph: The years of young adulthood are often associated with opening horizons. Making friends. Having adventures. The first independent steps into work, or study, or love. For many young Ukrainians, though, war with Russia has upended that reality, replacing it with danger and death, depression and dislocation.

headline: Tuesday Briefing
abstract: Israel ramps up Gaza strikes.
lead_paragraph: The death toll in Gaza, reported by the Hamas-run health ministry, rose sharply yesterday, after Israel said it had struck hundreds of targets in the territory in one of the biggest barrages of airstrikes in recent days.

headline: Word of the Day: quirky
abstract: This word has appeared in 319 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word quirky has appeared in 319 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Sept. 12 in “A Bathtub in the Kitchen? Not a Problem for New Yorkers” by Jess Eng:

headline: ‘Honest Mistake,’ Says U.S. Politician Arrested on Gun Charge in Hong Kong
abstract: A Washington state senator, Jeff Wilson, said he discovered the pistol on his flight and notified customs officials at the Hong Kong airport.
lead_paragraph: A Washington state senator was arrested at a Hong Kong airport and spent days in custody on charges of possessing a locally unregistered firearm, his office said on Monday.

headline: Late Night Finds the House Speaker Pool Lacking in Diversity
abstract: Stephen Colbert named actual candidates for the job before switching to made-up politicians — “and literally no one knows when I did, including me.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: See You Later, Not-An-Alligator
abstract: Caimans are an invasive species in Florida, where they ran wild over half a century ago. Researchers known as the Croc Docs may be close to helping eradicate them.
lead_paragraph: Sidney Godfrey was sitting in the passenger seat of a truck slowly cruising over a levee one night in 2018. This far into Florida’s dry season, the air was thick with the smell of mud wafting up from the exposed canals and wetlands along the edge of Biscayne Bay, south of Miami. Mr. Godfrey, a wildlife biologist, kept his gaze — and his headlamp — pointed down to light up the water at the base of the levee.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: TUESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: The Connections Companion
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Editor’s note: Tomorrow, Wyna Liu,  Connections editor, will be answering questions in our comments from 2-3 p.m. Eastern time! Ask her how she creates the boards, where she draws inspiration from, how she ended up as a puzzle editor and more. We’ll be taking questions from the comments section.

headline: With Rent Out of Reach, a Back Seat Becomes a Bedroom
abstract: For a Times journalist, months of reporting led to surprising discoveries about the growing number of Americans who, amid a nationwide housing crisis, live in their cars.
lead_paragraph: In August, when Rukmini Callimachi, a New York Times reporter who covers real estate, pulled into a parking lot in Kirkland, Wash., that’s dedicated to people who live in their cars, she expected to see clunkers, perhaps with bent fenders or a few broken windows protected by cardboard.

headline: How Aid in Dying Became Medical, Not Moral
abstract: The debate over aid in dying still rages in the language that medicine and the media use to describe the practice.
lead_paragraph: In rural Iowa, Peg Sandeen recalls, living with AIDS meant living under the cloud of your neighbors’ judgment. After her husband, John, fell ill in 1992, the rumors began swirling. The couple had almost learned to live with the stigma when things took a turn for the worse.

headline: New Normal or No Normal? How Economists Got It Wrong for 3 Years.
abstract: Economists first underestimated inflation, then underestimated consumers and the labor market. The key question is why.
lead_paragraph: Economists spent 2021 expecting inflation to prove “transitory.” They spent much of 2022 underestimating its staying power. And they spent early 2023 predicting that the Federal Reserve’s rate increases, meant to cure the inflation, would plunge the economy into a recession.

headline: Carving Pumpkins
abstract: How do you celebrate Halloween?
lead_paragraph: It’s spooky season. Do you look forward to this time of year? If so, what do you like about it? If not, why not?

headline: How to Enforce a Landmark Pollution Law? It’s Complicated.
abstract: Regulators are putting the finishing touches on Local Law 97, which takes effect next year, and aims to restrict greenhouse gases from buildings.
lead_paragraph: Environmental activists appeared in droves on Tuesday at an online public hearing in New York to voice concerns that the enforcement of a new climate law that aims to limit pollution from large buildings would be too lenient.

headline: Cohen Denounces Trump During Courtroom Face-Off
abstract: Michael D. Cohen accused his onetime boss, Donald J. Trump, of manipulating his net worth as Mr. Trump stared blankly ahead. It was their first interaction in five years.
lead_paragraph: For five years, Michael D. Cohen has waged battle with Donald J. Trump from afar: on social media, on cable television and in the pages of his books.

headline: Stabbed. Kicked. Spit On. Violence in American Hospitals Is Out of Control.
abstract: Emergency rooms are among the most dangerous workplaces in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Emergency rooms are among the most dangerous workplaces in the United States.

headline: A Book Critic as Wild for Food as He Is for Literature
abstract: “The Upstairs Delicatessen,” a memoir by Dwight Garner of The New York Times, traces his life’s twin passions.
lead_paragraph: Pity the freelancer tasked with reviewing for The New York Times the intimate and joyful new memoir by the esteemed Times book critic Dwight Garner. Unqualified praise in these pages for “The Upstairs Delicatessen: On Eating, Reading, Reading About Eating, and Eating While Reading” will never be entirely trusted. Fortunately, after my third reading of Garner’s eccentric bricolage of literary anecdote and autobiography, I did come up with a few qualifications.

headline: A New, Feminist Retelling of ‘1984’
abstract: Authorized by the Orwell estate, “Julia,” by Sandra Newman, revisits the events of the dystopian classic, this time as seen by Winston Smith’s love interest.
lead_paragraph: At the outset of “Julia” — Sandra Newman’s retelling of George Orwell’s classic “1984,” this time as seen by Winston Smith’s love interest, Julia — we learn that our protagonist is a mechanic in the Fiction Department. Fiction, along with Records and Research, makes up the Ministry of Truth, which is responsible for producing the official narrative of Oceania, and, since Oceania is a totalitarian state, producing history itself. While Orwell situated Winston in Records, altering past news articles, Newman has Julia crawling around within the systems of Fiction.

headline: Under the Leather Jackets: Anxiety, Bravado and the Keys to TV Stardom
abstract: Candid memoirs by Henry Winkler and John Stamos reveal how lucky breaks — and Yale training, and a curling iron — made them into household names.
lead_paragraph: When I worked for a casting director in the 1980s, the most fun part of the job was looking at the marked-up appointment sheet at the end of each day. Because film and TV auditions are intimate, often conducted over a desk, my boss had devised a code by which to secretly rate the sensitive actors sitting just inches away from her: CBNC (close but no cigar), LLIT (a little long in the tooth), and so on.

headline: In ‘Organ Meats,’ Best Friends Cling to Each Other Like a Dog Pack
abstract: The third book by K-Ming Chang is a coming-of-age story mired in body horror, feminism, rot and decay.
lead_paragraph: Say you had a brilliant friend, the Lila to your Lenù, but instead of being separated by education and opportunity, she was kidnapped by a banana ghost and fell into a sleep that lasted a decade. “Organ Meats” possesses something of the febrile intensity of Elena Ferrante’s Neapolitan novels, their laser focus on female friendship, but instead of Naples, K-Ming Chang’s wild girls inhabit a magical universe of talking dogs and shape-shifting body parts.

headline: Why My Fall Made Me Feel So Ashamed
abstract: If we could acknowledge that we are all vulnerable, our shame would go away.
lead_paragraph: The morning after I fell, I lay in bed assessing the damage. My knees were banged up. The right one was painful and swollen. I felt for the bandage my husband had secured around my chin the night before. It was still in place, sticky with blood. My jaw ached. I ran my tongue along my teeth; none seemed to be broken. A near miss, I thought. Disparate verses from one of my favorite poems, by Wislawa Szymborska, looped through my mind: It could have happened. It had to happen. It happened, but not to you.

headline: Unhappy Animals Languish in Overcrowded Shelters
abstract: Animal Care Centers of NYC is struggling to find homes for soaring numbers of abandoned pets.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Tuesday. I’m filling in for James Barron today. We’ll look at why so many dogs are coming into New York City’s animal shelters and how that is affecting the shelter animal population.

headline: At Home With Roz Chast
abstract: The New Yorker cartoonist says she has trouble making decisions about décor. Anyone who has seen the art collection in her home may not notice.
lead_paragraph: The New Yorker cartoonist says she has trouble making decisions about décor. Anyone who has seen the art collection in her home may not notice.

headline: Stabbed. Kicked. Spit On. Violence in American Hospitals Is Out of Control.
abstract: Emergency rooms are among the most dangerous workplaces in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Crushing chest pain, an itch that festers into torment, an inconsolable baby, no place to sleep at 3 a.m., an ankle twisted on a jog, a fentanyl overdose, a car crash, the need to tell someone, “I feel sad and lonely.” The only place that tends to this kaleidoscope of needs is the emergency room, its doors perpetually open to all.

headline: Is Pumpkin Good for You?
abstract: It’s the quintessential flavor of fall. It also has big benefits for your health.
lead_paragraph: Q: Pumpkins are everywhere in the fall. But are they good for me?

headline: Is Roz Chast ‘Terrible at Decorating’? You Decide.
abstract: The New Yorker cartoonist has trouble making decisions about décor. Anyone who has seen the art collection in her home may not notice.
lead_paragraph: For years after she moved to Connecticut from New York, Roz Chast had recurring dreams about her beloved post-college apartment on West 73rd Street. The storyline and set design of those reveries varied, but she was always on the street where she had lived.

headline: Carolyn Bessette Kennedy, Ghost Influencer
abstract: Almost 25 years after her tragic death, the lithe blonde is the muse of the season.
lead_paragraph: When John F. Kennedy Jr.’s plane crashed on July 16, 1999, killing both Mr. Kennedy and his wife, Carolyn Bessette Kennedy (as well as Carolyn’s older sister), at the peak of their glamour and celebrity, the couple became not just another tragic story, but a symbol.

headline: Is the American Dream More Dead Than Alive?
abstract: In “Ours Was the Shining Future,” the New York Times writer David Leonhardt dissects the country’s record on prosperity, arguing that progressive policies are best suited for achieving our ideals.
lead_paragraph: David Leonhardt, a senior writer for The New York Times, has written a “biography” of the American dream, specifically — as his title, “Ours Was the Shining Future,” suggests — an account of how the dream has withered and all but died.

headline: How Columbia Sportswear Is Loosening Its Ties to Asia
abstract: Confronted with the U.S.-China trade war and disruptions in the shipping industry, the company is shifting some production to Central America.
lead_paragraph: Stan Burton wandered the Guatemalan factory like a prospector probing for buried treasure.

headline: She Heeded Biden’s Warning to Migrants. Will She Regret It?
abstract: After surviving a perilous jungle, a mother and daughter obeyed the president’s plea to enter the United States legally. 341 days later, they’re still waiting.
lead_paragraph: They live in a rusty shack with no running water, hiding from the violence just outside their door, haunted by a question that won’t go away: Should they have listened to President Biden?

headline: Clean Energy, Cherished Waters and a Sacred California Rock Caught in the Middle
abstract: The proposed Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary could create a new model for Native collaborative management of public lands. But the sanctuary faces headwinds with a last-minute boundary change to accommodate a wind farm.
lead_paragraph: My paddle slips gently through calm ocean water as the kayak glides toward the mouth of Morro Bay Harbor. I approach a sandbar covered in resting cormorants, as sea otters float in nearby kelp, inky-eyed pups nestled on their mothers’ chests. On this windless morning, the marine layer paints the world in a gentle watercolor wash. In front of me, Morro Rock rises dramatically from the landscape.

headline: Do You Think Any of These Mythical Creatures Might Be Real?
abstract: Bigfoot. The Loch Ness monster. Yetis. Could they really exist? Or are they all hoaxes or superstitions?
lead_paragraph: Bigfoot was supposedly sighted again recently, this time wandering a mountainside in southwestern Colorado.

headline: Stop, Before You Close This Tab (or Any Others) …
abstract: Think of your browser like an ongoing autobiography. Why would you ever delete it?
lead_paragraph: Whenever my computer freezes and shuts down, I’m not surprised. I have a tab problem. As I’m writing this, I currently have 72 browser tabs open: my email, my calendar, the dinner menu of the restaurant where I’m meeting a friend tonight, directions for how to get there, an order confirmation for a refill of Sonicare toothbrush heads, my local yoga studio’s weekly schedule, medical claims forms, Ina Garten’s lemon orzo recipe to make this weekend. My phone, meanwhile, has no fewer than 263 open tabs.

headline: The Jewish Left Is Trying to Hold Two Thoughts at Once
abstract: Spencer Ackerman and Peter Beinart navigate the tensions between grief and solidarity in the aftermath of Hamas’s Oct. 7 attack.
lead_paragraph: Grief moves slowly, and war moves quickly. After Hamas assailants killed at least 1,400 Israelis and took hundreds more hostage, Israel dropped more than 6,000 bombs on Gaza in the first week of a conflict that is ongoing. So far, more than 5,000 Palestinians are reported dead and many more injured. There’s no one way to cover this that reconciles all that is happening and all that needs to be felt.

headline: When a Book Deal Feels Like ‘Winning the Middle-Age Lottery’
abstract: Dann McDorman, the executive producer of “The Beat With Ari Melber,” gave up writing fiction in his 20s. Now, he’s publishing his first novel at age 47.
lead_paragraph: For a few hours every morning, Dann McDorman sits on his windowed front porch in Brooklyn, a steaming cup of coffee by his side, a computer on his lap and maybe a space heater by his feet if it’s cold. There he sits, for an hour or two, writing novels.

headline: This Is What Keeps My Eco-Anxiety in Check
abstract: The simple act of picking up trash, I’ve found, has an outsize effect on my worrying over climate change and ecological catastrophe.
lead_paragraph: From spring until late fall, when winter weather drives me indoors to the treadmill, I spend 20 minutes each morning after my run around the Back Cove in Portland, Maine, walking the shoreline, picking up garbage. Every day is Groundhog Day — I gather plastic cups, syringes, food containers and cigarette butts the same as the morning before, and the same as the morning before that.

headline: How the Right’s Purity Tests Are Haunting the House G.O.P.
abstract: The question for House Republicans is: Does anybody here want to play this game?
lead_paragraph: When Casey Stengel had the misfortune to be the manager of the historically inept 1962 New York Mets, his famous plaint was, “Can’t anybody here play this game?”

headline: Two Illinois Parishes Live on Either Side of a Catholic Divide
abstract: As the pope and church leaders meet in Rome to discuss the Roman Catholic Church’s future, they face a chasm between conservatives and progressives in the pews.
lead_paragraph: When the Rev. John Trout heard that Pope Francis wanted feedback from parishes before a major Vatican gathering this month on the church’s future, he decided that his suburban Chicago congregation would go all in.

headline: ‘It’s Like Our Country Exploded’: Canada’s Year of Fire
abstract: Endless evacuations, unimaginable smoke and heat, 45 million acres burned — is this the nation’s new normal?

headline: We’re Disconnected and Lonely. David Brooks Has a Solution.
abstract: Become such a good listener, you’re “burning calories.”
lead_paragraph: When the Opinion columnist David Brooks was growing up, he was emotionally detached, he says. Over the past several years, he’s worked to change that. In this audio essay, Brooks shares what he learned opening up with others on his journey to become a fuller human being: that better conversation could help save America from its “social and emotional breakdown.”

headline: Israel Says It Will Destroy Hamas. But Who Will Govern Gaza?
abstract: Israel has set itself a stiff challenge in aiming to vanquish Hamas. But an even bigger question looms: Once in Gaza, how and when does Israel get out?
lead_paragraph: As Israeli soldiers have massed to enter Gaza in force, the defense minister has promised them, “You see Gaza now from a distance; you will soon see it from inside.”

headline: In Tight G.O.P. Primary in Ohio, Newt Gingrich Picks His Candidate
abstract: Three Ohio Republicans are competing in the Senate primary. Mr. Gingrich is backing Bernie Moreno, a businessman who is a relative political newcomer.
lead_paragraph: The Senate race in Ohio is one of the best chances for Republicans to capture a seat from Democrats next year. But first, the Republican Party has to survive a three-way primary without damaging its increasingly strong brand in the state.

headline: Millennials and Gen Z Are Tilting Left and Staying There
abstract: Younger voters may get more conservative as they age, but that doesn’t mean they will become Republicans.
lead_paragraph: There is an old saying that if you’re not a liberal when you’re young, then you have no heart, and if you’re not a conservative when you’re old, you have no brain.

headline: Inside Poland Spring’s Hidden Attack on Water Rules It Didn’t Like
abstract: When Maine lawmakers tried to tighten regulations on large-scale access to water, the brand’s little-known parent company set out to rewrite the rules.
lead_paragraph: When Maine lawmakers tried to tighten regulations on large-scale access to water, the brand’s little-known parent company set out to rewrite the rules.

headline: She Made Pesto. People Started Spilling Their Secrets.
abstract: Call us crazy if you want, but a TikTok star who made pesto instead of buying it inspired countless confessionals that had nothing to do with cooking.
lead_paragraph: Susi Vidal, a TikTok creator, makes pesto regularly for weeknight meals. She always has pasta on hand, and while she frequently posts videos of more elaborate creations like sun-dried tomato focaccia and ratatouille, more often than not she just wants a bowl of noodles with sauce for dinner.

headline: Something Wicked This Way Paddles
abstract: Every October, hundreds of revelers in witch costumes float on lakes and bays, ponds and harbors. Instead of brooms, they opt for paddle boards.
lead_paragraph: At first, the silhouette looked familiar — a person in a pointed hat with a long robe holding a broom-shaped object. But the setting felt out of place.

headline: The Lawyers Now Turning on Trump
abstract: Two members of the former president’s 2020 legal team pleaded guilty in Georgia, agreeing to cooperate with prosecutors.
lead_paragraph: Over the past few days, two of the lawyers who tried to help former President Donald J. Trump stay in power after losing the 2020 election pleaded guilty in a Georgia racketeering case and have agreed to cooperate with prosecutors against him.

headline: G.M. Profit Down 7% in Strike-Affected Quarter
abstract: The carmaker said the six-week strike by the United Automobile Workers union had cost it $800 million so far and could cost $200 million for every week it continued.
lead_paragraph: General Motors said on Tuesday that it made $3.1 billion in profit from July through September, a year-over-year decline of more than 7 percent that was partly due to the six-week strike by the United Automobile Workers union.

headline: Reviving the American Dream
abstract: The American political system helped create today’s problems, and only the American political system can solve them.
lead_paragraph: Many Americans have come to see the political system as rigged. They worry that grass-roots political movements are powerless to overcome entrenched interests, whether those interests are self-serving politicians, large employers or dominant social media platforms. And I understand why this cynicism exists.

headline: ‘Miss Juneteenth,’ ‘Dredd’ and More Streaming Gems
abstract: Women in competitions, chaos in high places and documentary portraits of Covid life are among the running themes of this month’s off-the-radar selections on your subscription streaming services.
lead_paragraph: Of all the films that would have been sleeper hits, had they not been released in 2020 when a theatrical push was off the table, it’s hard to top this, the debut feature from the writer and director Channing Godfrey Peoples. Nicole Beharie stars as Turquoise Jones, a Texas single mother whose 15-year-old daughter (Alexis Chikaeze) is about to compete in the local Miss Juneteenth pageant Turquoise won, once upon a time. Peoples’s screenplay sensitively explores poignant questions of opportunities lost and gained, and the mother/daughter dynamics are convincing and compelling. But the real takeaway here is Beharie, whose marvelous, lived-in performance is both inspiring and shattering.

headline: ‘Milli Vanilli’ Review: Blame It on the Fame
abstract: Luke Korem’s documentary retraces the manufactured pop duo’s rise and fall, while asking pertinent questions about the price of stardom.
lead_paragraph: The performers Fab Morvan and Rob Pilatus earn your empathy in the documentary “Milli Vanilli,” a jolting, eye-opening investigation on how fame destroyed them. The war-of-words film, directed by Luke Korem, unfolds like a whodunit.

headline: Despite State Bans, Legal Abortions Didn’t Fall Nationwide in Year After Dobbs
abstract: The first full-year census of U.S. abortion providers shows significant increases in abortion in states where it’s legal.
lead_paragraph: In the year after the Supreme Court ended the constitutional right to abortion, something unexpected happened: The total number of legal abortions in the United States did not fall. Instead, it appeared to increase slightly, by about 0.2 percent, according to the first full-year count of abortions provided nationwide.

headline: China Dismisses Defense Minister Amid Swirl of Speculation
abstract: The unexplained dismissal of Gen. Li Shangfu, the military’s top diplomat, came shortly after the foreign minister and two top commanders in the country’s rocket forces were also ousted.
lead_paragraph: Just four months ago, China’s defense minister, Gen. Li Shangfu, was at a forum for regional officials in Singapore, serving as the face of his country’s bold vision for reshaping Asia’s balance of power. He cast China as a force for stability and accused the United States of stirring trouble in the region, suggesting that its leaders should “mind your own business.”

headline: Weekly Student News Quiz: The Israel-Hamas War, a Viral Video, SAT Data
abstract: Have you been paying attention to the news recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.
lead_paragraph: Have you been paying attention to the news recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.

headline: Several People Hospitalized in Austria After Taking Suspected Fake Ozempic
abstract: The drug, used to treat diabetes, has become popular as a weight loss treatment. Now, officials are warning of counterfeit versions circulating in Europe.
lead_paragraph: Several people in Austria were treated in a hospital after using what government officials believe to be counterfeit Ozempic, underscoring worries across parts of Europe that fake versions of the diabetes drug may be circulating.

headline: Is E.S.G. Falling Out of Favor?
abstract: Chevron’s $53 billion bid for Hess may drive consolidation in the oil patch. Meanwhile, investors are pulling back from climate-focused investment products.
lead_paragraph: To oil analysts and investors, Chevron’s $53 billion takeover of Hess confirmed that there’s a new cycle of consolidation in the industry, coming less than two weeks after Exxon Mobil’s $59.5 billion bid for Pioneer Natural Resources.

headline: Trump Files More Motions to Derail Federal Jan. 6 Case
abstract: The former president’s lawyers made a series of arguments seeking dismissal of the federal charges that he conspired to overturn the 2020 election.
lead_paragraph: Lawyers for former President Donald J. Trump fired off a barrage of new attacks on Monday night against the federal charges accusing him of conspiring to overturn the 2020 election, filing nearly 100 pages of court papers seeking to have the case thrown out before it reaches a jury.

headline: G.O.P. Nominates Mike Johnson for Speaker After Spurning Emmer
abstract: The selection of the ultraconservative and low-profile Louisianian capped a topsy-turvy day and gave Republicans hope of ending the weekslong deadlock that has paralyzed the House.
lead_paragraph: House Republicans chose and then quickly repudiated yet another of their nominees for speaker on Tuesday and rushed to name a fourth, pressing to put an end to a remarkable three-week-long deadlock that has left Congress leaderless and paralyzed.

headline: Louis Vuitton Strikes Another Major Deal in Sports
abstract: The luxury brand will sponsor the prestigious America’s Cup yacht race in 2024 — the same year it sponsors the Olympics.
lead_paragraph: Louis Vuitton’s takeover of the sporting world continues apace: Next August, shortly after the LVMH-sponsored Summer Olympic Games end in Paris, the Louis Vuitton-sponsored America’s Cup will begin in Barcelona.

headline: Behind a Proposal to Create a Marine Sanctuary Along California’s Central Coast
abstract: The Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary would be a tribal-led effort that would protect more than 7,500 square miles on and offshore.
lead_paragraph: The scent of sage and the sounds of a traditional Chumash song filled the air on a recent gray afternoon in Morro Bay. Waves crashed against a nearby breakwater as Morro Rock, a 576-foot volcanic plug, loomed dramatically behind us.

headline: Black Sabbath Ballet Turns Up the Volume on a Varied London Season
abstract: The fall dance calendar began with English National Ballet under new leadership. Then came Royal Ballet’s “Don Quixote” and “Black Sabbath: The Ballet.”
lead_paragraph: As the crowds filed out of Sadler’s Wells theater on Friday, I approached a bushy-bearded man in a leather jacket and Black Sabbath T-shirt. Was he a die-hard aficionado of the heavy metal band? He was. What had he thought of the show we had just seen, “Black Sabbath: The Ballet”? “Fantastic!” he said, beaming. “But I’m also a big ballet fan. I was at ‘Don Quixote’ at the Royal Opera House last week.”

headline: Macron Says Israel Must Fight Hamas ‘Without Mercy but Not Without Rules’
abstract: The French president also suggested that the international coalition once deployed to fight the Islamic State could also fight Hamas.
lead_paragraph: President Emmanuel Macron of France expressed firm support for Israel during a trip there on Tuesday, even as he insisted that its war against Hamas should spare civilians and that Israel should not lose sight of a political resolution to the decades-long Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

headline: María José Llergo’s Songs Have Flamenco Roots. They Raise a Ruckus.
abstract: This Spanish singer’s debut, “Ultrabelleza,” experiments with a signature genre of her Andalusian homeland, creating an unexpected homage.
lead_paragraph: When the Spanish singer María José Llergo talks about flamenco, it often sounds as though she is describing something springing from beneath her feet. “The genre is rooted in my land,” she said, in a video call from her place just outside Madrid. “It’s in our roots.”

headline: Jenna Ellis, Former Trump Lawyer, Pleads Guilty in Georgia Election Case
abstract: Three lawyers indicted with Donald Trump for trying to overturn the 2020 election results will now cooperate with prosecutors in the racketeering case.
lead_paragraph: Jenna Ellis, a pro-Trump lawyer who amplified former President Donald J. Trump’s baseless claims of election fraud as part of what she called a legal “elite strike force team,” pleaded guilty on Tuesday as part of a deal with prosecutors in Georgia.

headline: British Freighter Sinks in Fatal North Sea Collision
abstract: Two cargo vessels collided in a busy shipping lane. At least one mariner is dead and several others are missing.
lead_paragraph: Two cargo ships collided in the North Sea in the early hours of Tuesday morning, sinking one vessel and leaving at least one mariner dead, the authorities said.

headline: Media Companies Eye Cricket-Loving Diaspora in the U.S.
abstract: Investors are trying to capitalize on the relatively small — but loyal and growing — audience for the sport.
lead_paragraph: Right after morning prayers on a Saturday this month, members of the Masjid Quba mosque in Brooklyn joined a party.

headline: The ‘Devil’s Playground’ of Urban Combat That Israel Is Preparing to Enter
abstract: A ground invasion in Gaza could produce some of the fiercest street-to-street fighting since World War II.
lead_paragraph: Heavy fire from rooftops and booby-trapped apartments. Armor-piercing projectiles blowing up troop carriers. Fighters blending in with civilians, launching drone ambushes, or surging from tunnels full of enough ammunition, food and water to sustain a long war.

headline: After a Long Intermission, a New Act for a Flagship Paris Theater
abstract: The Théâtre de la Ville, now named for Sarah Bernhardt, reopened after a seven-year renovation. But its once-radical approach to dance is now less of a calling card.
lead_paragraph: A lot can happen in seven years. When the Théâtre de la Ville — a flagship venue for Paris’s contemporary dance and theater scene — last welcomed audiences, in late 2016, TikTok had just launched. A pandemic seemed like a far-fetched idea. La(Horde), the influential dance collective featured prominently during the theater’s reopening festivities this month, was still wholly unknown.

headline: U.A.W.’s Expanding Strikes Could Signal an Endgame or a Long Struggle
abstract: The United Automobile Workers on Tuesday expanded its strike to General Motors’ largest U.S. plant a day after striking at a Ram truck plant.
lead_paragraph: The United Automobile Workers union shut down production at General Motors’ largest U.S. factory on Tuesday, significantly stepping up pressure on the large U.S. automakers as signs multiplied that the six-week strike is taking a toll on profits.

headline: Amid Intense Fighting, Ukraine Orders Evacuation of Children
abstract: The evacuations from villages near the front line underscored the ferocity of the fighting as both Ukraine and Russia press bloody assaults.
lead_paragraph: The Ukrainian government has ordered the evacuation of hundreds of children in shattered villages across southern Ukraine, and is sending police door to door to convince parents that it is time to escape the widespread Russian shelling in the region.

headline: Five Quick Fall Pastas
abstract: Think spaghetti tangled with butternut squash and brown butter, orecchiette with brussels sprouts, and cheesy stovetop mac with sausage and kale.
lead_paragraph: Hi, all! Genevieve here, filling in for Emily Weinstein and realizing that almost exactly a year ago, I wrote about how pasta was all I wanted for dinner. Maybe it’s the season — a little chill in the air, a lot of too much going on — that calls for tender noodles.

headline: Feeling Stressed? These 5 Books Can Help.
abstract: We asked psychologists, counselors and researchers for their recommendations.
lead_paragraph: Too much stress is bad for our health — putting us at risk for conditions like depression, heart disease and memory problems. But life is full of commitments and pressures that make relaxation seem impossible, and finding ways to soothe can be difficult.

headline: Edwaard Liang Appointed Artistic Director of Washington Ballet
abstract: Liang, a choreographer who has run BalletMet in Ohio for 10 years, is the first Asian American to lead a ballet company of this size and stature.
lead_paragraph: The Washington Ballet announced on Tuesday that Edwaard Liang would be its next artistic director, starting immediately.

headline: Men Accused of Stealing 2 Million Dimes Face Federal Charges
abstract: The four-man crew took the coins from a truck that had left the U.S. Mint in Philadelphia, prosecutors say. They are also accused of stealing liquor, appliances and frozen food in other heists.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this year, several things went missing from cargo trucks in Philadelphia. Six refrigerators. Sixty cases of Jose Cuervo tequila. And then, somehow, more than two million dimes, worth nearly a quarter of a million dollars.

headline: 85-Year-Old Held Hostage in Gaza Says She ‘Went Through Hell’
abstract: Yocheved Lifshitz offered the first public account to emerge from the more than 200 hostages estimated to be held in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: Yocheved Lifshitz, the 85-year-old woman who was released after being held hostage by Palestinian militants in Gaza for 17 days, on Tuesday described being beaten while her captors took her away on a motorcycle.

headline: Georgia Supreme Court Allows State’s Six-Week Abortion Ban to Remain in Effect
abstract: A lower court is now expected to hear arguments on the broader question of whether the right to privacy in the state constitution protects a right to abortion.
lead_paragraph: Georgia’s Supreme Court upheld the state’s prohibition of abortion Tuesday, rejecting arguments made by doctors and advocacy groups that the law was unconstitutional when the state legislature approved it in 2019, more than three years before the U.S. Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade.

headline: To Star at the Venice Biennale, Artists Need Patrons’ Deep Pockets
abstract: Jeffrey Gibson, the Indigenous artist representing the United States in April, must rely on patchwork private support. The promise of government sponsorship has not kept pace with rising costs.
lead_paragraph: When organizers with the State Department announced that Jeffrey Gibson would represent the United States at the 60th Venice Biennale next spring — the contemporary art world’s version of the Olympics — there were clear reasons to celebrate. Not only would the artist fulfill a personal dream, he would also be writing a chapter of American history as the first Indigenous artist to receive a solo exhibition there.

headline: Meta Accused by States of Using Features to Lure Children to Instagram and Facebook
abstract: More than three dozen states and the District of Columbia accused the tech giant of knowingly using addictive features to draw in and retain children and teenagers.
lead_paragraph: Meta was sued by more than three dozen states on Tuesday for knowingly using features on Instagram and Facebook to hook children to its platforms, even as the company said its social media sites were safe for young people.

headline: Democratic Group Steps Up Warnings Over a No Labels Third Party Bid
abstract: A Third Way memo cites a recent polling presentation from a centrist organization, No Labels, which shows a hypothetical ticket scrambling the presidential race.
lead_paragraph: The Democratic group Third Way has released a new broadside against the No Labels effort to field a third-party presidential ticket in 2024, citing a recent polling presentation that shows a hypothetical ticket scrambling a race between President Biden and former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: ‘Elephant’ at 20: A Drama About a Mass Shooting Remains Chilling
abstract: When Gus Van Sant made his experimental feature in response to the 1999 Columbine High School shooting, he said, he didn’t envision a future America with “an endless number of shootings.”
lead_paragraph: For a long time, after each new mass shooting, the actor Alex Frost would guiltily ponder whether the first movie he ever appeared in may have motivated the perpetrators. Frost played one of the gunmen in Gus Van Sant’s unflinching look at adolescent life, “Elephant,” when he was only 15 years old.

headline: New York Has Regained Its Lost Jobs. Why Doesn’t It Feel That Way?
abstract: Mayor Eric Adams announced last week that the city recovered all of the jobs lost during the pandemic. Analysts say that’s only part of the story.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Eric Adams last week celebrated a milestone in New York’s economic recovery: The city has regained all 946,000 private sector jobs lost during the coronavirus pandemic, more than a year ahead than predicted by the Independent Budget Office, a city watchdog. In total, the city had 4,709,400 public and private jobs in September, the most ever recorded.

headline: Who is Tom Emmer, the latest Republican nominee for speaker?
abstract: Mr. Emmer, the No. 3 Republican in the House, has pitched himself as a unity candidate, but some hard-right Trump supporters have said he was not supportive enough of the former president.
lead_paragraph: House Republicans on Tuesday elected Representative Tom Emmer of Minnesota, the No. 3 in the party, as their speaker nominee after five rounds of ballots that pointed to a precarious path forward.

headline: Donald Trump and Christian Nationalism
abstract: Responses to a column by David French. Also: The Georgia plea deals; a sniper in Ukraine; protecting the innocent in Gaza; marathon helpers.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: K-Pop Group Celebrates Wrong Rangers at Texas Show
abstract: Members of the band STAYC performed in Dallas last week in the jerseys of the Rangers, the Glaswegian soccer club, rather than the Rangers, the World Series-bound Texas baseball team.
lead_paragraph: It’s a longstanding concert tradition: A band comes to town for a show and performs a few songs while wearing the jerseys of a local sports team. The goal is to milk some good will and (cheap? you decide) applause from the fans on hand.

headline: Latest Figure to Flip in Election Case Had Direct Ties to Trump and Giuliani
abstract: Jenna Ellis, the lawyer who pleaded guilty and agreed to cooperate with the authorities in the Georgia prosecution, was closely involved in efforts to overturn the 2020 election.
lead_paragraph: A few days before the 2020 election was slated to be certified by Congress, the lawyer Jenna Ellis sent President Donald J. Trump a memo suggesting a way he could stay in power by upending the normal course of American democracy.

headline: Panera Bread’s ‘Charged Lemonade’ Is Linked to Death in Lawsuit
abstract: The lemonade has as much caffeine as an energy drink, but does not reflect that in its marketing, according to a lawsuit. A student with a heart condition died after drinking it, her parents say.
lead_paragraph: A college student with a heart condition died after she drank a heavily caffeinated drink from Panera Bread, likely thinking it had a safe amount of caffeine, her parents said in a lawsuit filed on Monday.

headline: Morgan Freeman Would Like to Tell You the History of Everything
abstract: In an interview, Freeman discusses narrating the Netflix documentary “Life on Our Planet,” which goes from the dawn of time to the present day.
lead_paragraph: Morgan Freeman’s rich, majestic voice has graced a number of documentaries over the years, about religion, Jewish refugees, even penguins. His next one has a scope and subject that befit a man popularly known as the voice of God: the entire history of life on Earth.

headline: Read the document
abstract: In one 2019 email, a Google executive, Jerry Dischler, wrote to a colleague that the company was at risk of missing its revenue targets.
lead_paragraph: In one 2019 email, a Google executive, Jerry Dischler, wrote to a colleague that the company was at risk of missing its revenue targets.

headline: The Rolling Stones Played Old! They Played New!
abstract: Last week the band played an intimate release show in New York celebrating its latest album, “Hackney Diamonds.” Now hear songs from the new LP in conversation with ones from the past.
lead_paragraph: Last Thursday, I had the absurd good fortune of going to Racket — a 650-capacity club in Manhattan that one recent Google review called an “intimate venue, perfect vibe to see a small concert — to see a seven-song set by … the Rolling Stones.

headline: Pilot Who Disrupted Flight Said He Had Taken Psychedelic Mushrooms, Complaint Says
abstract: In an interview with the police, the off-duty Alaska Airlines pilot also said he thought he was having a nervous breakdown and had not slept for more than 40 hours, according to a criminal complaint.
lead_paragraph: An off-duty Alaska Airlines pilot who tried to shut off the engines during a flight on Sunday told investigators that he had been sleepless and dehydrated since he consumed psychedelic mushrooms about 48 hours before boarding and that he had been depressed for a long time, state and federal court documents said.

headline: Columbia University Postpones a Fund-Raiser as Divisions Over War Deepen
abstract: Columbia has said it should be a space for “moral and intellectual conversations” about the Israel-Hamas war, but as those conversations harden, the choice may affect its finances.
lead_paragraph: Columbia University has postponed a major fund-raising drive in the latest sign that on-campus turmoil caused by the Israel-Hamas war is not only testing the limits of free speech on campus, but is also poised to affect the institution’s pocketbook.

headline: Clean Energy’s Powerful Momentum
abstract: Peak fossil fuel use may be only a few years away.
lead_paragraph: Nearly every day, there is confounding news to make us question whether the world is pushing hard enough to transition away from fossil fuels.

headline: Cruise’s Driverless Taxi Service in San Francisco Is Suspended
abstract: California’s Department of Motor Vehicles cited safety concerns for the suspension, about three months after the state allowed an expansion.
lead_paragraph: California regulators on Tuesday ordered Cruise, a General Motors subsidiary, to stop its driverless taxi service in San Francisco after a series of traffic mishaps, including one this month when a Cruise car dragged a pedestrian 20 feet after a crash.

headline: Dr. Donlin Long, Wide-Ranging Medical Innovator, Is Dead at 89
abstract: A neurosurgeon, he helped develop an insulin pump for diabetes patients and a device to relieve pain, and joined Ben Carson in a historic operation on conjoined infants.
lead_paragraph: Donlin M. Long, a pioneering neurosurgeon whose brain research helped millions of patients manage pain and who collaborated on the invention of an implantable pump to deliver insulin to people with diabetes, died on Sept. 19 near Gettysburg, Pa. He was 89.

headline: Tiny Love Stories: ‘You Have Me Now’
abstract: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
lead_paragraph: I watched the car on the ride-hailing app circle my block three times. When the driver finally arrived, he said the GPS was wonky.
