lead_paragraph: The humanitarian crisis in Gaza deepened yesterday as Israel said it had conducted “wide-scale” strikes and again warned residents in Gaza to flee south ahead of a possible invasion.

headline: 2 Jets Collide at Houston Airport After One Took Off Without Permission
abstract: No one was injured in the collision at Hobby Airport, which came as aviation officials have expressed concern over the regular near misses across the country.
lead_paragraph: Two jets collided at an airport in Houston on Tuesday when one took off without permission as another was landing, the National Transportation Safety Board said.

headline: A Relative of Israeli Hostages Has a Message for the U.N.
abstract: The latest from the Israel-Hamas war. Weekday afternoons with Lulu Garcia-Navarro, and Times journalists on the ground.
lead_paragraph: This week, a dramatic public battle has been playing out between the United Nations, Israel and the United States. On Wednesday, the U.N. Security Council voted down two competing resolutions on the Israel-Hamas war. These votes came one day after Israel called for the U.N. secretary general to resign in response to his comments that the Oct. 7 attack by Hamas on Israel, while appalling, “cannot justify the collective punishment of the Palestinian people.”

headline: Carnival Was Negligent in Covid Outbreak on Cruise Ship, Court Rules
abstract: An Australian judge found that the cruise company and a subsidiary “breached their duty of care” in handling a coronavirus outbreak on the Ruby Princess in March 2020.
lead_paragraph: The coronavirus was already devastating parts of the world, bringing illness and death, and the future was uncertain when Henry Karpik, a retired police officer from the Australian suburb of Figtree, and his wife of nearly 50 years, Susan Karpik, began their holiday cruise to New Zealand aboard the Ruby Princess.

headline: The House Finally Elects a Speaker
abstract: Also, a surprisingly powerful hurricane hit Mexico. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: After three weeks of legislative paralysis and intraparty fighting, the narrow House Republican majority finally united this afternoon around a new leader. Representative Mike Johnson of Louisiana, with all 220 Republicans in favor and all 209 Democrats in opposition, was elected as the 56th speaker of the House of Representatives.

headline: U.S. Seeks Delay in Gaza Ground Invasion to Put Air Defenses in Place
abstract: The systems would allow the United States to provide more protection for American troops at bases in Iraq, Syria and elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration has asked Israel to delay a ground invasion of Gaza for a few days to give the United States more time to put air defense batteries, fighter planes and other military assets in place to protect American troops, U.S. officials said.

headline: Turkey’s Leader, Lashing Out at Israel, Defends Hamas
abstract: In a speech in Parliament, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey accused Israel of committing “massacres” in Gaza and said Hamas was fighting for “liberation.”
lead_paragraph: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey lashed out at Israel and defended Hamas during a televised address on Wednesday, taking positions likely to increase tensions between his government and those of other NATO members, including the United States.

headline: What Guilty Pleas in Georgia Mean for the Federal Case Against Trump
abstract: The guilty pleas present a host of challenges as state and federal prosecutors engage in parallel efforts to hold Donald J. Trump accountable, defense lawyers and former federal prosecutors say.
lead_paragraph: Jack Smith, the special counsel investigating former President Donald J. Trump, brought a streamlined case against Mr. Trump in accusing him of trying to subvert democracy — with the goal of moving the case rapidly to trial in a presidential election year.

headline: House Declares Solidarity With Israel in First Legislation Under New Speaker
abstract: The resolution pledges to support Israel with whatever it needs as it fights Hamas. It passed overwhelmingly, but a small group of mostly Democratic holdouts remained.
lead_paragraph: The House voted overwhelmingly on Wednesday to pass a resolution declaring solidarity with Israel, pledging to give its government whatever security assistance it needs to fight and win its war with Hamas.

headline: 25 Short Films for Exploring the Joys and Challenges of Growing Up
abstract: A collection of mini-documentaries about young people’s coming-of-age.
lead_paragraph: How do we help students reflect on the complexities of growing up — the self doubt, unbounded curiosity, growing independence, deep frustration and genuine hope and fear that children and teenagers experience as they form their identities and interact with today’s complicated world?

headline: Robert Irwin, Artist of Fleeting Light and Space, Is Dead at 95
abstract: Part of a bold, experimental 1960s movement, his work sought to make viewers active participants in their experience of encountering art.
lead_paragraph: Robert Irwin, an acclaimed Southern California artist associated with the Light and Space movement of the 1960s, who early on stopped making paintings in favor of creating ephemeral and sometimes intangible art environments, died on Wednesday in the La Jolla section of San Diego. He was 95.

headline: Congestion Pricing Delays Threaten Subway Projects, M.T.A. Chair Says
abstract: A plan to toll drivers in Manhattan is expected to fund major improvements to New York City’s transit network. Officials fear delays threaten those plans.
lead_paragraph: New Jersey’s attempt to block new tolls to enter Manhattan risks the funding to improve the subway and bus network, New York transit officials said on Wednesday.

headline: Lauren Halsey, an Activist Artist, Joins Gagosian Gallery
abstract: The artist, whose upbringing in South Central Los Angeles is integral to her practice, combines community and commercial success.
lead_paragraph: Lauren Halsey, the Los Angeles artist who recently transformed the Metropolitan Museum’s rooftop into a contemporary monument and who created a food bank in her South Central neighborhood during Covid, is joining Gagosian, one of the largest art galleries, with 19 spaces worldwide.

headline: A ‘Nightmare Scenario’ Hurricane Batters Mexico’s Western Coast
abstract: Hurricane Otis defied forecasts when it quickly transformed from a tropical storm into a Category 5 storm and slammed into the coastal city of Acapulco.
lead_paragraph: Hurricane Otis exploded onto the southwest coast of Mexico early Wednesday, shocking forecasters as it emerged as one of the more powerful Category 5 storms to batter the region and create what one expert called a “nightmare scenario” for a popular tourist coastline.

headline: How Biden’s Support for Israel Could Complicate His Re-Election
abstract: An increasingly disaffected activist base on the left could be disastrous for the president in 2024.
lead_paragraph: Since the heinous Oct. 7 Hamas attacks and Israel’s declaration of war against the terrorist group, I have been going over and over a question I’ve not been able to answer fully: During this episode, why has the Palestinian cause sparked so much passion among veteran activists of the movement for Black lives?

headline: ‘I’m Crying for All the Victims That Are Going to Suffer’
abstract: Even in their anguish, some Israelis call for an end to the cycle of violence.
lead_paragraph: No one understands terrorism more viscerally than Maoz Inon: His 78-year-old father and 75-year-old mother were among those massacred by Hamas this month in southern Israel.

headline: The Full Guest List for Biden’s State Dinner With Australia
abstract: The Bidens invited more than 300 guests, including business leaders, musicians, athletes and prominent Australian Americans.
lead_paragraph: The White House invited more than 300 guests to the state dinner hosted by President Biden for Prime Minister Anthony Albanese of Australia on Wednesday night, including business leaders, musicians, athletes and prominent Australian Americans. Here is the full list of those invited as provided by the White House.

headline: Jamaal Bowman Charged With Setting Off False Fire Alarm
abstract: The congressman from New York set off the alarm in the Cannon House Office Building last month as Democrats were stalling for time to read a spending bill.
lead_paragraph: Prosecutors in the District of Columbia on Wednesday charged Representative Jamaal Bowman, Democrat of New York, with setting off a false fire alarm in a House office building last month in an episode that added to a day of mayhem on Capitol Hill as Congress rushed to avoid a government shutdown.

headline: U.A.W. and Ford Reach Tentative Contract Agreement
abstract: The deal, subject to approval by union members, could ease the way for deals with General Motors and Stellantis and end a growing wave of walkouts.
lead_paragraph: The United Automobile Workers and Ford Motor have reached a tentative agreement on a new four-year labor contract, the union announced Wednesday, nearly six weeks after the union began a growing wave of walkouts against the three Detroit automakers.

headline: Morgan Stanley Names Ted Pick, a Bank Veteran, Its Next C.E.O.
abstract: Mr. Pick’s ascension caps an unusually public three-way race to replace James Gorman, who presided over steady growth after taking over in 2010.
lead_paragraph: Morgan Stanley, one of Wall Street’s most prestigious banks, said on Wednesday that it had chosen Ted Pick, a three-decade veteran of the firm, to be its next chief executive, ending an unusually public three-way race that James Gorman, the chief executive since 2010, once jokingly compared to the television series “Succession.”

headline: Israel: From the Six-Day War to the Six-Front War
abstract: Threats to Israel are multipronged, including Iran and its proxies but also narratives from Western progressives and social media, Palestinians in the occupied territories and internal divisions.
lead_paragraph: If you care about Israel, you should be more worried than any other time since 1967. Back then, Israel defeated the armies of three Arab states — Egypt, Syria and Jordan — in what became known as the Six-Day War. Today, if you look closely, you’ll see that Israel is now fighting the Six-Front War.

headline: Several Family Members of Al Jazeera’s Gaza Bureau Chief Are Killed
abstract: Wael al-Dahdouh, described by his colleagues as “the voice of Palestinians in Gaza,” lost his wife, son, daughter and infant grandson, Al Jazeera said.
lead_paragraph: The following video includes graphic images.

headline: Corrections: Oct. 26, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, Oct. 26, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Wednesday about a lawsuit in which dozens of states accuse Meta of knowingly using addictive features to attract children misidentified one of the two states that led the legal action. It was Colorado and California, not Colorado and Tennessee.

headline: Quotation of the Day: As Bombs Fall, History Hangs Over Gaza Family
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Thursday, October 26, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “The majority of refugees in Gaza still have the keys, and the papers, to their old homes. And there is an expectation that one day we will go back.”

headline: Federal Prosecutors Push to Reinstate Gag Order on Trump
abstract: In court filings, the special counsel’s office said the gag order was needed to keep the former president from making “harmful and prejudicial attacks” on people in the federal election case.
lead_paragraph: For much of this week, after a federal judge temporarily froze the gag order she imposed on him, former President Donald J. Trump has acted like a mischievous latchkey kid, making the most of his unsupervised stint.

headline: City of Paris
abstract: John Donegan repeats himself.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues

headline: Jonathan Majors’s Accuser Is Arrested but Won’t Face Prosecution
abstract: Grace Jabbari, who accused the actor of assaulting her in a car, was herself arrested on a countercomplaint.
lead_paragraph: A woman who has accused the actor Jonathan Majors of assaulting her in a car in Manhattan in March was arrested late Wednesday on a countercomplaint he filed against her, claiming to be the true victim in the altercation, the police said.

headline: People Flee ‘Active Shooting’ Situation at Maine Bowling Alley
abstract: Law enforcement responded to a bowling alley in Lewiston, Maine, where an active shooting was reported.
lead_paragraph: Law enforcement responded to a bowling alley in Lewiston, Maine, where an active shooting was reported.

headline: Biden Keeps Australia’s Dinner Low-Key at a Moment of Global Turmoil
abstract: Before the state dinner was over, President Biden had stepped out for a briefing on a mass shooting in Maine and to call lawmakers in the state. He left shortly after 10 p.m.
lead_paragraph: How do you throw a state dinner on the South Lawn when the world is burning?

headline: Vowing Till Death Do Us Part at the Hotel That Inspired ‘The Shining’
abstract: The Stanley Hotel, which inspired the fictional hotel in the 1980 horror classic, has become a hot spot for couples seeking a spooky setting for their weddings.
lead_paragraph: Couples who get married in October at the Stanley Hotel, situated at the doorstep of the Rocky Mountains in Estes Park, Colo., sometimes have a hard time getting their guests to R.S.V.P.

headline: Denmark Aims a Wrecking Ball at ‘Non-Western’ Neighborhoods
abstract: A government program is using demolition and relocation to remake neighborhoods with immigrants, poverty or crime.
lead_paragraph: After they fled Iran decades ago, Nasrin Bahrampour and her husband settled in a bright public housing apartment overlooking the university city of Aarhus, Denmark. They filled it with potted plants, family photographs and Persian carpets, and raised two children there.

headline: Thursday Briefing
abstract: Biden calls for more aid into Gaza.
lead_paragraph: President Biden called for more aid into Gaza and assurances that the help was reaching those who needed it most amid a growing humanitarian crisis.

headline: India Is Devouring Its Best and Brightest
abstract: The charges against the writer Arundhati Roy herald a dark era.
lead_paragraph: Prison.

headline: Putin Is Getting What He Wants
abstract: Russia is emerging as a major beneficiary of the war in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: As Israel and Hamas descend into all-out war, Russia has been more of a bit player than a lead actor. There is no evidence that Moscow directly aided or abetted Hamas’s vicious attack against Israel on Oct. 7, despite some early suggestions. Diplomatically, too, the Kremlin has been of negligible significance, unable to defuse the metastasizing tensions.

headline: Late Night Roasts Mike Johnson
abstract: Stephen Colbert called the new House speaker “the most generic-sounding congressional leader since the election of Speaker James Kirkland Brand.”
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

headline: Word of the Day: reproof
abstract: This word has appeared in five articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
lead_paragraph: The word reproof has appeared in five articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Sept. 23 in the Opinion essay “What Thoreau Heard in the Song of the Crickets” by Lewis Hyde:

headline: South Korea Must Return Buddhist Statue to Japan, Supreme Court Says
abstract: The artifact, which was taken to Tsushima centuries ago, was stolen and smuggled back to South Korea by thieves in 2012.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court of South Korea ruled on Thursday that a Buddhist statue currently in government custody must be returned to a Japanese temple, ending a decade-old dispute between temples ​in both countries.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: THURSDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: Blank Space
abstract: What do you think this image is communicating?
lead_paragraph: What do you think this image is saying? How does it relate to or comment on society or current events? Can you relate to it personally? What is your opinion of its message?

headline: In a Democratic District, Can a Party Defector Get Elected?
abstract: A contest between two New York City councilmen, Justin Brannan and Ari Kagan, will measure how strong the rightward shift is in southern Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: At a public housing complex in Coney Island, Brooklyn, a powerful Democratic councilman sought to quickly make the case for why voters should reject his opponent.

headline: Trump’s Allies Pledged Loyalty to Him. Until They Didn’t.
abstract: The former president is facing down Michael Cohen, his longtime fixer, in a Manhattan courtroom, while other ex-loyalists are cooperating in a case against him in Georgia.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump could not hide his anger. Sitting at the front of a crowded New York courtroom this week, he folded his arms tightly across his chest. He tossed his head and scowled. He stared into the middle distance and scrolled through his phone.

headline: The Clothes Are Old. New Yorkers’ Love for Them Is Ageless.
abstract: The Manhattan Vintage Show featured Victorian-era diamonds, flapper dresses from the 1920s, motorcycle jackets from the 1990s and so much more.
lead_paragraph: Sofia Wallis held up a delicate lace garment, in awe of its history. “This is an original 1930s puff-sleeve wedding gown, and I have a photo of the original bride on her wedding day,” she said. “It’s from Texas. And I have the original box and where it was bought and everything.”

headline: Israel-Hamas War Protest Leads to Tense Scene at Cooper Union Library
abstract: A video shared on social media showed pro-Palestinian protesters pounding on one side of locked library doors and Jewish students on the other.
lead_paragraph: The tensions inflamed by the Israel-Hamas war that have roiled university campuses in the United States spilled into the Cooper Union in New York on Wednesday, with pro-Palestinian protesters pounding on one side of locked library doors and Jewish students on the other.

headline: Are ‘Secret Room’ Drawings by Michelangelo? Now, Visitors Can Judge for Themselves.
abstract: Since its discovery nearly 50 years ago, a room beneath the Medici Chapels in Florence covered in sketches has been closed to the public. Next month, that will change.
lead_paragraph: The narrow, arched room below the Medici Chapels Museum in Florence has some suspiciously virtuosic doodles on the walls.

headline: Tragedy Interrupted an American Pastime at a Maine Bowling Alley
abstract: The first of two shootings in Lewiston, Maine, on Wednesday occurred at a bowling alley with a restaurant.
lead_paragraph: The first of the two shootings in Lewiston, Maine, took place at a bowling alley, interrupting an American pastime on an ordinary Wednesday evening.

headline: What Is Going On in Britain’s Economy? The Picture Is Foggy.
abstract: The country’s statistics agency published new “experimental” labor market data, the latest in a series of economic re-evaluations.
lead_paragraph: It might never be possible to know precisely how an economy is performing in any given moment. But recently it has gotten harder to get a clear picture of Britain’s economy, particularly the labor market.

headline: A Hazy Issue for Couples: One Smokes (Pot), the Other Doesn’t
abstract: In many relationships, tensions arise as recreational cannabis use becomes more routine.
lead_paragraph: Like many spouses, Kindred Sparks has a list of marital grievances. But hers are not like everyone else’s.

headline: For a Ski Season Without Injury, Start Training Early
abstract: Hitting the slopes is an inherently risky endeavor. To protect your knees, shoulders and wrists this winter, here’s a 20-minute strength workout to start now.
lead_paragraph: If this season is anything like the last, more than 11 million people will flood into United States ski resorts — and about 66,000 of them will go to the hospital with an injury.

headline: What a College Degree Meant to Me and My 6-Year-Old
abstract: My belief was that a diploma could offer me a full-time job with benefits like health insurance and sick days that would allow me to support my family.
lead_paragraph: I started my senior year at the University of Montana in 2013 when I was almost 35 years old. My belief, my near expectation, was that a diploma, a piece of paper, could offer me a full-time job with benefits like health insurance and sick days — something service industry jobs never had — and allow me to support my family without government assistance.

headline: 6 Terrific Witchy Y.A. Novels
abstract: S. Isabelle, the author of “The Witchery” and its sequel, “Shadow Coven,” recommends some of her favorite Y.A. novels about witches.
lead_paragraph: My fascination with witchy characters began in childhood, when I often imagined myself with the powers I read about in fantasy novels. I’ll never tire of meeting characters who manipulate magic, whether they’re inspired by real cultural histories or common fantasy tropes. Thankfully, witches are a timeless fixture in literature, and the following books are incredible additions to the Y.A. canon.

headline: A New Generation of Artists in Roy Lichtenstein’s Studio
abstract: The Whitney Museum has acquired the artist’s former space, once a metalworking studio, in the West Village.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. It’s Thursday. Today we’ll find out what has happened to the studio in the West Village where the artist Roy Lichtenstein worked from the late 1980s until his death in 1997. We’ll also find out about how parking tickets figured in a court ruling on owning guns.

headline: Inside Google’s Plan to Stop Apple From Getting Serious About Search
abstract: Google has worried for years that Apple would one day expand its internet search technology, and has been working on ways to prevent that from happening.
lead_paragraph: For years, Google watched with increasing concern as Apple improved its search technology, not knowing whether its longtime partner and sometimes competitor would eventually build its own search engine.

headline: 36 Hours on the North Fork, Long Island
abstract: By late fall on Long Island’s North Fork, the crowds have ebbed, the beaches are mostly empty and locals are enjoying the autumn harvest.
lead_paragraph: By late fall on Long Island’s North Fork, the crowds have ebbed, the beaches are mostly empty and locals are enjoying the autumn harvest.

headline: Poem: Suddenly, Last Summer
abstract: Developing, through ecstatic repetition, a theology of lostness.
lead_paragraph: Lisa Jarnot’s “Suddenly, Last Summer” develops, through ecstatic repetition, a theology of lostness. The sea-turtle hatchlings, with their instinctual desire to move toward light, risk this desire’s fatal consequence when knowing no better, they mistake the neon lights of the beach for the guiding light of the moon and stars over the water. So, too, the human voice of the poem begins lost — ready to worship but bereft of a God. In the “blue blue night” of despair, human and animal alike retain a creaturely innocence. Even the title — a pop-culture hand-me-down — underlines the innocence and ordinariness of a shared and painful predicament, the guiltless way any of us might find ourselves heading in the wrong direction. The small and unsatisfying light of the library and the deceptive brightness of the neon instigate the poem’s revelation: By these small lights, and with our fellow creatures, we learn there is a greater light to which we may return. Selected by Anne Boyer

headline: Judge John Hodgman on the Tangled Yarn
abstract: A couple disagrees on what to do with a snarled skein.
lead_paragraph: Erin writes: I started crocheting during lockdown. Recently, I made the mistake of washing seven skeins of yarn at once, turning them into a giant wad. It took two days to untangle one skein. My husband says I should throw the wad away because the time spent untangling could be better spent crocheting. Who’s right?

headline: The ‘Total Stranger’ Who Wants You to Relive Your Dating Disasters on Camera
abstract: J.C. Carter was luckless in love. So, tiny microphone in hand, he started “Hopeless Romantic Society” to find others like him.
lead_paragraph: “What’s the craziest thing you ever did for love?”

headline: After Antifraud Crusade, a Trial Asks: Were Illegal Voters or Legal Ones the Target?
abstract: True the Vote challenged the legality of 250,000 Georgia voters, offered cash for fraud evidence and recruited poll watchers. A federal trial will determine why.
lead_paragraph: As Republican candidates and their supporters increasingly focus on specious claims of rampant voter fraud, a federal trial starting in Georgia on Thursday will examine whether a key campaign to unmask illegal voters in 2020 actually aimed to intimidate legal ones.

headline: For the Good of the Country, Older Americans Should Work More and Take Less
abstract: Congress’s refusal to adjust Social Security and Medicare means older Americans consume more of the country’s resources at the expense of the young.
lead_paragraph: We older Americans are not only controlling national politics; we are consuming an ever larger share of our economy’s resources through programs like Social Security and Medicare, leaving younger Americans to foot growing bills for their parents’ and grandparents’ retirements. And politicians of both parties are refusing to recognize the consequences.

headline: 3 Ways to Unlock Your ‘Hidden Potential’
abstract: In his new book, the organizational psychologist Adam Grant shares counterintuitive strategies for higher achievement.
lead_paragraph: In a culture that focuses so intensely on success, it’s easy to feel like a failure. But according to the organizational psychologist Adam Grant, that might be because we’re thinking about achievement all wrong.

headline: The Scientists Watching Their Life’s Work Disappear
abstract: Some are stubborn optimists. Others struggle with despair. Their faces show the weight they carry as they witness the impact of climate change.
lead_paragraph: Amid the chaos of climate change, humans tend to focus on humans. But Earth is home to countless other species, including animals, plants and fungi. For centuries, we have been making it harder for them to exist by cutting down forests, plowing grasslands, building roads, damming rivers, draining wetlands and polluting. Now that wildlife is depleted and hemmed in, climate change has come crashing down. In 2016, scientists in Australia announced the loss of a rodent called the Bramble Cay melomys, one of the first known species driven to global extinction by climate change. Others are all but certain to follow. How many depends on how much we let the planet heat.

headline: For Many in Wyoming, a Biden Plan to Protect Land Is Beyond Unpopular
abstract: Explosive reactions to the proposal, which would limit drilling, show how the president’s climate policies are crashing into walls in some oil and gas states.
lead_paragraph: Of all of the efforts by the Biden administration to protect environmentally fragile lands, few have generated as much vitriol as a proposal that would block oil and gas drilling on 1.6 million acres of high desert sagebrush steppe in Wyoming.

headline: Who Decides Penn’s Future: Donors or the University?
abstract: Some alumni want the president to resign. They are angry about a Palestinian conference and Penn’s response to the Hamas attacks — as well as D.E.I. and transgender rights.
lead_paragraph: In the two days after Hamas killed hundreds of men, women and children in a surprise attack on Israel, the University of Pennsylvania had not reached out to its students or alumni with an official statement.

headline: Desperate to Make Her Mother Smile, Nina Simon Wrote a Book
abstract: The author of “Mother-Daughter Murder Night” started working on her debut novel during a time of tremendous stress.
lead_paragraph: “I had never expected to write a novel,” Nina Simon said in a phone interview. “But then in August of 2020, I got a phone call that changed my life.” The call was from her mother, Sarina Simon, announcing that her recent cognitive decline had been caused by brain tumors that would require surgery. Later, the Simons learned that Sarina had lung cancer. “I proceeded to very rapidly switch from this life of running nonprofit organizations to caregiving for my mom,” Nina Simon said.

headline: Why the U.A.W.’s President Has Taken a Hard Line
abstract: Shawn Fain owes his rise within the United Automobile Workers to a group determined to make the union far more confrontational toward automakers.
lead_paragraph: When Shawn Fain sought the presidency of the United Automobile Workers union last year, he ran on a platform that promised: “No corruption. No concessions. No tiers.”

headline: PinkPantheress’s Music Broke the Internet. Up Next? Everything Else.
abstract: The 22-year-old British singer and producer learned to do things for herself early on. With “Heaven Knows,” a new album out in November, she’s preparing for bigger stages.
lead_paragraph: On a recent September evening at Nickelodeon Universe, the cavernous indoor theme park tucked into an East Rutherford, N.J. mall, the 22-year-old British pop musician PinkPantheress was perched 10 stories above the ground, gleefully waiting to ride Shredder, billed as the world’s tallest free-spinning roller coaster.

headline: Alone and Outgunned, Israeli Police Fought Hamas From House to House
abstract: Military support was slow to arrive in the quiet desert city of Ofakim but officers, most of them armed with handguns, fought back.
lead_paragraph: Roni Abuharon, a detective in the southern Israeli city of Ofakim, grabbed his pistol and floppy police hat. “Don’t leave me alone,” his wife pleaded as sirens signaled incoming rockets from the Gaza Strip, less than 20 miles away.

headline: What’s Happening in the Bond Market?
abstract: The rapid rise in interest rates in recent months has shaken investors and cast a cloud over the economy.
lead_paragraph: The interest rates on mortgages, credit cards and business loans have shot up in recent months, even as the Federal Reserve has left its key rate unchanged since July. The rapid rise has startled investors and put policymakers in a tough spot.

headline: What ‘Oddball Rituals’ Do You Have?
abstract: Experts say observing tiny rituals is good for us. What do you already do? Why? What new ones might you invent to add richness to your life?
lead_paragraph: Do you make wishes on stars? Celebrate tiny milestones, such as finishing your homework for the night or completing a workout? Say or do the same thing in the same way every time you greet a particular friend or family member?

headline: The Chief Ideologist of the Silicon Valley Elite Has Some Strange Ideas
abstract: The reactionary futurism of Marc Andreessen.
lead_paragraph: In July, Marc Andreessen — the godfather of the web browser, one of the founders of the venture capital firm Andreessen Horowitz and arguably the chief ideologist of the Silicon Valley elite — published a Substack piece that struck me as unusually revealing.

headline: Virginia Republicans Look to Neutralize Abortion as an Election Issue
abstract: The state’s governor, Glenn Youngkin, has a strategy to win the state. If it halts Democrats’ momentum on the issue, it could be a model for the party in 2024.
lead_paragraph: Abortion has been a losing issue at the polls for Republicans across the country since the Supreme Court’s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade. But now in Virginia, which holds elections in early November, the party thinks it has hit upon a formula to stop the electoral drubbings.

headline: U.S. Tries New Tack on Russian Disinformation: Pre-Empting It
abstract: The State Department’s Global Engagement Center is taking the unusual step of disclosing a covert Russian operation when it is barely off the ground.
lead_paragraph: An article that appeared in August on an international news outlet, Pressenza, recycled a false Russian claim that the West was looting religious relics and art from a monastery in Ukraine’s capital, Kyiv, one of the holiest sites in Russian Orthodoxy.

headline: Matt Gaetz Created a Win-Win Situation for Himself
abstract: The dynamics that ended Kevin McCarthy’s tenure created chaos for weeks and elevated Mike Johnson, but the underlying conflict remains unresolved.
lead_paragraph: After spending three weeks plumbing the depths of a chaotic power vacuum, House Republicans seem to have finally found their man. And while the selection of Representative Mike Johnson of Louisiana as speaker offers immediate relief from an exhausting, internecine process, his elevation does little to address the underlying conflict that led to Kevin McCarthy’s demise as speaker.

headline: Artists of Color Ask: When Is Visibility a Trap?
abstract: In “Going Dark” at the Guggenheim, 28 artists explore urgent questions around what it means to be seen, and to see each other.
lead_paragraph: Your first encounter in the Guggenheim Museum’s ambitious new show, “Going Dark: The Contemporary Figure at the Edge of Visibility,” is likely to be with four looming figures draped in voluminous garments. It’s hard to see if anyone (or anything) is underneath the slightly futuristic hoodies. Acid-green projected light — known as chroma green, used by film studios for “green screen” effects — bathes the big gallery off the rotunda. The result is paradoxical — the figures are so huge they should be unmissable, but with this intense illumination you may have trouble making them out.

headline: They Brought Their Brooklyn Budget to the Jersey Suburbs. Which House Would Be Theirs?
abstract: Looking to upsize from their one-bedroom rental in Downtown Brooklyn, a young couple scoured Essex County, N.J., for a single-family house they could make their own.
lead_paragraph: Looking to upsize from their one-bedroom rental in Downtown Brooklyn, a young couple scoured Essex County, N.J., for a single-family house they could make their own.

headline: ‘No Gas, No Water, No Food’: Otis Devastates Pacific Coast of Mexico
abstract: The storm was one of the strongest ever to hit the southwest coast, and the Mexican government dispatched thousands of troops to the region.
lead_paragraph: Sitting in his empty cab on Thursday as another taxi driver pushed it from behind, Miguel Ángel Dorantes surveyed the scene of devastation left by the most powerful hurricane to hit the Pacific coast of Mexico, wondering if he would be able to reach home. Mudslides blocked off his hillside house in Acapulco. Basic goods were scarce because of aggressive looting following the storm.

headline: New House Speaker Champions Fossil Fuels and Dismisses Climate Concerns
abstract: Representative Mike Johnson comes from Louisiana oil country and has said he does not believe burning fossil fuels is changing the climate.
lead_paragraph: Representative Mike Johnson of Louisiana, the newly elected House speaker, has questioned climate science, opposed clean energy and received more campaign contributions from oil and gas companies than from any other industry last year.

headline: The Kids of Rutherford County, Episode 1: The Egregious Video
abstract: Eleven children in Rutherford County, Tenn., were arrested for watching a fight. The arrests did not go smoothly.
lead_paragraph: In the spring of 2016, a video of kids fighting in Rutherford County, Tenn., was posted on the internet and caught the attention of a local police officer. She began an investigation that led to the arrest of 11 Black schoolchildren, some as young as 8 years old, for watching the fight and not stopping it.

headline: The House Finally Has a Speaker
abstract: The hard-right conservative Mike Johnson of Louisiana was elected to the chair, ending a weekslong deadlock.
lead_paragraph: Warning: this episode contains strong language.

headline: The Kids of Rutherford County, Episode 2: ‘What the Hell Are You People Doing?’
abstract: A young lawyer can’t get a juvenile court to let his clients out of detention — even when the law says they shouldn’t have been held in the first place.
lead_paragraph: A young lawyer named Wes Clark begins defending children at the Rutherford County juvenile court. He quickly sees a troubling pattern: Kids are jailed for minor offenses, even when the law says they shouldn’t be. But he can’t always persuade the juvenile judge to let them out.

headline: House Speaker Mike Johnson
abstract: Who is he?
lead_paragraph: Matt Gaetz’s gamble appears to have paid off.

headline: Hurricane Otis Batters Resort in Mexico
abstract: The hurricane slammed into the coast as a Category 5 storm, leaving a swath of destruction in Acapulco.
lead_paragraph: The hurricane slammed into the coast as a Category 5 storm, leaving a swath of destruction in Acapulco.

headline: ‘Four Daughters’ Review: The Role Family Plays
abstract: This documentary from Kaouther Ben Hania restages pivotal moments from a family’s life.
lead_paragraph: Re-enactment is not an unusual or particularly novel tool in documentary filmmaking yet recently it seems to have made a pointed resurgence — perhaps because the method has a distinct relationship to trauma and offers a compelling means of picking open old wounds for cathartic and/or healing purposes. Think “Framing Agnes,” “Procession,” and Nathan Fielder’s HBO series “The Rehearsal.”

headline: ‘Inspector Sun’ Review: A Web of Cinema Classics
abstract: The newly released English version of this Spanish children’s film about an arachnid gumshoe is a comic mystery indebted to Agatha Christie and swashbuckling epics.
lead_paragraph: “Inspector Sun,” a computer-animated family film released in Spain last year and now arriving in an English-language dubbed version, is very clearly a product of the director Julio Soto Gurpide and the screenwriter Rocco Pucillo’s deep affection for motion picture history. The movie draws on a range of classics, from silent adventure serials to screwball mysteries like “The Thin Man” to the swashbuckling epics of Douglas Fairbanks and Errol Flynn.

headline: ‘Pain Hustlers’ Review: Seeking Dr. Feelgood
abstract: In David Yates’s film, Emily Blunt plays a single mother who takes a job at a pharmaceutical start-up with questionable sales methods.
lead_paragraph: “Pain Hustlers,” a conflicted yet entertaining dramedy from David Yates, takes its title from a group of pitchmen hawking fentanyl to clinics across the southeast. The drug is legal. Their sales methods aren’t — but in the mockumentary footage that opens the film, they try to sell the audience on their innocence. One pusher (Catherine O’Hara) huffs defensively that she’s not “El Chapo or something.”

headline: ‘Priscilla’ Review: All Shook Up
abstract: Sofia Coppola re-examines Elvis Presley from the perspective of the woman he married.
lead_paragraph: Sofia Coppola has long been interested in how fame can foster a feeling of being walled off from the world. Her films have given us lonely movie stars (“Lost in Translation,” “Somewhere”), a princess bewildered by the rules of a strange new court (“Marie Antoinette”) and outsiders eager to crash the party (“The Bling Ring”).

headline: ‘Deep Rising’ Review: Who Gets to Mine the Ocean Floor?
abstract: Matthieu Rytz’s documentary about the bounty at the bottom of the sea examines the fight over whether to reap these riches or preserve them.
lead_paragraph: Documentaries on ecological crises often begin by scaring the bejesus out of viewers before adding a note of tempered optimism. For “Deep Rising,” a film about the race to mine the deep seabed (in particular, the floor beneath the Pacific’s vast Clarion-Clipperton Zone), the director Matthieu Rytz eschews shock for awe, and inflammatory rhetoric for measured persuasion.

headline: ‘Yellow Door: ’90s Lo-Fi Film Club’ Review: Cinema Education
abstract: This documentary is both a look at a small, obsessive film club that formed in the early ’90s in South Korea and an origin story of the director Bong Joon Ho, who was in the group.
lead_paragraph: Every filmmaker, including the great ones, starts somewhere — even if that means making a low-rent stop-motion short called “Looking for Paradise” that’s about a stuffed gorilla searching for freedom while fighting a caterpillar that emerged from its fecal matter. That was how a young, student Bong Joon Ho made his debut, a saga detailed in “Yellow Door: ’90s Lo-Fi Film Club,” a charming documentary about a cohort of South Korean cinephiles formed in 1992.

headline: ‘After Death’ Review: Visions at the Brink From Those Who Returned
abstract: A documentary about near-death experiences crescendos with redemptions and literal come-to-Jesus moments.
lead_paragraph: The faith film “After Death” enters a crowded field of testimonials about near-death experiences, a staple of YouTube videos and bookstores. This documentary convenes a supergroup of writers and survivors: from early expounders like the author Raymond Moody (widely credited with coining the term “near-death experience”) and the cardiologist Michael Sabom, to such recent best-selling names as the pastor Don Piper (“90 Minutes in Heaven”) and a surgeon, Mary Neal (“To Heaven and Back”).

headline: A Timeline of the Shootings in Lewiston, Maine
abstract: Around 7 p.m. on Wednesday, a gunman opened fire at a bowling alley and then a bar in Lewiston, Maine. The suspect’s body was found on Friday night.
lead_paragraph: Follow the latest updates on the search for the suspect in the Maine shootings.

headline: Trying for a Mortgage? Here’s How Much Money You Need to Make.
abstract: Qualifying incomes for standard mortgages on typical homes have gone through the roof. Especially in California.
lead_paragraph: The minimum income needed to qualify for a typical mortgage on a median-price home is higher than ever. The culprits: rising interest rates, high home prices and low inventory.

headline: Morgan Stanley’s Post-Gorman Era Begins
abstract: Wall Street’s most closely watched succession saga ended with the selection of Ted Pick as the bank’s next leader. But he now must keep the momentum going.
lead_paragraph: One of Wall Street’s most closely watched succession races is over as Ted Pick prepares to become Morgan Stanley’s next chief executive. He will take the baton in January from James Gorman, who since 2010 has transformed the firm from an investment bank into an asset-management behemoth.

headline: Henry Winkler’s Dream Dinner Guests Wrote for Stage, Page and TV
abstract: “I know my limitations, but I would still invite William Shakespeare,” says the actor, whose new memoir is “Being Henry: The Fonz … and Beyond.” “I would also invite Daniel Silva and definitely Larry David!”
lead_paragraph: What books are on your night stand?

headline: At the Australian State Dinner, Jill Biden Stays Neutral
abstract: The first lady wore a dress by designer Reem Acra.
lead_paragraph: It was a night of comfort food and canny comfort dressing — strange adjectives for a state dinner, an event normally known for pomp, circumstance and grand gowns. But everything is relative, and these are complicated times, demanding a careful balance between displays of power and humility in the face of other people’s pain.

headline: European Central Bank Keeps Rates on Hold for First Time in Over a Year
abstract: “Inflation is still expected to stay too high for too long,” the bank’s chief said, but noted that the campaign of interest rate increases was helping curb price pressures.
lead_paragraph: The European Central Bank held interest rates steady on Thursday for the first time in over a year as policymakers moved into their next phase of fighting inflation amid signs the region’s economy has weakened.

headline: U.S. Economic Growth Accelerated in the Third Quarter
abstract: Gross domestic product expanded at a 4.9 percent annual rate over the summer, powered by prodigious consumer spending. But the pace is not expected to be sustained.
lead_paragraph: The United States economy surged in the third quarter as a strong job market and falling inflation gave consumers the confidence to spend freely on goods and services.

headline: Texas Lawmakers Vote to Let Local Police Arrest Migrants
abstract: The proposal, which has now cleared both houses of the Legislature, poses a direct challenge to the federal government’s authority over policing the borders.
lead_paragraph: In a direct challenge to federal power over immigration, the Texas House on Thursday approved the creation of a state-level crime for entering the country from Mexico between ports of entry, allowing local police agencies to arrest and jail unauthorized migrants or order them back to Mexico.

headline: The Books That Explain California
abstract: Readers suggest books that help make sense of the nation’s most populous state.
lead_paragraph: Choosing your next book to read can be a dizzying task. I’m often overwhelmed by having so many options and, more often than not, so little time.

headline: ‘Tommy,’ the Who’s Rock Opera, Will Return to Broadway
abstract: An acclaimed revival of the musical plans to open in March at the Nederlander Theater.
lead_paragraph: “Tommy” is returning to Broadway.

headline: Khaite Clothes, Made Miniature
abstract: Plus: a ’70s-inspired hotel in London, jewelry made with river pebbles — and more.
lead_paragraph: The Khaite designer Catherine Holstein was newly pregnant in the fall of 2022 when the French children’s wear brand Bonpoint reached out to her about collaborating on a capsule collection. Now, the 11 new designs, intended to fit babies and children up to 10 years old and made with materials that are gentle against sensitive skin, are launching on Oct. 25 with a campaign featuring Holstein’s now-seven-month-old son, Calder. Standout pieces include a billowy white cotton top with a ruffled collar, a whimsical red-and-white botanical print skirt and miniature versions of two Khaite mainstays: a double-breasted Tanner blazer and a wool version of the brand’s flare-sleeved Scarlet cardigan. “I’m just amazed at the conversations you can have with kids after the age of three, and what their perspective is,” says Holstein. “I wanted the collection to give them the option to really home in on their individuality.” The pieces most dear to the designer are those inspired by her 1980s childhood. “I had black corduroy overalls that I would wear with suspenders with cars on them and a Fair Isle cardigan. … I really wanted to capture that nostalgia.” From $110, khaite.com and bonpoint.com.

headline: Homes for Sale in New York and Connecticut
abstract: This week’s properties are a five-bedroom homes in Westport, Conn., and Amityville, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: A five-bedroom, four-and-a-half-bath, 5,000-square-foot home built in 1952, with a two-story foyer, hardwood floors, a bright open floor plan for dining and living with a wood-burning fireplace, an eat-in kitchen with custom cabinetry and Caesarstone quartz countertops, a family room with beamed ceilings that is open to a screened-in porch and an outdoor patio with a pergola, a first-floor en suite primary bedroom with a fireplace and radiant-heat bathroom floors, a laundry room, a mudroom, an office, a bonus room and an oversized three-car garage, on 1.83 acres. Bobbie Abagnale, 203-240-9537; William Pitt Julia B Fee Sotheby’s International Realty, williampitt.com

headline: Dave Chappelle Laments ‘Nightmare’ Facing Israelis and Palestinians
abstract: The comedian, whose remarks about the Israel-Hamas war last week made headlines, returned to the subject at a show in North Carolina.
lead_paragraph: Dave Chappelle was about 24 minutes into his set on Wednesday night in Raleigh, N.C., when he briefly touched on remarks he had made about the Israel-Hamas conflict at a show in Boston last week that had led to cheers, some walkouts and headlines.

headline: Driver of N.Y.P.D. Tow Truck Is Charged After Killing 7-Year-Old Boy
abstract: The child, who was on his way to school, was riding a scooter next to his mother in the Fort Greene neighborhood of Brooklyn when he was hit in a crosswalk.
lead_paragraph: A 7-year-old boy was killed in Brooklyn on Thursday morning when the driver of a Police Department tow truck hit him while he was crossing the street, the police said.

headline: The Fuss About Fuchka: A Bengali Street Food’s N.Y. Origin Story
abstract: How a Bengali snack, largely unknown in New York City five years ago, spawned a glut of imitators, all within a one-block radius of one corner on 37th Avenue in Jackson Heights.
lead_paragraph: Naeem Khandaker believes he can see the future, and the future he sees is fuchka.

headline: Is It Time to Give Candy Corn the Respect It Deserves?
abstract: One woman in Mississippi has amassed a sizable collection. Another in Maine has built a wardrobe around it. Candy corn, one of the most divisive treats on the market, has proved it has staying power.
lead_paragraph: Sitting in her Wiggins, Miss., home one fall afternoon, Wanda King began counting all of the candy corn flavors she has collected over the years.

headline: Alcohol Might Be Ruining Your Orgasm
abstract: How much and how often you drink can affect your ability to climax during sexual activity.
lead_paragraph: Emma Schmidt, a clinical sexologist in Cincinnati, has lost track of the number of clients she’s seen for low libido and problems orgasming after they’ve first visited a doctor who advised them to “Just relax and have a glass of wine.”

headline: Schools and Public Buildings in Southern Maine Close as Manhunt Continues
abstract: Dozens of government buildings, school districts and universities in the state are closed, following advice from the authorities for residents to shelter in place.
lead_paragraph: As the police in Maine continue their search early Thursday for the suspect, dozens of government buildings, local school districts and universities in the southern portion of the state are closed, following advice from the authorities for residents of the area to stay home or shelter in place.

headline: As Winter Nears, Ukraine Braces for Attacks on Energy Grid
abstract: Russia targeted power systems last year and recent attacks suggest a return to that strategy, raising anxiety among Ukrainian civilians and officials.
lead_paragraph: Russian drone strikes near a nuclear power plant in western Ukraine this week have revived anxiety among Ukrainian officials and civilians over one of the most oppressive hardships of the war: a winter assault on their nation’s energy grid.

headline: Looking Past the Gadgets, and Into Spies’ Minds
abstract: There are plenty of crowd-pleasing tools and weapons in a London exhibition about espionage. But spying is about more than cool stuff.
lead_paragraph: A tube of lipstick hiding a miniature camera, issued to female K.G.B. spies during the 1970s. A box of matches containing message-writing tools, used by British double agents in World War II. A Russian-designed cassette player with secret compartments for surveillance equipment. A hollow battery in which an MI6 operative could store reels of miniature film.

headline: Who Is in Israel’s War Cabinet?
abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said that the small group of officials would play a key role in determining when Israel begins a ground invasion of Gaza.
lead_paragraph: Before the deadly Hamas attack on Oct. 7, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu was running a divisive government widely seen as the most conservative in Israel’s history. Amid anticipation of a protracted campaign to eradicate Hamas, Mr. Netanyahu responded to political pressure and formed a unity government that included opposition leaders.

headline: Homes for Sale in Manhattan and Brooklyn
abstract: This week’s properties are in the East Village, Sutton Place and Bay Ridge.
lead_paragraph: A one-bedroom, two-bath, 1,011-square-foot co-op duplex that has an open kitchen/living/dining area with a breakfast bar, a bedroom with a walk-in closet and a full bathroom on the upper level, and a living room and full bath on the lower level, as well as pivot doors, a washer/dryer, mini-split air-conditioning and complimentary basement storage, on the first two floors of a five-story prewar building with a video intercom and a shared garden. Jeffrey Spector, 908-294-8654, Christie’s International Real Estate Group; christiesrealestate.com

headline: What’s Going On in This Graph? | Nov. 8, 2023
abstract: What factors do high school students prioritize when selecting a college? How do these compare to the priorities of recent college graduates?
lead_paragraph: Note: A live moderated discussion of this graph will take place on Nov. 8.

headline: Monster Cookies, Chocolate Peanut Butter Cups and Popcorn Balls
abstract: Lots of Halloween treats, none of them tricky.
lead_paragraph: We’re firm believers that when it comes to Halloween, there’s no reason the kids should have all the fun. (They’re likely to take all the chocolate for themselves and stick you with stale Smarties and rock-hard Tootsie Rolls.) In our collection of Halloween cookie and candy recipes, you’ll find dangerously simple chocolate peanut butter cups, delightfully retro popcorn balls and, of course, Nigella Lawson’s monster cookies (above). Those cookies, by the way, as well as these kitchen sink cookies and these Rice Krispies treats with chocolate and pretzels, are a great way to use up fun-size Snickers and Milky Ways.

headline: As Violence Surges, Nations Seek U.S. Defense Pacts. Some Americans Are Wary.
abstract: Many countries, including Ukraine and Israel, want greater U.S. protection against Russia, China, Iran and North Korea. But some Americans resist further military commitments.
lead_paragraph: From around the world, they come to the halls of power in Washington seeking one thing: a commitment from the American government to protect their countries in a time of rising geopolitical crises.

headline: North Carolina Republicans Approve House Map That Flips at Least Three Seats
abstract: The gerrymandered congressional map, made possible by a new G.O.P. majority on the state Supreme Court, ensures Republican dominance in a closely divided state.
lead_paragraph: Republicans in North Carolina approved a heavily gerrymandered congressional map on Wednesday that is likely to knock out about half of the Democrats representing the state in the House of Representatives. It could result in as much as an 11-3 advantage for Republicans.

headline: Sam Bankman-Fried’s Testimony Is Delayed at Fraud Trial
abstract: The founder of the collapsed FTX crypto exchange will testify on Friday, after the judge decided to hold an evidentiary hearing on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: The wait for Sam Bankman-Fried’s testimony before a jury will be a little longer.

headline: Close Confidants of Sam Bankman-Fried Have Testified at His Trial
abstract: From his former girlfriend and colleague to high-ranking FTX executives, Sam Bankman-Fried’s trial has featured many people close to him.
lead_paragraph: Former employees and friends of Sam Bankman-Fried testified at his trial that he orchestrated a scheme to misappropriate billions of dollars in customer money from his FTX cryptocurrency exchange, which collapsed last year.

headline: Review: ‘Lyonesse’ Is a Starry Mess
abstract: In London, Lily James and Kristin Scott Thomas do their best in a new play that careers between near-slapstick one minute and speechifying the next.
lead_paragraph: “We dream big,” says a no-nonsense film executive early in “Lyonesse,” the starry, if overstuffed, new play that opened Wednesday night at the Harold Pinter Theater, in London. And so, too, does this West End debut from Penelope Skinner, a British playwright whose works have long enlivened small theaters on both sides of the Atlantic.

headline: ‘Make Noise Enough’: Excavating Shakespeare’s Songs
abstract: In Shakespeare, music is an integral part of the action. But the First Folio, which turns 400 this year, failed to transmit how it should sound.
lead_paragraph: Musicians from the early-music ensemble Collectio Musicorum were practicing a 17th-century round on a recent afternoon in Manhattan. The tune was jaunty, full of the cantering rhythms and mimetic horn calls that fit a song about hunting. But sung in canon, some of the notes bumped roughly against one another in daring dissonance. The singers broke off, looking at their conductor for guidance.

headline: ‘Nightmare’ Hurricane Otis Developed in a Flash
abstract: Hurricane experts were shocked by how quickly the storm intensified.
lead_paragraph: The tropical storm off the coast of southern Mexico looked as if it might bring some heavy rain to the tourist haven of Acapulco.

headline: What We Know About the Maine Shooting Suspect
abstract: Robert R. Card Jr. was found dead Friday night in Lisbon, Maine, near a recycling center where he once worked and the boat ramp where his car was left.
lead_paragraph: A two-day manhunt ended Friday when the authorities in Maine said they had found Robert R. Card Jr., 40, dead of an apparently self-inflicted gunshot wound. Mr. Card was suspected of fatally shooting 18 people and wounding 13 others at a bowling alley and a bar in Lewiston, Maine, on Wednesday.

headline: 5 Classical Music Albums You Can Listen to Right Now
abstract: Igor Levit’s latest amazement, an example of David Lang’s raucous side and French love songs for voice and lute are among the highlights.
lead_paragraph: Another year, another amazing album from Igor Levit. Like all this pianist’s recording projects, “Fantasia” is daringly yet elegantly programmed: Eight works from across some 200 years, with four meaty masterpieces each set alongside a smaller companion.

headline: The Comedy Club Was as Intimate as a Living Room. Actually, It Was One.
abstract: At Apartment Fest, audiences piled into a Harlem home for four nights of jokes from comedians who have to fight for stage time elsewhere.
lead_paragraph: When Eitan Levine, who’s been doing comedy for about 15 years, announced to his roughly 20,000 followers on Instagram that he would be holding a four-night stand-up comedy event called Apartment Fest in his two-bedroom Harlem home, he wasn’t too surprised when 157 applicants submitted audition tapes.

headline: With War Raging, Colleges Confront a Crisis of Their Own Making
abstract: Education and validation aren’t the same.
lead_paragraph: For the past two and a half weeks, college leaders have canceled or anxiously discussed canceling campus speeches and events that touch on Israel and Palestine. They’ve agonized over the wording of official school statements about the Oct. 7 massacre in Israel and, in some cases, issued second statements to amend, augment or atone for the first ones.

headline: Does Your Ex or Former Friend Haunt You? You Could Try Exorcism for Closure.
abstract: After a romantic or platonic breakup, these people tried hexing spells, smashing plates or erasing all traces of their exes from their digital life.
lead_paragraph: There’s an ex or two or three who haunts all of us. Or a devastating friend breakup that may be a girl-version of the Roman Empire: something you think about every day.

headline: An Annual Gathering of Jewish Republicans Takes on New Urgency
abstract: The Republican Jewish Coalition gathers in Las Vegas this weekend, drawing G.O.P. leaders and candidates at a moment of unique peril for Israel and American Jewry.
lead_paragraph: For years, the annual meeting of the Republican Jewish Coalition has been a routine stop on the presidential primary trail, an opportunity for would-be presidents to demonstrate their foreign-policy credentials while plying donors with requisite one-liners.

headline: After ‘Shaft,’ 8 Movies to Watch Featuring Black Action Heroes
abstract: “Shaft,” starring Richard Roundtree, created a template for Black action protagonists onscreen.
lead_paragraph: As unthinkable as it now seems, the role of John Shaft, paragon of movie star Black masculinity, was very nearly cast as a white character. Executives at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer wanted to flip the source material — a 1970 novel about a Black private detective — for white audiences. But the director Gordon Parks’s vision for the treatment convinced the studio to cast in the role the model and actor Richard Roundtree, who died Tuesday at 81.

headline: ‘The Great Gatsby’ Review: A Musical Take on Tragic Desire
abstract: This new version of F. Scott Fitzgerald’s classic remains largely faithful to the novel, but it trades subtle prose for a straightforward production.
lead_paragraph: F. Scott Fitzgerald’s “The Great Gatsby” requires no critical endorsement. His slim 1925 novel still takes up permanent residence in the book bags of students across the nation. Often it is crushed under tomes of greater size, but what “Gatsby,” lacks in length it makes up for in heart, opulence and tragedy. A new musical adaptation trades Fitzgerald’s subtle blend for a blunter approach.

headline: Good Times and Bum Times Made These Theater Veterans Even Stronger
abstract: Graciela Daniele and Priscilla Lopez are working together on Michael John LaChiusa’s memory musical, “The Gardens of Anuncia,” inspired by Daniele’s early life.
lead_paragraph: It’s challenging enough for an actor to portray someone who is alive and well. But can you imagine the extra scrutiny that comes when your model is sitting in the director’s chair?

headline: Maine Mass Shooting Is America’s 8th, and Deadliest, This Year
abstract: Here is how The New York Times tallies mass shootings.
lead_paragraph: Before a gunman in Maine, who has yet to be captured, killed 18 people and wounded 13 more in Lewiston on Wednesday night, there had been seven mass shootings in the United States this year, with the most recent one occurring in mid-July. But the shooting in Maine is the country’s deadliest of the year.

headline: Billions of Years Ago, Venus May Have Had a Key Earthlike Feature
abstract: A new study makes the case that the solar system’s hellish second planet once may have had plate tectonics that could have made it more hospitable to life.
lead_paragraph: Venus today is not like Earth. Temperatures hover around 860 degrees Fahrenheit day and night, and clouds of sulfuric acid float in its atmosphere.

headline: This Kids’ Show Is ‘Indiana Jones in Reverse’
abstract: In “Curses!,” a spooky animated series debuting Friday on Apple TV+, an archaeologist’s family deals with the consequences of looted artifacts.
lead_paragraph: Jeff Dixon wants to frighten your children.

headline: ‘Is He Going to Make It?’: A Mother Waits for News
abstract: Jessica Karcher’s son, Justin, was shot four times and is in critical condition at Central Maine Medical Center in Lewiston.
lead_paragraph: For hours and hours on Wednesday night, Jessica Karcher waited at the Central Maine Medical Center in Lewiston for news of her son Justin.

headline: It’s the Great Pumpkin Veggie
abstract: Save the big field pumpkins for carving (and roasted pumpkin seeds) and reach for a can to make coconut curry chickpeas, creamy pumpkin soup and a sheet-pan pancake.
lead_paragraph: With Halloween looming ominously in the distance, allow me to regale you with a spooky tale. You’re in the canned goods aisle at your grocery store, on the hunt for the season’s hottest commodity: pumpkin. You grab a couple of cans of purée, visions of cheeky jack-o’-lanterns dancing in your mind.

headline: Speaker Mike Johnson’s Rise: ‘The Republicans Have Elevated an Extremist’
abstract: Readers discuss the resolution of the weeks of stalemate and feuding in the House. Also: Baseball on the clock; iron deficiency; governors and immigration.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
abstract: Our TV critic recommends an outrageous relationship show, a deep docudrama and a poetic survival series.
lead_paragraph: ‘In Love & Toxic: Blue Therapy’

headline: The Beatles’ ‘Now and Then,’ Billed as ‘Last Song,’ Due Nov. 2
abstract: “Now and Then,” an unfinished composition from the late 1970s, was completed using technology that separated John Lennon’s vocal from a piano track.
lead_paragraph: “Now and Then,” a recently finished recording from the late 1970s that is being billed as the “last song” by the Beatles, will be released on Nov. 2, more than half a century after the group broke up, thanks to advancements in audio technology, the band’s remaining members announced Thursday.

headline: Ford’s U.A.W. Deal Will Raise Costs While Easing Labor Strife
abstract: A tentative agreement gives union members at the carmaker their best terms in decades but could complicate Ford’s electric vehicle plans.
lead_paragraph: When autoworkers went on strike in September, executives of the large U.S. automakers warned that union demands could significantly undermine their ability to compete in a fast-changing industry. The chief executive of Ford Motor said that the company might have to scrap its investment in electric vehicles.

headline: As War Looms Over Mideast, Saudi Arabia Tries to Keep the Music Going
abstract: The kingdom is embracing business as usual, hosting an investment forum, concerts and even fashion shows. But grief, fear and outrage over Israel’s bombardment of Gaza simmer just below the surface.
lead_paragraph: As the curtain rose this week on an annual investment forum hosted by the Saudi crown prince, dancers in silver bodysuits undulated through the crowd, and a teenage boy in a sequined suit sang an operatic solo while an image of a white dove — a symbol of peace — flew across the screens surrounding the darkened room.

headline: Maine, a Rare Democratic-Controlled State With Loose Gun Laws
abstract: The mass shooting that killed at least 18 people on Wednesday occurred in a state with a record of resisting gun restrictions.
lead_paragraph: Just months before this week’s mass shooting in Lewiston, Maine’s Legislature considered three major bills to tighten gun restrictions: one to require criminal background checks for gun purchases, another to create a 72-hour waiting period before someone could take possession of a gun after purchasing it and a third to outlaw modifications that make semiautomatic weapons more deadly.

headline: ‘The Holdovers’ Review: Three Sad Souls Stranded for Christmas
abstract: Alexander Payne’s jaunt to the past, with Paul Giamatti playing a curmudgeonly instructor at a 1970s boarding school, is crackling with pungent life.
lead_paragraph: “The Holdovers” takes place in New England somewhere, in 1970, at a tony, all-boys boarding school called Barton, where the students who can’t go home for Christmas wind up spending their breaks in the care of Paul Hunham (Paul Giamatti), the sourest, most pompous instructor the movie can find. He teaches ancient civilizations and prides himself on being the sort of principled educator who flunks senators’ kids and says stuff like, “Such are the vicissitudes of life” and “Listen, you hormonal vulgarian!” He smells bad, and breaks into Greek and Latin as much out of spite as bonhomie. The man can read everything but the room.

headline: A Central Park Garden, Renewed
abstract: Rows of new crab apple trees are being carefully planted to replace dying ones as part of the Conservatory Garden's multi-year restoration.
lead_paragraph: Rows of new crab apple trees are being carefully planted to replace dying ones as part of the Conservatory Garden's multi-year restoration.

headline: 9 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
lead_paragraph: Our recommended books this week have a decidedly British cast, with a new history of the marriage between Henry VIII and Anne Boleyn, an analysis of Shakespeare and race, a Welsh memoir and a group biography of the eccentric logophiles who contributed to the Oxford English Dictionary.

headline: At the Lewiston Bowling Alley, a Crash, Disbelief and a Run for the Exit
abstract: Chad Vincent, who was bowling in a league game when gunfire broke out Wednesday, described confusion and a hectic flight to safety.
lead_paragraph: Chad Vincent was in the fifth frame of his weekly bowling league game at Just-In-Time Recreation on Wednesday night when he heard a loud sound.

headline: How Judges Restrain Trump: Gag Orders, Fines and Possible Jail Time
abstract: Courts have a variety of options to stop Donald J. Trump’s attacks on staff members and witnesses. The question is whether any of them will work.
lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump has twice run afoul of a narrow gag order placed on him by the judge overseeing his civil fraud trial in New York, and has been fined a total of $15,000.

headline: Chimpanzees Go Through Menopause, Too
abstract: A new study challenges a prominent evolutionary theory about why women live long after their childbearing years.
lead_paragraph: For biologists, menopause is baffling. If natural selection favors genes that produce more descendants, why don’t women remain fertile their entire lives? What’s the evolutionary benefit of living for so many years without having more babies?

headline: As ‘Billions’ Ends, Its Creators Discuss the Changing Face of the Ultrarich
abstract: In an interview, the showrunners discussed its imminent conclusion and the rise of billionaires who believe they are “making the world a better place.”
lead_paragraph: As the Showtime financial thriller “Billions” prepares to air its final episode this weekend, it’s worth considering how far we’ve come. The show started as the story of the crusading U.S. Attorney Chuck Rhoades (Paul Giamatti) and the hard-charging hedge funder Bobby Axelrod (Damian Lewis). Exclusive restaurants, elaborate schemes and a host of cameos by real-world power players provided the backdrop for their battle.

headline: What to Know About UNRWA, the Largest Aid Organization in Gaza
abstract: Established to provide temporary relief for Palestinians who fled or were expelled from their homes during the 1948 Arab-Israeli war, the agency now mainly provides services and funding for those registered as Palestinian refugees across the Mideast.
lead_paragraph: The U.N. agency that has been aiding Palestinian refugees for the past 74 years said on Thursday that it had begun to significantly reduce its operations in the Gaza Strip after nearly exhausting its fuel reserves, exacerbating a humanitarian crisis that the agency’s top official described as “hell on Earth.”

headline: Teenagers on What They Have Learned From Failure
abstract: “Failure only has the power that you give it.”
lead_paragraph: Failure is a part of life. But most of us try to avoid it and are embarrassed when things go wrong. Instead, experts say, we should try to embrace our mistakes.

headline: Slovakia Says It’s Halting Arms Deliveries to Ukraine
abstract: The newly appointed prime minister, Robert Fico, whose party aligned with pro-Russian forces during the recent election campaign, had promised “not to send a single cartridge” of ammunition to Kyiv.
lead_paragraph: Slovakia, a small Eastern European nation that has been in the vanguard of sending arms to Ukraine, says it is halting all military aid to its embattled neighbor, a policy shift that is unlikely to change the balance of forces on the battlefield but that delivers a symbolic blow to Kyiv at a time of growing fatigue in parts of Europe after 20 months of war.

headline: Air Canada Apologizes for Questioning a British Lawmaker About His Background
abstract: The airline and Canadian immigration officials were accused of singling out the lawmaker, Mohammad Yasin, “because his name was Mohammad.”
lead_paragraph: Canada’s largest airline, Air Canada, has apologized to a British lawmaker, Mohammad Yasin, after lawmakers said Mr. Yasin was singled out for questioning because of his name and background on a recent official trip to the country.

headline: Mom’s Favorite Chicken Dinner Gets a Makeover
abstract: Melissa Clark takes mustardy, bread crumb-laden thighs to new heights.
lead_paragraph: The only problem with crumby chicken is the silent b. Try calling your mother’s awesome bread crumb-coated chicken by its traditional name in conversation, and people will think you’re being mean. But Mom’s crumb-y chicken is not crummy at all.

headline: Suspect in Killing of Maryland Judge Is Found Dead
abstract: Pedro Argote was wanted for murder after the death of Maryland Circuit Court Judge Andrew Wilkinson earlier this month, the authorities said.
lead_paragraph: A man suspected of killing a Maryland judge outside his home last week was found dead on Thursday morning, ending a weeklong manhunt, the local authorities said.

headline: A Britney Spears Book Tour: No TV, No Podcasts, Lots of Instagram
abstract: The singer, who has not given a face-to-face interview since 2018, has avoided traditional public appearances for “The Woman in Me,” which is still finding audiences.
lead_paragraph: In the run-up to the release of his blockbuster autobiography earlier this year, Prince Harry sat down with “60 Minutes” — and “CBS Mornings,” “ABC News Live,” “The Late Show With Stephen Colbert” and others. Paris Hilton did “The View” and spoke with the BBC. Kerry Washington appeared on NPR’s “Fresh Air” and “Good Morning America.” Arnold Schwarzenegger opted for Kelly Clarkson and Howard Stern.

headline: These Boxers Plan to Show They Can Fight by Men’s Rules
abstract: When Amanda Serrano and Danila Ramos meet in the ring Friday night, they will spar for 12 three-minute rounds, following the format used for men’s fights.
lead_paragraph: When Amanda Serrano trains for a championship fight, she often spars with men for at least a dozen three-minute rounds, using the standard male regulation format to push her athleticism to the edge.

headline: Listen: Serial’s New Show!
abstract: Each week, we share the best of new audio journalism and storytelling.
lead_paragraph: Audiophiles,

headline: Georgia’s Voting Maps Are Struck Down
abstract: Republicans in the state violated a landmark civil rights law in drawing maps that diluted the power of Black voters, a federal judge in Atlanta ruled.
lead_paragraph: Republicans in Georgia violated a landmark civil rights law in drawing voting maps that diluted the power of Black voters, a federal judge in Atlanta ruled on Thursday, ordering that new maps must be drawn in time for the 2024 elections.

headline: The Flatiron Building Will Be Converted Into Condos
abstract: The storied office building will receive a second life as home to roughly 40 residences, according to the owners.
lead_paragraph: The Flatiron, the storied office building in the heart of Manhattan that has recently fallen on hard times, will be converted into luxury housing, its owners announced on Thursday.

headline: Hipgnosis Made Mega Deals for Song Catalogs. Its Future Is Unclear.
abstract: The company’s shareholders on Thursday rejected a $440 million divestment plan and voted against maintaining its current structure.
lead_paragraph: The future of Hipgnosis Songs Fund, the British company that helped kick off the music industry’s trend of top-dollar deals for artists’ song catalogs, is in question after its shareholders on Thursday rejected a $440 million divestment plan and voted against maintaining the company’s current structure.

headline: Johnson Faces the Same Spending Dilemmas That Plagued McCarthy
abstract: The newly installed Republican speaker opposed the bill to avert a government shutdown and has been against continued U.S. funding for Ukraine. Now it is his job to accomplish both.
lead_paragraph: Newly installed Speaker Mike Johnson is confronting a multitude of crises during his first days in office, chief among them a deadline just weeks away to avert a government shutdown and an urgent request from President Biden for a behemoth $105 billion aid bill for Israel and Ukraine.

headline: Could Mike Johnson, the New House Speaker, Undermine the 2024 Election?
abstract: The Louisiana Republican played a pivotal role in efforts to overturn the 2020 election. But his elevation to the top post in the House does not give him special powers in the certification process if he tries again.
lead_paragraph: Ever since Speaker Mike Johnson of Louisiana assumed office on Wednesday, a question has been on Democrats’ minds: Could the elevation of Mr. Johnson, who worked in league with former President Donald J. Trump in trying to undermine the 2020 election results, allow him to succeed in 2024 where he failed the last time?

headline: Anita A. Summers, Economist, Dies at 98; Brought Rigor to Public Policy
abstract: As a professor at the Wharton School and a pioneering woman in a male-dominated field, she developed new ways of thinking about tough issues.
lead_paragraph: Anita A. Summers, an economist at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania who injected quantitative rigor into a wide variety of public policy topics, including zoning, education and tax incentives, died on Sunday at her home in Gladwyne, Pa. She was 98.

headline: Google Search Boss Says Company Invests to Avoid Becoming ‘Roadkill’
abstract: At the start of its antitrust defense, Google attributed its success to relentless investment, countering government claims that it broke the law to stay ahead.
lead_paragraph: The Justice Department has spent weeks arguing in a federal antitrust trial that Google has built an impenetrable barrier around its search business with strong-arm tactics and multibillion-dollar deals.

headline: Siemens Energy in Talks With German Government for Financial Help
abstract: Financial problems at the company, a major supplier of wind turbines and power plants, could hamper the energy transition.
lead_paragraph: Siemens Energy, a major European manufacturer of wind farms, power grids and natural gas turbines, said Thursday that it was in talks with the German government about securing financial guarantees to help it continue to build future large projects.

headline: The Perfect Between-Meals Snack to Throw in Your Bag
abstract: Omusubi, curry puffs, Malaysian jerky and more bites to get you through the day.
lead_paragraph: Hi, it’s Pete Wells, restaurant critic for The Times and inveterate between-meal snacker. I’ll get to that in a minute.

headline: Manhunt Underway for Gunman in Maine Shootings
