abstract: About 7 percent of adults have rolled up their sleeves for the new vaccines, according to new agency data.
lead_paragraph: Few Americans have received the latest vaccines against the coronavirus: Just over 7 percent of adults and 2 percent of children had received the shot as of Oct. 14, according to a survey presented on Thursday to scientific advisers to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

headline: The Weekender
abstract: Lionel Messi’s fabulously popular pink jersey. Also: Taylor Swift fan fiction and a new podcast from Serial.

headline: Security Guard Cleared of Assaulting Top Adviser to Mayor Adams
abstract: Manhattan prosecutors said that camera footage and numerous witness interviews did not support the allegations made by Timothy Pearson, a top mayoral aide.
lead_paragraph: A security guard at a New York City migrant shelter who was accused by one of Mayor’s Eric Adams’s top advisers of shoving him during a violent altercation was cleared on Friday of criminal wrongdoing when a judge dismissed charges.

headline: At Nearby Bates College, Anxious Hours and Sleepless Nights
abstract: Students on the campus, midway between the two shooting scenes in Lewiston, Maine, were confined to their dorms during the first two days of the manhunt.
lead_paragraph: Omar Yaish, 17, woke up on the floor of a friend’s dorm room at Bates College on Friday to face another day of anxious lockdown.

headline: Michael Bragman, 83, Dies; Led a Failed Legislative Coup in New York
abstract: As the State Assembly’s respected majority leader, he attempted to oust his boss, Sheldon Silver, the body’s imperious speaker. That move ended his career.
lead_paragraph: Michael J. Bragman, a Democratic powerhouse who was deposed as the majority leader of the New York State Assembly and retired from politics after mounting an unsuccessful and politically suicidal coup against the speaker, Sheldon Silver, in 2000, died on Oct. 13 in Syracuse, N.Y. He was 83.

headline: Older Americans Are Winning the Economic War of the Generations
abstract: That might not be great for the long-term financial health of the country.
lead_paragraph: If there is a war of the generations, we older Americans are winning it. As evidence, I present two remarkable charts, which are my versions of charts made by the Center on the Economics and Demography of Aging at the University of California, Berkeley.

headline: Ukraine Aid in Doubt as Johnson Moves to Drop It From Israel Assistance Bill
abstract: The newly elected House speaker, who has opposed continued funding for Kyiv, is now insisting on separating it from aid to Israel, leaving its fate uncertain.
lead_paragraph: Representative Mike Johnson’s election as speaker has thrown the fate of U.S. assistance for Ukraine into doubt, as the Louisiana Republican, a longtime opponent of funding the war effort, resists President Biden’s call to package money for Kyiv in a large emergency spending bill to tackle global crises including Israel’s war against Hamas.

headline: Ivor Robson, Golf’s Celebrated Voice at the British Open, Dies at 83
abstract: For four decades he announced the names of players — Jack Nicklaus, Tiger Woods, Rory McIlroy and more — before they teed off. He rarely took a break.
lead_paragraph: At the British Open, a Scotsman named Ivor Robson became one of the most distinctive and revered voices in golf by saying little. Called a starter, he stood at a lectern near the first tee at each round of that major championship, where his job was simple: to introduce each player.

headline: Iran’s Proxies Fire Back After U.S. Airstrikes
abstract: The tit-for-tat raises questions about whether groups backed by Iran can be deterred after a flurry of attacks targeting American troops.
lead_paragraph: Just hours after U.S. fighter jets bombed facilities used by Iran’s Islamic Revolutionary Guards Corps and its proxies in Syria early Friday, the proxies fired back — launching an attack drone at U.S. forces in western Iraq.

headline: Washington Was Stunned by the New Speaker’s Rise. So Was His District.
abstract: Many in Mike Johnson’s northern Louisiana district hope his surprise elevation will bring attention to their region, which they feel has been overlooked.
lead_paragraph: When Chip Hemphill is on a hunting trip with his friends, looking for white-tailed deer and hogs, he doesn’t typically find himself discussing who is second in line to the presidency. His wife, Kathleen, barely mentions politics while overseeing archery lessons at Hoot & Holler Archery, their store in Bossier City in northern Louisiana.

headline: ‘Covenant’ Review: When Inner Turmoil Is Its Own Ghost Story
abstract: The playwright York Walker makes a promising New York debut at Roundabout Underground.
lead_paragraph: Much is made over whether one is “with God” or not in “Covenant,” a striking new Southern gothic work by York Walker. Following a town’s reaction to a bluesman’s mysterious homecoming in 1930s Georgia, this small, potent Roundabout Underground production sustains a scorching end-of-days tune as much through its electric cast and design elements as by Walker’s script and Tiffany Nichole Greene’s swift direction.

headline: How to Choose Your Flatware
abstract: It's best to do it in person.
lead_paragraph: It's best to do it in person.

headline: Joe Hill, Swashbuckling South Street Seaport Merchant, Dies at 76
abstract: His shop selling nautical bric-a-brac was a last link to Lower Manhattan’s seafaring history before the neighborhood became, in his words, a “shopping mall.”
lead_paragraph: Joe Hill, a purveyor of maritime junk and jewels and a swashbuckling South Street Seaport fixture for decades, died on Oct. 17 in Huntington, N.Y., on Long Island. He was 76.

headline: 5 Minutes to Make You Love Music
abstract: We asked musicians, writers and others to tell us what moves them.
lead_paragraph: We asked musicians, writers and others to tell us what moves them.

headline: U.S. Airstrikes Contain Twin Messages to Iran, American Officials Say
abstract: The airstrikes were the latest gamble by the United States to modify Iran’s behavior, few of which have worked in the past.
lead_paragraph: The American strikes on two Iranian military munitions stockpiles in Syria on Friday were carefully designed, President Biden’s aides said, to send two distinct messages to Tehran.

headline: Flashback: Your Weekly History Quiz, October 29, 2023
abstract: Can you sort 8 historical events?
lead_paragraph: Can you sort 8 historical events?

headline: Transcript: Carlos Lozada Interviews McKay Coppins
abstract: The Oct. 27, 2023, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
lead_paragraph: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode, guest-hosted by Carlos Lozada, with McKay Coppins. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: Ida Applebroog, Whose Art Confronted Relationships, Dies at 93
abstract: Gender and authority were her particular concerns as she developed a varied but recognizable style in multiple mediums, characterized by raw, mordant humor.
lead_paragraph: Ida Applebroog, an acclaimed artist who confronted the violence, coercion and mortality that can simmer beneath everyday relationships with a prolific stream of drawings, paintings, sculptures and videos, died on Oct. 21 at her home in Manhattan. She was 93.

headline: Israel Expands Its Operations in Gaza
abstract: Also, police scour a river for the gunman in Maine. Here’s the latest at the end of Friday.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli military launched an intense bombardment of the Gaza Strip this evening and said it was “expanding” its activity there. Cellular and internet service were cut off for much of the territory, and Palestinians said fear and panic were spreading.

headline: Artists Call for Boycott After Artforum Fires Its Top Editor
abstract: Several artists have said they will stop working with the magazine after its response to an open letter that called for Palestinian liberation and a cease-fire.
lead_paragraph: In the days after Artforum magazine fired its top editor, David Velasco, because of an open letter it published about the Israel-Hamas war, at least four other editors resigned and several prominent artists said they would boycott the publication unless Velasco was reinstated.

headline: Portraits of the Dead Emerge From Tragedy in Maine
abstract: What began as a seemingly ordinary evening in Lewiston turned horrific after a gunman entered a bowling alley and a local bar and began shooting, killing 18 people.
lead_paragraph: Some were bowling, others were playing cornhole, some were enjoying a game of pool.

headline: The Proxy Forces Iran Has Assembled Across the Middle East
abstract: A “Shiite Crescent” stretches from Yemen on the Arabian Peninsula through Iraq, Syria and Lebanon and back down to the Gaza Strip.
lead_paragraph: For decades, the Shiite Muslim ayatollahs who came to power in Iran through the 1979 Islamic Revolution have worked to build an arc of like-minded proxy forces across the Middle East.

headline: ‘Billions’ Series Finale Recap: The Last Battle
abstract: In its final hour, “Billions” delivered that rarest of prestige-TV commodities: a happy ending.
lead_paragraph: Am I at a loss for words over the series finale of “Billions”? That depends. Do hooting and hollering count as “words”?

headline: Gaza Goes Dark as Israel Attacks Intensify
abstract: Two major Palestinian mobile networks, Jawwal and Paltel, said that their phone lines and internet services were down.
lead_paragraph: It was increasingly difficult to reach people in the Gaza Strip or know what was happening in the enclave late Friday as Israel said it was stepping up its bombardment and staging another incursion.

headline: Israel Intensifies Gaza Strikes and Says It Is Expanding Ground Activity
abstract: Cellular and internet service abruptly vanished for much of the territory, stoking fears that a full-scale invasion was imminent — or already underway.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli military launched a particularly intense bombardment of the Gaza Strip late on Friday and said it was “expanding ground activity” there overnight, while cellular and internet service abruptly vanished for much of the territory, raising the possibility that a full-scale invasion was underway or imminent.

headline: Did A.I. Write Product Reviews? Gannett Says No.
abstract: Writers and editors at Reviewed, a product recommendation website, say that the company used artificial intelligence to create reviews last week.
lead_paragraph: When several articles were published last week on Reviewed, a USA Today-owned website that recommends products, something seemed off. No one at Reviewed recognized the bylines on the pieces.

headline: Biden Hosts China’s Top Diplomat Ahead of Expected Xi Meeting
abstract: Wang Yi met with the president and other senior officials amid talk of cooperation within a frosty relationship.
lead_paragraph: President Biden met with China’s top diplomat on Friday to prepare for Mr. Biden’s planned meeting with President Xi Jinping next month as relations remain strained between Washington and Beijing.

headline: ‘I Feel a Human Deterioration’
abstract: The Israeli writer Etgar Keret has spent the last few weeks trying to make sense of the violence and loss around him. So far, he can’t.
lead_paragraph: When I spoke with the writer Etgar Keret at home in Tel Aviv earlier this week, he was in anguish. Keret is one of Israel’s most beloved contemporary authors, whose books include “Suddenly, a Knock on the Door” and “The Seven Good Years.” He primarily writes short stories that are whimsical, surrealist and darkly funny, and that make meaning from life’s smallest, most unremarkable interactions.

headline: Stephen King on Mass Shootings: We’re Out of Things to Say
abstract: Every mass shooting is a gut punch, but such things can and will happen anywhere and everywhere in this locked-and-loaded country.
lead_paragraph: There is no solution to the gun problem and little more to write, because Americans are addicted to firearms.

headline: ‘Let Gaza Live’: Calls for Cease-Fire Fill Grand Central Terminal
abstract: A large demonstration, organized by Jewish Voice for Peace, came as Israel ramped up its military operations in Gaza.
lead_paragraph: Crowds of protesters calling for a cease-fire in the Israel-Hamas war streamed into Grand Central Terminal in Midtown Manhattan on Friday, in one of the largest protests New York City has seen since the start of the conflict three weeks ago.

headline: After Shooting, Maine Senators in the Spotlight on Guns
abstract: The shooting in Lewiston that left 18 dead prompted the town’s conservative Democratic representative to embrace an assault weapons ban, but Senators Susan Collins and Angus King are still resisting.
lead_paragraph: The mass shooting in Lewiston, Maine, coupled with a conservative Democratic congressman’s reversal on an assault weapons ban, has turned the spotlight on the state’s two senators, Susan Collins, a moderate Republican, and Angus King, a Democrat-leaning independent, both of whom are skeptical about banning military-style rifles.

headline: On Race, Mike Johnson Says His Views Were Shaped by Raising a Black Child
abstract: The new House speaker has kept his oldest son out of the public eye — except when the Republican talks about race.
lead_paragraph: When Mike Johnson, the new House speaker, talks about race in America, he often draws a striking personal connection, telling the story of how he and his wife, Kelly, “took custody” of a Black teenager 24 years ago and raised him as a son.

headline: Hawaii Settles Sex Discrimination Case With High School Female Athletes
abstract: The landmark class-action case was one of the farthest-reaching challenges to high school sports under federal Title IX protections.
lead_paragraph: Hawaii education officials on Friday agreed to settle a class-action lawsuit filed by female athletes at the state’s biggest public high school alleging widespread and systemic sex discrimination, as well as retaliation against the girls who raised those concerns.

headline: Without Getting Beat
abstract: Ryan McCarty’s puzzle looks impossible, but we’ll claw through.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Sometimes a puzzle comes along that makes my solving skills feel paltry, a teaspoon of water on a swirling inferno of misdirects and unfamiliar pop culture. On a Saturday, that puzzle is often by Ryan McCarty, who now has 22 such constructions under his belt. They are always entertaining, confounding and full of debuts and eccentric usages.

headline: Team Trump Revives Attack Ads Against DeSantis in Iowa
abstract: A super PAC supporting Trump is shifting its strategy again, with less than three months before the state’s first-in-the-nation caucuses.
lead_paragraph: The super PAC supporting Donald J. Trump will begin airing an attack against Ron DeSantis in Iowa, a shift in strategy after months of focusing their messaging on their likely general election opponent.

headline: Richard Moll, Towering Bailiff on ‘Night Court,’ Dies at 80
abstract: His career spanned more than four decades, but he was best known for playing the imposing but lovable Bull Shannon on the long-running NBC sitcom.
lead_paragraph: Richard Moll, the 6-foot-8 actor who delighted television audiences with a childlike charm in his role as the hulking bailiff on the NBC sitcom “Night Court,” died on Thursday at his home in Big Bear Lake, Calif. He was 80.

headline: For Mike Johnson, Religion Is at the Forefront of Politics and Policy
abstract: The new House speaker has put his faith at the center of his political career, and aligned himself with a newer cohort of conservative Christianity that some describe as Christian nationalism.
lead_paragraph: In the moments before he was to face a vote on becoming speaker of the House this week, Representative Mike Johnson posted a photograph on social media of the inscription carved into marble atop the chamber’s rostrum: “In God We Trust.”

headline: Quotation of the Day: Violence Grinds On in Sudan, Putting a Generation of Students at Risk
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, October 28, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “I am starting from zero.”

headline: Suspect in Maine Shooting Is Found Dead, Ending Sprawling Manhunt
abstract: The body of the man suspected of killing 18 and injuring 13 others in Lewiston was found with an apparent self-inflicted gunshot wound late Friday.
lead_paragraph: The man suspected of killing 18 people and injuring 13 others at a bar and a bowling alley in Lewiston, Maine, on Wednesday night was found dead of an apparent self-inflicted gunshot wound on Friday, officials said, ending a sweeping manhunt that had forced thousands of residents throughout the region to remain in their homes.

headline: Corrections: Oct. 28, 2023
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Oct. 28, 2023.
lead_paragraph: An article on Friday about Georgia’s voting maps misstated the year that Georgia elected its two Democratic senators. It was 2021, not 2020.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Early Voting Begins in New York: Here’s What to Know
abstract: Although no citywide offices are being contested this year, the New York City Council is up for election, and voters statewide will consider two ballot questions.
lead_paragraph: Election Day is still several days away, but voters in New York can get a head start on Saturday, when early voting begins.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: How ‘Madame Morbid,’ a Ghost Tour Guide, Spends Her Sundays
abstract: Allison Chase leads tours of Brooklyn’s gruesome history, hidden cemeteries and paranormal sightings in a replica Victorian trolley.
lead_paragraph: Allison Chase was at a crossroads and venting to her father about the direction of her life at 26 years old. Having dabbled in doing special effects makeup, writing restaurant reviews and obtaining a sommelier certificate, she quipped half in jest, “What if I want to start a ghost tour?”

headline: How Cohen’s Testimony Sets the Stage for Trump’s Hush Money Trial
abstract: Michael D. Cohen, Donald J. Trump’s former fixer, was not an essential witness in Mr. Trump’s civil fraud trial this week. He will be when he takes the stand in a Manhattan criminal case.
lead_paragraph: As Michael D. Cohen prepared to take the stand at the civil fraud trial of Donald J. Trump this week, two women who shared an intense interest in his testimony slipped into the courtroom.

headline: Migrants Search for Beds as New York Quietly Stops Offering Them to All
abstract: “They want you to get tired so you give up, and they are achieving it,” said one migrant who has been searching for a place to stay in New York City for several days.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, Vinicius Funes, a 26-year-old migrant from Honduras, went in search of a bed.

headline: Minor Earthquake Under San Francisco’s Airport Rattles Nerves
abstract: The 3.7-magnitude quake was felt in the San Francisco Bay Area during the Friday evening rush. There were no immediate reports of injuries or damage.
lead_paragraph: A 3.7-magnitude earthquake hit San Francisco on Friday evening, with an epicenter under the city’s international airport, the United States Geological Survey said.

headline: Chapter 2: Chasing Dreams at a Steep Cost
abstract: She escaped an abusive betrothal, but her family’s reputation was suffering for it.
lead_paragraph: As Nasreen Parveen ran, her mind focused on nothing but putting one foot in front of the other.

headline: ‘The Berry Pickers’ Is a Harrowing Tale of Indigenous Family Separation
abstract: In Amanda Peters’s debut novel, a 4-year-old Mi’kmaw girl disappears one summer, prompting a lifelong saga of mystery and tragedy.
lead_paragraph: It is 1962 and a Mi’kmaw family crosses from Nova Scotia into Maine to harvest berries as migrant workers. Once they arrive, everything falls into a summer rhythm, but one afternoon, the family’s youngest, 4-year-old Ruthie, disappears. Her brother Joe is the last to see her, which will haunt him for the rest of his life. As he grows up, more tragedies befall him: After witnessing the murder of his brother, he emotionally spirals, feeling that he is bad luck to his family, which leads him first to the bottle, then to an accident that disables him and to an act of violence that causes him to leave the life he knows behind.

headline: Weddings at the Edge of the World
abstract: How far would you go for your wedding? These adventurous couples trekked to Mount Everest base camp, skied down the Rockies and swam in the Cozumel Channel to say “I do.”
lead_paragraph: To reach their wedding venue, Austin O’Reilly and Iulia O’Reilly crossed a swaying suspension bridge, trying not to glance down at the glacial river below. With each step, the bridge shook under the weight of people and yaks. Mr. O’Reilly, 25, had seen similar bridges in the 2015 movie “Everest.” Now, he was on that titular mountain with his fiancée: walking a precarious bridge, crossing jagged moraines and traversing rocky terrain on a nine-day trek to the Everest base camp.

headline: ‘Annika’ Star Nicola Walker on the Book She’d Save From a Burning Home
abstract: When it comes to the actress’s favorite things, give her the American version of “Alone” and a true-crime podcast from Australia.
lead_paragraph: No one broods quite like Nicola Walker, whose eyes have transfixed viewers in television shows like “Unforgotten,” “Last Tango in Halifax” and “The Split.”

headline: Is It Time to Pull Up Stakes and Head for Mars?
abstract: Probably not, Kelly and Zach Weinersmith argue in “A City on Mars.”
lead_paragraph: Face it, folks. Earth is finished. It’s overheated, overcrowded, overregulated. It’s the ultimate fixer-upper, a dump we inherited from our parents that we’d be cruel to pass on to our children. It’s time to pull up stakes. It’s time for Mars.

headline: Practical Magic: The Lucrative Business of Being a Witch on Etsy and TikTok
abstract: Modern witches no longer lurk in dark alleys or operate out of the back rooms of stores, you can instead buy their services online for a pretty penny or two.
lead_paragraph: When Maira Khan’s boyfriend left her last year, she was desperate to win him back. “I knew he was seeing someone else, but I didn’t know how serious it was,” said Ms. Khan, an influencer in Toronto. “I kind of just wanted her gone.”

headline: Joey Evans Is Back. This Time He’s a Struggling Artist.
abstract: A new “Pal Joey” at City Center has reimagined the never-quite-satisfying script to make Joey (Ephraim Sykes) a forward-thinking Black jazz singer.
lead_paragraph: Joey Evans is a charming cad, a heel, an unapologetic womanizer, a gigolo. He’s a second-rate nightclub entertainer who breaks the heart of an ingénue and seduces a rich older woman, trading sex for money.

headline: TikTok’s Finest Lobsterman
abstract: A new crop of popular social media personalities includes a trucker, a shepherd and a commercial fisherman. What they earn from sponsorships is just a nice bonus.
lead_paragraph: It was another busy day for the crew of the Rest-Ashoar, a lobster fishing boat that works the waters off the rocky coast of Winter Harbor, Maine. The captain, Jacob Knowles, had gotten up at 3 a.m. on a brisk October morning and took his vessel 10 miles into the ocean.

headline: A.I. Muddies Israel-Hamas War in Unexpected Way
abstract: Fakes related to the conflict have been limited and largely unconvincing, but their presence has people doubting real evidence.
lead_paragraph: It was a gruesome image that shot rapidly around the internet: a charred body, described as a deceased child, that was apparently photographed in the opening days of the conflict between Israel and Hamas.

headline: If Short-Term Rentals Are Illegal, How Does My Neighbor Get Away With It?
abstract: Most co-ops require shareholders to comply with local laws and regulations, not just their own rules.
lead_paragraph: Q: I live in a midsize co-op building in the West Village. A rent-stabilized tenant on the first floor had listed a room in her apartment on Airbnb for years, until such rentals were prohibited. We also registered our building on the city’s prohibited buildings list. Her Airbnb listing was removed, but she continues to rent out a room (or the whole apartment, we’re not sure) on Facebook Marketplace. We’ve shared this information with the apartment’s sponsor and several others in our building. The sponsor hasn’t told the tenant to stop this illegal practice. What rights does the co-op have here? Can we evict the tenant, or take action against the sponsor?

headline: A Night of Reading, Cover to Uncover
abstract: The author of “On Fire Island” wasn’t sure what to expect when she was invited to appear at a “Books & Burlesque” event. Here’s her unblushing report.
lead_paragraph: Early in the summer, an unusual email popped up in my inbox. Sandwiched between a podcast request and an offer to speak at a South Florida chapter of Hadassah was an invitation to read an excerpt from my latest novel, “On Fire Island,” at a “Books & Burlesque” evening on Manhattan’s Lower East Side. The event, as the show’s producers Fortune Cookie and Rosie Tulips explained, would feature five writers reading, each paired with a burlesque or drag artist creating an act inspired by the author’s work.

headline: ‘A Bright Light in a Dark Time’: A New School for Uvalde
abstract: More than a year after a mass shooting at Robb Elementary School, the community broke ground on a new campus.
lead_paragraph: In the year since a teenage gunman strode into Robb Elementary School in Uvalde and killed 19 fourth graders and two teachers, the building has stood empty, its windows boarded over, its students dispersed to other campuses with little chance to maintain the bonds they once shared.

headline: When Your Age, and Everyone Else’s, Is Showing
abstract: Colleagues of different generations can bridge age gaps. But first, they must ask some questions.
lead_paragraph: Send questions about the office, money, careers and work-life balance to workfriend@nytimes.com. Include your name and location, or a request to remain anonymous. Letters may be edited.

headline: With Fans Ever More Fickle, Sports Leagues Warm to Rule Changes
abstract: Baseball’s pitch clock is just one example of how professional sports are competing for public attention in an ever-evolving entertainment world.
lead_paragraph: Texas Rangers fans are hoping the slugger Adolis Garcia can blast the franchise to its first World Series title. Arizona supporters know the Diamondbacks need to continue being greedy on the basepaths if they’re to capture a second championship. Everyone else watching has already won, thanks to a pitch clock, bigger bases and a made-over American pastime that is faster and more balletic and gets them to bed earlier.

headline: Meg Ryan Wrestles With the Rom-Com
abstract: She always had concerns about the happily-ever-after ideals of the genre. Now as a director she’s pushing its boundaries to examine issues of aging and regret.
lead_paragraph: Meg Ryan was hurting.

headline: Writing ‘Maid’ Pulled Stephanie Land Out of Poverty. She’s Fine Now, Right?
abstract: Despite writing a best seller that became a hit Netflix series, Ms. Land says she still worries about her job security.
lead_paragraph: What do you do with the money you earn from a story you wrote about not having much for too many years?

headline: The ‘Silver Lining to the Pandemic’ for Working Mothers
abstract: The share of women working has reached a record high, with the biggest increases among mothers of children under 5.
lead_paragraph: The share of American women working for pay is at a record high. According to a recent analysis, the surge has been led by an unexpected group: mothers of children under 5.

headline: The World Is Becoming More African
abstract: Africa has the fastest growing, youngest population of any continent. By 2050, one in four people on the planet will be African. Early tremors of this seismic change are already registering around the world.
lead_paragraph: Africa has the fastest growing, youngest population of any continent. By 2050, one in four people on the planet will be African. Early tremors of this seismic change are already registering around the world.

headline: Top 10 Hardest and Easiest Spelling Bee Words, Oct. 21-27
abstract: This week’s toughest challenge may have been a little bombastic.
lead_paragraph: Note: If you plan to play Spelling Bee’s Past Puzzles from the last week, this list may contain spoilers.

headline: The Real End of David Chang’s Momofuku Ko Happened Years Ago
abstract: The revolutionary tasting-menu restaurant eventually came to resemble the fine-dining titans it tried to dethrone.
lead_paragraph: David Chang is “pausing operations” at Momofuku Ko next week, according to a post on his company’s Instagram account. It goes on: “we won’t call this a goodbye, but ko will no longer operate in the way it has.”

headline: The House G.O.P Has Its Leader. But Can He Be a Rainmaker?
abstract: The former speaker, Kevin McCarthy, was a prolific fund-raiser for his House colleagues. The new speaker, Mike Johnson, doesn’t yet have the same juice.
lead_paragraph: The decision to oust Kevin McCarthy as speaker and replace him with a little-known congressman, Mike Johnson of Louisiana, has left a glaring financial gap for House Republicans headed into 2024 when the party has to defend its narrow and fragile majority.

headline: Desperate for Air Defense, Ukraine Pushes U.S. for ‘Franken’ Weapons
abstract: To meet the demand, the U.S. is producing so-called FrankenSAM systems that marry advanced Western weaponry with Soviet-era items still in Ukrainian stockpiles.
lead_paragraph: With winter approaching, Ukrainian officials are desperate for more air defenses to protect their power grids from Russian strikes that could plunge the country into freezing darkness.

headline: Ghostly Presence
abstract: In a time when everything’s gone virtual, Halloween costumes represent an old-fashioned commitment to the physical world.
lead_paragraph: Tombstones are planted in the flower beds. A witch appears to have flown into a tree and is suspended there, broom sticking out from the trunk. An undead crone, motion sensitive, accosts passers-by from the hedge. On my otherwise very quiet, very nothing-to-see-here Brooklyn block, there’s a lot to see this time of year. I arrive home to tourists taking pictures with the skeletons.

headline: Lured by Federal Dollars, Canadian Cities Rethink Zoning
abstract: Major Canadian cities are opening up development zoning to include fourplexes in exchange for federal funds to build housing.
lead_paragraph: Fourplexes, multiunit dwellings that are relatively rare in Canada — a country where detached homes dominate residential streets — appear set to become more prominent in major cities. The lure of federal cash to build housing is causing many municipalities to bend staunch zoning rules that once prohibited fourplexes.

headline: As China Looks to Broker Gaza Peace, Antisemitism Surges Online
abstract: China’s state-run media has blamed the United States for deepening the crisis, while perpetuating tropes of Jewish control of American politics.
lead_paragraph: As the Israel-Hamas conflict intensifies, raising the prospect of a wider war, China has stepped up efforts to pitch itself as a neutral broker for Mideast peace.

headline: Listen Early to ‘This American Life’: And the Call Was Coming From the Basement
abstract: Zombie raccoons, David Sedaris and haunted houses.
lead_paragraph: For the lead-up to Halloween, scary stories that are all true. Zombie raccoons, real haunted houses and things that go “EEEEK!!!” in the night. Plus, a story by David Sedaris, in which he walks among the dead.

headline: Improving Treatments for Children With Cancer
abstract: Readers, including Christie Brinkley, discuss a column by Pamela Paul about the lifelong health issues these children face.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: A Tech Overlord’s Horrifying, Silly Vision for Who Should Rule the World
abstract: It’s no mystery why Marc Andreessen thinks people like him should be in charge. But how did he get so many of the rest of us to sign on?
lead_paragraph: It takes a certain kind of person to write grandiose manifestoes for public consumption, unafflicted by self-doubt or denuded of self-interest. The latest example is Marc Andreessen, a co-founder of the top-tier venture capital firm Andreessen Horowitz and best known, to those of us who came of age before TikTok, as a co-founder of the pioneering internet browser Netscape. In “The Techno-Optimist Manifesto,” a recent 5,000-plus-word post on the Andreessen Horowitz website, Mr. Andreessen outlines a vision of technologists as the authors of a future in which the “techno-capital machine” produces everything that is good in the world.

headline: A Dispatch From the Muslim Girl Scouts of Astoria
abstract: A young activist in Queens supports Palestinian aspirations.
lead_paragraph: In her short 17 years on earth, Amira Ismail had never been called a baby killer.

headline: A Man Orphaned by Hamas Calls on Israel: Stop the ‘Cycle of Blood’
abstract: Nicholas Kristof reports from Tel Aviv.
lead_paragraph: Maoz Inon last spoke with his 78-year-old father and 75-year-old mother on Oct. 7, shortly before they were murdered by Hamas. In this audio essay, he tells Nicholas Kristof why he wants a cease-fire in Gaza.

headline: There Is Another Paris
abstract: With a little bit of time and patience, you can still find it.
lead_paragraph: Tourists visiting the Sacré-Coeur Basilica, the magnificent snow-white cathedral towering over northern Paris, tend to descend the Butte Montmartre the way they came up. After visiting the church, they might make a stop at the Place du Tertre, the historic square of Montmartre encircled by restaurants promising authentic French cuisine at unauthentically French prices. They might admire the dozens of street artists churning out quick sketches of passers-by and peddling hastily made watercolors. They might even jostle to the edge of the square to sneak a final glance at the city from one of its highest points. But once they’ve had enough, they’ll most likely make their way down the south side of the hill, following the path of the funicular toward the recognizable sights of central Paris.

headline: I Fought for the I.D.F. in Gaza. It Made Me Fight for Peace.
abstract: An Israeli veteran reflects on his experience the last time Israeli troops entered Gaza in force.
lead_paragraph: When my Israeli infantry unit arrived at the first village in Gaza, in July 2014, we cleared houses by sending grenades through windows, blowing doors open and firing bullets into rooms to avoid ambush and booby traps. We were told Palestinian civilians had fled.

headline: Fitting Race in a Box
abstract: We explain what the next census could look like.
lead_paragraph: [This article is also a weekly newsletter. Sign up for Race/Related here.]

headline: The Victory Hamas Has Already Won
abstract: When barbarity has a revolutionary logic.
lead_paragraph: In 2014, a new state was formed in the heart of the Middle East. It had a capital, a government, an army and almost 12 million subjects — a larger population than Jordan or Israel. It also had a commitment to butchery, savagery and fanatical violence that quickly earned it the enmity of the entire civilized world.

headline: America’s Disaster Recovery System Is a Disaster
abstract: The help Americans receive after disasters isn’t just inadequate; it’s complicated to navigate and painfully slow to arrive.
lead_paragraph: This summer, 12 people let me into their lives to tell me about their experiences in the aftermath of disasters, including hurricanes, floods, freezes, wildfires and derechos. All said, they did not receive the aid they expected, and the effects have been devastating. “It’s been a very humbling experience, to say the least, to go from ‘We’re fine, we just got a new house, we have a huge savings, biggest we’ve ever had’ to ‘You have nothing and you lost everything and you have to go to food pantries for food,’” said Aleasha LeClere, whose life was turned upside down by a 2020 derecho in Iowa. According to research on disasters and advocacy groups, these survivors’ experiences are very much the norm.

headline: ‘We Are Overpaying the Price for a Sin We Didn’t Commit’
abstract: Israel has every right to defend itself and fight terrorists. But is this really the best way?
lead_paragraph: The most consequential decision Israel will face in the coming days is how hard to continue hitting Gaza. Should it undertake a monthslong ground invasion? Continue with large-scale aerial bombardment? Allow fuel into Gaza to keep hospitals running?

headline: Gaza’s Tunnels Loom Large for Israel’s Ground Forces
abstract: Hamas is believed to hide weapons, fighters and even command centers in miles of subterranean pathways and chambers.
lead_paragraph: Just after midnight on Tuesday, the Israel Defense Forces announced that they had struck a tunnel that allowed Hamas to “infiltrate Israel through the sea.”

headline: Two Books for a Mental Vacation
abstract: Madeleine L’Engle’s domestic memoir; Julie Orringer’s humane short stories
lead_paragraph: Dear readers,

headline: Is Crypto Financing Terrorism?
abstract: A report that terror groups raised more than $130 million in crypto during recent years has set off a debate in Washington and finance circles.
lead_paragraph: The United States will go after cryptocurrency firms that fail to stop terrorist groups from moving money, the U.S. deputy Treasury secretary, Wally Adeyemo, warned on Friday.

headline: In Michigan, Muslim and Arab American Voters Reconsider Support for Biden
abstract: Many in the swing state say they feel betrayed by the president’s support for Israel.
lead_paragraph: Sam Baydoun, a Wayne County commissioner in Dearborn, Mich., has been glued to Al Jazeera for weeks to absorb news from the war in Israel and Gaza.

headline: Biden’s Israel Ties Rooted in Long Career: ‘From His Gut to His Heart to His Head’
abstract: The president’s “unwavering support” for Israel stems from childhood dinner table conversations and half a century of trips to the Jewish state. But it puts him at odds with some in his own party.
lead_paragraph: One morning during a spasm of violence two decades ago, with suicide bombings shattering Israel every other day, the King David Hotel in Jerusalem seemed eerily empty. Foreigners were staying away. Nobody was in the dining room. Except for two people having breakfast: Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr. and his aide, Antony J. Blinken.

headline: Residents Awaiting Help Resort to Looting in Acapulco
abstract: Military planes carrying food and water have begun to arrive in Acapulco, Mexico, but residents say the aid is not enough after Hurricane Otis caused widespread destruction.
lead_paragraph: Military planes carrying food and water have begun to arrive in Acapulco, Mexico, but residents say the aid is not enough after Hurricane Otis caused widespread destruction.

headline: CUNY Halts Investigation of Alzheimer’s Researcher
abstract: Citing questions about the integrity of the process, the university said that “no final action” had been taken.
lead_paragraph: The City University of New York is pausing its investigation into a faculty member, an Alzheimer’s researcher accused of misconduct, the university said in a statement on Friday.

headline: Joanna Merlin, Known for Her Work Both Onstage and Off, Dies at 92
abstract: Soon after appearing in the original Broadway production of “Fiddler on the Roof,” she began a new career as a prominent casting director.
lead_paragraph: Joanna Merlin, who, after originating the role of Tzeitel, the eldest daughter, in the hit Broadway musical “Fiddler on the Roof,” became a renowned casting director, notably for Stephen Sondheim musicals including “Into the Woods” and “Follies,” died on Oct. 15 at her younger daughter’s home in Los Angeles. She was 92.

headline: Pleas for Aid and a Scramble for Supplies in Acapulco After Hurricane Otis
abstract: Days after the storm, the death toll rose to 39 and residents were navigating broken glass, searching for water and food, and trying to find loved ones. Many said the government was not doing enough.
lead_paragraph: The tourists were bused out of Acapulco to find relief as far away as Mexico’s capital. But thousands of residents were left behind to deal with the chaos and destruction of Hurricane Otis, which had turned their paradise into a wasteland.

headline: Kremlin’s Onetime Pick to Be Ukraine’s Puppet Leader Is Shot in Crimea
abstract: Oleg Tsaryov, a pro-Russian businessman and former lawmaker, was said to have been wounded in the attack. Moscow had planned to set him up as head of government in Kyiv if its invasion had succeeded.
lead_paragraph: A Ukrainian former lawmaker whom the Kremlin had handpicked to lead a puppet administration in Kyiv, Ukraine, was shot and wounded in occupied Crimea in an apparent assassination attempt, Ukrainian and Russian officials said on Saturday.

headline: The Main Problem With Pedestrian Deaths Isn’t the Pedestrians
abstract: When drivers rule the road, irresponsibility becomes fatal.
lead_paragraph: I want to talk about two things that have happened since last weekend’s newsletter on pedestrian deaths. One of them was covered in this newspaper, and the other was a personal experience.

headline: Green Beans With Plenty of Texture and Spice
abstract: The almond butter in Priya Krishna’s clever new sabzi makes for an almost tempura-like coating.
lead_paragraph: You can never have too many green bean or broccoli recipes. These two Kelly green vegetables are present at every grocery store, have a subtle sweetness and lend themselves well to all manner of cooking: roasting, steaming, blanching, or even raw. Priya Krishna’s new green bean and potato sabzi is an excellent addition to your green bean repertoire. In a clever twist, Priya uses almond butter to give the veggies an almost tempura-like coating, and a dusting of chaat masala gives the finished dish a tart, salty sparkle. You could tuck this recipe into your broccoli folder as well: The florets may need an extra minute or two of cook time, but they make an excellent sub for the green beans.

headline: Iranian Teenager Dies Weeks After Mysterious Collapse
abstract: The death of Armita Geravand comes after word of her injuries fueled outrage because she was so young and because of previous cases in which women have been brutalized for protesting dress codes.
lead_paragraph: Armita Geravand, a 16-year-old Iranian high school student, has died weeks after she collapsed and fell into a coma following what many believe was an encounter over not covering her hair in public.

headline: Is It OK to Hire a Surrogate to Bear Twins?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on the financial realities of family planning.
lead_paragraph: My husband and I want to have children, and as a gay couple, we think that surrogacy is our most realistic option. Surrogacy, however, is expensive. It could easily cost between $150,000 and $200,000 per pregnancy. We could afford two rounds, but this would deplete nearly all our savings. We are well-off, but don’t come from especially affluent backgrounds, and it took a long time to accumulate these savings. These savings, in part, are for our future retirement too.

headline: Gunman in Maine Mass Shooting Had Paranoid Beliefs, Officials Say
abstract: The man was found dead on Friday night, ending a two-day manhunt. The police said he had legally purchased several guns, including in recent days.
lead_paragraph: The man who killed 18 people and wounded 13 more in Lewiston, Maine, the deadliest mass shooting in America this year, had paranoid beliefs that people were talking about him, and he may have been hearing voices, the authorities said on Saturday.

headline: Haley Offers Scathing Critique of Trump at Jewish Republican Event in Las Vegas
abstract: At the annual Republican Jewish Coalition gathering, G.O.P. leaders are seizing political opportunities in the divisions that the conflict has opened up at home.
lead_paragraph: A series of speeches by Republican presidential candidates on Saturday to a large gathering of Jewish donors and activists demonstrated how the escalating conflict in the Middle East has elevated foreign policy into a dominant campaign issue and exposed fresh divides within the primary contest.

headline: Vocal on Israel, DeSantis Is Challenged on His Silence on Neo-Nazis in Florida
abstract: One of the governor’s closest Jewish allies in the state publicly switched his support to Donald J. Trump, citing past incidents.
lead_paragraph: As Israel’s war against Hamas has become an animating force in the Republican presidential primary, Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida has cast himself as a staunch defender of the Jewish state, sending taxpayer-funded charter flights to rescue Americans stranded in Israel, calling for harsh measures against the civilians of Gaza and ordering pro-Palestinian groups on public university campuses in his state to disband.

headline: ‘You Think of Dying at Any Time’
abstract: Gaza residents say Israeli airstrikes come mostly without warning and hit indiscriminately, leading to the feeling that death is imminent and inevitable.
lead_paragraph: Nayrouz Qarmout, a Palestinian author who lives in the Gaza Strip, recalled that during past wars with Israel, Gazans would feel extreme pangs of fear when they heard explosions, but afterward hope would return. Hope of cease-fires, and of life going on.

headline: Israel Says Al Shifa Hospital Conceals Hamas Underground Command Centers
abstract: The group denies the accusation, saying Israel has offered “fabricated” evidence.
lead_paragraph: To people in Gaza, Al Shifa is the biggest and most advanced hospital around — a lifeline, in normal times, and now a place of refuge from relentless Israeli airstrikes.

headline: Two Plead Guilty in Alabama Riverfront Brawl
abstract: A man and a woman pleaded guilty on Friday to charges related to an attack on a Black boat captain that garnered widespread attention and backlash on social media.
lead_paragraph: More than two months after a group of white boaters attacked a Black riverboat captain in Montgomery, Ala., two of five people charged in connection with the racially charged melee pleaded guilty on Friday.

headline: Pence Bows Out of 2024 Presidential Race That Trump Is Dominating
abstract: The former vice president said he would end his bid in a surprise announcement at a gathering of Jewish Republican donors. “It’s become clear to me that this is not my time,” he said.
lead_paragraph: Former Vice President Mike Pence, who spent four years dutifully serving President Donald J. Trump but refused to carry out Mr. Trump’s demand that he block the 2020 election results, ended his presidential bid on Saturday, with a final appeal for his party to return to conservative principles and resist the “siren song of populism.”

headline: U.A.W. Reaches Tentative Deal With Stellantis, Following Ford
abstract: The United Automobile Workers union announced the deal with Stellantis, the parent of Chrysler, Jeep and Ram. It also expanded its strike against G.M.
lead_paragraph: The United Automobile Workers union announced on Saturday that it had reached a tentative agreement on a new labor contract with Stellantis, the parent company of Chrysler, Jeep and Ram.

headline: ‘Lewiston Strong’: After Mass Shooting, Residents Emerge With Grit
abstract: After two long days of being locked down amid the manhunt for a gunman who killed 18 people, the small city in Maine started to come back to life, forever changed.
lead_paragraph: On a sparkling October morning, with peak fall foliage blazing red and yellow, the residents of Lewiston emerged from two long days of lockdown on Saturday into a city forever changed.

headline: At Least 32 Killed in Vehicle Pileup in Egypt
abstract: Several cars caught fire after a passenger bus and several vehicles collided on a main road north of Cairo, injuring more than 60 other people, state media reported.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — At least 32 people were killed and 63 others injured on Saturday morning in Egypt after a passenger bus and several vehicles collided about 82 miles north of the capital, Cairo, the health ministry said.

headline: Israeli Approach to Ground War in Gaza Aligns with U.S. Advice, Officials Say
abstract: The initial decision to undertake limited ground incursions rather than a full-scale invasion appears to follow guidance from top U.S. military officials.
lead_paragraph: Israel’s apparent decision to hold off on a full-scale invasion of the Gaza Strip and instead conduct more limited ground incursions, at least initially, aligns with suggestions that the U.S. defense secretary, Lloyd J. Austin III, made to his Israeli counterparts in recent days, American officials said on Saturday.

headline: Fabric-ations
abstract: Alina Abidi whips up a cozy Sunday puzzle debut.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme

headline: Fisherman Last Sighted Two Weeks Ago Rescued at Sea
abstract: A fishing vessel with two aboard left Washington State on Oct. 12 and was reported missing on Sunday. On Thursday, one of the men was rescued, officials said.
lead_paragraph: Canadian fishermen help hoist a man wearing a green hat and a blue plaid shirt onto a Canadian Coast Guard rescue boat that has pulled alongside them. As the man steadies himself, he turns around and says, “Thanks a lot guys,” then waves as the Coast Guard boat pulls away.

headline: Israel-Hamas War Enters ‘Second Stage,’ Netanyahu Says
abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel did not describe the ground incursion as an invasion, but it was accompanied by an enormous aerial and artillery bombardment.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said in a televised news conference on Saturday that Israel’s forces had entered the Gaza Strip, calling it his country’s “second war of independence” and warning Israelis to expect a “long and difficult” campaign to eradicate Hamas.

headline: Vatican Deems Bigger Church Role for Women ‘Urgent,’ but Postpones Major Issues
abstract: Progressives who once hoped that the synod would create momentum for things like reaching out to L.G.B.T.Q.+ Catholics said the meeting had failed to move the institution.
lead_paragraph: A monthlong meeting convened by Pope Francis to determine the future of the Roman Catholic Church ended Saturday night with a document that said it was “urgent” that women have a larger role but postponed discussion of major issues such as ordaining women as deacons and failed to address outreach to L.G.B.T.Q.+ Catholics.

headline: Maine Sheriff Says He Sent Statewide Alert About Gunman Last Month
abstract: The sheriff said the gunman had made threats against the Army base where he was assigned, prompting an alert to all law enforcement agencies in the state weeks before the mass shooting.
lead_paragraph: A sheriff in Maine says he sent an alert to all law enforcement agencies in the state last month after learning that an Army reservist had made threats against his base, a notification that came weeks before the reservist fatally shot 18 people in America’s deadliest mass shooting this year.

headline: Protesters fill the streets in New York to support Palestinians in Gaza.
abstract: A large demonstration crossed the Brooklyn Bridge a day after Israel pushed into Gaza.
lead_paragraph: Crowds of pro-Palestinian demonstrators packed the streets of Brooklyn on Saturday as they called on the U.S. government to stop sending aid to Israel.

headline: Quotation of the Day: After Mexico Hurricane, a Frantic Hunt for Food, Water and Loved Ones
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, October 29, 2023.
lead_paragraph: “They loot because they want to eat.”

headline: Israel’s Hidden Victims, Arab Bedouins, Were Attacked by Hamas Too
abstract: At least 17 died in the Hamas attacks, and many more in the impoverished community have since lost their livelihoods in Jewish farms that were ransacked.
lead_paragraph: During their murderous Oct. 7 rampage, Hamas militants attacked Zikkim Beach near the Gaza Strip where Abd Alrahman Aatef Ziadna and his family had been camping along the coast of the Mediterranean Sea.

headline: A Less Polarized Poland? Not Yet, Election Results Suggest.
abstract: On whatever side they stand, many voters say they yearn for a more united nation. But after a brutal campaign, divisions — between left and right, urban and rural, young and old — remain stark.
lead_paragraph: Three years apart in age, the brother and sister grew up in a tiny village in eastern Poland, helping out on the family farm and going to church each Sunday under pressure from their parents.

headline: What’s on TV This Week: BravoCon and a Classic Rom-Com
abstract: Andy Cohen’s annual convention airs on Bravo, and HBO plays “Definitely, Maybe.”
lead_paragraph: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Oct. 30-Nov. 5. Details and times are subject to change.

headline: Matthew Perry, Star of ‘Friends,’ Is Dead at 54
abstract: He was known for playing the sarcastic but lovable Chandler Bing and for his struggles with drugs and alcohol, which he chronicled in a memoir.
lead_paragraph: Matthew Perry, who gained sitcom superstardom as Chandler Bing on the show “Friends,” becoming a model of the ability to tease your pals as an expression of love, has died. He was 54.

headline: ‘S.N.L.’ Elects Another President Biden
abstract: Mikey Day made his debut as the president in an episode that was hosted by the comic Nate Bargatze and featured Christopher Walken as the Spirit of Halloween.
lead_paragraph: Mikey Day became the latest “Saturday Night Live” cast member to take a turn at playing President Biden in an opening sketch that was nominally about a Halloween celebration at the White House, but was also a satirical commentary on whether or not Americans should have concerns about the president’s age.

headline: Today’s Wordle Review
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.

headline: The Connections Companion
abstract: In case you need some puzzle help.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

headline: A Critic With Monsters on His Mind
abstract: The scariest part of Erik Piepenburg’s job as a reporter who covers horror movies? Films that fail to frighten him.
lead_paragraph: Some 10-year-olds might shield their eyes while watching a horror movie. But at that age, Erik Piepenburg was glued to the screen.

headline: ‘I Decided I Needed a Slice of Junior’s Strawberry Cheesecake’
abstract: A long trip to satisfy a craving, a Greenwich Village walk and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:

headline: From Smugglers and TikTok, Migrants Get a Message: Go to New York
abstract: Many migrants entering the U.S. southern border have been steered to New York City by relatives, politicians and smugglers, in part because of the city’s right-to-shelter policy.
lead_paragraph: Mohamed was well along a zigzag journey from his native Mauritania in West Africa, not knowing precisely where he would wind up, and not caring — just as long as it was somewhere in the United States.

headline: A Seal of Recognition
abstract: A postage stamp issued in 2020 commemorated Gwen Ifill, a New York Times correspondent who covered the White House in the early ’90s.
lead_paragraph: New York Times journalists have received many honors. But recognition by way of U.S. postage stamps has proved elusive. It seems that only two people closely associated with The Times have been the subjects of commemorative stamps.

headline: One Year After Tragedy, a Subdued Halloween in Itaewon
abstract: The authorities in Seoul were out in force over the weekend, but the crowds in the typically bustling neighborhood were sparse.
lead_paragraph: Seoul marked a somber anniversary over the weekend, a year after nearly 160 people died in a crowd surge in Itaewon, a popular nightlife district in the city.

headline: Obama’s Presidential Center Is Rising, Finally, in Chicago
abstract: The city beat out others to host Barack Obama’s presidential center. But as construction continues on the South Side, some residents fear being priced out.
lead_paragraph: More than eight years have passed since Barack Obama proclaimed that his presidential center would be built on Chicago’s South Side, where he got his start as a community organizer and politician.

headline: Tug-of-War Over N.B.A. Rights Provides Glimpse of Media’s Future
abstract: The league’s longtime television partners, including ESPN and Turner, are undergoing major changes, which could alter how games are watched.
lead_paragraph: The National Basketball Association’s season tipped off on Tuesday with stars like LeBron James and Nikola Jokic beginning the long quest for a title. But the action that will have longer-term ramifications for the league, and the media and entertainment landscape, is happening off the court.

headline: A New Place to Learn Civics: The Workplace
abstract: Fearing that rising distrust could spell doom for businesses, some companies are offering employees lessons in democracy.
lead_paragraph: A peaceful end to the war in Ukraine. That was the wish behind a post that Simge Krüger made on LinkedIn in March.

headline: Dylan’s Back Pages, and Then Some
abstract: This collection of archival treasures at the Bob Dylan Center includes fan mail from Paul McCartney and Bruce Springsteen.
lead_paragraph: In 2016, the world learned that a new Bob Dylan Center was coming to Tulsa, Okla. Dylan said, “I’m glad that my archives, which have been collected all these years, have finally found a home and are to be included with the works of Woody Guthrie and especially alongside all the valuable artifacts from the Native American Nations.” “Bob Dylan: Mixing Up the Medicine” is the center’s official publication, a lavishly illustrated collection of archival treasures, edited by Mark Davidson and Parker Fishel. It also has new essays by a host of Dylan scholars, from artists like Ed Ruscha, Richard Hell and Lee Ranaldo to writers like Greil Marcus, Joy Harjo, Michael Ondaatje and Amanda Petrusich.

headline: Friends From Childhood. Brothers in War.
abstract: Three friends met as boys in western Ukraine. When Russia invaded, they enlisted in the same unit. There was comfort, and dread, in serving together.
lead_paragraph: At a gas station in western Ukraine, three men in their late 20s, friends since childhood, slid into plastic chairs. Exhausted and anxious, they began to sing.

headline: Reaction to Hamas Attack Leaves Some Jews in Hollywood Feeling Unmoored
abstract: The response to the Oct. 7 assault, and to Israel’s retaliation, has revealed a schism in the entertainment world that many did not realize was there.
lead_paragraph: With the exception of the rare conservative, Hollywood has long seemed to exist in an ideological bubble — a bastion of progressive politics, where Jewish people have thrived, Democratic politicians have been celebrated and stars have espoused liberal ideas from the Oscar stage and rushed to support movements like Black Lives Matter.

headline: Halloween Headaches in Salem, Mass.: Traffic. Crowds. Tiny Liquor Bottles?
abstract: Miniature bottles of alcohol known as “nips” litter gardens, parks and playgrounds, prompting the Witch City to propose a ban.
lead_paragraph: The list of public nuisances in Salem, Mass., in high Halloween season is long and weird: Rowdy crowds imperiling 17th-century gravestones. Unlicensed fortune tellers. Skirmishes over parking spaces at Gallows Hill or the Museum of Torture.

headline: Halloween Shoppers Not Spooked as Economic Slowdown Remains Elusive
abstract: From apple picking to skeleton cows, early seasonal spending seems solid. It’s the latest sign that Federal Reserve policy to combat inflation hasn’t slowed growth.
lead_paragraph: Economists spent much of 2023 warning that a recession could be imminent as the Federal Reserve raised interest rates to the highest level in more than two decades. But for companies like Soergel Orchards in western Pennsylvania, a slowdown is nowhere in sight.

headline: How California Became America’s Contemporary Music Capital
abstract: On the eve of a sprawling new festival, John Adams, Esa-Pekka Salonen, Gustavo Dudamel and others recount how the state reinvigorated classical music.
lead_paragraph: Nobody will be able to take in the entire California Festival, a statewide series of classical music events spanning 650 miles with such density that some nights will have 10 or more performances happening at once.

headline: The Rigid World of French Cheesemaking Meets Unbound Climate Change
abstract: Reams of rules govern how the best French cheeses are made, but hotter, drier summers may unshackle struggling producers.
lead_paragraph: Just past the neat vineyards and country houses with their blue shutters and tile roofs, goats munch their way through a field of thigh-high plants more typical to Sudan and India than Southern France.

headline: Marina Abramovic Thinks the Pain of Love Is Hell on Earth
abstract: “I don’t see any good art made out of happiness,” says the legendary performance artist.
lead_paragraph: “I don’t see any good art made out of happiness,” says the legendary performance artist.

headline: Why Illegal Border Crossings Are at Sustained Highs
abstract: Shifting U.S. policies, global migration patterns and changing migrant demographics all contribute to record levels of border crossings.
lead_paragraph: Shifting U.S. policies, global migration patterns and changing migrant demographics all contribute to record levels of border crossings.

headline: Primary Battles Brew Over Progressive Democrats’ Stances on Israel
abstract: Representative Summer Lee of Pennsylvania, who joined calls for a cease-fire, has become one of several progressive lawmakers facing new pressure from primary challengers.
lead_paragraph: As Congregation Beth Shalom in Pittsburgh observed a special evening of prayer on Oct. 22 for the Israeli captives in Gaza, Representative Summer Lee, the progressive Democrat whose district includes the synagogue, paid her respects. She was late to arrive and could not stay long, but the rabbi, Seth Adelson, called her chief of staff the next day to offer his thanks.

headline: These Tiny, Beautiful Wasps Eat the Hearts Out of Cockroaches
abstract: Jewel wasps carve up cockroaches like jack-o’-lanterns in a way scientists have never seen before.
lead_paragraph: If you loathe cockroaches, you’re going to love the emerald jewel wasp.

headline: The Devil’s Bargain Mike Pence Could Not Escape
abstract: The former vice president tied himself to Donald Trump in the 2016 campaign and it may have cost him a political future.
lead_paragraph: The decision by Mike Pence to end his presidential campaign on Saturday was a bow to what had finally become inevitable. He was struggling to raise money, win support from the party’s base and manage the torments from the man who had made him nationally famous, Donald J. Trump.

headline: No, Xi Jinping Is Not About to Attack Taiwan
abstract: The Chinese leader still has plenty of reason to doubt whether seizing Taiwan is worth the risks.
lead_paragraph: To some observers, it may seem like Xi Jinping is itching to unify Taiwan with China.

headline: The City That Never Sleeps … or Shops in Person
abstract: New York is clogged with packages ordered by residents who buy online far more than they need to.
lead_paragraph: Walking through New York City — America’s great harborer of people, culture and activity — can feel like strolling the world’s largest outdoor mall. Opportunities to acquire are everywhere, waiting either around the corner or at the end of a subway ride: exotic foods, knickknacks, records, books, medicine, tents, computers, sunglasses and everything else. It’s difficult to imagine a product one can’t buy in Manhattan, let alone the boroughs.

headline: I’m a Pediatrician in Gaza. Please Save Us From This Horror.
abstract: There is still hope we can avoid the worst outcomes.
lead_paragraph: At Kamal Adwan Hospital in northern Gaza, we are no strangers to treating victims of airstrikes over the years. The team all too often must rush into the emergency room, all hands on deck, ready to treat shrapnel wounds, burns and blood loss. In the early days of the current Israel-Hamas conflict, our hospital of only 80 beds was quickly overrun. On Oct. 17, following the explosion at Al-Ahli Arab Hospital in Gaza City, we were flooded with dozens of wounded and dying victims. By the next day, our patient roster had grown by nearly 120. We knew it would be another sleepless night, another in a string of far too many since the violence started 10 days earlier.

headline: El Niños Are Predictable. We Should Prepare for Their Possibly Disastrous Consequences.
abstract: Rich countries must deepen their assistance to developing countries in the path of the weather pattern.
lead_paragraph: As we head toward winter, the good news for those who shiver at the thought of cold weather is that temperatures are likely to be warmer for people who live in the nation’s northern tier.

headline: Jenna Ellis Could Become a Star Witness Against Trump
abstract: She has given prosecutors a powerful tool.
lead_paragraph: When Jenna Ellis last week became the most recent lawyer to join in an accelerating series of guilty pleas in the Fulton County, Ga., prosecution of Donald Trump and his co-conspirators, she offered a powerful repudiation of the “Big Lie” that could potentially cut the legs out from under Donald Trump’s defense, make her a star witness for prosecutors and a potent weapon against the former president’s political ambitions.

headline: The Sunday Read: ‘Who Hired the Hitmen to Silence Zitácuaro?’
abstract: In one small Mexican city, journalists who tried to expose cartel violence and government corruption became swept up in the murders devouring the country.
lead_paragraph: On Oct. 19, 2021, Armando Linares López was writing up notes from an interview when his cellphone buzzed with an unknown number. Linares, 49 and stocky with black hair that was just starting to show gray streaks, ran an online news site in a small Mexican city called Zitácuaro. He knew his beat so intimately that calls from unfamiliar phone numbers were rare.

headline: Joe Biden Knows What He’s Doing
abstract: The combination of tragedy, confusion and cost is what makes leadership so difficult.
lead_paragraph: There’s a gathering sense that President Biden’s response to the war in Gaza may cost him the 2024 election. A recent Gallup poll showed that his support among Democrats has slipped 11 points in the past month to 75 percent, the lowest of his presidency. On Friday my colleagues in the newsroom reported on a growing backlash against Biden coming from young and left-leaning voters.

headline: In Kenya, King Charles Will ‘Walk a Tightrope’ on Britain’s Past
abstract: More candid than his mother, he is likely to acknowledge the monarchy’s brutal colonial history but avoid inviting calls for reparations.
lead_paragraph: When King Charles III travels to Kenya this week, it will be a journey steeped in family memory for Britain’s new monarch: In 1952, his mother, Elizabeth, had just spent the night at Treetops, a remote Kenyan game-viewing lodge, when she learned of the death of her father, George VI, which thrust her onto the throne.

headline: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Oct. 30, 2023
abstract: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
lead_paragraph: 1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:

headline: Israeli Troops in Gaza
abstract: The war’s “next stage” has started.
lead_paragraph: Israel announced it will attack Gaza from the air, land and sea, expanding its war against Hamas days after its tanks began an intense ground operation. The military again urged civilians to move south as troops have entered Gaza from the north (see where troops crossed the border).

headline: The Day Disco Was Demolished
abstract: “The War on Disco,” a new PBS documentary, explores the backlash against the genre and the issues of race, gender and sexuality that informed it.
lead_paragraph: The plan was simple enough: Gather a bunch of disco records, put them in a crate and blow them to smithereens in between games of a doubleheader between the Chicago White Sox and Detroit Tigers at Comiskey Park. What could possibly go wrong?

headline: Watch Matthew Perry’s Best Performances
abstract: Perry will always be remembered as Chandler Bing. But he had a long and varied career that included films and many other series.
lead_paragraph: Matthew Perry, who died Saturday at 54, was one of the biggest TV stars of the past three decades thanks to his role on “Friends,” the blockbuster NBC sitcom that continues to be enormously popular in the streaming era.

headline: Netanyahu Apologizes After Blaming Security Chiefs for Failure in Hamas Attack
abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who has not taken responsibility for Israel’s lapses in the Oct. 7 massacre, deleted a social media post in which he had pointed a finger at security agencies.
lead_paragraph: The rifts and disarray among Israel’s top leaders erupted into the open on Sunday when Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu appeared to blame the military and security establishment for the failures that led to the surprise Hamas assault on Oct. 7 — even as Israeli forces were broadening their ground war in Gaza.

headline: They Refused to Serve. Now They’re Supporting Israel’s War Effort.
abstract: The Brothers in Arms group helped lead protests against the government, with members vowing to ignore military call-ups. But after the Hamas attacks, it pivoted to aid those affected by the conflict.
lead_paragraph: Made up largely of veterans and reservists, the group that calls itself Brothers in Arms started nine months ago as a protest movement against the government of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. It helped to organize giant weekly demonstrations against his plans to give the government unprecedented control over the judiciary. And many of its members vowed that they would not serve in the army if called.

headline: A Chill in the Air and Chili in Your Pot
abstract: Turkey chili, chili con carne, black bean chili with mushrooms, white bean chili with lamb — our chili collection is comprehensive comfort.
lead_paragraph: Good morning. Chili season gets underway in my house after the first day I am well and truly chilled on my daily bike ride north along the harbor, wind whistling out of the west as if to knock me over. That sure wasn’t yesterday, not in New York!

headline: As Fighting Rages, Ukraine Takes Its Battle to the Diplomatic Arena
abstract: A forum in Malta was intended to encourage countries that have taken a neutral stance on the invasion of Ukraine not to side with Russia.
lead_paragraph: Dozens of countries met for a second day on Sunday at a forum in Malta intended to rally support for Ukraine and to encourage countries in Africa, Latin America and Asia that have taken a neutral stance in the conflict there not to side with Russia.

headline: An Anti-Obesity Drug and Cultural Stigmas
abstract: Readers discuss a column by Tressie McMillan Cottom. Also: Insights into Republican voters; a scandal at Liberty University; free analysis?
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Nazis in Canada? A Secret List With Answers May Soon Be Released.
abstract: A report from an inquiry into possible war criminals in Canada has been kept from the public for almost 40 years.
lead_paragraph: For 37 years, Canada has kept close guard on an explosive roster of names.

headline: Review: An Opera About Drones Brings a Pilot’s War Home
abstract: Jeanine Tesori and George Brant’s “Grounded,” which Washington National Opera premiered on Saturday, is headed to the Metropolitan Opera next year.
lead_paragraph: The young mezzo-soprano Emily D’Angelo has a wide grin, haunted eyes and a mellow, confident voice that flashes with lean anxiety. In tone and presence, she’s driven, intense, wry. Onstage she’s unsentimental — and unsettled.

headline: The One Without Matthew Perry
abstract: Even as he struggled with drug and alcohol addiction, the “Friends” star Matthew Perry, who died at the age of 54, made it all look easy.
lead_paragraph: A confession: When I received a news alert that the actor Matthew Perry had died, my mind adopted the particular cadence that Perry perfected as Chandler Bing, the character he played for 10 seasons on the NBC sitcom “Friends.” Here is what I thought, “Could this be any sadder?”

headline: Film Based on Horror-Survival Video Game Is Surprise Box Office Hit
abstract: “Five Nights at Freddy’s,” which sold an estimated $78 million in tickets at North American theaters, reinforced moviegoers’ desire for something other than a sequel.
lead_paragraph: An evil pizzeria mascot, Freddy Fazbear, became a surprise box office sensation over the weekend, reinforcing a message that moviegoers have been sending to Hollywood all year: Give us something new.

headline: Colleagues and Friends Mourn Actor Matthew Perry
abstract: Fans and celebrities paid tribute to Perry, who died at age 54 on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: Celebrities, actors and entertainment and political leaders shared tributes to Matthew Perry, who starred on the hit television series “Friends” and died on Saturday at the age of 54.

headline: Anthony Vidler, Architectural Historian Who Reshaped His Field, Dies at 82
abstract: He reached beyond conventional history to bring in perspectives from literary theory, philosophy and psychoanalysis.
lead_paragraph: Anthony Vidler, an architectural historian who, beginning in the 1960s, reshaped his field by setting aside dry chronologies of styles and movements for an interdisciplinary approach borrowing from psychoanalysis, French literary theory and cultural studies, died on Oct. 19 at his home in Manhattan. He was 82.

headline: Back-to-Back Premieres Defy a Season of Leaner Offerings
abstract: Institutions are cutting back, but in corners of the city there is still new music to be found, like song cycles by Ted Hearne and Paul Pinto.
lead_paragraph: New York classical music institutions are in a period of economic challenges. This season, the Metropolitan Opera is dark more nights than in the past. At the Brooklyn Academy of Music, the historic Next Wave Festival is a shadow of its former self.

headline: Robert Brustein, Passionate Force in Nonprofit Theater, Dies at 96
abstract: A critic and dramatist himself, he started repertory companies at Yale and Harvard and fiercely defended the art form, even if it meant feuding with playwrights.
lead_paragraph: Robert Brustein, an erudite and contentious advocate for profit-indifferent theater, in the service of which he wore many hats — critic, teacher, producer, director, playwright and even actor — died on Sunday at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 96.

headline: Colombia Mobilizes Troops to Search for Kidnapped Father of Liverpool Player
abstract: The parents of Luis Díaz, a Colombian star of the English club, were both kidnapped on Saturday. His mother was rescued hours later, but his father remains missing.
lead_paragraph: The authorities in Colombia have mobilized the national police and the military to look for the father of the soccer star Luis Díaz, a Colombian standout for the English club Liverpool whose parents were kidnapped in his hometown on Saturday. Given soccer’s popularity here, the incident captured the South American country’s attention, but it also stoked fears of increasing insecurity in a nation where such kidnappings were becoming less common until a surge in recent years.

headline: Maine Gunman Disclosed He Had Mental Health Issues, Gun Shop Owner Says
abstract: The man sought to purchase a gun suppressor in August, but was denied the item after he reported mental health issues on a federal form, the gun store owner said.
lead_paragraph: Nearly three months before Robert R. Card II fatally shot 18 people in Lewiston, Maine, a gun shop declined to let him complete his purchase of a firearm sound suppressor after he disclosed on a form that he had mental health issues, the shop’s owner said in an interview Sunday.

headline: 34 Hours of Fear: The Blackout That Cut Gaza Off From the World
abstract: As Israeli forces entered Gaza on Friday to fight Hamas, phone and internet service was severed, sowing chaos for Palestinian civilians and leaving rescuers driving blindly toward explosions.
lead_paragraph: For 34 hours, the vast majority of the more than two million Palestinians who live in Gaza had no way to reach the outside world, or one another.

headline: Netanyahu Finds Himself at War in Gaza and at Home
abstract: Israel’s prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, apologized for accusing military and security officials of lapses that led to the Hamas massacre but declined to accept responsibility himself.
lead_paragraph: Follow live updates on the Israel-Hamas war and Gaza.

headline: Monday Briefing: Israel Extends Gaza Ground Campaign
abstract: Plus as the world ages, Africa blooms with youth.
lead_paragraph: The Israeli military yesterday signaled a heavier assault on Gaza and warned with increasing “urgency” that Palestinian civilians should move to the southern part of the coastal Gaza Strip.

headline: The Israeli Officials I Speak With Tell Me They Know Two Things for Sure
abstract: Hamas will never again govern Gaza, and Israel will not govern a post-Hamas Gaza.
