lead_paragraph: After touring several retirement communities, Marta Genoni winnowed the field to two appealing possibilities not far from the home she shared with her husband, Kenneth, a lawyer, in Westfield, N.J. But unable to make a final decision she asked her elder daughter, a college administrator in Richmond, Va., to come north and weigh in.

headline: I Was Trying to Build My Son’s Resilience, Not Scar Him for Life
abstract: Nine hundred feet up a rock, I began to question my parenting strategy.
lead_paragraph: When my wife and I took our 7-year-old son to climb a 900-hundred-foot piece of rock near our home in Colorado, it seemed like a good idea at the time.

headline: The Big Cheese (Tour)
abstract: A writer spends eight days exploring the world of British farmhouse cheeses, from London to the West Country, where a good Cheddar rules the day.
lead_paragraph: On a sunny October afternoon in the London neighborhood of Bermondsey, a cool breeze surprised me with the winy smell of apples. It brought on a sudden sharp craving for a nice chunk of Cheddar, the fruit and the cheese together being a favorite after-school snack when I was growing up in Connecticut. This was an appropriate prompt, too, since I was on my way to a very privileged lesson in British farmhouse cheeses at the beginning of an eight-day, cheese-themed trip to London and Somerset run by the specialty tour company Cheese Journeys.

headline: Should I Be Taking Supplements?
abstract: There are thousands on the market, but relatively few situations where they’re proven to be beneficial.
lead_paragraph: Q: Are any supplements proven to be helpful for health?

headline: Why Can’t We Give Up the Ghosting?
abstract: How a disappearing act became the default ending to so much human interaction.
lead_paragraph: Horror movies are always a good reflection of the culture that created them. In the 1980s, as if in response to the repressive evangelical movement gaining hold in American politics, grotesque body horror (“The Fly,” “Society”) became a defining genre, along with a succession of gratuitously violent slasher films in which hormonal teenagers meet gruesome ends, usually just beyond the sphere of adult supervision (“The Burning,” “Friday the 13th,” “Sleepaway Camp”). In the 1990s, horror films grew more excessive, with bigger budgets, but some added irony and self-awareness to speak to a generation of jaded young viewers who had seen it all: The potential victims in Wes Craven’s “Scream” (1996) display a deep knowledge of horror film tropes.

headline: The Busy Doctor Who Gave Himself Another Job: Tracking Nazi Loot
abstract: Despite limited success, Dr. Michael R. Hayden has spent more than a decade patiently searching for the looted silver Judaica stolen from his grandparents, who were killed by the Nazis.
lead_paragraph: His day began at 6 a.m. with a call to Amsterdam from his office in Vancouver. An hour later he gave an online lecture to a class in Ireland, immediately followed by a call with a scientist in Boston about research.

headline: In Chicago, a Neighborhood of Immigrants Is Conflicted About More Arrivals
abstract: Brighton Park has taken in immigrants for generations, but residents are split over plans to house migrants in winterized tents on an empty lot.
lead_paragraph: For generations, Chicago’s Brighton Park neighborhood has been made and remade by successive waves of immigrants.

headline: A Meteoric Career, Cut Short, Still Burns Bright
abstract: Michael Richards, who died on 9/11, expanded the political possibilities of art. His sculptures embodied suffering and hope in a way that now seems prescient.
lead_paragraph: A heavy irony hangs over Michael Richards’s work: The artist known for images of pilots, airplanes, wings and targets died, age 38, in the Sept. 11 attacks. He had spent the night in his studio on the 92nd floor of the World Trade Center’s north tower.

headline: Why Modern Micromanagement of Kids Is Spooky
abstract: For Halloween, try this parenting hack: Back off.
lead_paragraph: The Halloween season means one thing for today’s parents: work. There’s costumes, there’s decorations and, if you follow parenting trends, there’s now convincing your kids to hand over their candy to the “switch witch.”

headline: School Cellphone Bans Are Trending. Do They Work?
abstract: Proponents say no-phone rules reduce student distractions and bullying. Critics say the bans could hinder student self-direction and critical thinking.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this year, Florida passed a law requiring public schools statewide to ban student cellphone use during class time. The new state rules reflect an intensifying global crackdown on young people and social media.

headline: The Joy of Picking Up Other People’s Trash
abstract: When my neighborhood changed around me, I decided to change it.
lead_paragraph: I’ve become a real kvetch. I have lived in the same neighborhood, in Brooklyn, for the better part of the past decade, spending the last five years in a hand-me-down apartment from a friend. One day I recognized where I lived; the next, I didn’t. Overnight, gaggles of 20-somethings began to roam the streets, presumably in search of eyebrows, which none of them seemed to have. Rent became obscene. I’d find myself the only Black person standing on the corner, waiting for the light to change. New high-rises as elegant as Lego blocks appeared on what seemed like every other street. Passive-aggressive notes from new residents started popping up in my lobby. One night, I came home to a can of alcoholic seltzer on top of my mailbox.

headline: On This Issue, the House G.O.P. ‘Whack Jobs’ Have a Point
abstract: Why Speaker Johnson should bring back regular order.
lead_paragraph: Just days before winning the race for speaker of the House last week, Representative Mike Johnson of Louisiana sent a letter to colleagues laying out a plan to complete the budget process by bringing 12 individual appropriations bills to the floor. Mr. Johnson billed his plan as a way to “allow us to demonstrate good governance.”

headline: If Not This, Then What Should Israel Do?
abstract: Zack Beauchamp explores the costs of Israel’s ground invasion in Gaza, as well as alternative military and political responses to the Oct. 7 attacks.
lead_paragraph: “Two things are true: Israel must do something, and what it’s doing now is indefensible.” So writes Zack Beauchamp, a senior correspondent at Vox.

headline: They Bought a House Together (and Haven’t Lived to Regret It)
abstract: For two art enthusiasts who pooled their resources to buy a country house outside New York City, the idea seemed brilliant: “Why wouldn’t we do this?”
lead_paragraph: For two art enthusiasts who pooled their resources to buy a country house outside New York City, the idea seemed brilliant: “Why wouldn’t we do this?”

headline: American Muslims Are in a Painful, Familiar Place
abstract: There seems to be a sense of both resignation (we’ve been here before) and shock (but we’ve been here before).
lead_paragraph: When President Biden landed in Tel Aviv days after Hamas’s Oct. 7 massacre of more than 1,400 people, he told an audience of Israelis that this was not just Israel’s Sept. 11, that “it was like 15 9/11s.”

headline: Past Lies About War in the Middle East are Getting in the Way of the Truth Today
abstract: Many cannot forget the false or exaggerated claims that led to the Iraq war.
lead_paragraph: Moshe Lavi, whose relatives have been taken hostage by Hamas, recently talked to a group of New York Times journalists about his family’s agony.

headline: Is Buying Real Estate With a Friend Really a Good Idea?
abstract: For two art enthusiasts who went in together on a “cathedral-esque” country house outside New York City, it seemed brilliant: “Why wouldn’t we do this?”
lead_paragraph: In the early days of the pandemic, Jonathan Travis and his friend Ethan Rafii were visiting another friend’s country house outside New York City when they began to dream big. What if they pooled their resources and bought a shared house together?

headline: The Supreme Court’s Social Media Cases Can Strengthen Our Democracy
abstract: The justices should remember that the First Amendment’s highest purpose is to protect the speech that’s necessary to democracy.
lead_paragraph: Americans spend a lot of time on social media, and this term the Supreme Court will do the same. Over the next few months — beginning Tuesday — the court will hear a series of cases requiring it to resolve First Amendment questions arising out of the role that major social media platforms play in hosting, shaping and setting the limits of public discourse online.

headline: What to Watch for as the Federal Reserve Meets This Week
abstract: Central bankers are expected to leave interest rates steady at a 22-year high of 5.25 to 5.5 percent. Investors are looking for hints at what’s next.
lead_paragraph: Federal Reserve officials are widely expected to leave interest rates steady at the conclusion of their two-day meeting on Wednesday. But investors and economists will watch for any hint about whether rates are likely to stay that way — or whether central bankers still think they might need to increase them again in the coming months.

headline: Hezbollah Hesitates as Israel Strikes Gaza
abstract: After years of spoiling for a fight with Israel, the group is torn between maintaining its credibility as a defender of the Palestinians, and its hesitation to drag Lebanon into a full-scale war.
lead_paragraph: As Israeli troops move deeper south into Gaza with the goal of destroying Hamas, the world is closely watching what happens on Israel’s northern border, where its forces have engaged for weeks in intense clashes with another, more powerful foe, Hezbollah.

headline: Bariatric Surgery at 16
abstract: If childhood obesity is an ‘epidemic,’ how far should doctors go to treat it?
lead_paragraph: Last fall, Alexandra Duarte, who is now 16, went to see her endocrinologist at Texas Children’s Hospital, outside Houston. From age 10, she had been living with polycystic ovary syndrome and, more recently, prediabetes. After Alexandra described her recent quinceañera, the doctor brought up an operation that might benefit her, one that might help her lose weight and, as a result, improve these obesity-related problems.

headline: With Executive Order, White House Tries to Balance A.I.’s Potential and Peril
abstract: President Biden announced regulations on Monday that seemed to have a little bit for everyone.
lead_paragraph: How do you regulate something that has the potential to both help and harm people, that touches every sector of the economy and that is changing so quickly even the experts can’t keep up?

headline: U.S. Looks to Allay European Fears of a Subsidy War
abstract: Wally Adeyemo, the deputy Treasury secretary, will argue in a speech in Germany that the Biden administration’s climate law is not protectionist.
lead_paragraph: The Biden administration is trying to ease European concerns about America’s new climate and tax law, which some allies view as a protectionist industrial policy that threatens their economies.

headline: America’s Rifle Fetish Is Destroying Its Sense of Freedom
abstract: Loving our guns to death.
lead_paragraph: In Anthony Mann’s 1950 western “Winchester ’73,” a rare and much-desired Winchester rifle brings misery and death to the unlucky souls who manage to bring it into their possession. In the West as brought to you by Mann — and his star, a troubled and morally ambiguous Jimmy Stewart — the gun isn’t a symbol of freedom as much as it is a curse, destined to ruin everyone who covets its power.

headline: Matthew Perry and the Loneliness of Addiction
abstract: He was a brilliant performer, but his honesty will be his greatest legacy.
lead_paragraph: A long time ago I lay awake for hours, terrified that they would be my last ones on earth. I had committed myself to quitting cocaine, which was my second addiction, the first being years of amphetamines. I was devoting myself to cleaning up and getting healthy. But then a friend called who I had routinely done coke with and who always had a supply of the drug. Earlier on that black night, I’d careened backward into the familiar land of white lines on a mirror and a heart racing way too fast. It was pounding so hard, so fast, so loud, I was certain it and I couldn’t survive.

headline: In Cyberattacks, Iran Shows Signs of Improved Hacking Capabilities
abstract: A monthslong hacking campaign targeted the governments of regional rivals, including Israel, and marked a turn, a new report says, as the attacks were used to collect intelligence, not just disrupt services.
lead_paragraph: Iranian hackers are waging a sophisticated espionage campaign targeting the country’s rivals across the Middle East and attacking key defense and intelligence agencies, according to a leading Israeli-American cybersecurity company, a sign of how Iran’s quickly improving cyberattacks have become a new, important prong in a shadow war.

headline: What Is the Scariest Song of All Time? Poem? YouTube Video?
abstract: Times writers revealed their picks. Listen at your own risk.
lead_paragraph: For Halloween, we asked writers and editors around The New York Times for the pieces of art or culture that they turn to when they need a good scare. The result is a collection of audio stories that will send a chill down your spine, make your hair stand on end and keep you entertained.

headline: A Historic Strike (and Win) for Autoworkers
abstract: The tentative deals with Ford Motor, General Motors and Stellantis are the most generous in decades.
lead_paragraph: A wave of strikes that has paralyzed the auto industry came to an end on Monday, when the last of the three big car manufacturers, General Motors, reached a deal with the United Automobile Workers union.

headline: Saudi Arabia Is Set to Be Sole Bidder for 2034 World Cup
abstract: Australia announced it would not bid, clearing the way for the Saudis to bring soccer’s biggest tournament back to the Gulf.
lead_paragraph: Saudi Arabia emerged as the likely winner in the abbreviated race to host soccer’s World Cup in 2034 on Tuesday after Australia’s soccer federation announced that it would not bid for the tournament. The decision most likely removed the only hurdle in the way of Saudi Arabia’s plan to bring the world’s most-watched sporting event back to the Gulf.

headline: The Autoworkers’ Victories
abstract: The pay increases are the largest that autoworkers have received in decades.
lead_paragraph: If you want to understand why the United Auto Workers union has evidently won its strikes against Detroit’s Big Three, it helps to return to the work of a 20th-century economist named Richard Lester.

headline: Bankman-Fried’s Risky Defense Strategy Faces Another Big Test
abstract: The fallen crypto mogul’s decision to take the stand was long seen as a gamble. That risk will come into focus again on Tuesday as his testimony continues.
lead_paragraph: Sam Bankman-Fried is to return to the stand today after the former wunderkind faced a four-hour grilling that exposed inconsistencies in his assertion that he didn’t defraud customers of FTX, his bankrupt crypto exchange.

headline: Raging Fire in California Forces Thousands From Their Homes
abstract: The Highland Fire in Southern California, fueled in part by the Santa Ana winds, was zero percent contained as of Tuesday morning.
lead_paragraph: A fast-moving fire in the small town of Aguanga in Southern California forced the evacuation of thousands of people and had burned more than 1,200 acres as of Tuesday morning, according to the Riverside County Fire Department.

headline: Eurozone Economy Shrinks, While Price Pressures Ease
abstract: Economic growth contracted 0.1 percent last quarter, and inflation in October fell to a two-year low, a sign that high interest rates were taking a toll.
lead_paragraph: Growth in the eurozone contracted unexpectedly this summer, as  rising interest rates cooled momentum in Germany and France, the region’s two biggest economies, Europe’s statistics agency reported Tuesday.

headline: A Key Measure of Wages Grew at a Moderate Pace This Summer
abstract: The Employment Cost Index, which Federal Reserve officials watch closely as a gauge of pay trends, has come down since last year.
lead_paragraph: A measure of pay and benefits that officials at the Federal Reserve have been watching closely as they try to gauge the heat of the labor market grew at a moderate pace over the summer.

headline: Does Salvation for California’s Redwoods Lie Out of State?
abstract: A conversation with Moises Velasquez-Manoff about an effort to plant redwoods in the Pacific Northwest as threats mount to their habitat in California.
lead_paragraph: California has some impressive distinctions when it comes to trees: The state is home to the largest, tallest and oldest trees in the world.

headline: The First of Our Friends to Go
abstract: What do we mourn when we mourn a TV companion?
lead_paragraph: If you’re fortunate to live long enough, eventually you get The Call. Sometimes it’s an actual call, sometimes a social media post or a conversation on the street. But the message is the same: A friend of your youth has died.

headline: Why Doug Burgum Is Staying in a Race He Can Afford to Lose
abstract: With a substantial personal fortune, the North Dakota governor is insistent on spreading his message despite calls to drop out.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Doug Burgum of North Dakota knows that many people, including powerful voices in his own party, think he should quit the Republican presidential primary, abandoning his quixotic bid so that momentum can gather behind a challenger to Donald J. Trump, and ultimately President Biden.

headline: News Group Says A.I. Chatbots Heavily Rely on News Content
abstract: The News Media Alliance, a trade group that represents newspapers, says that A.I. chatbots use news articles significantly more than generic content online.
lead_paragraph: News publishers have argued for the past year that A.I. chatbots like ChatGPT rely on copyrighted articles to power the technology. Now the publishers say developers of these tools disproportionately use news content.

headline: Biden Administration Approves Biggest Offshore Wind Farm Yet, in Virginia
abstract: The decision comes as other projects to build wind farms along the Atlantic Coast have run into trouble.
lead_paragraph: The Interior Department on Tuesday approved a plan to install up to 176 giant wind turbines off the coast of Virginia, clearing the way for what would be the nation’s largest offshore wind farm yet.

headline: Where Israelis, Palestinians and Iranians Must Listen to One Another
abstract: Students from the Middle East come to Berlin to study music with the star conductor Daniel Barenboim. Now the Israel-Hamas war is testing their ideals.
lead_paragraph: The young musicians, in jeans and fuzzy sweaters, had just finished rehearsing a Prokofiev symphony in an empty concert hall. Then they put away their instruments and settled back into their orchestra chairs to talk about the war.

headline: Weekly Student News Quiz: Gaza Strip, Matthew Perry, World Series
abstract: Have you been paying attention to the news recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.
lead_paragraph: Have you been paying attention to the news recently? See how many of these 10 questions you can get right.

headline: A Footpath in England, Torn Down, Keeps Being Rebuilt by ‘Fairies’
abstract: A small bridge in the English village of Stiffkey, northeast of Cambridge, was dismantled last year. It was rebuilt overnight, dismantled a second time and rebuilt again.
lead_paragraph: A small, beloved footbridge in the county of Norfolk has been dismantled twice only to be replaced by “local fairies,” according to village lore, in a long-running dispute between a coastal English village and the National Trust, a conservation charity.

headline: Three Great Documentaries to Stream
abstract: In this month’s picks, an actor and a director reflect on their careers, while another director reflects on everything else.
lead_paragraph: The proliferation of documentaries on streaming services makes it difficult to choose what to watch. Each month, we’ll choose three nonfiction films — classics, overlooked recent docs and more — that will reward your time.

headline: Let’s Make Some Meatballs
abstract: With plenty of tomato sauce, slabs of garlic bread and a big green salad — that’s dinner.
lead_paragraph: Everyone has comfort food. Here’s mine: juicy meatballs done Italian American style, served with homemade tomato sauce or piled on top of a spaghetti heap.

headline: Russia Detains Two Soldiers Suspected of Killing 9 Civilians
abstract: The arrest in an occupied area of Ukraine was a rare admission by Moscow that its forces may have committed a crime against Ukrainian civilians. Experts warned that it might just be political posturing.
lead_paragraph: Two Russian soldiers have been detained in connection with the killing of nine people, including two children, in Ukrainian territory controlled by Moscow, Russian authorities said, in a rare admission that occupying forces may have committed a crime against Ukrainian civilians.

headline: After Mass Shooting in Maine, No Clarity on Whether Gun Laws Will Change
abstract: A state ban on assault weapons? Expanded concealed-carry restrictions? Tighter mental health laws? As Maine grieves, it weighs a roiling debate over gun laws.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday, Arthur Barnard will bury his oldest child, Artie Strout, 42, who was one of the 18 people killed in the country’s deadliest mass shooting so far this year.

headline: Israel’s U.N. Ambassador Criticized for Wearing a Yellow Star of David
abstract: Dani Dayan, chairman of Yad Vashem museum in Jerusalem, said Israelis should instead display the country’s flag as a sign of strength.
lead_paragraph: The head of Israel’s Holocaust memorial on Tuesday criticized the country’s ambassador to the United Nations for wearing a yellow Star of David patch during an address to the Security Council, saying the symbol, which was used under the Nazis to identify Jews, dishonors both the country and victims of the Holocaust.
